Another man held a sign wishing the eventual winner, Vreni Schneider of Switzerland, much luck. And, of course, all eyes were riveted on the giant slalom course when those other Swiss misses, Maria Walliser and Michela

LEAD: In more than 20 years as a businessman in Brooklyn, Eric Bullen has faced riots and looting and mounting drug-related crime, including more burglaries than he cares to remember. But lately, he says, the sense of siege has been reduced, and he has noticed something unusual: customers browsing casually at the windows of his men's clothing store on Fulton Street.
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would increase its automotive production in North America, adding about 175,000 cars and trucks in the remainder of 1988.

LEAD: Most players of the highest class began bridge when they were teen-agers, and a few began even earlier. The record for the youngest to achieve Life Master rank is held by Douglas Hsieh of Manhattan, who was 11 when he did so.

LEAD: Steve Konroyd, the valuable defenseman for the Islanders, has a fractured orbital rim above one eye as well as a fractured frontal sinus. He was hit in the face with a puck Sunday in Hartford and is expected to miss three weeks. The loss of Konroyd is just one more setback for the Islanders, who have been troubled by injuries in recent weeks.

LEAD: An additional 700,000 metric tons of subsidized United States wheat has been sold to the Soviet Union, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. Overall wheat exports, spurred by subsidized sales to China and the Soviet Union, are expected to rise more than 50 percent from last year, reducing the American stockpile to its lowest level in six years.

LEAD: A crisis over the legality of the state budget blew over today almost as quickly as it developed after state officials agreed to continue government as usual until they hear more on the issue from the State Supreme Court.

LEAD: Fred Kayne makes investments by playing conservative odds. But he owes his new job to a long shot: spotting a company that had the rights to the harness-racing franchise in California and owned land in a Los Angeles suburb.

LEAD: RIBBONS and bows, swags and rosettes are still popular in interiors, though using them has always taken skill and a professional eye. In response to a growing do-it-yourself market, several companies are producing these decorations as precut pieces of wallpaper, some to coordinate with wallpaper and fabric lines.
LEAD: Anything that moves, so to speak, falls within a dance critic's purview. So why not saddle-bronc riders who, like ballet dancers, earn points the more they turn their toes out?

LEAD: IN the late 1960's, Kjell-Evart Sigvardsson realized he was one of Sweden's last master makers of wood-burning tiled stoves in a nation swiftly converting to central heating. He decided to fight back.

LEAD: The Greyhound Corporation has acquired Twenty Mule Team Borax, an early broadcast sponsor of the long-running radio and television Western ''Death Valley Days,'' and two other household cleaning product lines from the United States Borax and Chemical Company.

LEAD: A principal leader of the Afghan resistance alliance brought into the open tonight the guerrillas' smoldering resentment of what they believe to be American collusion with the Soviet Union to reach a compromise over Afghanistan.

LEAD: WCBS Channel 2 is expected to announce today that it has purchased the new syndicated news-and-information program based on the USA Today newspaper, a move that may lead to the removal of the CBS ''Evening News'' from its customary 7 P.M. time slot on the network's flagship station.

LEAD: Ruth Ashouri, whose boyfriend, Amir Zidner, was one of two Israeli soldiers killed in an ambush Tuesday in southern Lebanon, at his funeral yesterday. With her were Mr. Zidner's mother, Naomi, and brother, Alon. The soldiers were killed in the Israeli-designated security zone when their patrol was hit by a guerrilla rocket attack.

LEAD: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci retreated today from the Pentagon's plan to begin deploying MX nuclear missiles on railroad cars in 1991 to make it easier for them to escape detection by an enemy. He said more research and discussions with Congress must come before the program proceeds.

LEAD: * Alba-Waldensian Inc., Valdese, N.C., a maker of women's and men's hosiery, elected William F. Karnbach president and chief operating officer, succeeding William D. Shubert, who remains chairman and chief executive.

LEAD: * Schlage Lock Company to Mojo Advertising, San Francisco, part of Mojo MDA of Australia.

LEAD: An official of the National Theater of Great Britain said yesterday that an important Soviet company had been dropped from the 1988 schedule of Pepsico Summerfare because the performances would have included a simultaneous translation delivered by Vanessa Redgrave.

LEAD: Since Tom Flores resigned as head coach of the Los Angeles Raiders on Jan. 20, Al Davis, the team's owner, has been interviewing candidates in the hope of filling the vacancy before the National Football League meetings begin on March 14. Yesterday, The Associated Press said Davis was leaning toward one of five candidates but would not say which one: Mike Shanahan, the offensive coordinator of the Denver Broncos; Dennis Green, an assistant coach with the San Francisco 49ers; or one of three Raider assistant coaches, Charlie Sumner, Tom Walsh and Sam Gruneisen.

LEAD: The National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday that the over-the-counter market's ''short interest'' position -the number of shares sold short and not yet covered -in the month ended Feb. 12 soared by 34.7 million shares, or 19.8 percent.
LEAD: About 100 students of Hampshire College who took over a dormitory office to protest racism, marched across campus today to present a list of 12 demands to the college president.
LEAD: Dr. Jonathan T. Lanman, a pediatrician who served in a high research post at the National Institutes of Health, died of a lung ailment Monday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 70 years old.

LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3*NATIONAL HEALTHCARE SYSTEMS (OTC) Qtr to Dec 31 1987 1986 Revenue 60,806,000 60,863,000 Net loss 6,758,000 8,453,000 6mo rev 123,240,000 115,298,000 Net loss 14,269,000 7,794,000 The year-ago periods' losses included an after-tax charge of about $7 million for additional provisions for uncollectible accounts and allowances, charges associated with the disposition of two rural hospitals, and for an accounting change.

LEAD: Western officials and analysts reacted with dismay yesterday to South Africa's crackdown on major anti-apartheid organizations and predicted that the move would hasten the growth of violent conflict between the Government and its opponents.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Maj. Gen. Harry M. Arthur, retired who spent two years as the ranking American officer with the Chinese Army in World War II, died Tuesday. He was 88.
LEAD: Since the eve of the Year of the Dragon, members of New York's Chinese community have been struggling to fit New Year's festivities into busy lives.

LEAD: Gold prices plunged to a 10-month low yesterday as mining companies and speculators increased their sales in a market weakened by a firmer dollar, declining energy futures and the Federal Reserve's forecast of continued low inflation.

LEAD: ABC's coverage of the Winter Olympics gave the network 4 of the top 10 places in last week's ratings, and moved ABC into first place for the month among the three major networks, according to figures by the A. C. Nielsen Company.
LEAD: Portugal and the United States agreed today to reopen talks on an agreement that allows the United States to use a military base in the Azores in exchange for military and economic aid.

LEAD: The United States may seek a reduction in its financial commitments to the United Nations and affiliated organizations because Congress refuses to pay the current dues, Reagan Administration officials say.
LEAD: * Adler & Shaykin announced that it had completed its acquisition of Wherehouse Entertainment Inc. for $14 a share, or about $190 million.

LEAD: The Koch administration threatened yesterday afternoon to seek a court order to halt what it called an illegal job action organized by the firefighters' union to protest the quick and quiet closing of a Brooklyn firehouse last month.

LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3*FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (AUSTIN) Qtr to Dec 31 1987 1986 Net loss b13,697,000 2,373,000 Yr net loss b13,653,000 4,317,000 b-Includes an $11.6 million addition to loan reserves, which brings total loan loss reserves to about $30 million.

LEAD: The Coastal Corporation is offering $200 million of 11 1/8 percent senior subordinated notes due in 1998 at a price of 99.673 to yield 11.18 percent through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

LEAD: For Dr. Jules Hirsch, a professor at Rockefeller University in New York and a senior physician at the university's hospital, the new studies showing that fat people are biochemically different from thin people are a vindication of a view he has promoted for more than two decades.

LEAD: A new drug that blocks the production of sex hormones appears to be an effective alternative for treating endometriosis, the growth of tissue from the lining of the uterus elsewhere in the body, a study concludes. The condition affects about 5 percent of all women in their reproductive years.
LEAD: To The Home Section:
LEAD: One of John A. Mulheren Jr.'s closer friends on Wall Street was the fallen arbitrager Ivan F. Boesky. It was a relationship that helped Mr. Boesky greatly at a crucial time in his career.

LEAD: A 16-month-old girl bitten by a horde of ants was in critical condition today, a spokeswoman for Sacred Heart Hospital said. Tiffany Cheatam of Navarre, a community about 20 miles east of this Panhandle city, had stopped breathing when rescuers arrived at her home shortly after noon Tuesday, emergency personnel said.

LEAD: The driver of the car that accidently killed Michael Griffith, the black victim in the Howard Beach racial assault case, has been ruled guilty of state motor vehicle violations in the death and is scheduled to lose his driver's license for 30 days.

LEAD: A joint on the redesigned space shuttle booster rocket apparently survived another test of its ability to contain the hot gases blamed in the explosion of the Challenger, a space agency official said today.
LEAD: In a sharp setback for landlords, the Supreme Court upheld, by 6 to 2, the constitutionality of a San Jose, Calif., rent control law. Page A23.

LEAD: An article yesterday about the Justice Department's failure to provide the Congressional Iran-contra committees with a memo on a Middle East pipeline project misstated the committee's means of seeking documents from the department. It requested them in a letter to the Justice Department, not by subpoena.

LEAD: The New York Botanical Garden, deeply concerned with the welfare of growing things, now faces the need for growth of its own. Its new expansion plan deserves the support of all who would celebrate and protect plant life around the globe.

LEAD: Tuition, room and board at Dartmouth College will cost $18,199 next year, up 6.4 percent from this year, the trustees have announced. Tuition will rise from $12,474 to $13,335, a 6.9 percent increase. Room and board will go up 5 percent. Robert Field, the college treasurer, said continued pressure for higher salaries and increases in financial aid were largely responsible for the increases.

LEAD: Five months after the Federal Bureau of Investigation dismissed him, John C. Ryan. a former agent, is grappling with a religious renewal that caused him to question his past, challenge his supervisors and lose his job.
LEAD: To The Home Section:

LEAD: Seven defendants were convicted yesterday of racketeering charges involving several murders and other crimes carried out by the Westies, a gang accused of terrorizing a Manhattan neighborhood for 20 years.

LEAD: TAKEOVER proposals always raise questions about price and terms, and often about regulatory approval, but an announcement that the New England Electric System had opened discussions with the bankrupt Public Service Company of New Hampshire has more than the usual share of uncertainties, experts in the field say.

LEAD: Several months ago in New York City, a young girl died while waiting for the heart and lung transplant that was the only means of extending her life. A few weeks later, a baby boy died before he could be given a new heart.

LEAD: A $150 million lawsuit against the Hunt brothers of Dallas went to trial yesterday in Manhattan, with a lawyer representing the leading Peruvian mineral company accusing the Hunts of engaging in an elaborate scheme in 1979 and 1980 to manipulate silver prices.

LEAD: A former New York City police sergeant and a suspended officer were convicted yesterday of felony assault and other charges for torturing a marijuana dealer with an electronic stun gun at a Queens station house.

LEAD: Roh Tae Woo being installed as President in Seoul. He replaced Chun Doo Hwan in the first peaceful transfer of power in South Korea's history. Page A6. (Reuters)

LEAD: A Federal report today urged a huge infusion of up to $90 billion a year to repair and expand the nation's dilapidated highways, mass transit systems, waste disposal facilities and other public facilities and services.

LEAD: The Alban Berg Quartet is to give an all-Beethoven program tonight at 8 at Carnegie Hall. The musicians - Gunther Pichler and Gerhard Schulz, violinists; Thomas Kakuska, violist, and Valentin Erben, cellist - are to play the Quartet No. 2 in G (Op. 18, No. 2), No. 11 in F minor (Op. 95, ''Serioso''), and No.
LEAD: Some days, there is no toilet paper in the bathrooms at Riverdale Junior High School in the Bronx. Other days, exit doors remain chained, and garbage swirls in the wind outside the building.

LEAD: The New York State Council on the Arts announced this week the first grant recipients in a new program to support building repairs and other capital projects for arts organizations. The Capital Aid Program represents a new departure for the nation's largest state arts agency, whose legislative mandate has in the past prohibited it from supporting capital projects.

LEAD: Once again, as it has done periodically over the last seven decades, the Senate has pinned itself to the floor with its own unusual wrestling move: the filibuster.
LEAD: MY gardening friends sometimes accuse me of being altogether enamored of hardy perennials, and a glance around my garden in the summer probably shows that they are on the right track.

LEAD: President Reagan defended Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d tonight against accusations of impropriety and said his opponents had created ''a kind of lynch mob atmosphere'' that unfairly charged members of his Administration with ethical misconduct.

LEAD: Not to worry. The all too frequent debate over whether ice dance is sport or art came to a rest at the Olympics when the free dance program wound up the ice dancing competition. Whatever was on view, it wasn't art.

LEAD: The American Association of Blood Banks announced today that it was studying new screening techniques that might further reduce the chances of transmitting the AIDS virus through blood transfusions.

LEAD: An article on Tuesday about an administrative judge's ruling on an investigation of a Manhattan dentist's refusal to treat an AIDS patient, carried an erroneous identification of the dentist, supplied by the patient's lawyer. The dentist is Dr. Michael Hurwitz, not Dr. David Hurwitz.

LEAD: The chairman of President Reagan's AIDS commission today called for a $2 billion-a-year effort to expand treatment programs for drug abuse and improve health care services to combat the growing epidemic. He urged hiring 32,000 drug treatment specialists and setting up 3,300 drug centers.

LEAD: How far will Senate Republicans go to resist limits on campaign spending by candidates for the Senate? One answer is 5 feet 11 inches. Normally, that's how tall Bob Packwood, the Oregon Republican, stands. At dawn yesterday he wasn't standing; he was carried into the Senate, feet first, by Capitol police officers.
LEAD: IT is obvious when an oil painting is torn, blistered or cracked and in need of repair. But how do you tell when it needs cleaning?

LEAD: Bill Cartwright was suppposed to be traded to the Portland Trail Blazers, the Atlanta Hawks, the Dallas Mavericks, the Chicago Bulls or any other team that would have him. Chris Mullin was coming to the Knicks from the Golden State Warriors for either Kenny Walker or Gerald Wilkins. Pat Cummings was going to Portland.

LEAD: WHEN voices are raised, cooler heads generally prevail. So it is that with all the high-flown rhetoric one can see nowadays in works on display at galleries along 57th Street and uptown, several of the more soft-spoken artists make the most persuasive statements: at the Cordier & Ekstrom Gallery (417 East 75th Street, through March 19), for instance, are the small, Surrealistic collages of Varujan Boghosian.

LEAD: When a Supreme Court headed by William Rehnquist declares the deepest commitment to free speech, and does so unanimously, it furthers a thrilling principle of liberty. Larry Flynt's rancid Hustler magazine may have ridiculed the Rev. Jerry Falwell in the coarsest and most outrageous way. But freedom of speech, the Court declares, extends to utterances that are outlandish, even detestable.

The production at the American Repertory Theater is filtered through two diverse sensibilities, the one German and philosophical, the other American and visual.

LEAD: The South African Government's crackdown this week on anti-apartheid groups is in many ways a logical progression of the process that began with the outright banning of the African National Congress and the Pan Africanist Congress in 1960.

LEAD: Victor Derevianko's program of Brahms and Liszt at Alice Tully Hall Wednesday night was narrow in its choice of repertory but probably said the most any music could about his tastes and skills. LEAD: William Harold Cox, a Federal district judge who enraged civil rights advocates with his remarks about blacks but presided over a 1967 trial that convicted eight members of the Ku Klux Klan of killing three civil rights workers, died Thursday at his home here. He was 87 years old. Judge Cox, the son of a Sunflower County sheriff, had a successful practice in corporate and civil law before being named to the Federal bench in 1961.

At his side, his son, Ross Jr., couldn't help but note the symmetry of the moment.

LEAD: One night about 30 years ago, as he hovered somewhere between sleep and consciousness, Jimmy Swaggart says, he found himself in a windowless, bare room suffused with a palpable sense of evil.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Sherman F. Sosnow of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Stephanie K. Sosnow to Ernest Raymond Pysher 3d, a son of Mrs. Pysher Jr. of Youngstown, Ohio, and the late Mr. Pysher. The wedding is to be late next month.

LEAD: WHEN gale-force winds ripped across southern England last fall, they destroyed in a few hours what generations of gardeners and landscape planners had labored to achieve. Thousands of trees - some of them planted centuries ago - were felled in gardens and parks. Ornamental avenues were battered, rare species damaged or destroyed.

LEAD: THE high cost of real estate coupled with restrictive zoning in lower Fairfield County has put an essential suburban industry, the local automobile dealer, at risk. Land on which to store new cars, cars under repair and even employees' cars has become unaffordable or unavailable.

LEAD: GOVERNOR KEAN'S failure, in his recent budget proposal, to provide adequate financing for New Jersey's mental-health system demonstrates a startling insensitivity to the needs of the mentally ill men and women of this state.
LEAD: When Seton Hall defeated St. Peter's to begin its winning streak, skeptics said the Pirates were simply a better team from a stronger conference.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Lovell Jr. of New Vernon, N.J., and Raymond, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kimberly Whyte Lovell to Douglas Ralph Hiscano, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raphael A. Hiscano of Short Hills and Andover, N.J. The couple plan to marry in April.
LEAD: Little by little, American lis-teners are growing familiar with the music of black South Africa.

LEAD: IN a 1762 portrait painted by Pompeo Batoni, James Bruce of Kinnaird stands corpulent, wearing a richly frogged coat and a periwig and looking the embodiment of kindliness. So much for appearances: the rest of the evidence suggests that the naturalist and explorer was something of a scoundrel, and mean-spirited to boot.

LEAD: FOR gardeners and garden lovers, Europe is the place. Its gardens not only display some of the finest collections of rare plantings but also reveal the development of landscape design. Some encompass flowing fountains and conservatories; others are nestled in woodlands and parks; many feature rock gardens, herbaceous borders and topiary as well as carpets of dazzling blooms.

LEAD: CHIEF Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote two decisions issued last Wednesday, involving free speech and rent control, that did not sound like the Court's most predictably conservative member.

LEAD: THE theater was a dimly lighted room in the basement of a church in Manhasset, L.I. The star - John Savage, best known for his roles in films like ''The Deer Hunter'' and ''Salvador'' - arrived two hours late. And the audience and critics - a group of teen-agers, parents and youth workers - sat on legless couches and discarded pews.

LEAD: National Hall in Westport, Conn., is on the Saugatuck River, but no one need look outside to realize that. ''The basement is tidal,'' said Peter F. Tauck, general manager of the company restoring the structure, which is in a historic district. ''When the tide comes up, the cellar fills up.'' A leaky foundation is only one of troubles plaguing the one-time home of The Westport News, the Westport Bank and Trust and the Westport High School.

LEAD: A Navy Trident 1 missile was launched successfully today from a submerged submarine off Cape Canaveral, after two failed launchings last year and one on Feb. 6, officials said. The missile was fired down the Air Force Eastern Space and Missile Test Range at 10:27 A.M. from the U.S.S. Stonewall Jackson and landed in the Atlantic.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz flew to Jordan and Syria today to discuss a package of American proposals for a Middle East negotiating formula but made little apparent headway in his quest.

LEAD: After receiving assurances from Mikhail S. Gorbachev that he would personally study their grievances, Armenian nationalist leaders called today for a one-month suspension of the demonstrations that have shaken two southern Soviet republics, Armenian representatives said.

LEAD: COCO CHANEL ONCE explained to Horst the essence of elegance. ''If you walk into a room and people say, 'What a marvelous dress,' you are badly dressed,'' the designer told the photographer. ''If they say, 'What a marvelous woman,' you are well dressed.''

LEAD: THAT ARTISTS WHO ARE KNOWN primarily as painters also take photographs is not news. Photography, after all, is no longer considered a natural enemy of the brush, as it was in the dark ages 100 years ago. As a result, what matters today is not whether an artist uses photographs, but the part that camera images play in his or her work.

LEAD: It is unlikely that AIDS would have spread in this country if there had been vigilant guard against unhygienic and promiscuous sexual practices and a serious effort to eradicate or at least control drug addiction. The current campaigns for ''safe'' sex and ''sterile'' drug use will do little to reduce the spread of disease.

LEAD: The vitality of youth in black South Africa is celebrated in ''Sarafina!'', a musical with a message that reverberates long after one has left the theater. ''Sarafina'' is a song of freedom, persisting in spite of years of repression. Watching the show, one is saddened by the slowness of change in South Africa, at the same time one is uplifted by the idealism on stage.

LEAD: As Roh Tae Woo took over as President last week in the first peaceful transfer of power in South Korea's history, he served notice that his tolerance for violent dissent would be limited. Mr. Roh, a former general who once participated in a military coup, promised an era of ''democratic reforms and national reconciliation,'' but said the days were over when civil unrest could be ''irresponsibly created on the pretext of freedom and participation.

LEAD: Texaco agreed to pay $1.25 billion to the Energy Department to settle a complaint that it overcharged customers when oil-price controls were in effect in the 1970's. Texaco, trying to emerge from bankruptcy protection, has also agreed to pay $3 billion to Pennzoil in a dispute over Texaco's acquisition of Getty Oil.

LEAD: Stephen Bean likes to think he's a patriotic fellow. He served in the Air Force doing maintenance on B-52's and he believes people sometimes have to put up with some inconveniences for national defense. But cruise missiles over Maine? He's not too sure about that.

LEAD: In his article ''Leveraged Buyouts: On the Level?'' (Jan. 17), Benjamin J. Stein presumes, but never offers any proof, that management's offer for Narragansett Capital was below fair market value. No higher bids emerged from outsiders and 97 percent of the shareholders voted in favor of the deal, so only a small minority of those involved appear to agree with the author.

LEAD: BACK-COUNTRY skiing is cross-country skiing in areas that are not groomed and tracked by machines. You can do back-country skiing in three kinds of areas: public parks and state forests, where bridle paths and carriage roads become perfect ski trails in winter, touring centers that have back-country trails linked to their main trail systems, and true wilderness regions, which may involve skiing up and down mountains on hiking trails.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Early music is flourishing on recordings. The term early music serves as a convenient label for the vast number of works composed before the universal adoption of our modern scales, around the time of Bach. Pre-Bach music is based on scales that differ significantly from our present major and minor, and therefore often sounds strange to modern listeners.

LEAD: Mary Dunhill, the last surviving child of Alfred Dunhill, founder of the tobacco and pipe-making company, died Wednesday, death notices said today. She was 81 years old. The only daughter among Dunhill's four children, Ms. Dunhill joined the board of Dunhill Holdings in 1944, explaining ''they were rather short of men,'' and in 1961 became chairman, succeeding her eldest brother, Alfred.

LEAD: 2 MUSICAL GENERATIONS Experienced and novice musicians star in two concerts this afternoon. LEAD: Zany Tactics, thoroughbred racing's world-record holder for six furlongs on dirt, has died of an apparent heart attack after a workout at Santa Anita.

LEAD: To the Editor: I have good news for millions of Americans insured by Blue Cross and Blue Shield.

LEAD: THE sari is merely a length of cloth about six yards long, but it enfolds all the exoticism of India. Without the need for tailoring, buttons or zippers, the sari provides its wearer with the modesty of a veil, a shield from the sun and protection from the cold. Like the sarong and the serape, the sari combines simplicity with ingenuity to become an elegant solution in the technical sense of the word.

LEAD: THIS season marks the return of the dinner suit, an ensemble that evokes the long-legged, cigarette-in-a-holder look of New York in the 40's. Not many cigarette holders are in evidence these days (nor many cigarettes, for that matter), but the suit still wafts up its share of heady, nighttime-in-the-big-city sophistication.

That's why the sale of shortwave radios perks up during political crises. For example, during last year's Congressional investigation of arms sales to Iran, there was a run on such radios, and - according to trade reports - they have been selling briskly since.

LEAD: AT first glance Coral Gables appears more likely the goal of upwardly mobile Miami residents than the destination of winter vacationers.

LEAD: Wade Evan Roberts, the American serviceman who defected to the Soviet Union last year, is leaving today for West Germany, where, he said, he hopes, at last, that he and his wife can ''live at peace.''

LEAD: MABEL MERCER: A Life. By James Haskins. (Atheneum, $19.95.) Mabel Mercer was the antithesis of a show-business personality. She was shy, self-conscious and had little confidence in her singing talent. She never reached a wide audience, but was a strong influence on singers who did - singers such as Frank Sinatra and Peggy Lee, who appreciated her superb craftsmanship.

LEAD: Gen. Benny Murdani, until recently considered the second most powerful man in Indonesia after President Suharto, was replaced today as armed forces commander. The move is seen as a prelude to more Government changes in the next few weeks.

LEAD: Britain's Prince Andrew and his wife, Sarah, began a 10-day visit to Southern California today, and they were greeted by a freeway traffic jam that delayed their arrival at a City Hall ceremony by 25 minutes. The car carrying the Duke and Duchess of York had to make a detour around the congestion on the trip from the royal yacht Britannia, moored at Long Beach, 25 miles south of Los Angeles.

LEAD: Two days before the scheduled start of his impeachment trial in the state Senate, Gov. Evan Mecham said he was preparing to ask a Federal court to halt it. He said he feared his constitutional rights would be trampled in ''a lynch-mob atmosphere.''

LEAD: Calling portions of a former Panamanian official's Senate testimony ''lies and slanders,'' President Fidel Castro of Cuba said he would be willing to travel to Washington to rebut testimony against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama. But Mr. Castro said a visit to Washington would have to include discussion of other issues, which he did not specify.

LEAD: It has been said that the Olympics lacked a compelling figure, someone whose signature of success could be stamped on the Winter Games. The search could have very well ended on the slopes of Mount Allan today, where Alberto Tomba of Italy won his second gold medal, prompting a wild celebration that turned the base of a ski trail into a street festival.

LEAD: Pamela Gwyn Kripke's engagement to Robert Neil Chimbel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Chimbel of Torrington, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. David C. Kripke of Scarsdale, N.Y. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: THE Italians over the years have adorned their historic buildings with countless inscriptions: So-and-So lived here, So-and-So built (or rebuilt) this building, here lies So-and-So, and the like. Before the 19th century virtually all such inscriptions were written in Latin. This used to mean that they could be read by all literate people, from anywhere.
LEAD: The latest Czechoslovak television hit is called ''Sondy,'' or ''Probes,'' and it dissects, ''60-Minutes'' style, society's ills.

LEAD: An Aeroflot airliner carrying 51 people on a 1,600-mile flight across the western Soviet Union crashed on landing today at its final stop in Siberia, and some passengers were killed or injured, the official news agency Tass reported.

LEAD: THE future of a century-old Hempstead house has become the focal point of a larger issue: the conversion of old houses into offices and the consequent change in patterns of neighborhoods within the village. The Zoning Board of Appeals is scheduled to decide the house's status Thursday.

LEAD: There was a time when he cared only about dreaming up new ideas and persuading friends and relatives to work for nothing, but that was before he got lucky. That was before his sleeper, his pet project, his low-budget labor of love became an overnight sensation. After that, studio executives pursued him tirelessly and the press sang his praises; everyone seemed to share the single happy hope that this golden goose would repeat his miracle.

LEAD: RISTORANTE IL POZZO in Hauppauge was conceived with love. At its heart is the owner, Pat Zummo. He is everywhere: greeting diners, table hopping in the dining room and on weekends popping out from the kitchen in his chef's whites. On a slow night, diners might find his gregariousness a mite intrusive, but he has a genuine enthusiasm for food and his restaurant that's contagious.

LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: YOU don't have to look far to see polar bears when you camp out with them on the shores of Hudson Bay near Churchill in Manitoba province. Even at the cocktail hour, when you're having a snotch (Scotch poured over a cup of snow) and a smoked oyster, you're likely to hear and feel half a ton of bear slam against the school bus that serves the camp's meals and smack its black snout against a frosted windowpane inches from your face.

LEAD: BY making a map of your home's electrical circuits, you can know at a glance which paths of wiring routed throughout the house serve which outlets. A map can also help you determine whether any circuits supply too many outlets and thus are overloaded.
LEAD: MACBETH wore a business suit. The witches were punk rockers who predicted he would become chief executive officer - news that greatly pleased the social-climbing Lady Macbeth.
LEAD: A Great Day for the Polish NEW YORK STATE has added a commemorative day to honor Polish-Americans, but no one has bothered to tell Long Island's Polish-Americans about it.
LEAD: An article on Jan. 10 about Water Mill contained errors [ ''Fears on Growth Divide Residents of Water Mill'' ] . I believe the following to be more accurate.

LEAD: Q. Some of the floorboards in our house have raised slightly at the edges, and they often break when stepped upon. As a result, we now have spaces between the boards. This condition seems to have developed after the floors were stained. Can you help us solve this problem?

LEAD: Linda Hilliard Eglin's engagement to Cole Edmund Harrop, a son of Yolanda W. McPhee of Princeton, N.J., and David C. Harrop of New York, has been announced by her mother, Mrs. Thomas Wilson Eglin of Lawrenceville, N.J., and Watch Hill, R.I. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: Judge and Mrs. Eugene M. Hanofee of Liberty, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Deirdre Constance Hanofee to Eric Todd Friedland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Friedland of Liberty. An August wedding is planned.
LEAD: A chart with the Travel Advisory column on Jan. 31 about air fares to Australia misstated terms of Air New Zealand's lowest fare. No stops en route are permitted.

LEAD: In a sense, the Hirschl & Adler Folk Gallery is attempting to do for Jacquard coverlets what the Whitney Museum of American Art did for quilts in its 1971 exhibition ''Abstract Design in American Quilts'': elevate the craft to an American art form. The show of 55 Jacquard coverlets opened yesterday at the gallery (851 Madison Avenue, at 70th Street), where it will run through March 26.

LEAD: THE Metropolitan Opera's current production of Wagner's ''Siegfried,'' unveiled two weeks ago, was offered Thursday evening with an almost entirely new cast. Only Wolfgang Neumann, as Siegfried, and John Macurdy, as the offstage voice of Fafner, remained from the original lineup.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Louis F. Bantle of Darien, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Terri Ann Bantle, to E. Christopher Walker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen S. Walker, also of Darien. The couple plan to marry June 25.

LEAD: Teams begin playing exhibition games later this week, but anyone looking for clues to the coming season's division champions should not waste too much time on the spring training standings. No correlation exists between a team's success in spring training and its performance during the season.

LEAD: To listen to the competitors at the USA/Mobil Indoor Track and Field Championships at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, the completion of the indoor season in an Olympic year, the most intense race may have been the one to the door.

LEAD: Vice President Bush maintained a solid lead today in Maine's Republican caucuses, forging occasional alliances with Senator Bob Dole's supporters to fend off a strong challenge from Pat Robertson.

LEAD: In 1984 Walter F. Mondale came to this proud citadel of the civil rights movement, wrapped himself in the approbation of its black establishment, and began a head-to-head, vote-to-vote struggle with the Rev. Jesse Jackson for the support of Southern blacks.

LEAD: After driving nine hours down the length of Florida to report to the Baltimore Orioles' training camp in Miami, Ray Knight found out that he had driven about four hours too far. The Orioles are still in Miami, to be sure, but while the former Mets star was on the road from South Carolina with his wife, Nancy Lopez, and their two daughters, the 35-year-old third baseman was being traded to the Detroit Tigers, whose camp is in Lakeland, Fla., 200 miles to the north of Miami.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The most haunting sound ever made by an instrument of human devising is the far-off whistle of a steam locomotive. The impact is doubled if the locomotive is visible in the middle distance, pulling a fast train from one city to another, blowing for every curve and crossing. It's tripled if all this happens at night, so that you wake at 2 A.M.

LEAD: Vyacheslav Fetisov, the comrade from Moscow who is ''Kaptain'' of his nation's hockey team today but may become a skating quarterback for New Jersey tomorrow, is hunched over his stick, which for reasons of his own he wraps in neon orange tape. He idles himself near his blue line, not quite at rest, his eyes fastened on the puck, his skates twitching.

LEAD: President Reagan will not impose the maximum economic sanctions against Panama when he declares Tuesday that it and several other countries have failed to take adequate steps to control drug trafficking, senior Administration officials said today.

LEAD: Negotiators for Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Campeau Corporation mainly discussed contract terms, including financing, as they worked through the weekend on proposals for a $6.3 billion merger of the two companies, according to people close to the talks.

LEAD: Maya Plisetskaya is to lead 65 dancers from the Bolshoi Ballet of Moscow in the dance component of the Festival of Russian Music and Dance in Boston, in March and April. The festival has been organized by Sarah Caldwell, the artistic director of the Opera Company of Boston; Miss Plisetskaya, a prima ballerina with the Bolshoi, and her husband, Rodion Shchedrin, a Soviet composer.

LEAD: A proposal by Governor Cuomo to expand Medicaid coverage for prenatal care, but not for abortion, has abortion rights groups gearing up for their first major fight in the state in almost a decade.
LEAD: A 77-year-old Soviet Jew who battled for 13 years to leave the Soviet Union embraced his daughter when he arrived today in Israel.
LEAD: Like a line on a graph, Euclid Avenue traces 20 years of race relations in this old industrial town, an east-west passage from American dream to American nightmare.

LEAD: The Rev. Jimmy Swaggart, who stepped down from his electronic pulpit after confessing to moral lapses, thanked members of all religions today for their support during ''the darkest week'' he has experienced.

LEAD: The Champion Spark Plug Company announced that it would lay off more than a quarter of its work force here. The layoffs, which will begin March 22, will be phased in over four months, said William Walker, Champion's director of industrial relations. A total of 243 workers - 119 people from the aviation products group and 124 from automotive operations -will lose their jobs in Toledo, where Champion employs 834 production workers.

LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's plan to end Government ownership of Britain's electrical power system is emerging as a major test of public satisfaction with her policy of privatization.

LEAD: Peter McDermott, a 32-year-old Liverpool drug addict, is a regular at the Hope Street clinic here, Britain's largest program for giving out clean needles to drug addicts in an effort to curb the spread of AIDS.

LEAD: For a septuagenarian with a cane, Harpagon, the funniest skinflint in literature (''so mean he won't even give you a good day, he'll lend it to you'') is covering a lot of stage in ''The Miser'' at the Yale Repertory Theater. He comes on with a bound and goes off with a dive. In a burst of despair, he jumps and jumps and jumps, higher and higher till he threatens to fly from the premises; in an excess of agitation, he climbs a pole that occupies the center of his living room for no particular purpose other than to provide something for people to climb when emotions require it.

LEAD: SINCE there were no premieres on the Arditti String Quartet's New York debut program Sunday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, one might reverse the usual focus of contemporary music discussion and consider the performers before the composers. LEAD: AS Jane Gennaro's one-woman show, ''The Boob Story,'' opens, an eerily caressing recorded voice advertises the female body, using the vocabulary of fashion design to describe its components as parts of a wardrobe in which the hands and fingers are accessories. LEAD: A 16-month-old girl bitten last week by a swarm of ants has died, a hospital spokeswoman said today. I wanted to get going.'' Keith Miller is a 24-year-old rookie, and he wanted to get going because he had no job on a team loaded with stars.

LEAD: CAN a play whose heroine is crucified by cannibals and devoured by ants be a real comedy? As the production of T. S. Eliot's ''Cocktail Party'' by the Jean Cocteau Repertory at the Bouwerie Lane Theater reminds one, the play is definitely a comedy and, after 39 years, still resilient. It helps a lot that Celia Copplestone's grisly demise is thousands of miles off stage, of course.

LEAD: It remained unclear yesterday which of the two competing bids for Federated Department Stores Inc. would prevail. But investors seemed to agree that the newest offer, from R. H. Macy & Company, was no better than the one from the Campeau Corporation. Federated's stock rose only $1.25, to $67.75, in heavy trading yesterday.
LEAD: The featured speaker at the annual conference of the National Association of Independent Schools last week was Governor Kean, a favorite of educators because of his long outspoken support.

LEAD: The bottom may be about to fall out of the assumption that underlies Middle East peace negotiations. The assumption has been that Palestinians would sit at the peace talks as part of the Jordanian delegation, and that the parties thus could sidestep direct dealings with the Palestine Liberation Organization.

LEAD: John B. Kenny, co-founder and principal of the High School of Art and Design, formerly the New York School of Industrial Art, died Thursday at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., after a long illness. He was 88 years old.

LEAD: With ''Magda and Callas,'' at the Philadelphia Festival Theater for New Plays, Albert Innaurato returns to South Philadelphia for a story dealing with such favorite subjects as grand opera, passion and motherhood. In a neighboring backyard can be heard the lingering laughter of ''Gemini'' (the playwright's long-running Broadway comedy) but in the world of the La Selva family, there is a definite strain of solemnity beneath the jocularity.

LEAD: The Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev has asked to postpone a long-scheduled meeting in Moscow this month in which possible business deals were to be discussed with more than 500 American corporate leaders and Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr., according to American and Soviet officials. It was unclear when the meeting might be rescheduled.

LEAD: The Rangers have signed Tony Granato, a member of the United States Olympic hockey team. Granato, a 23-year-old right wing who played at the University of Wisconsin, scored a goal and had seven assists in the United States' six games in Calgary, Alberta. . . . Mary Decker Slaney has entered the L'eggs Mini Marathon for the first time, organizers of the 10-kilometer race announced yesterday.

LEAD: The Government today revised upward the December figure for its principal economic-forecasting index, ending a string of three consecutive monthly declines, which is sometimes considered a signal of an imminent recession. It also reported that the figure fell six-tenths of 1 percent in January, slightly more than most analysts had expected.

LEAD: An assembly created to elect the next President and Vice President of Indonesia opened an 11-day session here today with a subdued ceremony, but amid lively public speculation over who will fill the second-highest position.

LEAD: HIGH school physics students learn that matter is composed of waves - light waves, electromagnetic waves, sound waves -and that if two trains of waves are exactly out of phase and collide head-on they can cancel each other. Engineers have toyed with the possibility of blanking out noise by bombarding offensive sound waves with their exact opposites, or anti-noise.

LEAD: Julie Krone, who is involved in a race with Patty Cooksey for most career victories by a woman jockey, picked up her 1,200th triumph Monday night at Garden State Park in Cherry Hill, N.J., in an unusual fashion. In the featured eighth race, Krone's horse, Explodom, had a head advantage over Flying Daisey as the horses neared the finish line when the opposing jockey, Armando Marquez, reached out with his left hand and grabbed Explodom's reins from Krone's right hand.

LEAD: Wayne Gretzky got his record-breaking 1,050th career assist and Esa Tikkanen helped set up three goals tonight night, pacing the Edmonton Oilers to a 5-3 victory over the Los Angeles Kings. Gretzky's record point, breaking the assist of 1,049 set by Gordie Howe, came at 12 minutes 44 seconds of the opening period.

LEAD: Joe Besser, a comedian who was one of the later members of the Three Stooges and played the whining brat Stinky in the Abbott and Costello television show, was found dead in his home today. He was 80 years old and had been ill for six months, said his press agent of 15 years, Jeff Lenburg.

LEAD: To intervene or not to intervene? That really isn't the question. The litany enshrining non-intervention as a principle of Western Hemisphere relations arose from the U.S. dispatch of armed force and gunboat diplomacy, and on that level the taboo is clear enough.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration, which has blamed Federal Reserve policies of last year for much of the slowing of the election-year economy, today applauded the new policies that Fed officials disclosed last week.

LEAD: REMEMBER when restaurant food meant French, Italian or Chinese? Everything else was what you ate at home. And whatever you ate at home was called home cooking. It probably had an exotic accent if your parents were first-generation Americans, but it took a long time for those exotic ingredients to make their way into mainstream cooking.

LEAD: ARNOLD SCAASI is aware that the fashion mood of the moment tilts more to razzle-dazzle than to sobriety. Somberness was certainly not what he had in mind when he designed his spring and summer couture collection, which was shown this week in his salon in New York.

LEAD: The Islanders' Denis Potvin returns tonight to perhaps the most difficult building he has visited in his National Hockey League career. Barring an encounter in the playoffs, this evening's game against the Rangers will be Potvin's final appearance at Madison Square Garden. The 34-year-old defenseman, one of the most accomplished in the game's history, is retiring at the end of the season.

LEAD: What the House and Senate passed separately added up to 2,000 pages of trouble. The trade bill, it's called, but anti-trade is more like it. Now the conference committees charged with reconciling the two versions have, encouragingly, started to hack away much of the blatant special-interest mischief.

LEAD: Three companies have introduced new high-powered computers. Apollo Computer Inc. of Chelmsford, Mass., has a work station for engineers with supercomputer power that is priced from $69,900 to $130,000.

LEAD: Q. The door chime in our house is in the entrance foyer, and I can't hear it when I am working in the basement. Can I install a second chime that will sound at the same time the upstairs one does? A. Yes. LEAD: It has been a big season for jump-starts, which, this being winter, is reasonable enough for the literal kind. ''Jump-start'' is a perfectly straightforward way to describe the transfusion of juice, via jumper cables, from a car that's already running to one whose battery has gone dead overnight.

LEAD: The First Interstate Bancorp yesterday priced $100 million in 8 3/4 percent notes due in 1995 at par through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. Noncallable for five years, the notes at pricing were yielding about 87-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: To train for an air strike near the Persian Gulf, the two F-15 Eagle fighters streaked toward the target low to the ground, slipped over a ridge and up a valley, then climbed through clouds into the sun to protect the attack force behind them against hostile planes.

LEAD: The State Department's annual report on narcotics worldwide is certain to arouse Congress, but for the wrong reasons. Everyone is coming to recognize the report's blunt finding that production, consumption and trafficking now blaze out of control, beyond the ability of any single government to suppress.
LEAD: Mayor Federico Pena has ordered an investigation into reports that street crews spend more time eating and reading than working.

LEAD: Between impassioned telephone calls to plead a case that might bring a beating or death, the Palestinian lit one cigarette after another in his office here today and said that, yes, he was very nervous.

LEAD: For the eighth time, an all-time record, legislation to federally fund Senate campaigns has come to the floor but not to a final vote. Despite the filibuster, the majority leader, Robert C. Byrd, promises to repeat the exercise. If he does, constitutional principle, not a selfish desire to line politicians' pockets, will be at stake.
LEAD: There is one notable bridge personality who ought to be in the Guinness Book of World Records in one category, and has a good claim in another.

They are the International Public Relations Company, its first purchase in Japan, and the McCann Consultancy, a London subsidiary of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

LEAD: AS we are told too often, ''deep pain'' infects a Brooklyn household in ''A Subject of Childhood,'' a new play by Loren-Paul Caplin at the WPA Theater. A 3-year-old boy's playmate has died in a mysterious tumble down a staircase, and the 3-year-old's father and stepmother are trying to decide if the death was an accident or homicide.

LEAD: Classes resumed today for some high school seniors as a teachers' strike entered its seventh day. The 5,093 members of the Cleveland Teachers Union struck Thursday in a contract dispute with the school board. The district has nearly 73,000 students.

LEAD: The new chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission took issue today with another key Federal regulator over whether margin, or down payment, requirements on stock-index futures need to be increased.

LEAD: THE rehabilitation of a huge manufacturing plant outside this city of 15,500 in northwest Pennsylvania is the centerpiece of an effort to attract businesses to the area, which has been hit hard by plant closings and layoffs.

LEAD: Sales of new single-family houses fell by 9 percent in January, to their lowest level in more than five years, the Commerce Department said yesterday.

LEAD: When two jockeys are thundering toward the finish line in one of those neck-and-neck duels, the will to win can sometimes get so intense that it's all a jockey can do to keep himself from reaching over and yanking on his rival's reins. For one jockey, it seems, the impulse proved irresistable. That, in the view of racing officials, was exactly what happened in the eighth race at Garden State Park Monday night when Armando Marquez found himself coming down to the wire with Julie Krone right by his side and threatening to beat him across the line.
LEAD: Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman, yesterday solved the riddle of where he would go next by announcing that he would split his time between Wall Street and academia.

LEAD: A record low number of right whales, the rarest of the large whale species, were sighted last month in an annual survey conducted by the New England Aquarium in the whales' usual wintering grounds off the Georgia and Florida coast.

LEAD: A man accused of killing 16 people, including 14 members of his own family, is competent to stand trial, a judge has ruled in setting a May 9 trial date. The man, R. Gene Simmons, 47 years old, surrendered to the police Dec. 28 after a shooting spree left two former co-workers dead and led to the discovery of the bodies of his wife; four daughters; three sons; two spouses of his children; three grandchilden and a child who officials say he fathered by his oldest daughter.
LEAD: A Soviet spokesman said today that an unspecified number of people were killed in nationalist rioting Sunday in the southern Soviet city of Sumgait.

LEAD: The Commerce Department said today that orders to the nation's factories for manufactured goods fell six-tenths of 1 percent in January, the first decline in five months, but private economists said the setback was not serious.

LEAD: A system designed by CBS Records to prevent the recording of compact disks onto digital tape is inadequate, a Government agency has reported after a five-month test.

LEAD: The Scott Paper Company is dropping the J. Walter Thompson Company as an agency for its United States consumer products business after 60 years and also shifting all but one product from Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn in the United States. None of this will cause major hardship because most of the brands do not have an ad budget for 1988.

LEAD: Poppe Tyson, a subsidiary of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt with offices in New York and Union, N.J., has promoted Fergus O'Daly, 44-year-old president and creative director, to chief executive. The title was formerly held by Ron Vrba, 54, who is chairman.

LEAD: Despite revolutionary progress in preventing and treating life-threatening infections through immunization and antibiotics, teen-agers today are as likely to get sick and die before reaching their 20's as they were in the 1940's and 1950's. Only the causes of death and disability have changed dramatically, shifting from traditional medical problems to health effects stemming more from social causes.

LEAD: The jury in the trial of Larry Davis, who is accused of the execution-style murders of four suspected drug dealers in the South Bronx, concluded its eighth day of deliberations last night without reaching a verdict.

LEAD: KUMIKO KIMOTO'S percussion setup - gongs, cymbal, cowbell, tambourine, Roto-tom tunable drum, electronic sound generator and a hubcap - just about summed up the music of Bosho, the six-piece band that performed Monday at Dance Theater Workshop. LEAD: The State Parole Board refused yesterday to release Thomas Trantino, imprisoned since 1964 for the slaying of two Lodi police officers, and ordered that he serve at least three more years before being considered for parole again.

LEAD: A ''puff'' of tritium escaped from the Department of Energy's Savannah River plant Tuesday, officials said. They said the release from the plant that makes materials used in the production of nuclear weapons did not pose a hazard to the public. The release of 20,000 curies of tritium, a radioactive isotope of hydrogen, was described as a puff that lasted less than a minute.
LEAD: The Sandinista Government said tonight that it was ready to hold high-level talks inside Nicaragua next week with leaders of United States-backed contra guerrillas.

LEAD: First Republicbank Dallas lost more than 8 percent of its deposits as customers withdrew $599 million in one week last month amid speculation about the financial health of its parent company, regulators said.

LEAD: Concerned by skepticism about his commitment to separation of church and state, the former evangelist Pat Robertson said in a statewide 30-minute television address today that he neither desired nor sought to impose his religious views on the people of America.
LEAD: James Webb, who resigned recently as Secretary of the Navy, signed a contract with Random House yesterday for a novel that he expects to complete in about 18 months.

LEAD: When a 26-year-old man died in a respirator fire two weeks ago at New York Infirmary-Beekman Downtown Hospital, the hospital announced he was an AIDS patient, making public the confidential information that had not even been disclosed to his family.
LEAD: Manhattan Cable TV, pressed by a citizens' lawsuit to add more pay-television channels, will offer Bravo, the movie and performing-arts service, beginning in May.

LEAD: ''VERSAILLES: The View From Sweden'' at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum is on more than one count a remarkable exhibition. Made up entirely of drawings from Swedish sources, it looks good, it isn't too big, it is very amusing and it is consistently instructive. We see great architecture and great gardens as they were set down on paper by the people who designed them, but we also get to read the small print of history.

LEAD: ''Honest music,'' said Bono Vox of U2, won two top Grammy Awards for the Irish rock band and its album, ''The Joshua Tree.'' LEAD: THE top item on the economic agenda confronting Congress and the Presidential candidates remains the Federal budget deficit and how to cut it. This mixed response, a dilemma of sorts, has never been clearer than it is at the artist's current exhibition of new paintings at Hirschl & Adler Modern.

LEAD: John A. Mulheren Jr., once one of Wall Street's leading arbitrage specialists, threatened to kill Ivan F. Boesky and another witness in an investigation after an employee from Mr. Mulheren's firm was subpoenaed by a grand jury, a Federal prosecutor asserted yesterday.
LEAD: Representative Richard A. Gephardt, stung by advertising that lists his corporate contributors, today began running a commercial that accused Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of ''dirty tricks.''

LEAD: Mortgage Shopping As spring approaches, the start of the home-buying season begins. Just in time, mortgage rates have been dropping. A fixed-rate 30-year mortgage is lower than last years' high of about 11.25 percent, while an adjustable-rate mortgage is down from about 8.25 percent. Adjustable rates are attractive to first-time home buyers as well as trade-up buyers because of the initial low rate.

LEAD: The Southland Corporation said it had sold its Reddy Ice subsidiary to the Kaminski-Engles Capital Corporation, an investment firm, for an undisclosed amount of cash. Reddy Ice is a major producer of fragmentary ice and operates seven plants in Texas, Florida and Nevada.
LEAD: The United States said today that it would not end aid to the Afghan guerrillas unless Moscow agreed to stop sending military supplies to the Afghan Government.

LEAD: Prince Charles after arriving in Pittsburgh. He toured old steel mill towns and offered encouragement for better times ahead, while British and American planners studied ways to revive industrial wastelands. (NYT/Scott Goldsmith)

LEAD: A struggle between New York's small opera companies and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians may soon change the face of the city's fringe operatic activity. Most of the companies have operated for years without union contracts, but several have been unionized over the past three seasons and three more are targets of a current organizing campaign.

LEAD: The space agency has many groups assigned to assess the safety of launching space shuttles, but its efforts are fragmented and lack objective measures for evaluating the hazards, a National Research Council panel said in a report made public today.
LEAD: The Upjohn Company said today that it had signed a letter of intent with the Chugai Pharmaceutical Company of Tokyo to form a joint venture that would develop and market drugs.

LEAD: J. Saunders Redding, a historian who is believed to have been the first black to teach at an Ivy League institution, died of heart failure Wednesday at his home in Ithaca, N. Y. He was 81 years old.
LEAD: Gulfstream Park will briefly change from a hippodrome to a hippo hippodrome this morning.

LEAD: With Marvin Powell in retirement after undergoing several knee operations, George Martin of the Giants was selected yesterday to succeed him as president of the National Football League Players Association. Martin, a defensive end with 13 years of N.F.L. experience and seven years of service as the Giants' player representative, was elected during the second day of a three-day meeting of the union's player representatives in Washington.
LEAD: A woman fell five stories yesterday while trying to escape an apartment fire that the authorities said was set by a man who had argued with her roommate.

LEAD: Richard Pryor has been given the full Bill Cosby treatment for his role in ''Moving,'' complete with charming family, fancy sweaters and brand-new Saab. Mr. Pryor plays Arlo Pear, a mass transit engineer who has been living in suburban splendor in New Jersey when a career change makes it necessary for him to relocate to Idaho.

LEAD: Jeff Reardon, the relief pitcher whose 31 saves helped Minnesota to the American League pennant and then victory in the World Series last year, has agreed to a one-year contract extension for 1989 that will pay him $1.15 million, with incentives that could be worth an extra $250,000. This season he will earn $850,000, the same as in 1987.

LEAD: Three contenders for the Republican Presidential nomination crisscrossed the state today, striving to pull their campaigns out of the doldrums in time for the South Carolina primary on Saturday and the Republican balloting in 17 other states on Tuesday.

LEAD: The mediator in the Afghan peace talks said today that the two sides had removed all significant obstacles to an agreement ending the Soviet military presence in Afghanistan and that country's eight-year-old civil war.

LEAD: The Labor Department asked the Justice Department today to consider prosecuting a Texas contractor in the collapse last April of a high-rise complex being built in Bridgeport, Conn., a Labor Department spokesman said today.

LEAD: George Brett couldn't resist it. ''I saw the thing go around a hundred times a day,'' he said. ''I had to go on it. I'm glad I got it out of the way. It's scary. That thing flies.'' Brett, the Kansas City Royals' fearsome first baseman, was talking about the Hurricane, the roller coaster at the amusement park that is the Boardwalk part of Boardwalk and Baseball.

LEAD: MAPLE SYRUP, the authentic, old-fashioned pancake and waffle topping, is beginning to boil in the state's sugarhouses. But cold weather threatens to limit production, no syrup was carried over from last year, a complicated problem of ''maple decline'' is emerging, and prices for local syrup will be at least as high as last year's, maybe even higher.

LEAD: Listeners who like multidirectional loudspeakers are usually quite vocal about their preference, extolling the spacious sound typical of such designs. Yet for all their enthusiasm, these listeners remain a minority, and multidirectional speakers are therefore relatively rare and frequently expensive.

LEAD: The marriage of Nancy Chanin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marcy Chanin of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., to Andrew Sneider, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Sneider of Miami, took place last evening at the Carlyle in New York. Rabbi Richard Jacobs, a cousin of the bride, officiated.

LEAD: OFFICIALS at the two county health departments on Long Island say that new Federal regulations prohibiting any mention of abortion in clinics that receive Federal funds will discriminate against poor women, interfere with their right to manage their pregnancies and hamper doctors and counselers.

LEAD: HANDBAGS, totes and suitcases ($130 to $380) designed to take foul weather by storm are among the 400 stylish accessories that Frances Patiky Stein, left, recently brought from Europe to show to store buyers.

LEAD: Without a doubt Lisbon is one of the more relaxed cities of the world. It has a genuine joie de vivre that does not seemed forced as in some cities, and hustling-turned-hassling seems to be at a minimum.

LEAD: Princeton, if you believe the real-estate developers, now begins at New Brunswick and ends at Trenton. LEAD: The Justice Department has begun a review of 300 Federal school desegregation cases and is seeking to release 17 Georgia school districts from court supervision.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel P. Moulton of Norwich, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Jean Moulton to James Bradford Straus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Straus of Rye, N.Y. The couple plan a June wedding.
LEAD: Euphemisms and platitudes suitable for sampler embroidery have so overcome NATO discourse that the straight message scarcely gets through.

LEAD: The meeting of six Balkan Foreign Ministers in Belgrade last week is being widely praised for bringing together representatives of countries burdened by historic rivalries and for producing several bilateral agreements.

LEAD: The decision this week by a small political organization to field its own vice presidential candidate rather than support the nominee of President Suharto created an unexpected crisis for the country's ruling party.

LEAD: Louis G. Seaton, chief bargainer for the General Motors Corporation in the early years of contract negotiations with the United Automobile Workers, died Thursday at Sarasota (Fla.) Memorial Hospital. Mr. Seaton, who suffered a stroke four days earlier, was 81 years old and lived in Sarasota.

LEAD: Everyone is in favor of closing up loopholes in the tax law - a loophole, after all, is something the other guy is wriggling through to avoid taxes. And the Congressional tax writers did just that in the Tax Reform Act of 1986, tightening deductions and taxing income that was previously exempt. That was how they kept the law ''revenue neutral'' while lowering marginal tax rates.

LEAD: The recent move by the Museum of Modern Art in appointing Kirk Varnedoe, age 42, to succeed William Rubin, age 60, as head of its department of painting and sculpture, marks a major generational shift. With the world's greatest assemblage of 20th-century masterworks and a long roster of illustrious exhibitions to its credit, the department is the museum's biggest, its best funded and its most powerful esthetic presence.

LEAD: FRED HALL'S tastes about winter weather are strange but understandable. Like most people, he revels in sunny days in the summer. But in the winter, he is happiest if it is snowing, raining or sleeting.

LEAD: What's the most offensive music video clip ever? For me, one candidate reigns supreme: the clip for Michael Jackson's current single, ''Man in the Mirror.'' LEAD: Lilli is a loser who has landed in Eden. But in this case, Eden is not exactly Paradise - it's a patch of land on the Australian coast that cradles a dingy caravan park filled with squatty trailers. Indeed, its only Edenic quality is a breathtaking view of the percolating surf and the gloriously rugged beach.

LEAD: The Republican Party's search for a successor to Ronald Reagan, whose landslide victories stirred the party's hopes for a national realignment under Republicans, has turned into a campaign so rough that some party leaders are worrying that they may lose the White House and many other offices this fall.

LEAD: FROM a developer's point of view, Snug Harbor is one that got away. An enclave of 19th-century buildings -some are Greek Revival in style - it is set on 75 acres and might have become a high-rise heaven if preservation groups and the people of Staten Island had not pressured the City of New York to buy it.

LEAD: WHEN a Mayoral task force issued a stinging critique of New York City's Human Rights Commission last month, saying it took years to handle complaints that should be resolved in months, few were surprised.

LEAD: ON FIRST seeing the battered bus, one rescuer said it looked as if it had been filleted. A boulder weighing several tons, dislodged by a Colorado state road crew, had thundered down a Rocky Mountain slope and crashed into the tourist vehicle 60 miles northwest of Denver. Six people were killed instantly, one died later, 21 were injured.

LEAD: Where the Gertz Department Store failed, sponsors hope the Gertz Mall will succeed. The new shopping center in the Jamaica section of Queens will open on Saturday with 76 stores and seven food outlets in the basement and first floor of what once was one of the largest department stores in New York.
LEAD: JUST as they have for the last 15 years, members of the postwar baby-boom generation, by the strength of their numbers, are again reshaping the housing market to fit their own needs.

LEAD: America spends too much for its military and receives too little for its money. The military consumes 6.7 percent of gross national product and 32 percent of America's research and development expenditures. Germany spends 3.1 percent of G.N.P. and employs 6 percent of its R.&D. talent in the service of its defense; Japan spends even less.

LEAD: Saying it has been paying too much for rail service, the Rockland County Legislature voted unanimously last week to withdraw from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The move, which requires the County Executive's approval, would take effect Jan. 1, 1989.
LEAD: For years, car collectors in the United States used the strong dollar to buy classic European cars at bargain prices. That trend reversed a couple of years back.
LEAD: STRANGER IN THE FOREST On Foot Across Borneo. By Eric Hansen. Illustrated. 286 pp. Boston: A Yolla Bolly Press Book/ Houghton Mifflin Company. $17.95.
LEAD: FREE RADICAL Albert Szent-Gyorgyi and The Battle Over Vitamin C. By Ralph W. Moss. Preface by Studs Terkel. Illustrated. 316 pp. New York: Paragon House Publishers. $22.95.

LEAD: I'VE NEVER MET VIKTOR M. CHEBRIKOV, the head of the K.G.B., but after living in Moscow for two and a half years I can't help feeling we're well acquainted. Every time I see his somber visage in newspapers and on television I think about the dozens of times the K.G.B. has intruded in my life.

LEAD: The uprising in the Israeli occupied West Bank and Gaza has revived the hopes of militant Palestinian organizations here that they can restore their old influence after years of obscure existence and internal discord.

LEAD: Although at times the small screen seems to be overflowing with young marrieds, adorable children and teen-age heartthrobs, television is in many ways proving a boon to what might diplomatically be called the ''veteran performer.'' This is the actor who once may have enjoyed considerable success in television and/or films but now, having reached a ''certain age'' or run into a luckless stretch of unemployment, finds decent job offers more and more scarce.

LEAD: The State Attorney General's office has joined a review of the Jersey City Police Department, which was rocked recently by the suicide of its chief and has been accused of racism and brutality by the city's Indian and Hispanic communities.
LEAD: PEARS make delicious desserts, raw or cooked. A plain ripe pear is a perfect end to a meal, when served with a piece of Roquefort cheese and a glass of Sauterne - or with Stilton and port.

LEAD: The table below shows the net present value of after-tax interest and closing costs on a $10,000 loan taken out in 1987. It assumes a 10 percent discount rate and nondeductible closing costs of $400 and $200 on second mortgages and home equity loans respectively with closing costs amortized over the life of the loan.

LEAD: The audit. The dreaded Internal Revenue Service audit. This year, more than two million Americans will learn firsthand what the word means, when their tax returns are selected for examination. While some of these returns will be chosen randomly, the vast majority will have raised some red flag that triggered an audit - failing to report income, for instance, or claiming unusual or outsized deductions.
LEAD: SAFETY PATROL By Michael Martone. 128 pp. Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins University Press. $14.95.

As the score piles up in my friend Bruce's favor, I feel a kind of serene apathy come over me vis-a-vis pursuing this small, thwacked piece of black rub-ber around this claustrophobic arena.

LEAD: To the Editor: Returning from a recent trip to England, I found I had lost one of the 11 rolls of films I had taken. It was only after having the rolls developed that I realized the missing roll contained all the photos I had taken at Stonehenge.

LEAD: HOW LOVE'S SWEET song has changed. Just a decade ago it was marked by bold discordancies and feisty lyrics: alternate life styles, swinging, open marriage. All those are gone now, and the new lyrics sound remarkably old: constancy, stability, tradition.

LEAD: Prince Charles, whose criticisms of postwar British architecture and planning have made him his own country's most celebrated architecture critic, took his crusade to the United States today for the first time and expanded his target accordingly.

Only a half dozen operating under majority rule - Senegal, Gambia, Botswana, Madagascar, Sudan and

LEAD: A network of services for elderly crime victims here in this western Massachusetts city and the rest of Hampden County has encouraged the elderly to report crimes against them to the police, officials say.

We are grateful to leave the opaque stillness of ungodly hours to the profane: paper carriers, fishermen, sanitation workers, Jane Pauley, and a dangerously proliferating number of hot-air balloonists.

LEAD: Whether you plan to have your return prepared professionally or to do it yourself, walking through a return prepared by top professionals can be helpful, both in terms of getting records organized for this year's filing and in planning tax strategies for future years. LEAD: THE season is upon us. Crocuses are baring their tender shoots in the rock garden. Heavy woolens have hit the 50-percent-off rack in the stores. Winter is on the wane. I'm talking bathing suits.

LEAD: In DOWNRIVER (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95), Loren D. Estleman is back where he belongs, with his tough private eye Amos Walker. The eighth in this Detroit series, the book bears a slight resemblance to Robert B. Parker's Spenser mysteries: Spenser works with a lethal black man named Hawk, and Walker now has an equivalent of Hawk on his side - a black giant named Richard DeVries, just released after 20 years in prison, and somebody you most definitely do not want to mess around with.

LEAD: New details emerged yesterday about Philip Copeland, who the police believe was the messenger between an imprisoned drug dealer and the three other men accused of murdering Officer Edward Byrne.

LEAD: As World Series champions, the Minnesota Twins have a spring corps of pitchers that more closely resembles the tired, the poor and the huddled masses that Emma Lazarus had in mind when she wrote the words that adorn the base of the Statue of Liberty.

LEAD: Although experiments have shown that orchestras cannot often get along without conductors, it is an open secret that they cannot always get along with them, either. LEAD: Georgetown ended Seton Hall's five-game winning streak this afternoon, but it took two overtimes, an outstanding effort by Jaren Jackson and perhaps the Hoyas' best game of the season to do it.

LEAD: Skiing Swiss Takes First: Brigitte Oertli, in the absence of her three injured Swiss teammates, yesterday won the weather-delayed women's World Cup downhill race in Aspen, Colo., and moved into first place in the overall standings. The Swiss have won all seven downhill races this season. Oertli, silver medalist in both the downhill and combined at the Winter Olympics, was clocked in 1 minute 22.83 seconds down a course that was icier than on Friday, when the race was stopped.

Instant replay is more than a video technique: it's an epiphany, the moment of truth caught, held and made accessible. Until the 20th century, people had only one look, but art is so ambiguous now that the single look won't do.

LEAD: Lincoln High School of Brooklyn (23-0) got a game-high 26 points from Norman Marbury, a sophomore, on the way to a 76-71 victory over Grady of Brooklyn (18-7) yesterday in a Public Schools Athletic League Section A quarterfinal game at Canarsie High School in Brooklyn. Lincoln will face Newtown (25-0), which defeated Springfield Gardens, 56-55, in overtime Friday, next Sunday in a semifinal at Brandeis High School in Manhattan.

LEAD: The Musee D'Orsay may be only a little more than a year old, but it is already the most controversial museum built in this decade. It includes almost every form of visual expression in France between 1848 and 1914. The great Realist, Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings that were in the Louvre and the Jeu de Paume are here.

LEAD: While cautioning that everyone's return must be considered individually, four experts found the following deductions reasonable for the family situations described. This is not to warn taxpayers away from taking larger deductions if they are entitled to them and have adequate records. Nor should anyone with smaller actual deductions beef them up.

LEAD: When the stock market collapsed on Oct. 19, collectible car owners, auctioneers and others with a financial stake wondered about the fallout in their market. ''I was biting my fingernails for a while,'' said Brian Jackson, co-owner of the Barrett Jackson Auction Company. Almost immediately, however, values of many collectible cars increased.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: Judye Suttenberg admits she's one of those mothers who bought her children absolutely everything. Back in the late 1960's, she got the World Book for her three daughters when they barely knew who Howdy Doody was. Why isn't everyone like that? She can't understand it.
