All are obviously talented. Yet, the inquisitive dance-goer may wonder how and why Mr.
LEAD: SUSAN SULLIVAN admits that it's tricky looking into other people's refrigerators, but she tries, especially when the refrigerators are owned by friends who are men.

LEAD: IF there was a conclusion to be drawn from Gerard Schwarz's Music Today program Wednesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, it was that contemporary composers have slowly found their way out of the woods: The earliest work offered, Harrison Birtwistle's ''World Is Discovered'' (1961), was virtually impenetrable, while the latest, Richard Danielpour's ''First Light'' (1988), was instantly accessible.

LEAD: A judge in Florida has set Sept. 7 as the starting date of a new trial for Denny McLain on charges of racketeering related to drug dealings. McLain, a former two-time Cy Young Award winner and the last major leaguer to win 30 games in a season, was convicted of the charges in 1986, but the conviction was overturned last year by an appeals court.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: International negotiators, even Soviet and American negotiators, sometimes develop a curious consanguinity, a common impulse to reach agreement even where it runs against their governments' policies. At times, they explore possibilities for compromise that exceed their instructions, and conspire to sell their joint product to their respective capitals.
LEAD: It is usually those who are physically unattractive who bemoan the fact that physical beauty is valued. It is those who cannot make it financially who scorn the rich.

LEAD: THE deterioration of the value of the dollar against many foreign currencies is causing a lot of people to rethink their plans for travel abroad this year. Some, with the encouragement of their travel agents, are looking over the maps of Eastern Europe.

LEAD: THIRTY-FIVE miles south of the high-rises of Cancun is a luxury resort made of canvas and sand. It's a full-service establishment - only your bed is in a tent and your tent, a stone's throw from the Mexican Caribbean, is in a secluded, sandy grove of tropical trees and shrubs. Operated by an American family, the resort offers maid service, real beds, excellent food and a full bar open all day long, a resident masseuse and hot tub.

LEAD: The 37-year-old investment banker was shopping for a used fur coat recently at a thrift shop in Manhattan. The owner of three furs, she wanted another. She decided to buy it second hand, she said, because of the collapse of the stock market in October and an uncertain economy.

LEAD: IT was not the first time my wife, quite rightly perhaps, tried to get me to throw my old gym shorts into the trash. They are tattered, old, ugly, made for a person 35 pounds lighter than myself, and would be rejected from most rag bags. I, however, refuse to dispose of them, for purely sentimental reasons.

LEAD: Who stole the strawberries? Who put the eye-black in Kirk Gibson's cap? Who threw the overalls in Mrs. Murphy's chowder? Why did Willie Hernandez throw more cold water on a columnist than he does on opposing rallies for months at a time?

LEAD: FINISH dormant pruning and spraying. Check flower borders and young shrubs; push back into the ground, gently, any that have had their roots heaved by frosts. Indoors transplant annual seedlings that have developed their second pair of true leaves; plant seed of tomatoes, peppers and eggplants indoors.

LEAD: THIS IS CER-TAINLY a case of a fashion that's caught on. In their recent collections, many leading designers in Paris, London and New York fell for flowers, using all sorts of blooms - especially roses - as motifs for printed fabrics and accessories.

LEAD: In her letter to the editor (Feb. 7), Natania Rosenfeld complains bitterly and cogently about the ''elitism'' of Allan Bloom's views in his book ''The Closing of the American Mind.'' Yet her complaint is exactly what Mr. Bloom is talking about -the American desire to ''democratize'' art and literature so that ''elitist'' distinctions of quality are banished.

LEAD: To the Editor: In ''Insuring Against a Medical Crisis'' (Practical Traveler, Dec. 27), there was an incomplete description regarding memberships and duration of coverage with our company, WorldCare Travel Assistance. In addition to coverage ranging from 8 days ($38) to 90 days ($115), we offer six-month coverage ($155) and coverage for a full 365 days ($200).

LEAD: The engagement of Beth Janet Pearlstein to Lawrence Edward Tofel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Tofel of Riverdale, the Bronx, has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Pearlstein of Bridgewater, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: The shameless commercialism of the Games as presented by ABC, was the worst part of the Olympics. Apparently the Games exist for the coverage; the Games are not covered. What was once sport is now more about hamburgers and diet soda. Too few gold medals means lower revenues from sponsors. Of course this trend can't be allowed to continue.

LEAD: Jessica Einstein and George Couri were married yesterday at St. Gregory's Episcopal Church in Boca Raton, Fla. The Rev. Paul Schneirla, a priest of the Antiochian Orthodox Church, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Sylvia Jukes Morris's research into the life and times of the fascinating Clare Boothe Luce was both honest and gentle (''In Search of Clare Boothe Luce,'' Jan. 31).

LEAD: ZIONS CAUSE (1920-1950). By Jim Peyton. (Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill, $14.95.) It's odd to read a book and think it would make a handful of one-acters, but this first novel by a retired Kentucky teacher talks itself into the notion pretty quick. ''Zions Cause'' is an anecdotal tale of a Kentucky hamlet over 30 years.

LEAD: WINTER winds, coupled with freezing and thawing over several months, can wreak havoc with a home's exterior. Although early spring is usually too soon to repair shingled roofs (not only do icy surfaces still make such work dangerous, but also the ground may be too soggy to support ladders), you can get a head start on outdoor maintenance by repairing shingle siding.

The runners, both former winners of the New York City Marathon, are hoping to use a victory in Los Angeles as a springboard to the Olympics.

The exhibit is intended to generate interest in the Brooklyn movie palace, which has been silent for a decade.

LEAD: Taking control of your tax situation involves a lot more than filling out the forms, or gathering up folders of last year's records to drop by the accountant's office. Actually, financial planning is an ongoing, year-round affair, and for those who spend an hour or two a week monitoring their finances - checking whether their portfolios are meeting expectations and how their household budgets are shaping up - income-tax preparation is a relatively effortless exercise.

LEAD: Randy Romero learned last month how tough it is to run down Forty Niner. In the Fountain of Youth Stakes Feb. 15, the jockey spent almost the entire race unsuccessfully battling to get a colt named Notebook to edge past Forty Niner, only to fall a nose short at the finish line.
LEAD: THE state commission studying taxes and spending wants the state to assume some expenses paid by counties and municipalities.

LEAD: DETENTE - a French word once distinctly malodorous in the United States - is breaking out again, and Ronald Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev are responsible, or at least presiding over the process. In Western Europe, not all the allies are wholeheartedly enthusiastic by Detente II.

LEAD: Plans for a 52-story luxury apartment tower near City Hall have startled and angered some neighbors, but the proposal apparently conforms to zoning rules and is not subject to prolonged review - or bargaining.

LEAD: If there is a coaching equivalent of a slam dunk, Willis Reed made one last week. Tuesday, in their first game under Reed, the New Jersey Nets beat the Los Angeles Clippers by 29 points. Nice, but no big surprise: The Clippers currently have the worst record in the National Basketball Association.

LEAD: Jeff Taggart, a junior guard for Canisius, suffered a fatal seizure tonight while sitting on the bench during the game with Niagara, a 71-60 loss. The Erie County Medical Examiners office said Taggart was dead on arrival at Sheehan Emergency Hospital.
LEAD: ANN SULLIVAN acts as the eyes and ears of Connecticut in the nation's capital.

LEAD: A PROPOSED law that would eliminate parole for anyone convicted of willfully killing a law-enforcement officer is gaining support in Trenton, even though some legislators and the Attorney General, fearing inmate violence, initially objected to it.

LEAD: The Mets transplanted a bit of the Big Apple to the Gold Coast of Florida today after training for 26 years on the Gulf Coast. And they were welcomed to their new springtime home by cheering crowds, spouting sprinklers and wide-ranging predictions that this was the year the Mets would rise again.

LEAD: When he collected the puck tonight, Ulf Dahlen immediately understood the significance of what he was about to do. There were 15 minutes left in the third period, there was some room to the far side, and there was a chance to put away the game against the Whalers.

LEAD: EVERY year at this time, camera manufacturers bring forth their newest creations in a flurry of press releases, press luncheons and pressing of the flesh. The occasion: the Photo Marketing Association trade show, held this year in Chicago. It is a time when just about any news is better than no news.

Dukakis of Massachusetts fought to a standstill in Wyoming's Democratic Presidential caucuses yesterday while the state's Republicans were dividing their delegates between Vice President Bush and Senator Bob Dole, Mr. Gore and Mr. Dukakis each won enough representatives to the state convention to earn at least four delegates to the Democratic National Convention in Atlanta.

LEAD: The Bobcats of Oregon-Davis High School in tiny Hamlet, Ind., kept up their winning ways Friday night with a 59-54 victory over neighboring North Judson High, moving a step nearer the regional basketball tournament. With a record of 21 victories and 1 defeat, the school has 9 of the 20 male seniors on the varsity team.

LEAD: The cultural highlights in Europe this spring and summer range from two new festivals in London to a new museum in Haarlem, the Netherlands, to an exhibition in Venice about the Phoenicians. This listing was compiled by Carol Plum based on reports from New York Times bureaus in London, Paris, Bonn, Rome and Madrid.

LEAD: TSUTOMU HATA has earned a lasting entry in the lore of United States-Japan relations with a recent discourse on why his country could not accept more imports of American beef. Japanese are incapable of eating much beef, said Mr. Hata, a former agriculture minister who had gone to Washington as his Government's point man on this issue.

LEAD: IN a few days my daughter will be 22 years old. It's hard to believe that I have been somebody's mother for 22 years when I barely feel grown-up myself. She was the first of four, the one I practiced on, and the one who is still teaching me the art of motherhood.

LEAD: The New Zealand challenger, Michael Fay, is going to be in California for a speaking engagement this week, and before he returns home, officials of Sail America, which is managing the defense of the America's Cup for the San Diego Yacht Club, hope he will accept some proposals to change the race format.

LEAD: The young couple thought they had it all figured out. They had sold their co-op and were closing on a Monday. On the following Friday, they planned to close on their new home. They asked the buyer of the co-op to furnish a certified check at the first closing, assuming that the funds would then be available for the second.
LEAD: Melvin McCants scored a career-high 24 points, including three crucial free throws in the closing minutes, as Purdue survived frigid shooting down the stretch to defeat Michigan, 80-67.

LEAD: Between 1985 and 1987, Louis G. Boli, 69 years old, a retired aerospace engineer from Santa Barbara, Calif., and an otherwise very private person, took on the Federal Government in a test case concerning the Government's right to tax Social security benefits of retirees who also receive substantial tax-free income from municipal bonds, a change that took effect in 1984.

LEAD: FOR nine years, the Abenaki Indians of Vermont have been trying to get the state to prosecute them for fishing and hunting without licenses. Their wish may be granted soon. So far they have succeeded only in getting summonses three times. Twice the state, unprepared to argue its case, declined to prosecute.

LEAD: A report in The Week in Review on Jan. 24 about Israeli reactions to the conflict on the West Bank misspelled the name of an Arab member of the Israeli Parliament who said there was ''real opportunity'' in the situation. The correct spelling is Abed Darawshe.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: AMBIVALENCE toward a neighbor that is 10 times larger in population and economic strength has been a perennial feature of Canadian life. Lately, the strains of admiration and resentment have been in the forefront of public debate, with those who look south for social and economic models increasingly at odds with those who warn of creeping ''Americanization.

LEAD: Altagracia R. Coleman, who had combined a sales career with being a wife and mother, took a leave of absence of more than a year to be with her three children. Then, in 1984 she returned to work after she and her husband, Richard, realized that her salary was needed to meet the family's expenses.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John R. Robinson of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Abigail Phipps Robinson, to Thomas Bowers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Bowers of Greenwich. The couple plan to marry in July.

LEAD: FOR SEVERAL weeks now I have been depressed by the thought that we can no longer have mean Presidents. This became apparent after the hysteria known as the New Hampshire primary, when many news people said Senator Robert Dole was afflicted with ''a mean streak'' that would hurt his campaign.

LEAD: Anchored in the rich fishing waters of the Gulf of Guinea, the African archipelago of Sao Tome e Principe was shaken in 1981 by food riots. The new Government could no longer afford to import dried fish.

LEAD: Going through the worksheet will help you determine which records you need to gather up and organize for tax preparation, as well as give you a ball-park figure on taxable income and help you see where you may want to make adjustments this year. Enter losses as a negative number.
LEAD: IT is doubtful whether one bridge player in a hundred could answer either of the following questions: Who is the most successful tournament player in the past year? Or in the past four years?

LEAD: Nancy C. Wallace and Fred Allen Cooper, a son of Mrs. Louis Cooper of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Cooper, plan to marry in April, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leveritt A. Wallace of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced.
LEAD: An article on Feb. 7 about European travel packages misstated Alitalia Airlines' rate for six nights at the Nord Hotel in Rome. It is $299.

LEAD: The London Piano School. How many know what that means, much less the composers who were part of it? Who, even in a lifetime of concert going, has ever heard a piece of music by Thomas Busby? John Burton? Cipriani Potter? Ferdinand Ries? William Thomas Best? The once-famous William Sterndale Bennett?

LEAD: CATAMOUNT BRIDGE. By Don Metz. (Harper & Row, $16.95.) In Don Metz's first novel, the Vietnam War is an ominous backdrop to a family drama set in northern Vermont. Its central conflict is between Bodie Woodard, a shy, sensitive introvert who opposes the war, and his twin brother, Harmon, a swaggering macho go-getter who supports it.

LEAD: THE NEW CHINATOWN By Peter Kwong. 198 pp. New York: Hill & Wang. $18.95. BITTER MELON Stories From the Last Rural Chinese Town in America. By Jeff Gillenkirk and James Motlow. Illustrated. 142 pp. Seattle: University of Washington Press. Cloth, $35. Paper, $19.95. THE CHINESE LAUNDRYMAN A Study of Social Isolation.

LEAD: Bishop J. Brooke Mosley Jr., a former president of the Union Theological Seminary, died of a heart attack Friday in Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan as he was preparing to board a train to his home in Philadelphia. He was 72 years old.
LEAD: In 1968 and 1969, ''The Joke'' was translated into all the Western languages. But what surprises!
LEAD: THE STORY OF MY WIFE The Reminiscences of Captain Storr. By Milan Fust. Translated by Ivan Sanders. Preface by George Konrad. 336 pp. New York: PAJ Publications. $18.95.

LEAD: At the Harvard Club in Boston, Lucinda Jean Alpert, a daughter of Mrs. Malcolm C. Green of Boston and East Hebron, N.H., and Leonard Alpert of Sacramento, Calif., was married yesterday to Dodd Harrison Grande, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Grande of Des Moines, Wash. The ceremony was performed by Richard Alpert, an uncle of the bride, who is known as Baba Ram Dass, the Hindu spiritual leader of the Hanumam Temple in Taos, N.M.
LEAD: MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV begins his fourth year as Soviet leader this week probably worried less about the state of the economy than the stability of the state.
LEAD: THEATRICAL DEBUTS Two plays will make their American premieres this week at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: The Devils were inspiring today as they beat the Boston Bruins, 7-6, on a goal by Andy Brickley 47 seconds into overtime.

LEAD: Policemen and mourners scuffled today during a funeral procession for an Irish Republican Army member who was one of two men killed when they accidentally detonated a bomb they were installing in a van, the police said.

LEAD: All of us who have felt an emotional link to Israel since the moment the state was born in 1948 now face fundamental questions. Do we believe that Israel's safety lies in holding on to the West Bank and Gaza? Or would it be wiser for Israel to seek an accommodation with the Palestinians, an exchange of land for peace?

LEAD: The rates will be lowered over a five-year period, and at the same time larger standard deductions will be phased in, as shown below. The top marginal rates will apply to most taxpayers; the 1987 threshold is $14,000 for single persons and $23,300 for married couples filing jointly.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: One of my parents' most valuable gifts to me was the understanding that my eldest sister's ''illness'' was nothing of which to be ashamed (About Men: ''A Brother's Dreams,'' by Paul Aronowitz, Jan. 24). Consequently, I have always told my friends of her diagnosis of schizophrenia. However, until recently,

LEAD: Brad Sloat couldn't remember what numbers were stitched to the backs of the football uniforms worn by the Three Stooges in one of their movies. So he got a pie in the face. But he wasn't taking anything off the pie thrower; he sent it flying right back. A group of kids joined in, hurling handfuls of whipped cream all over the Quality Inn meeting room.

LEAD: GAELIC FESTIVAL Step-dancing demonstrations, pipe bands, Irish coffee and speeches by Westchester officials of Irish extraction are on the bill for the Gaelic Feis, or festival, scheduled from 6 to 10 P.M. Friday and from noon to 10 P.M. Saturday and next Sunday. It is to take place under a 60-by-100-foot heated tent on Glen Island in New Rochelle, in observance of the city's tricentennial and the 125th birthday of the Irish Benevolent

LEAD: CHESS is one of the three principal human activities - mathematics and music are the others - in which youth can shine. Not only do these fields produce child prodigies, but the general level of development in them is also by far greatest in adolescence.
LEAD: Henry A. Kissinger yesterday disputed the accuracy of some of the remarks attributed to him in a report in The New York Times on his statements to a group of prominent American Jews last month.
LEAD: The police detained 15 Crimean Tatars today after members of the ethnic group held up a banner demanding the right to live in their homeland, a dissident said.

LEAD: It was Saturday morning, and though most of the tiny offices in the big Regent Street building were closed, Iain Carstairs, who owns Orion Travel, was seated behind his sleek wooden desk in his tiny travel agency, manning the telephone. ''A lot of people walk in or call up and ask what's cheap at the moment,'' he said, sifting through a pile of travel brochures.

LEAD: While it is true that some women choose repeat Caesarean birth out of ignorance [ Long Island Journal, Jan. 24 ] , from my own experience I believe it is more common that women are not told by their physicians that vaginal delivery after Caesarean birth is feasible.

LEAD: Private security agencies, which provide guards, security systems and investigators for industrial and individual use, have become big business in India because of growing wealth, greater business competition and the fear of terrorism in the Punjab.
LEAD: ''The best investment is land, because they ain't making anymore of it.'' - Will Rogers

LEAD: Blanche Du Bois first appeared to Tennessee Williams as an image: a woman sitting in a chair in the moonlight, waiting for a man to show up. Though she grew to be the heroine of ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' she never stopped waiting for men to save her.
LEAD: ''This is the most unkindest cut of all.'' - William Shakespeare

LEAD: The question arises at regular intervals, no doubt related to the periodic impingement of the Olympics on public consciousness. This year it is posed succinctly by John L. Liddle of Riverside, Calif., who writes to ask, ''Since track and field and swimming records fall all the time, why shouldn't singers improve?

LEAD: The Indy-car season doesn't open until April 10 in Phoenix, but the top teams in the series have been testing their 1988 cars almost since the last race of the 1987 season in Miami more than three months ago. Drivers and team owners say that the lonely, sometimes dangerous work of testing new equipment over the winter is one of the keys to success when the season begins.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Roy L. Still of Chattanooga, Tenn., and Washington, Iowa, have announced the engagement of their daughter Cindy Jo Still to Niles Ainsworth Howard, a son of Mrs. Leon Earl Howard of Clinton, N.C., and the late Mr. Howard.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Norman Schaumberger of Douglaston, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Gail Schaumberger, to Steven Nicokiris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Nicokiris of Pompano Beach, Fla. A September wedding is planned.
LEAD: The bad news is it happened. The good news is it is over. PAT SHANLEY Berkeley Heights, N.J.

LEAD: Thoughts Tossing in a Hammock In anthropology now, says Clifford Geertz, there's ''a pervasive nervousness about the whole business of claiming to explain enigmatical others.'' This is from his ''Works and Lives: the Anthropologist as Author'' (Stanford University).

LEAD: Duquesne University in Pittsburgh, which attracted national attention when it instituted a plan for prepayment of tuition at a child's birth, has been forced to suspend the program because of changing economic conditions.
LEAD: WINDS of change, stirred up by a new political administration, have shaken the tranquillity of artists working in studios at Riker Hill Art Park here.
LEAD: SINCE trains stopped running across it in 1982, the Spuyten Duyvil swing bridge has been stuck in the open position, like a faucet that cannot be turned off.

LEAD: THERE was once a Broadway play called ''Subways Are for Sleeping.'' Given the crime rate, I doubt that's true anymore. The updated version, Fairfield County-style, would be ''Theaters Are for Sleeping.''
LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Elias P. Gyftopoulos of Lincoln, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Vasso Gyftopoulos to Hugh J. Kelly 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kelly Jr. of Weston, Mass.

LEAD: It is difficult to judge the Olympics because of the determined interference of the television coverage. We seemed to see far more of ABC's commentators than the Olympic events. Is there no way to shut these people up? CLARENCE FISHER Jr. New York

LEAD: Country music is easy to come by in Europe and in the British Isles. There is local imitation country music; you can hear it sung in Danish in trucker bars in Jutland, for example. There is imported mainstream American country: Willie Nelson will play Wembley Stadium here in April.
LEAD: Senator Albert Gore Jr., who is counting on Southern voters Tuesday to give him the lift his Presidential campaign needs, saw none of them Friday.
LEAD: At St. Joan of Arc Roman Catholic Church in Jackson Heights, Queens, Claudine Suzanne Puglisi and Thomas Leland Cagwin were married yesterday by the Rev. Martin Geraghty.

LEAD: Reagan Administration officials report a sharp increase in the number of Armenians trying to leave the Soviet Union, and the State Department has drafted a proposal to admit 12,000 of them to the United States as refugees.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Deborah Mullin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Mullin of Chicago, was married there last night to Anthony Jon Lembeck, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lembeck of Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi William Frankel officiated at the Standard Club.

LEAD: A large majority of Southerners favor legislation limiting imports, although they realize that such measures might cause other countries to retaliate against American products, according to a poll released today.
LEAD: Israeli soldiers shot to death two more Palestinians today in continued widespread unrest in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

LEAD: The sponsors of the Towers at London Terrace in the Chelsea section of Manhattan are thinking of outfitting their doormen as turn-of-the-century English bobbies to recreate the atmosphere of the London Terrace apartment community when it opened in 1931. The lobby fashion statement is a small part of a large noneviction cooperative conversion.
LEAD: SEEKING to emulate the success of Japanese and Korean car makers, the Soviet Union moved last year to penetrate the heavy-machinery market in the United States.

LEAD: The engagement of Vivienne Hanna Barr to Perry Howard Braun, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman L. Braun of Highland Park, Ill., has been made known by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Charles E. Barr of New York. The couple plan to marry in the fall.
LEAD: Rioting broke out in Lhasa today, and a police station was attacked as a Buddhist festival drew to a close in the Tibetan capital, according to the official New China News Agency.

LEAD: A tiny part of the British public claimed a blow for free expression as they gathered here to view some forbidden glimmerings of Michael Collins, the Irishman who led the rebel war against Britain almost seven decades ago.

LEAD: Julia Holbrook Mills, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon L. Mills of Greenwich, Conn., and Andrew Seth Levine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Levine of Pikesville, Md., and Palm Beach, Fla., plan to marry in June, the future bride's parents have announced.

LEAD: To the Editor: ''What's Doing in Cleveland'' (Travel, Jan. 3) needs some filling in. If the Stouffer Tower City Plaza Hotel is found wanting, there are three fine large hotels in downtown Cleveland, all within easy walking distance of both the Convention Center and the Galleria: the Holiday Inn Lakeside, the Hollenden and the Bond Court Hotel.

LEAD: I never thought I would make it to China. Every time I heard stories from friends and colleagues about their journeys to Asia, I was envious. A figure of between $3,000 and $4,000 a person was usually mentioned, a cost that seemed prohibitive to me.

LEAD: THE presidents of the five main Central American countries have yet to carry out the peace plan they signed seven months ago - and it looks as if they never will. But even if the treaty dies a slow death, it may manage to have a few lasting effects.

LEAD: THE French in the postwar era have been carefully establishing a series of musical ensembles that both serve and reflect the country's different regions. One is the Chamber Orchestra of the Auvergne. It was formed in 1981, and Jean-Jacques Kantorow has been its conductor for the last three years. The orchestra -about 20 strong - came to New York Thursday night with a concert at the Metropolitan

LEAD: PAPRIKA is to the entrees and main dishes of Hungary what whipped cream is to its desserts and pastries: it is theoretically possible to do without, but on the evidence of many a meal in homes and restaurants, the dominant hue of the first and second courses is rosy more often than not, and what follows is likely to be hiding under a billow of white.

LEAD: The annual Southern Ocean Racing Conference is having its second lean year in a row. Last year, organizers for the yacht-racing series off the Florida coast blamed the America's Cup in Australia for a poor turnout. This year, they cite the stock market crash last October.

LEAD: At least 300,000 people in the United States collect old cars for love or money or both. And while the number of collectors is increasing by 5 to 10 percent a year, the real growth in the collectible car market is measured in dollars. This year, participants estimate that up to $500 million will change hands at auctions and private sales.

LEAD: The decision to submit ''A Brother's Dreams'' to your magazine was not an easy one for me to make. Even after the piece appeared, I worried about whether I had done the right thing. However, the overwhelming response from friends and many strangers from around the country has vanquished any doubt I had.

LEAD: IN hindsight, the early days of Latin America's debt crisis were adventurous as government officials, foreign bankers and international experts stepped gingerly into the unknown, aware only that one false move - a moment of panic or an act of despair - could bring chaos to the international monetary system.

LEAD: TWELVE string players, three keyboardists, two guitarists, one bassist, three background singers, two drummers, and six horns helped the Brazilian singer Roberto Carlos charm the sold-out crowd at Radio City Music Hall on Saturday night. Mr. Carlos, looking healthy and tan in a white suit with sleeves rolled up, acts the repentant playboy who has found the power of true love - his songs leap all the way from phrases like ''I want you to be my love'' to ''What will be with you?

LEAD: It is not often in first youth that people fall in love with Dutch 17th-century landscape painting. At 18 or 20, we prefer wilder shores and a more ecstatic mode of expression. Rare is the young person who would pass up a Provencal landscape by van Gogh or a Fauve harbor scene by Matisse or Derain in favor of rutted flatlands, blasted trees and tumbledown cottages by painters whose names we cannot pronounce, let along remember.

LEAD: In ''Juan Darien,'' by the Uru-guayan short-story writer Horacio Quiroga, a woman's compassion transforms an orphaned tiger cub into a child.
LEAD: A rash of strikes in Portugal since the beginning of the year represents the first serious test for the Government of Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva and his promise of political stability.
LEAD: Leslie Pihas's article ''Choices Both Great and Small'' [ Opinion Page, Jan. 10 ] underlines the problems parents have to deal with when their handicapped youngsters reach the age of 21.

LEAD: Shareholders of First City Bancorporation of Texas have approved a $1.5 billion restructuring plan, the second largest federally assisted bailout of a United States bank.

What had finally looked like a done deal with the Campeau Corporation fell apart when R.H.

LEAD: Through a series of small steps over the last three years, Congress has dramatically expanded Medicaid, the health program for the poor, extending coverage to several million children, elderly people and pregnant women.
LEAD: WHEN JIM CROW MET JOHN BULL Black American Soldiers in World War II Britain. By Graham Smith. 265 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $24.95.

LEAD: They waved goodbye to Mr. Nice Guy at the Pillsbury Company last week, and welcomed back William H. Spoor as chairman, chief executive officer and president. Mr. Spoor, now 65 years old, earned a reputation for brusque management while presiding over a 12-year period of rapid growth at Pillsbury, but took an early retirement in 1985.

LEAD: Alongside a cobblestone pathway in the Boston Public Garden is a slightly larger-than-life bronze sculpture of a mallard followed by eight ducklings. The sculpture is frequently patted and hugged by children who recognize the duck family as the one made famous by Robert McCloskey's award-winning 1941 book ''Make Way for Ducklings.

LEAD: SALLY GROSS has labored long and persuasively in dance, but she is surprisingly little known among dancegoers. She is also a choreographer with a sharp sense of visual effect, one who can indicate complex atmospheres and personal histories with the most minimal of brush strokes and the simplest of props.

LEAD: The second life granted St. Peter's College by Fairfield Coach Mitch Buonaguro's premature victory dance Wednesday night ended abruptly today. The Peacocks were beaten in the final minute by Fordham, 53-52, in one semifinal of the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference Tournament at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

LEAD: Sir John Templeton, sponsor of the $369,000 Templeton Prize for Progress in Religion, has expressed surprise at charges that this year's prize winner was associated with anti-Semitic and anti-Israel causes.

LEAD: The Syrian Government, in its first official comment on the Middle East peace proposals submitted by Secretary of State George P. Shultz on Friday, said today that Washington was trying to put ''an American stamp'' on what is meant to be an international effort.

LEAD: On Wall Street, data-watching was always a favorite sport among economists, but not as much as it is today. Hand-holding of clients was always important; now, it can dominate an economist's working day. The principal task used to be the quarterly forecast. Now, the horizon can be as short as a few days - and sometimes less.

LEAD: IT is ironic that as the State Department is reporting that, with the exception of Greece, dining out in Portugal is less expensive than anywhere in Western Europe, dining at Stamford's new Portuguese restaurant, Pearl of the Atlantic, is one of the more expensive experiences in Fairfield County.
LEAD: A race car plunged into a crowd of spectators after one of its tires exploded today, killing at least 16 persons and injuring more than a dozen others, the police said.

LEAD: Barry Manilow still sells records and still does major tours, but the pop singer seems to have reached a pivotal point in his career. Going are the soaring ballads with their soupy crescendos that seduced the hearts of teeny-boppers throughout the world. In his last couple of albums, Mr. Manilow has been reaching out to different sounds and styles, tapping especially the American heritage of jazz and Latin music.
LEAD: Tomorrow voters in 20 states will pick nearly a third of the delegates to the parties' conventions. A state-by-state summary, page A17.
LEAD: Hasbro's quest for an agency to do print advertising for its Playskool division has ended with the decision to retain Kornhauser & Calene.

LEAD: The Pentagon is mortgaging its present to its future. LEAD: Mention sushi in this pocket of paradise and you'll probably be run off the island. The raw fish, a much-maligned food of the stylish moderns, is wrapped in seaweed, which the Japanese called nori. Now plans are under way to make Guemes Island the nori capital of the Western Hemisphere by establishing a 700-acre seaweed farm here, Farming, in this part of the world, has clearly changed: salmon are raised in pens and seaweed is grown in underwater nets suspended from floats in saltwater ranches, dried and then processed into thin sheets of edible wrapping.

LEAD: The United States and Britain vetoed a Security Council resolution today that would have imposed an oil embargo and other sanctions against South Africa for its imposition of restrictions on 17 anti-apartheid groups.

LEAD: When you're lost in the Silicon Valley, there's no need to do something so low tech as to look at a map. The Navigation Technologies Corporation, a start-up based in Sunnyvale, Calif., has created a small computer that tells you where to go and how to get there by the most efficient route.

LEAD: The details emerging about the violent anti-Chinese demonstrations Saturday in Tibet leave little doubt that Beijing's attempt to court Tibetans through a display of greater tolerance has won neither their loyalty nor acceptance of the Chinese presence.
LEAD: The 1988 Guide Michelin for France has awarded its highest rating to the Paris restaurant L'Ambroisie, the only restaurant to be added to the three-star category this year.
LEAD: Martin L. Longstreth Jr., chairman of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange since 1984, died of lung cancer on Sunday at his home in Oreland, Pa. He was 43 years old.

LEAD: Bob Wieland, who lost both legs during the Vietnam War, crossed the finish line yesterday morning and completed the Los Angeles Marathon, which he started last Saturday. Wieland covered the 26-mile-385-yard course in about 74 1/2 hours, using his powerful arms to push himself along. He bettered his 1987 time by 18 hours.

LEAD: One day after being released from Pembroke Pines General Hospital in Florida after tests for a stomach disorder he suffered last Saturday, Dan Marino of the Miami Dolphins headed for California and another knee operation yesterday. Dr. Richard Steadman is to perform arthroscopic surgery in Lake Tahoe, on Marino's left knee, the quarterback's fourth such operation in five years.

Redington left the town on the Kuskokwim River after staying just over four hours to feed and rest his 14 dogs.

LEAD: The Jets traded Barry Bennett, the 32-year-old defensive lineman, to the Los Angeles Raiders yesterday for an undisclosed draft choice. LEAD: REAL linoleum, made from linseed oil, wood dust, cork and resins, has not been manufactured in the United States for over 10 years. American manufacturers are keeping up by making new vinyl tiles and sheets with brick, floral and marbleized motifs that recall the old look.

LEAD: The tests New York City uses to license public school teachers are discriminatory, and the city should rely instead on a state-mandated test already in use, a Columbia Law School panel has recommended.

Single tickets are $5, except for screenings of ''Little Dorrit,'' which cost $10. A series ticket is $90. Additional showings may be scheduled for some sold-out films.

LEAD: LEGEND has it that Marco Polo packed his saddle bags with pasta from China in the 13th century and carried it back to Italy, where it became a national dish. Be that true or not - I find it difficult to believe that he didn't polish it off en route - pasta of all sorts has never ceased to be popular in China.

LEAD: Barry McGuigan of Northern Ireland won the world featherweight championship from Eusebio Pedroza on June 8, 1985. He defended it twice, then lost a controversial decision to Stevie Cruz in Las Vegas, Nev., on June 23, 1986. He has not fought since. McGuigan, 27 years old, plans to make his comeback April 20 in London as a superfeatherweight against one of three opponents - Francisco Tomas Cruz of Brazil, Gerome Porras of Puerto Rico, or Tommie Cordova of the United States.

LEAD: Derek Bok, president of Harvard University, refused today to grant tenure to an assistant law professor associated with an ideology challenging the traditional view of the law.

LEAD: Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Bacall met each other in 1944. He was in his mid-40's; she was 19. The star and the starlet had been signed to make ''To Have and Have Not,'' the first of their four movies together. They were married in 1945. He died in 1957.
LEAD: An article from Moscow on Wednesday about a new Soviet income tax misstated the number of employees in Soviet cooperatives.

LEAD: Many reasonable observers think that this year's Big East Conference tournament is anyone's tournament, that any of six teams could wind up in Sunday's championship game. Pitt is the regular-season champion, Syracuse is right on the Panthers' heels, Seton Hall is on a roll, and Georgetown is ever Georgetown.

LEAD: Luck doesn't get any worse than it has for ''Vice Versa,'' the twin of an identically plotted film released only a few months previously. Originality isn't a factor for either this or ''Like Father, Like Son,'' since they both owe a good deal to the earlier ''Freaky Friday,'' but timeliness undoubtedly is.

LEAD: Faced with a steady cooling in America's love affair with Scotch whisky and other so-called brown goods, the Seagram Company Ltd. said yesterday that it would buy Tropicana Products Inc., makers of Tropicana orange juice, for $1.2 billion from the Beatrice Company.
LEAD: Contra leaders, reversing their position, said today that they were willing to negotiate with the Sandinista Government under conditions proposed by President Daniel Ortega Saavedra.
LEAD: Cleaning up the Energy Department's nuclear weapons production plants may cost as much as $100 billion and will pose a major challenge for the Federal Government, a House panel was told today.
LEAD: As missile attacks continued in the Persian Gulf war, Iraq offered today to halt the 11-day-old ''war of the cities'' with Iran Friday as long as Iraq fires the last shot.

LEAD: A seventh-grader was expelled and a classmate was suspended for 30 days for making at least three bombs and taking them to school, reportedly to get revenge on a teacher, officials said today. The Boone County Board of Education took the action against the unidentified boys after hearings on March 1 and 2, school officials said.
LEAD: President Kurt Waldheim publicly apologized today on behalf of his country for Nazi crimes committed by Austrians.

LEAD: Doug Williams, the Washington Redskins quarterback voted the outstanding player in the Super Bowl, will be released Friday from a Birmingham, Ala., hospital following a knee operation. LEAD: Representative Mario Biaggi was accused by a Government prosecutor yesterday of demanding millions of dollars in bribes for helping a South Bronx company win military contracts.
LEAD: For 31 years, Margit Homs has been braiding the hair of other people's children, helping them with their homework, teaching them to tie their shoes.

LEAD: David F. Cavers, retired Fessenden Professor of Law at the Harvard Law School, died of prostate cancer at his home in Cambridge, Mass., on March 4. He was 85 years old. Professor Cavers taught at the law school from 1946 until 1969 and was its first associate dean. He was a specialist in the field of conflicts of law, the process of resolving conflicts between the laws of different jurisdictions.

LEAD: American Brands Inc. of Old Greenwich, Conn., said it had decided to dispose of three additional subsidiaries of its recently acquired E-II Holdings Inc.: the Culligan International Company, the Samsonite Corporation and most of the Samsonite Furniture Company. American Brands said it would retain the Vogel Peterson division of Samsonite Furniture.

LEAD: The New York State Assembly's approval of a campaign finance reform bill leaves State Senate Republicans with no place to hide. For years, they have quietly killed similar bills in the adjournment rush. Not this year.

LEAD: There has been jubilation at Seton Hall over the last few days: the basketball coach signed a new contract on Wednesday, and won the Big East coach-of-the-year award on Thursday. But Seton Hall players knew yesterday that it would take more than momentum and optimism to beat Georgetown in the Big East tournament.
LEAD: St. John's seemed on the verge of righting all the wrongs of its season last night.
LEAD: The Utah Textbook Commission has rejected an Indian request that grade schools remove a book containing stories by Washington Irving and John Smith that depict Indians as blood-thirsty savages.

LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra says he thinks contra leaders will come to the negotiating table this month in ''a position of weakness'' because of the recent Congressional vote cutting off aid to their movement.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration said the Palestine Liberation Organization must shut its observer mission to the United Nations within 10 days or the United States would take action in Federal court to close it. Page 4.

LEAD: The photograph used to illustrate yesterday's editorial on the Blizzard of 1888 was misidentified. It was supplied to The Times 30 years ago by a photo archive as having been taken in the famous blizzard. It turns out to be a poor reproduction of Alfred Stieglitz's ''Winter - Fifth Avenue,'' taken in 1892.

LEAD: It was payday today at the Acsesa automobile repair shop here, but instead of receiving checks or cash, the 90 mechanics and drivers stood in line as a fellow employee doled out payment in food.

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson won nearly 35 percent of the delegates selected at Alaska Democratic Party precinct caucuses, narrowly edging out Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, who took 31 percent, party officials announced today.
LEAD: The judge in the Howard Beach racial-attack case ruled yesterday that the seven remaining defendants will have a single trial with two juries.

LEAD: Paine Webber Inc. was censured today by the Securities and Exchange Commission for defrauding its customers on coupons of the brokerage's ''stripped'' Treasury bonds between January 1984 and July 1985. A source close to the investigation put the amount of the fraud at $200,000.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: * Amerifirst Federal Savings and Loan Association, Miami, said it had received inquiries about a merger.

LEAD: Leos Janacek's operas have been performed less frequently in Paris than in most major Western cities, but when the Paris Opera set about rectifying that omission, it did so in flamboyant style. Instead of producing just one opera, there were two, and they were presented within the context of a two-month
LEAD: Steve Mills, one of the last of the vaudeville comedians who worked with the Shubert organization in the 1930's and 1940's, died Wednesday at his home. He was 92 years old.

LEAD: Staying Dry Spring showers bring out raincoats and umbrellas. But which ones will keep you driest? While raindrops roll off water-repellent fabric in a light rain, the material won't prevent a soaking in a downpour. Water-repellent material is better at keeping raindrops out of the fibers.

LEAD: The board of directors of the San Diego Yacht Club, defender of the America's Cup, said today that it would be willing to negotiate on a New Zealand challenger's compromise offer calling for a 1989 multinational regatta in waters off San Diego. But Michael Fay, who made the proposal, later refused to meet with the defenders.

LEAD: Two or three times in a bridge lifetime a player can expect to pick up a complete two-suiter, with seven cards in one suit and six in another. In this rare situation he usually finds himself fighting his opponents and his partner for the right to be the declarer with one of his suits as trump.

LEAD: Israel's 40th anniversary will be celebrated at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, this weekend with a program of contemporary Israeli music and dance called ''Shalom '88.'' A company of 40 young Israeli performers - including such stars as Boaz Sharabi, Yaffa Yarkoni and Amalia Izhak - will provide a sampler of Israel's many ethnic cultures.

LEAD: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair is expected to reach a decision soon about whether to bring indictments against four prominent subjects of his investigation. Here are descriptions of their roles in the affair: JOHN M. POINDEXTER Vice admiral and national security adviser from December 1985 to November 1986, when he was allowed to resign.

LEAD: Radu Lupu will be the soloist with the New York Philharmonic in the Beethoven Third Piano Concerto at 8 P.M. tonight. The performance, which will be conducted by Klaus Tennstedt, will include Beethoven's Symphony No. 3 (''Eroica''). Tickets are $35 to $7.50. Information: 580-8700.

LEAD: If you think everything that happens on a professional wrestling card has been rehearsed several times, check with Martin Gallagher, 28 years old, of Watertown, N.Y., a 6-foot, 200-pound construction worker. Gallagher went to a wrestling match at Watertown High School Wednesday night and began heckling 212-pound David Sammartino, the son of Bruno Sammartino, a former World Wrestling Federation champion.
LEAD: Jury selection began yesterday in Queens in the murder case of a Jamaica man who, according to court records, drove up to a man in a parked car, got out and shot him in the head three times.

LEAD: No evidence has been found to substantiate suspicions that hazardous chemicals might have been dumped into the Ohio River under the cover of a huge oil spill in January, an environmental official said Thursday.
LEAD: A local anesthetic provides a safe and effective way to reduce the distress of circumcision of infant boys, a new study has shown.
LEAD: Morris Enouch Kaufman, co-founder and chairman of American Mortgage Banking Ltd., died of heart failure March 5 at his home in Floral Park, Queens. He was 50 years old.

LEAD: ''Cross Court,'' the second composition played by the guitarist Jim Hall at Sweet Basil on Tuesday, opened with a stop-time section. Usually, the blank spaces of a stop-time break provoke a soloist, as if competing with Charlie Parker's famous outburst on ''A Night in Tunisia,'' to gush music. Mr.

LEAD: To a certain extent, the Big East tournament is like starting over for Pitt. Three months have been condensed into one long weekend in New York, a game of roulette, really, in which the Panthers are trying to reaffirm that they are the class of the conference. The regular-season championship they won last Sunday in

LEAD: A picture caption in Business Day last Saturday with an article about the Rover Group inaccurately described the Range-Rover, a four-wheel-drive, four-door vehicle intended for highway and off-the-road driving. It is sold worldwide, not just in the United States.

LEAD: Milt Jackson, a vibraphonist, is appearing with a trio led by Monty Alexander on piano tonight and tomorrow at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Sets begin at 9 and 11:30 P.M. with a 1:30 A.M. show tonight; there is a $17.50 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, or a $10 charge at the bar.
LEAD: The new president of Gallaudet University, the nation's only college for the deaf, resigned early today in response to protests by students and faculty because she was not deaf.

LEAD: Pirelli S.p.A., the giant Italian tire maker that made a $1.86 billion takeover bid for the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, asked Firestone officials yesterday to meet with them before taking a position on the week-old offer.
LEAD: Gov. Evan Mecham believed he was ''divinely guided'' in making executive decisions, one of his closest aides testified Friday at the Governor's impeachment trial.
LEAD: Murray Rimmer, administrator of Gracie Square Hospital, died of cardiac arrest Wednesday at New York Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived in Bayside, Queens.

LEAD: Ben Feliciano, a jockey at Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore, was fined $300 yesterday after Zeus Belle, a filly he was riding, was blinded in the right eye on Monday. Feliciano's whip broke the plastic cup of the horse's blinkers, damaging the horse's eye with splinters. Zeus Belle, who finished third, will probably continue racing whether or not she undergoes surgery to save the eye.
LEAD: President Suharto's nominee for Vice President was elected by acclamation today after the reluctant, last-minute withdrawal of the only other contender.

LEAD: Dale Murphy stepped into the batter's box for the Braves as a new pitcher was brought in, and just as Murphy was taking his practice cuts and getting all loose and warm and comfy, he heard the announcement:

LEAD: An article yesterday about Brooklyn co-op owners whose building is threatened with seizure by the Federal Government in the Hyfin Credit Union scandal incompletely identified a mortgage lender. It is the Dime Savings Bank of Williamsburg.

LEAD: When the Burlington Northern Railroad confirmed last month that it had sold parts of this city's popular bicycling and jogging trail to a wealthy real estate developer, some critics said it was as if the Space Needle had gone condo.

LEAD: After the United States Ski Team failed to win a medal and placed no higher than ninth at the Olympic Winter Games in Calgary, it came as no surprise when Harald Schoenhaar, the team's Alpine director, announced yesterday in Vail, Colo., that he had given his resignation to the board of directors.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office cast doubt today as to whether cutting the capital gains tax - one of Vice President Bush's important campaign promises - would raise Government revenues.

LEAD: Pamela Lawrence Dempsey, an assistant district attorney in Manhattan, and Bruce Jay Charendoff, an associate at the Hartford law firm of Shipman & Goodwin, were married yesterday at the Lotos Club in Manhattan. The Rev. Henry Fehren, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Harold Swiss officiated.
LEAD: Dominique Wilkins scored 40 points tonight, including 5 during a 17-10 spurt over the last 5 minutes 30 seconds, as the Atlanta Hawks beat the Knicks, 122-115.
LEAD: To Keep Our Wealth From Flowing Out

LEAD: Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries seem to have abandoned a proposal to reduce production by about 5 percent because of fears that any sacrifices in output would simply turn a larger share of the market over to non-OPEC oil producers.

LEAD: The jazz guitarist Jim Hall is to lead a quartet tonight and tomorrow at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.
LEAD: Pacific Coast
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Reggie Workman, a bassist, will lead a quintet and the Maya Milenovic dancers will perform at 8 P.M. tonight at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street (662-2133). Admission is free.

LEAD: Evidence of cocaine use was found in the body of an airline captain who was among nine people killed in the crash of a commuter airliner near Durango, Colo., on Jan. l9, the National Transportation Safety Board said yesterday.

LEAD: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, has rejected Secretary of State George P. Shultz's approach to an international conference on the Middle East and insisted that the P.L.O. must be fully represented at any such talks.

LEAD: In his bid for the Presidency, Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee has relied on a strategy that emphasizes the conservative side of his record to set himself apart from the rest of the Democratic field and to support his contention that he has the best chance of being elected.
LEAD: Theaters as Landmarks

LEAD: An associate of Irwin Schiff, the enigmatic millionaire businessman who was slain last summer, was a ''cooperating Federal informant'' when he was arrested by the Manhattan District Attorney's office Thursday, the United States Attorney in Brooklyn said yesterday.

LEAD: Half a million New Yorkers routinely ignore summonses for minor offenses each year - from illegal parking to littering -despite aggressive campaigns by city agencies to find them and make it easier to pay fines, city officials say.
LEAD: Every spring, it's the same old thing: one bad game follows another, and Dave Righetti can neither explain his troubles nor find an answer to them.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Two youths were charged yesterday in the slaying of a Hasidic Jew on a street corner in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn last Dec. 25, the police said.

LEAD: Wyoming today became the last state to raise its minimum drinking age to 21. Gov. Mike Sullivan signed into law a bill raising the age from 19 effective July 1. The bill had stalled for years in the state Legislature over what its opponents called Federal blackmail. Wyoming stood to lose $8.2 million in Federal highway funds immediately if the increase were not in place by July and the Government would have continued to withhold funds until the state adopted the increase.
LEAD: Harvard Is Upset: Clarkson upset first-seeded Harvard, 6-4, in a ECAC Hockey tournament semifinal last night after St. Lawrence defeated Vermont, 4-2, at Boston Garden.

LEAD: It's still a bit early to go outdoors and begin planting, although by this time of year the urge is there. It's not too soon, however, to do some shopping. Browsing in gardening catalogues and centers will turn up new products to help with spring cleanup and get plants off to a healthy start, even potted ones on a city windowsill.
LEAD: We Dream of Honour John Berryman's Letters to His Mother By John Berryman Edited by Richard J. Kelly. Illustrated. 405 pages. W. W. Norton & Company. $22.50.

LEAD: In Jim O'Brien's estimation, Boston College did not have many options. The Eagles could have attempted to fly with Syracuse, and the game would have probably been over at halftime. So with apologies, O'Brien chose to have his team hold the basketball yesterday for as long as the rules allowed, hoping to frustrate the
LEAD: Joseph P. C. Mei, a former president of the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Society, died of a heart attack on March 3 at his home in Chinatown. He was 76 years old.
LEAD: In a dozen mud hut camps along both sides of the road between this nondescript market town and the even smaller village of Thal, 40 miles nearer the Afghan border, 150,000 refugees are waiting.

LEAD: The Long Island Lighting Company, as expected, said today that it would take a $1.35 billion write-down related to its investments in three nuclear plants. Lilco also announced that its earnings in 1987 fell by 14.8 percent, to $269.9 million, or $1.72 a share, from $316.7 million, or $2.13 a share, the year before.

LEAD: The judge in the fraud trial of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. today delayed a resumption of testimony pending searches of Government records for any evidence suggesting infiltration of the political extremist's organizations by Federal agents.
LEAD: An article in the Business People column on Monday about Donna Frame Tuttle, the nominee for Deputy Secretary of Commerce, misstated her college graduation year.

LEAD: In a pair of largely reassuring reports on the economy, the Government said today that prices at the producer level declined in February while retail sales continued to show scarcely any adverse effect from last fall's stock market plunge.

LEAD: Bond prices rose yesterday, buoyed by new indications of modest economic growth and continued low inflation. But bond dealers cautioned that most of the day's gains reflected purchases by those who had previously sold Treasury issues short rather than buying by retail investors.

LEAD: ''The Great Race'' is a metaphor for Poland in the 1950's - and possibly in 1988, too. Feliks Falk's screenplay centers on a ''Peace Run'' by model factory workers, high-producing farmers and zealous activists, thoroughly manipulated by Communist Party bureaucrats. The director, Jerzy Domaradzki, does not spare the satire.

LEAD: Andrew Jackson Bennett, an economist who advised the United States military government in Germany after World War II, died of pneumonia on Tuesday at North Carolina Memorial Hospital in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 86 years old and lived in Chapel Hill.

LEAD: A number of leading retailers had an average decline in sales of 1.6 percent in the New York metropolitan area in February, compared with the same month of 1987. The retailers' stores in New York City, however, had an average gain of 2.5 percent.
LEAD: Could this finally be the year for modernizing Depression-era regulation of financial services?

LEAD: A commission on state taxes and spending approved recommendations today to help cut property taxes while easing the burden on lower-income families by raising taxes on those earning more than $50,000 a year.

LEAD: Charles A. Atkins, who was convicted in what the Government has called the largest case of tax-shelter fraud ever brought to court, was sentenced yesterday to two years in jail, followed by four years of community service. Two co-defendants received lesser sentences.

LEAD: Every element of ''A Little Night Music,'' from the waltz tempos of Stephen Sondheim's thrilling score to the graceful pirouettes of Hugh Wheeler's dialogue, is infused with a delicate three-quarter-time pulse.
LEAD: The weekly Beirut magazine Al Shiraa said today that the captors of an American Marine officer have promised to free him but have set no date.

LEAD: An undertaker found two bullet wounds in the body of a 58-year-man thought by authorities to have died a natural death on March 9 in his Greenwich Village apartment. The death of John Hunter of 52 Carmine Street was ruled a homicide yesterday by the New York City Medical Examiner after X-rays confirmed that there were very small bullet wounds to the scalp and groin, said a police spokesman, Sgt.

LEAD: Federated Department Stores said that its board had postponed putting into effect the rights plan attached to Federated's common shares until next Friday or later. The shareholder rights plan, sometimes referred to as a ''poison pill,'' would allow shareholders to buy new Federated shares at a 50 percent discount if another company acquired 30 percent of the company.
LEAD: From time to time when the Romans couldn't decide which of three leaders they wanted to rule they simply fudged the whole problem by putting all three in office.

LEAD: The Speaker of the New York State Assembly said yesterday that he would push legislation to reduce the power of members of the New York City Board of Education by stripping them of their salaries and perquisites.
LEAD: Two days before his departure on a crucial visit to Washington, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today sharply criticized the newest United States proposals for a Mideast peace settlement.

LEAD: Michael Jackson may have lost out on the top laurels at the recent Grammy Awards, but he still was the indisputable star of the show. Glancing over my shoulder during his sensational ''Man in the Mirror'' production number, I caught the members of Ireland's U2 group, which did win several top awards, watching the stage with unabashed respect and admiration.
LEAD: Saying ''we're hanging by our fingernails,'' Bob Dole announced today that he planned a final appeal over Illinois television Saturday night in an effort to salvage his Presidential campaign.
LEAD: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.
LEAD: When city officials, acting on a tip, found that illegal immigrants were crowding into houses in a poor neighborhood here, they began a campaign to crack down on building-code violations.

LEAD: Urging his countrymen to learn from their past for the sake of their future, Chancellor Franz Vranitzky led Austrians through a day of somber ceremonies and events marking the 50th anniversary of Austria's willing absorption by Nazi Germany.

LEAD: New York doesn't have an exclusive on first-rate young jazz musicians. To record an album next week for Nonesuch Records, Geri Allen, a keyboardist, has imported a singer and a half-dozen instrumentalists from Detroit, and she's warming them up - and introducing them to New York listeners - with a four-night stand through tonight at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street at Mulberry

LEAD: Every day before she sets off to work, Roberta Berk, a 48-year-old commodities broker, takes one aspirin, 500 milligrams of vitamin C, 1,000 milligrams of calcium, an antihistamine tablet and powdered fiber in water.

LEAD: Music demands muscle - one fact it's impossible to forget during a concert by Kodo, the 10-man, two-woman Japanese percussion-and-dance group that's appearing through Sunday at City Center, 131 West 55th Street. Traditional rituals recast as theater and contemporary thoughts about ancient instruments both figure in Kodo's performance, which includes ancient and modern compositions.
LEAD: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about the Guide Michelin gave an incorrect address for the Traveller's Bookstore. It is at 22 West 52d Street in Manhattan.

LEAD: The New York City Board of Estimate, in a major victory for preservationists and the Koch administration, unanimously approved landmark status early yesterday for 28 Broadway theaters that have been home to some of the greatest moments in American stage history.

LEAD: A study of Enimase, a drug made by Beecham Group P.L.C. of Britain to treat heart disease has shown positive results, the medical journal Lancet reported yesterday. But analysts said that sales of tissue plasminogen activator, or TPA, the genetically engineered drug made by Genentech Inc. for the treatment of heart attacks, are unlikely to be affected before 1990.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration said today that the Palestine Liberation Organization must shut its observer mission to the United Nations within 10 days or the United States would take action in Federal court to close it.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A severe shortage of computer memory chips is hurting the sales of computers and placing new strains on the semiconductor trade agreement between the United States and Japan, an agreement that some executives blame for the shortage.

LEAD: President Reagan, who has persistently threatened to veto a comprehensive trade bill that is approaching final passage in Congress, said today that the lawmakers had thrown ''overboard many objectionable provisions.''

LEAD: New York City is a clump of islands joined to mainland America only at the Bronx. The 76 bridges that lace it together, and the 2,000-plus that span rail lines and roadways, are lifelines. Yet New Yorkers take these vital links for granted. Almost all the bridges are victims of deferred maintenance.

LEAD: One hundred years ago this weekend, New York City's most dramatic snowstorm, the Blizzard of '88, burst upon a New York that had been basking in a warming sun that seemed to be a curtain raiser for the spring that would be official 10 days later. The blizzard began as rain that turned into snow late Sunday, March 11.

LEAD: Robert C. McFarlane, President Reagan's former national security adviser, pleaded guilty today to four misdemeanor counts of withholding information from Congress and agreed to serve as a prosecution witness in the criminal investigation of the Iran-contra affair.

LEAD: The Massachusetts Supreme Court, in a decision Thursday, upheld the convictions of four men who raped a woman on a barroom table in New Bedford in 1983, rejecting defense arguments about the fairness of the 1984 trial in Bristol Superior Court.

LEAD: The weak dollar that has caused the price of luxury European cars to soar and their sales to plunge in the United States would seem to create a golden opportunity for domestic car makers. But for reasons ranging from lack of production capacity to unpopular models, they seem unable to expand their share of the potentially lucrative market for cars that go for $20,000 and up.

LEAD: As Bobby Short pounded out ''Happy Birthday'' on the small platform stage of the Village Vanguard early Thursday evening, some 200 guests joined voices to celebrate the 85th birthday, two days early, of the veteran jazz impresario Max Gordon.

LEAD: The General Services Administration said yesterday that it would extend the deadline for submitting bids for contracts to build the Government's new telecommunications system to allow the U S Sprint Communications Corporation more time to prepare its bid.
LEAD: An article yesterday about recommendations of a New York State education task force misidentified a co-chairman. He is Dr. Edward J. Mortola, current Chancellor of Pace University.
LEAD: It was the mildest winter in 17 years. New Yorkers had faith in the March 11, 1888, forecast that ''slightly warmer weather would be followed by rain.''

LEAD: Mike Tyson, the world heavyweight champion, and Tony Tubbs, the man who will challenge for his title later this month, passed their physical examinations yesterday and were declared fit for the bout March 21 at the Tokyo Dome. They took their exams at the Jikei Medical College Hospital, where the champion's neck was measured at 20.1 inches against 17.3 inches for Tubbs.
LEAD: Questions appear on page 18.

LEAD: At the age of 55, Jean-Pierre Voidies had a sex-change operation. He had been a political activist, poet, novelist, husband of the bird-like Huguette Voidies and the father of one son, Jean-Noel. By his own account, Mr. Voidies was a member of the Underground during the Nazi occupation of France and was tortured by the

LEAD: On May 11, Pocket Books will publish ''The Quilt: Stories from the Names Project,'' with a foreword by Elizabeth Taylor, national chairman of the American Foundation for AIDS Research. The Names Project Quilt - the national AIDS memorial, which weighs about 3 1/2 tons and is the size of two football fields - contains more than 3,000 individual panels, each depicting the name of someone who has died of acquired immune deficiency syndrome.
LEAD: A thought for spring skiers and other travelers: Let someone else haul your gear.

LEAD: The New York City Board of Estimate yesterday rejected plans to convert two vacant commercial buildings into homeless shelters, a major setback to a Koch administration plan to provide housing for the homeless.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Economy
LEAD: Suzanne Lee Bricker and William Joseph Sullivan were married yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York by the Rev. William D. Roberts.
LEAD: The United Automobile Workers has agreed to early contract talks with Chrysler Corporation, the union's president, Owen F. Bieber, says.

LEAD: A couple of fellows from the Royal Shakespeare Company have been in town for a fortnight trying to show students from 45 schools that the Bard was user friendly, not impenetrable. All this week the two gentlemen of London have focused on Verona, the setting of ''The Tragedy of Romeo and Juliet,'' and ninth graders who cast a less than enthusiastic eye on the work at the outset have come away thinking it didn't hurt so much after all.
LEAD: Texaco's creditors sought to induce management to settle the company's dispute with the Pennzoil Company by offering top executives protection from lawsuits by shareholders.

LEAD: Petra Tolle Shattuck, a lawyer who specialized in the legal status of American Indians and who taught civil liberties and American constitutional law at the City University of New York, died Wednesday after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage a week ago. She was 46 years old.

LEAD: A headline in Weekend yesterday in the Sounds Around Town column misstated the location for performances by John Wallowitch and Bertram Ross. They are at Danny's Skylight Room, 346 West 46th Street.
LEAD: Dwight Gooden buzzed four vintage innings against the Atlanta Braves today in his second start of the spring, and said later that part of the credit should go to Sandy Koufax.
LEAD: BASEBALL
LEAD: Pham Hung, the Prime Minister of Vietnam, died of a heart attack Thursday. He was 75 years old.
LEAD: Futures and options tables reflect trading only up to 1 P.M. because of a power failure. Settlement prices unavailable.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission has broadened its investigation of suspected insider trading in the securities of Sterling Drug Inc., issuing nearly two dozen subpoenas to arbitragers who bought the securities while the merger was being planned or negotiated, a number of Wall Street professionals said yesterday.
LEAD: The dog that frisked its way through so many years of your life is not eager to play anymore. And the cat seems to spend more time than ever sleeping.

LEAD: Merrill K. Riddick, who campaigned for President three times as the candidate of the Puritan Ethic and Epic, Magnetohydrodynamics and Prohibition Party, died here Wednesday of cancer. He was 93 years old.

LEAD: The American Film Institute gave its 16th annual Life Achievement Award to Jack Lemmon at a fund-raising dinner Thursday night. Mr. Lemmon was praised for his decency, dedication and how good he looks in women's clothes.
LEAD: The Alfama district is Lisbon's slum by the sea, along the banks of the Tagus River where it widens to enter the Atlantic.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: After 12 days and hundreds of casualties, Iran and Iraq stopped missile attacks on each other's cities this afternoon. But each side threatened to resume the strikes if the other broke the unofficial truce.

LEAD: Modern dance would appear to be alive but not too well in Japan, to judge by a program presented on Tuesday evening at the Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium of the Asia Society. The three dances on the program, produced by the Contemporary Dance Association of Japan and presented by Asia Society, did suggest that there is some very good dance training to be had in Japan and that the Butoh style is not the only kind of modern dance in Japan these days.

LEAD: Prime Minister Giovanni Goria resigned tonight after his Government split apart over a decision to resume the construction of a nuclear power plant. It was the third time that Mr. Goria had quit since taking office almost eight months ago, but this time his departure seemed final.

LEAD: Toni Allen Bodini and Jean Goutal, partners in the Tapis Rouge restaurant in New York, were married Wednesday at the Manhattan home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Hamilton Kramer, by the Rev. David Cockcroft, a Presbyterian minister.
LEAD: The anger and defiance that marked Gary Hart's first withdrawal from the 1988 Presidential race last May were gone today as he withdrew a second time.

LEAD: Manager Gene Mauch of the California Angels has left the team's spring training camp in Mesa, Ariz., for unspecified health reasons, the team announced yesterday. He is scheduled to undergo an examination Monday in Palm Springs, Calif. The Angels hold the latter part of their spring training in Palm Springs, and Mauch owns a home in nearby Rancho Mirage.

LEAD: Commissioner David Stern of the National Basketball Association fined the Nets $25,000 yesterday for failing to tell the league about an incident in a hotel room in training camp last fall involving the Nets' forward, Orlando Woolridge, who is now in drug rehabilitation.
LEAD: ''We're hanging by our fingernails.'' - Senator Bob Dole. [ 1:3. ]

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today left the next major campaign battleground, Illinois, where the primary will be held Tuesday, for a day of stumping across South Carolina to nail down what seems to be a solid lead here for the state's Democratic caucuses Saturday.

LEAD: Barbara Ellen Reichart, a certified financial planner who is a sales assistant with Alex. Brown & Sons in Washington, and Robert Ingram Nooter, an assistant director of national affairs for the American Farm Bureau Federation in Washington, were married yesterday. The Rev. Harley Bender performed the ceremony at St.

LEAD: The engagement of Pamela Renee Akers to Kevin Andrew Sjodin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton F. Sjodin of Fairfield, Conn., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John F. Akers of Westport, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass., parents of the bride-to-be. An October wedding is planned.
LEAD: The South African Government today banned a new church-led anti-apartheid movement headed by Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu.

LEAD: In her Jan. 17 letter to the editor, in response to Lisa Belkin's article ''The Makeover at Estee Lauder,'' (Nov. 29), Phyllis Kraemer really did miss the point. Age is not the question. Vitality is. At Estee Lauder, we are trying to inject a bit more energy and vitality into our approach. We have never targeted our marketing to a specific age group - at either end of the spectrum - nor do we plan to at this time.

LEAD: HOW to divide jurisdiction over children's education between the home and the school is in dispute in Southampton, where parents say they are being stifled by school officials and teachers say they are being assailed by overzealous parents.

LEAD: WE had to board Paradise before 6 P.M., but we just could not find it. Paradise is the name of the new tourist boat that runs overnight between Suzhou and Hangzhou along the Grand Canal. Paradise is also the name that Chinese give to the twin cities of Suzhou and Hangzhou, linked in an ancient Chinese saying that Marco Polo elaborated on when he told the West of the fabulous cities of the East: ''In heaven, paradise; on earth, Suzhou and Hangzhou.

Since ''The Case of Herman the Stoker'' makes some effort to penetrate the mind of its subject, a lot of it is about firewood. Leszek Wosiewicz's short film includes the information that birch logs are good for keeping bad thoughts away and for making a person ready to work. Maple, on the other hand, produces a more dynamic state of mind. A man named Herman, who presumably contributed these observations (which are presented by two unseen narrators), learned to make fires when he worked at a mental institution. Later, once the patients were liquidated, it became a school for German officers during the days of the Third Reich. Herman was so sensitive to the nuances of firewood, and so adroit at making fires to suit particular personalities, that he came to hold a privileged position within the ranks of the regime; he eventually rose to the honor of building fires for the Fuhrer himself. Hitler was a maple man.

But most economists say the curve is not an accurate guide.

LEAD: IT'S a rare day when problems arising from South Africa's policy of apartheid fail to make news. But even the most detailed report cannot examine the emotional, soul-searing effects of apartheid on the people living the headlines. Communicating the secrets of the human heart is the job of literature and the arts, and the South African playwright Athol Fugard's drama ''The Blood Knot'' is a case in point.

LEAD: Brussels seems to affect different people in different ways. Emily Bronte and Baudelaire hated it, Victor Hugo and Cocteau adored it, Lord Byron was impressed by the parks. Marx and Engels read the tentative chapters of the ''Communist Manifesto'' to Brussels workingmen, Verlaine shot Rimbaud after a lovers' spat in the narrow street that runs by the Hotel Amigo, Emily's sister Charlotte wrote her last novel, ''Villette,'' with Brussels as the setting.
