In some ways, it was characteristic of evangelicalism that the health of the church should take priority over matters of state.
LEAD: ON a recent Saturday, dozens of children crowded inside a barn at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center to watch five day-old lambs nestle by their mother's side.
LEAD: Men and women do not fall in love with each other in the movies anymore. They fall in love with babies. Babies are the new lovers - unpredictable, uncontrollable, impossible and irresistible.

LEAD: Neighborhood opposition is forcing the only center in Queens for people with AIDS to move its counseling services, and the uproar has led to a discrimination complaint against two neighborhood groups and an assemblyman.

LEAD: The marriage of Stacy Beth Weiss, the senior manager of the education department at Sotheby's in New York, to Ronald Scheinberg, an associate at the New York law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, took place last night at the Harvard Club in New York. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein performed the ceremony.

LEAD: APRIL in Colorado is indeed the cruelest month, dumping snow on lilacs at altitudes as low as 5,000 feet, sometimes burying the entire bush higher up. This seeming endlessness of high-country winter is hard on would-be gardeners and tennis players, but not so hard on skiers, who may still enjoy the lingering snow, as well as April's longer days and higher temperatures.

LEAD: THE students, secretaries and computer programmers who live at the White Plains Young Women's Christian Association on North Broadway are as diverse as any group of women -perhaps a bit more so.

LEAD: Since its revival under Lee A. Iacocca, the Chrysler Corporation has been closely identified with incentive programs. Despite the problems others cite with this approach, Chrysler has continued to use it. Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman, talked with Bud Liebler, director of marketing services of the Chrysler Motors Corporation.

LEAD: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 1 FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.95.) The vicissitudes of a son of the 60's on his way to the 80's. 2 6 DESTINY, by Sally Beauman. (Bantam, $4.95.) The 30-year romance of a couple with diverse backgrounds and ambitions.

LEAD: WHEN friends came home from Greece, they had made no plans for getting out of Kennedy International Airport and traveling home to the suburbs in Bergen County, N.J. They piled into a metered medallion cab and across New York City they went, over two bridges and home to the tune of $100, including the tip.

LEAD: South Africa's ban on news coverage of violent repression, especially by television, has worked in a sense. There is no longer a steaming head of outrage in the U.S. and Western Europe, or demands for greater outside pressure on the regime.

LEAD: The San Diego Yacht Club yesterday rejected a proposal by Michael Fay, chairman of New Zealand's America's Cup challenge, to postpone the yachting series until next year so that other challengers could join in a sailoff.

LEAD: THE World Wrestling Federation, saying it was ''shocked and appalled,'' has suspended David Sammartino for an incident with a ringside fan following a match in Watertown, N.Y., last week. The federation said that Sammartino, son of Bruno Sammartino, assaulted Martin Gallagher, a 200-pound construction worker who heckled him after David lost his match at Watertown High School Wednesday.

LEAD: ONE way to deal with a fear of flying is to shrug it off, perhaps by wearing a Survive! T-shirt. This new line comes from United Stars of America, a division of J. G. Hook. The shirts, in eye-popping black, orange and white, are emblazoned with bold graphics inspired by the emergency-procedure diagrams in airplane seat pockets.

LEAD: I laughed all the way through Fred Halliday's essay ''Oh My Cracking Pistons!'' (Feb. 14). I had kept an MG on the road for almost 10 years - with similar experiences. I, too, learned to keep a ''winter rat'' sitting in the driveway, just in case!

LEAD: To trave, as we did, from Venice direct to Florence is to experience the Time Machine at its most devastating. Venice, still recognizably the city of Canaletto and Guardi, is the world's largest pedestrian precinct; Florence is a gigantic toyshop with malignant, destructive boys in little vehicles tearing up and down the aisles, bent on raising havoc.

LEAD: Tibetan women burning a Chinese flag yesterday in New Delhi, as they vowed to return to their homeland. Some 150 refugees took part in the demonstration, the latest to commemorate the 29th anniversary of an unsuccessful uprising against Chinese rule in the Tibetan capital, Lhasa. (AP)

LEAD: GARRY WINOGRAND NEVER CARED for moderation. For him, to be a photographer was to see pictures everywhere, in everything. It was normal for him to shoot several rolls of film before lunch, or during lunch, every day. And he wasn't just behind in developing and editing his work, as all photographers are.

LEAD: At the Answer Shops/House of Spiritual Knowledge, a tiny cluttered store wedged between a barber shop and a check-cashing stand on Girard Avenue, people come to buy candy, tea and cigarettes. The answers are free.
LEAD: Perhaps the most trite expression in baseball is ''you can never have enough pitching.'' In the Boston Red Sox camp, they have a variation on that theme: you can never have enough outfielders.
LEAD: EAST OF THE MOUNTAINS OF THE MOON Chimpanzee Society in the African Rain Forest. By Michael P. Ghiglieri. Maps and tables. 315 pp. New York: The Free Press. $22.50.
LEAD: DESPITE mailing lists in the thousands and heavy advertising and promotion, most of New York's concert halls frequently are less than full.

LEAD: On the second stage of the venerated Maly Theater here, James, Mary, Edmund and Jamie Tyrone are trying to untangle their hatreds and groping to save one another in Eugene O'Neill's ''Long Day's Journey Into Night.''

LEAD: The Pentagon set up several highly secret units in the early 1980's that carried out operations that in some cases were not disclosed to Congress or to appropriate senior officials in the military and intelligence agencies, according to a forthcoming book.

LEAD: AT a recent business lunch, one of the men spoke of his son coming home from college with a girlfriend. He thought he was prepared for that, but found he wasn't. Whereupon one of the women at lunch quipped, ''Just be glad he didn't come home with a boy.''

LEAD: In Phillip Longman's article, Edwin Feulner, president of the Heritage Foundation, says that he observed the late Secretary of Commerce Malcolm Baldrige's enthusiasm for David Stockman's budget-cutting proposals in 1981. But, ''within two years, he [ Baldrige ] was fighting for every 35 cents and trying to get more,'' having become Commerce's spokesman ''instead of the President's representative to Commerce.

LEAD: With tensions here running high, the Administrator of the Panama Canal met last week with American residents of the former Canal Zone to discuss emergency evacuation plans. But the meeting had to be adjourned after the headquarters of the Canal Commission received a bomb threat.

LEAD: An American human rights organization said today that torture, extrajudicial killings and other human rights abuses have increased alarmingly in Ecuador over the last three years.

LEAD: Commissioner Pete Rozelle, more than 200 National Football League executives, and virtually all the league's coaches will have little time to explore the grounds of their hotel, designed by Frank Lloyd Wright, when the league's annual meeting starts today in Phoenix.

LEAD: Funny, isn't it, that only dumb people who get smart are news. People who were smart all along are not news.
LEAD: KEA'S ARK, the controversial hand-built vessel that stood in the parking lot of a Baptist church here and was envisioned as a land-based ark and urban museum, is slowly being dismantled.

LEAD: OPEC apparently dropped plans to cut oil production. Officials said the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had studied a plan to reduce oil output by 5 percent in hopes of raising sagging prices. But it reportedly abandoned the proposal because of fears that any cuts in output would be made up by non-OPEC producers.
LEAD: Crossroads of Spring: grand boulevards and rustic byways.

LEAD: The first academy award for costume design was given, in 1948, to Dorothy Jeakins for ''Joan of Arc.'' If years are locomotives, then 1948 is 40 stations down a twisted track, a world that only exists in memory and old snapshots. But there are survivors. ''Joan of Arc'' was her first screen credit as a costume designer.
LEAD: THE state's Department of Education is beginning a broad-based inquiry into the feasibility of allowing New Jersey parents to choose the public schools their children attend.
LEAD: The river forms a green gauze belt, the mountains are like jade hairpins. - Han Yu, a Tang dynasty poet
LEAD: STATISTICS compiled by Manhattan apartment brokers are beginning to reflect the fear and hesitation that all but the most affluent buyers felt after the stock market crash last October.

LEAD: I am not often in exactly the right place at the right time, unless you consider it lucky to be near Cape Hatteras during a hurricane or on the subway when there's a derailment. LEAD: To the Editor: Anyone who has ever been bumped from an overbooked flight knows only too well how infuriating that experience can be. But air travelers should know that being bumped can also be something like winning a lottery.

LEAD: A demonstrator being removed from the site of a rally sponsored by the Coalition for a Nuclear-Free Harbor yesterday on Staten Island. About 250 demonstrators protested construction of a naval base at Stapleton. Fifteen people were arrested and charged with criminal tresspassing. (The New York Times/John
LEAD: IT was called a corpse that would not die, the immigration legislation that finally became law in 1986 after a year-to-year Congressional marathon.

LEAD: IN MONTE CARLO, THERE'S THE OLD, THE NEW and the newly old. The newly old buildings are the newest, as seen in the still-unfinished Metropole Hotel, which is being rebuilt in the style of the Belle Epoque, with pillars, marble floors and ''riotous over-decoration,'' as one Monacan lovingly described it.

LEAD: AT ski areas throughout the West, the arrival of spring brings sun, shorter lift lines, a boisterous mood in the apres-ski lounge and, in most cases, discounted hotel and lift rates. Spring skiing can stretch into the summer at a few resorts, with slopes staying open into June. At others, mid-April signals the end of the season.

LEAD: Stacy King converted a 3-point play in the closing seconds and finished with 35 points today as Oklahoma turned back a furious Missouri rally for a 102-99 victory in a semifinal game of the Big Eight tournament. The Sooners (29-3) moved into the final on Sunday against Kansas State.

LEAD: FOR a quarter of a century, the International Bridge Press Association has given awards annually to the best-played hand and the best-bid hand. There was not, however, a comparable award for the best-defended hand. Last year this gap was remedied, and there is now a Precision Award for the best defense of the year.

LEAD: For six weeks, lawyers in Federal District Court here have been presenting jurors with internal tobacco industry documents in an effort to show how some cigarette companies tried to mislead the public about the health risks of smoking.

LEAD: IN China, a place where taxes were once paid in bolts of silk and decorative needlework ranked among the most highly esteemed art forms, the ancient crafts of sericulture and embroidery are as firmly entrenched in national tradition as the daily bowl of rice.

LEAD: THE death of a pet can be tantamount to the death of a family member, but owners are often surprised when they ''overreact'' to the pet's death, according to Patricia Gallagher of Stamford, a counselor.

LEAD: Last weekend, when Prince Charles gave the concluding address at an international conference of architects in Pittsburgh, he confirmed to an American audience what the British have known for some time now - that he does not think much of modern architecture and planning, and is prepared to be outspoken, even blunt, about it.
LEAD: The Army, which has a decidely mixed record in the first battle of a war, has started training generals to win that vital fight if the United States goes to war again.
LEAD: IN recent months, Fairfield County has been blessed with the opening of several fine restaurants. Now add L'Hotellerie des Bois (Little Hotel in the Woods) in West Redding to the growing list.

LEAD: Louise de Clercq Rambo, a personal fashion adviser at Lord & Taylor in New York, plans to be married April 30 to Anthony Lane Adams, a managing director of the QSR Capital Corporation, an investment counseling concern in New York.

LEAD: It's comforting to know that I'm not the only one giving up the thrill of a Porsche. I plunked down $25,000 three years ago, roared away from the dealership and promptly skidded 180 degrees into a snowbank. ''You need a set of four all-weather tires with rims,'' said the dealer. ''They will run about $2,500.
LEAD: REVOLUTIONARY MEXICO The Coming and Process of the Mexican Revolution. By John Mason Hart. Illustrated. 478 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $35.

LEAD: SUMMER may be fine for visiting drafty British country houses and walking the length and breadth of their gardens. But during the perennial spring drizzle, one seeks the cozier atmosphere of drawing rooms in town. Also, in only visiting stately aristocratic homes, one neglects the equally rich heritage of the frequently more stylish rooms of merchants' houses.
LEAD: HIGH UP IN THE SCENERY of language, in his lair among old mental sets, lurks the Phantom of the Phrases, ready to hurl down a chandelier on some speaker who dares cross his purposes.
LEAD: More cases of influenza, coming later in the flu season, have recently been reported around the country, but Federal and state health officials say there is no cause for national alarm.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Herbert A. Blough of Lafayette Hill, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter Linda Jill Blough to David Kenneth Shuffman, the son of Rose Shuffman of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Oscar Shuffman. The couple plan to marry April 17.

LEAD: At nearly 10 P.M., the bell finally rang and 10 neatly dressed homeless men stepped off a city bus and in the side door of the B'nai Jeshurun Synagogue on West 89th Street for a home-style meal and a bed for the night.

LEAD: The protests at Gallaudet University, the nation's only liberal arts college for the deaf, represent the blossoming of a new civil rights movement, deliberately patterned on the black civil rights actions of the 1960's, according to deaf people and advocates for the handicapped.
LEAD: SAM SHIKAZE, private eye, is expected to stop off in Purchase next Sunday. And the search for the missing Cherry Blossom Queen will be on.
LEAD: GOV. MICHAEL N. CASTLE of Delaware is trying to bring stronger state control to real estate development with a package of land-use and related highway legislation.

LEAD: GOVERNOR Cuomo had a vision in January 1986: ''a revolutionary fiber-optic telecommunications cable'' along the entire 559-mile Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway. Such a cable carries messages on beams of laser light at tremendous speed, and the Governor said it would ''dramatically improve the state's communications'' and ''attract high-tech industry and jobs to New York.
LEAD: That was quite a Valentine's Day message you sent to women in your ''created scenario'' of a ''modern'' wedding (''The Wedding,'' Feb. 14).

LEAD: Shimmering Swedish silver masterpieces -powerful forms embellished sparingly with boldly crafted flourishes - fill two galleries at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, at Fifth Avenue and 91st Street. The 81 tankards, tureens, platters and coffee pots selected for ''The Triumph of Simplicity: 350 Years of Swedish Silver'' are from the collections of the Nationalmuseum in Stockholm and the Swedish royal family.

LEAD: In 1831, a lawyer and real estate developer named Samuel Ruggles created the neighborhood of Gramercy Park. Ruggles was a major figure in Manhattan's cultural and physical development in the 19th century and when he mapped out the graceful Manhattan square and its surrounding streets, he hoped to create a bastion of civility and serenity that would calm the spirit after a day in the harsher world ''outside.

LEAD: CONVERTING an old barn into a home has been a fond fantasy, and for some people a realized dream, for decades. In Connecticut, where so many farms have been plowed under to make way for housing developments and shopping centers, barns are scarce, and, of course, they aren't being built any more. Or are they?

LEAD: LAST call to complete and mail nursery/seed catalogue orders; some sources have run out of stock of first choices and substitutions are being made, when requested. Continue transplanting indoor seedlings of vegetables and annuals to individual pots. Check house plants for mealybugs, aphids and white flies; control, if found.

LEAD: When he talks about hitting, he is talking about the thing that matters most to him on a professional level. He speaks almost nonstop about the subject, pausing only momentarily to take a breath, and then continuing.
LEAD: The only work in Dennis Adams's show at the Nature Morte Gallery (through March 27) is a wall piece called ''Falling Water.''

LEAD: ARMY Brigadier General Myrna Hennrich Williamson is the services' senior female officer, outside the nurse corps whose officers traditionally are women. Commissioned in 1960, General Williamson has served as a company commander, commander of a military police training battalion, brigade commander and commanding general of the Third Reserve Officer Training Corps Region, with headquarters at Fort Riley, Kan.

LEAD: Representative Thomas J. Manton, the Queens Democratic chairman, has joined the list of Democratic county leaders at odds with Mayor Koch - a political development that is unusual but less significant than it would have been when political ''bosses'' were really bosses.
LEAD: Conventional wisdom has it that Portugal's Renaissance seafarers had a gift for staking out handsome vantage points; witness the splendid bays they picked for Rio de Janeiro and Salvador.

LEAD: The engagement of Shawn Avery Lester to Stephen Carl Swett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Swett of Summit, N.J., has been announced by Miss Lester's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jonathan A. Lester of Avon, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: The Streetscapes article on Feb. 21 incorrectly stated that the building at 503 Fifth Avenue had been emptied of tenants and not since relet. There are three ground-floor tenants - Picadilly and Showplace I, both clothing stores, and Showcase Sports, selling athletic clothes and shoes.

LEAD: IN THE ETHNIC COMMUNITIES that spawned them, artists who manage to cross over into the mainstream from Harlem or Watts or Chinatown east or west call the journey ''riding on the hyphen.'' Pop musicians like Mexican-American Ricardo Valenzuela, who as Ritchie Valens topped the charts in the 1950's with ''La Bamba,'' were among the first.

LEAD: The pews are crowded these days in the Arab mosques and churches of Little Palestine here, and prominent local Palestinian-Americans have been meeting to talk about the rioting now entering its fourth month in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

LEAD: Never in memory has the classical-record marketplace been as confusing as it is right now, thanks to the compact disk and the increasing competition engendered by an explosion in the number of plants capable of manufacturing them.

LEAD: A senior State Department official will meet South Africa's Foreign Minister next week at an undisclosed site in Europe to press an American initiative for peace in southern Africa, the State Department said today.

The Rev. Sharami Kerr performed the interfaith ceremony in the chapel of the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New

LEAD: By nature hockey tends to be a bit more hot-headed than, let us say, chess. But harsher penalties and an injection of guts into N.H.L. leadership might help restore the attraction of the game to those of us whose taste is slightly above that of female mud wrestling.

LEAD: Mr and Mrs. William Henry Peters of Bay Head. N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Margaret Mary Peters to Scott Allen Nedrow, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Nedrow of Donora, Pa. The wedding is to be in July.

LEAD: A Pennysaver by another name would attract more readers. So reasoned Stephen A. Traube, the 45-year-old president of The New Pennysaver Group Inc. in Elmsford, when he changed the name of 13 of his community Pennysavers to Westchester Life and began adding local news and syndicated editorial features to the weekly giveaway.

LEAD: THERE is no other way to get blackened redfish as fresh as the ones making their way on a waiter's tray across the wide, screened veranda of the Rod and Gun Club this evening. The table of four awaiting the treat, men and women in slacks and shorts, sipping cocktails under the paddle fans and watching the sun set over the mangroves of the Barron River, caught the redfish earlier in the day.

LEAD: Rony Seikaly was in another world, Derrick Coleman was in a funk and Seton Hall was on the verge of chasing Syracuse out of Madison Square Garden and the Big East Conference Tournament.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Alfin of Sands Point, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Lisa Alfin, to Michael Thomas Finley Johnson, a son of Mrs. John H. Hapeman of New Boston, N.H., and Gardiner Porter Johnson of Dallas.

LEAD: THE 4,000 residents of this tiny Arab village in the West Bank mountains say they have held some 20 demonstrations since the Palestinian uprisings began last Dec. 9. The village's Israeli-appointed leaders have all resigned and its youth have broken apart one of the ancient stone terraces on the hillside sloping down from Mazraa Sharqiya in order to build a series of roadblocks at the entrance to the town.

LEAD: Workers of the Safeway Environmental Corporation removing asbestos-based insulation yesterday from pipes in a partly demolished building on Duane Street between Broadway and Church Street. The operation was carried out under the supervision of the Environmental Protection Agency after the agency found a violation of rules for removing asbestos on Friday.

LEAD: THEY make motors here at the General Electric Company's aging plants on Taylor Street and on Broadway, and they want to keep making them. They like to say that they are the best motor makers in the world.

LEAD: AFTER years of unquestioned dominance in the PC arena, Lotus 1-2-3 is suddenly facing serious challenges from a host of new spreadsheets. The upstarts are faster, prettier and better suited for today's more powerful computers. To counter, Lotus is putting the finishing touches on a couple of new versions of 1-2-3, its first major overhaul in a long time.

LEAD: A batch of documents reported to have been captured from Marxist guerrillas here indicate that the rebels are planning a major political and military offensive over the next 10 months, according to Salvadoran officials and several foreign diplomats.

LEAD: Thirty United States senators wrote to Secretary of State Shultz to support his Middle East peace plan and to criticize Prime Minister Shamir for rejecting the heart of the plan - land for peace. The Israeli leader replies that he is ''astonished'' by the letter and that the only valid part of the Shultz plan is the Secretary's signature.

LEAD: A review of self-help products last Sunday in Your Taxes, section 13, incorrectly listed the computers on which ''J. K. Lasser's Your Income Tax'' will operate. The software is available for personal computers made by the International Business Machines Corporation and compatible models.

LEAD: Travel serendipity? Because I grew up among life scientists, my most vivid images of the unexpected tend to be biological. But which to choose? Should it be the toucans glimpsed while up to my knees in mud beside Lake Catamaco in Mexico? The fire ants I sat down on by mistake in the Galapagos? Or the popular hole in a wooden wall in the rudimentary zoo of Kabul, Afghanistan, on the other side of which was a single elephant eye, looking back out?

LEAD: THE votes of 13 million Americans last week increased the chances that a nonprotectionist trade bill will be be signed into law this year after months of acrimonious deadlock.

LEAD: American intelligence agencies are watching anxiously to see whether China's recent pledges to end deliveries of Silkworm anti-ship missiles to Iran will be expanded to include a cutoff of anticipated sales of several other types of weapons.

LEAD: Hardly anyone in this coastal town regretted the departure of Dr. Timothy A. Patrick - not his relatives and friends, not his former patients, certainly not his former colleagues.

LEAD: LUCK OF THE IRISH The Irish are not being ignored this St. Patrick's Day, as special programming essentially turns the celebration into St. Patrick's Week. Things get under way today with a touch of the offbeat, a Culinary Tour of the Emerald Isle during the weekly brunch at the New York Institute of Technology's Culinary Arts Center.

LEAD: Dave Anderson's open letter to John Ziegler, president of the National Hockey League (''Hockey the Way It Oughta Be,'' The New York Times, Feb. 26), focuses on a need of long standing: attention to the utter lack of management and guts in the N.H.L. to keep a premier sport from losing its tradition, its skills and its wonder to those who watch.

LEAD: FANS of the radio show ''A Prairie Home Companion'' learned that travelers in Minnesota could blend with the natives by using a few key Midwesternisms: phrases like ''Cold enough for you?'' and ''You bet.''In Sheboygan, Wis., one phrase will suffice: ''Double brat with with the works, please.''
LEAD: An official who has presided over nearly 300 Police Department disciplinary cases has taken office as head of the department's Civilian Complaint Review Board.

LEAD: An article on Feb. 7 about corporate efforts to register voters gave an incorrect location for the headquarters of the Nationwide Insurance Company. It is in Columbus, Ohio.

LEAD: I wouldn't have believed it if I hadn't tried it myself, but Kodak's new Ektachrome 100 Plus Professional slide film has a quality few films of its type can match: truly neutral shadow tones.

LEAD: SINCE the whodunits of Agatha Christie are a proven box office draw in small theaters, it follows that a fledgling company would dig up a musicalized mystery spoof that acknowledges its inspiration in a big second-act number with the lyric: ''I owe it all to Agatha Christie.''

LEAD: Oscar Arias Sanchez, President of Costa Rica and winner of the 1987 Nobel Peace Prize for the regional peace plan that bears his name, has written a letter to Mikhail S. Gorbachev asking him to end the supply of Soviet arms to Central America.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Morton M. Davis of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah V. Davis to Thomas Eliot Ascheim, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Ascheim of New York and Old Chatham, N.Y. A June wedding is planned. Miss Davis, who graduated from the Brearley School and cum laude from Wellesley College, is a second-year medical student at New York University.

LEAD: EVEN on one of those raw, blustery days that bedevil the winter visitor to Florida, there are no vacant seats on the tram tour that explores the Everglades at Shark Valley. Thirty miles west of Miami, along the well-traveled Tamiami Trail, Shark Valley is the most accessible of the three entrances to Everglades National Park, the one closest to south Florida's booming resort communities.
LEAD: ALICE ROOSEVELT LONGWORTH By Carol Felsenthal. Illustrated. 320 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $19.95.
LEAD: Residents of this tiny village in the hills of northwest Massachusetts have won their fight with the state to save their 98-year-old iron bridge.

LEAD: On one of the most built-up streets in Manhattan, Sheldon Werdiger, the project manager for 125 West 55th Street, speaks of creating a park feeling. Though the 23-story office building being developed there by the Harry Macklowe Real Estate Company has two of New York's tallest new buildings as neighbors, it is near a mid-block public plaza and will yield to small plazas of its own on both 55th and 56th Streets.

LEAD: For the Bobcats of Oregon-Davis High School, and the fans who had backed them, it took less than two minutes yesterday to end - at least for this season - the dream of becoming an Indiana basketball legend.

LEAD: The Rev. Thomas F. Pike, rector of Calvary and St. George's Episcopal Church in Manhattan, has been elected chairman of the Partnership for the Homeless, a private group that operates a network of shelters in churches and synagogues throughout New York City. The partnership also elected as vice chairman Leonard Harris, recently retired director of corporate relations for The New York Times Company.

LEAD: For the past few months I've been enjoying an album as exotically euphonious as the name of the Indonesian singer who made it: Idjah Hadidjah. ''Tonggeret'' (Nonesuch 79173 LP, cassette and CD) is a compilation of Ms. Hadidjah's recordings from 1979 to 1986. As a listener, I can bask in the way it sounds: the serene counterpoint that issues from resonant gongs, a fiddle-like instrument called a rebab, tinkling ''keyed metallophones'' and Ms.

LEAD: Aloha Prospector, who beat the highly regarded Tejano in California last month, posted a similar front-running 2 3/4-length victory yesterday to win the $141,000 Swift Stakes for 3-year-olds at Aqueduct.

LEAD: Because of a film distributor's change of plans, a picture caption in the Arts and Leisure section today and a listing in the Arts and Leisure Guide give outdated theater information for ''Stand and Deliver.'' It opens on Friday at the National Twin, the Plaza, Loews 84th Street Six and the Art Greenwich Twin.

LEAD: We will hear about The Road to Kansas City until we have memorized every turn. Late this afternoon, the selection and seeding of the 64 teams for the 50th National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, a process that once consisted of a few telephone calls, will again be presented live on network television.

LEAD: When you watch pop singers in a nightclub or on television, you usually see them hugging and kissing the microphone. Such passionate gestures toward the hardware are meant to underline the performer's capacity for emotional abandon, but they are not likely to produce good sound. In fact, the hand-held mike subjected to these dramatic antics is usually supplemented by another microphone, known as the body mike, sequestered in the singer's clothes to yield an acceptable sound balance - and the output of nearby stage microphones is also blended in.
LEAD: TRADING UP By Nancy Bazelon Goldstone. 262 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $17.95.
LEAD: The Reagan Administration has appealed a Federal judge's order overturning regulations that would have cut off Federal financing to family planning clinics that offer abortion counseling.

LEAD: ALONG the undulating highway that leads southwest from this city, a traveler passes through countryside made lush by summer rains. It is a place of farms and fruit stalls, but on the hillsides back from the road stand the sentinels of a harsher world - the towers of concrete and steel atop South Africa's richest gold field.
LEAD: Lobbyists spent a record $17.9 million last year wooing state legislators, Cuomo administration officials and others in state government, according to a new report.

LEAD: IT IS THE LARGEST ATRIUM IN Washington. Its Corinthian columns, 75 feet high, 8 feet in diameter, are the world's biggest. The Pension Building in Judiciary Square was erected between 1882 and 1887 with a dual purpose - to house the offices of the Federal Government's pension bureau and to serve as a setting for large gatherings.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John H. Higgs of Pelham Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne Forbush Higgs to Robert Alan Morin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Elias Morin of Forest Hills, Queens. The wedding is to be late next summer.

LEAD: AS A RULE OF thumb, a man has as many barbers in his lifetime as he has affairs. This includes one-cut visits as well as liaisons that go on for years. The similarities between the two relationships extend to the sensitive courtship, or tryout, period, the growing intimacy and fear of intimacy, the meetings that result in complete satisfaction and those that disappoint a little or a lot, and ultimately - and perhaps inevitably - the guilt at the end.

LEAD: The Rangers, who are locked in a prolonged struggle for the playoffs, spent the final minutes of the game tonight fighting for oxygen. As they sat in the satisfied silence of the locker room, their chests gradually stopped heaving.

LEAD: USUALLY a skillfully played victory over a great player will provide the winner with enough inspiration to carry him through to an excellent result in the competition. But apparently not always.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Claudy of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elisabeth Joan Marshall Claudy, to Charles Mark Fleischman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Fleischman of Washington. The wedding is to be June 18.

Tickets must be purchased 30 days in advance.

LEAD: VISIT BY JUDY CHICAGO ''The Dinner Party,'' a sculpture by Judy Chicago that was first exhibited in 1979 at the San Francisco Museum of Fine Art, was a room-sized chez d'oeuvre that incorporated the needlework and china-painting of 39 women and took five years to complete.

LEAD: The engagement of Anne Robertson Dowden to Franz Ferdinand Colloredo-Mansfeld has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Donald Smith Dowden of Islip, L.I., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ferdinand Colloredo-Mansfeld of Hamilton, Mass. A July wedding is planned.

LEAD: SUPER Tuesday, the nation's first experiment with a megaprimary, didn't exactly work out as its Southern Democratic sponsors had planned, in that it produced a surge in participation in the Republican contests, and a muddle, rather than a clear front-runner with a conservative bent, for the Democrats.

LEAD: UNTIL recently colleges that cater to black students were flailing to stay afloat in the mainstream of higher education. Hit by a tidal wave of competition from predominantly white institutions during the 1960's, several weaker schools have repeatedly come close to going under.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The return this week of ''Rumpole of the Bailey,'' cheery news in itself, is a reminder that ''Mystery!,'' the popular public-television series that first brought us Horace Rumpole in February 1980, is now in its ninth season. Between Rumpole and Rumpole, we have met 13 other sleuths, including such addictions as Lord Peter Wimsey, Miss Marple, Chief Inspector Dalgliesh and, of course, Sherlock Holmes.

LEAD: LAST month's uprising in New York City's Rikers Island jail complex, in which 550 inmates seized control of 12 dormitories for three and a half hours, sounded yet another warning about the dangers of jail and prison crowding. Yet at both the city and state levels, the government response so far has amounted to chronic crisis management.

LEAD: At 2:30 A.M. on Jan. 15, 1987, Leon Golomb saw a fire raging through the old Roanoke apartment house at 69 South Oxford Street in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn. ''By the time I looked out the window, the flames were already roaring through the roof,'' said Mr. Golomb, who lives across the street in a brownstone.

LEAD: Alexander M. Haig Jr., left, with Elizabeth Hanford Dole, wife of Senator Bob Dole, at the Dole for President Illinois headquarters in Elmhurst. Mr. Haig, who recently quit the race, and Mrs. Dole addressed Dole volunteers. Mr. Dole canceled his public schedule to prepare for a television appearance.

LEAD: CONVINCING an employee in the Atlanta area to trade the spacious family homestead for one that is half the size and twice the price in the Westchester area is a hard sell. Companies find that disparate living costs are a major concern of employees who resist relocation.

LEAD: Dance-theater is a term used lately to cover a multitude of sins, and it is one that has particular appeal to the burgeoning experimental dance scene in Montreal. In the late 1970's, West German choreographers called their work dance-theater -Pina Bausch made the label famous - and it became applicable thereafter to Japan's Butoh dance and to work, such as Maguy Marin's, that grew out of the French dance explosion.

LEAD: FOR several years now, American automobile manufacturers have been using sales incentive and rebate programs to increase the sales of selected models. The effect of these programs is so large that total consumer spending is substantially affected when the incentive programs end.

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson scored an overwhelming victory in the Democratic caucuses today in South Carolina, his native state, showing far greater support for his Presidential campaign than when he won in 1984.

LEAD: A political storm developed in Canada today over a strong criticism of Israel's handling of Palestinian unrest in the West Bank and Gaza Strip voiced by Joe Clark, the Secretary of State for External Affairs.
LEAD: Jack Swedberg, who can hold a young eagle to his chest as gently as if it were his grandchild, once said, ''To find eagles, you have to find people, then proceed in the opposite direction.''

LEAD: While the Jan. 31 article ''A New Commitment to Save the Sound'' describes a recently initiated Assembly task force committed to working on cleaning up Long Island Sound, it did not mention efforts already taken by the State Legislature.
LEAD: CONTRARY to public opinion, life is not easier when children grow up.

LEAD: Iraq said today that its jets attacked a tanker in the Persian Gulf and an oil pumping station on the Iranian mainland, indicating renewed hostilities against economic targets in the Persian Gulf war. The raids came a day after both sides called a halt in the missile strikes on each other's cities.

LEAD: The Brooklyn Museum is one of the great incomplete buildings of New York, the same symbol of unfulfilled dreams for its borough that the Cathedral of St. John the Divine is for Manhattan. The cathedral, of course, resumed building a few years ago, and recently the Brooklyn Museum announced the same intention - to complete its monumental structure within our time.

LEAD: In January, a few days before Villanova's opening conference game this season, Coach Rollie Massimino sat in a deserted Villanova locker room, stewing about the predictions that the Wildcats would finish near last place in the Big East.

LEAD: The engagement of Laura Combs Rankin to David William Stokes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter McCook Stokes of Blue Bell, Pa., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Robert Rankin of Tenafly, N.J. Miss Rankin and her fiance, graduates of Hartwick College, plan to marry in September.

LEAD: The Millstone 1 nuclear power plant shut down automatically at 5:45 A.M. today when a water feed pump lost power, a Northeast Utilities spokesman, Anthony Nericcio, said. The plant will be put back into service when the cause of the power interruption is determined and any problems corrected, he said.

LEAD: The scene is a room in Odessa. Five literary men face the camera - all seated, all formally attired in the fashion of 1913. The two on the far left and the far right are unfamiliar names today, but the trio in the middle remain celebrated figures wherever modern Jewish culture is studied. In the very center sits Simon Dubnow, the foremost Jewish historian of his era.
LEAD: A 73-year-old woman was found alive in the trunk of her car today, after being locked in it for three days, according to the state police.

LEAD: The arrest of two men is believed to have solved 21 bank robberies committed in the area in the last two months, the police say. Coincidentally, the two were arrested Thursday, although the police say the two carried out the robberies individually. Mark MacAdoo, 22 years old, was arrested in connection with 10 robberies in which the bandit escaped on a motorcycle with a total of about $6,000, the police said.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: ONE day in 1984, said Alice Carey, she walked into the lobby of 155 East 52d Street in Manhattan and overheard some ''some really tough-looking guys, like gangsters'' telling the doorman that the building had been sold and that that staff no longer had jobs.

LEAD: Boxing Whitaker Loses Title Bid: Jose Luis Ramirez of Mexico retained his World Boxing Council lightweight title yesterday in Paris with a controversial split decision over Pernell Whitaker of the United States. Whitaker, who won a gold medal at the 1984 Olympics, appeared to have an easy time from the start and was peppering the champion with right jabs throughout the fight.

LEAD: The empty tract on which the 150 to 200 homes of Deerfield will be built is outside the most established residential areas of New Jersey but centered among them. Bergen County is off to the north, Cherry Hill is well to the south, Princeton University is west and Asbury Park is east. The site, once farms and woodlands, is at the intersection of Middlesex, Mercer and Monmouth Counties and Monroe and Millstone townships.

LEAD: To the Editor: Paul Delaney's article ''Aboard the Andalusian Express'' (Travel, Jan. 17) painted a wonderful picture of Spanish rail life. LEAD: THE LAST TIME I WAS IN JERUSALEM, white-hot midsummer, a poet friend suggested that I meet her at a cafe on Ben Yehuda Street. I was astonished. There are a few leafy garden spots to which visitors tend to be taken again and again by their eager hosts - I usually pretend, out of politeness, that I haven't been to any of them yet, so that my current hosts can surprise me.

Get out your pencil and start at the top - you may choose your own entrance - and find your way back to the adjacent exit.
LEAD: WHEN Japan recently announced plans to place its first American-Japanese high school in Harrison, it became the second foreign government to claim educational territory in Westchester.

LEAD: NEAR the reception desk of Danfords Inn in Port Jefferson is a picture of George Washington. Under it, in a spidery 18th-century hand, is the message, ''I never slept here.'' George wouldn't lie. In spite of its Colonial look, Danfords Inn is a 1980's creation.

LEAD: Big plastic bags of trash line New York's downtown sidewalks every day, waiting for commercial carters. Meanwhile, scavengers tear them open looking for returnable bottles. Garbage-combers scatter scraps. Rats dart out, scratching for food. Here is the domain of the Emperors of Trash.
LEAD: Eastern Airlines, embroiled in labor problems, says it has been forced to cancel numerous flights because of a shortage of pilots.

LEAD: Peter Elder, a former partner of Peat Marwick Main & Company, the accounting concern, died of cancer Thursday at Shands Hospital in Gainesville, Fla. He was 64 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

LEAD: The Israeli Defense Force, the citizen army that has seemed to many Israelis the finest expression of their nation's modern spirit, is facing a difficult and divisive battle as it struggles to suppress Palestinian protests in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

LEAD: THE WOMAN OF THE PHARISEES, by Francois Mauriac. Translated by Gerard Hopkins. (Carrol & Graf, $8.95.) In this novel, Francois Mauriac, winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1952, tells the story of Brigitte, who forces her religion on unwitting members of a Bordeaux community, sowing tragedy in their lives.

LEAD: Yankee pitching needs an owner who knows how to develop good young pitchers within the farm system instead of wasting time on annual shopping trips to baseball's overpriced free-agent market. Taking time to develop talent instead of going for the quick fix - Candelarias, Niekros, et al., will pay off in the long run.

LEAD: Hard by the Indian hunting grounds, religious sites and battlefields of Montana and northern Wyoming, the traveler can find rich collections of the arts and artifacts of the area. The region holds a number of museums where fragments of American Indian history and culture have been preserved. But few collections are as successful - or as elclectic - as those of the Buffalo Bill Historical Center in Cody, Wyo.

LEAD: FOR YEARS, Tony Randall has spoken, with customary eloquence and elegance, of the need for New York-based classical repertory theater.
LEAD: SPRING, as measured in the town of Kent, is here. It arrived at 7:34 P.M. last Monday, when the thick mantle of ice covering the Housatonic River broke.
LEAD: DO you want to hit the boredom nerve of any child alive? Just remark how much tougher you had it when you were a kid.
LEAD: GOV. MICHAEL N. CASTLE of Delaware is trying to bring stronger state control to real estate development with a package of land-use and related highway legislation.

LEAD: WEEKS BEFORE WINTER OFFICIALLY submits to spring, the signs are there. From Brittany's port of Erquy to the bustling riverside quays of Lyons, from Nice's sun-kissed Cours Saleya to the sunrise tuna auction in St.-Jean-de-Luz, one's senses are alerted to the change of season. Already, plump melons from Cavailon, tiny peas from Barbentane, strawberries from just north of Marseilles, peaches from Salon-de-Provence, cherries from Ceret, have begun to trickle into market stalls.

The mainstays in this business are the bridal-wear designers whose gowns cost between $500 and $600.

LEAD: To the Editor: My wife and I were particularly pleased with the article ''Scholarly and Epicurean Bologna'' by William Weaver (Travel, June 29, 1986), which we saved. Recently en route from Venice to Florence, we stopped for the night. The Accademia hotel was exactly as described: clean, friendly and inexpensive.

LEAD: SOMETIMES I AM SURPRISED THAT the French have cookbooks at all. For even though the written word is sacrosanct in France, all one has to do is walk out the door and, inevitably, the subject of food comes up. Before you know it, you're jotting down recipes for the cheesemonger's favorite potato gratin, the hairdresser's grandmother's version of creme caramel, the dry cleaner's apple tart and the farmer's wife's cheesecake.

LEAD: At the age of 26, Paul Rice had a rewarding career as a New York City architect, with time for friends, music and skiing, but he sensed that his life needed another dimension. He began calling hospitals and offering to be a volunteer.

LEAD: Witold Gombrowicz was born into a family of Polish gentry in 1904. He completed his law studies in Warsaw and studied philosophy and economics in Paris, but abandoned a legal career when he made his literary debut with a collection of short stories, ''Memoir From Adolescence,'' in 1933. ''Ferdydurke,'' a novel, and ''Yvonne, Princess of Burgundy,'' a play, followed in 1938.

LEAD: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel said tonight that the rioting by Palestinians in the occupied territories was not a demonstration of civil disobedience but a war, waged not merely against the Israeli occupation but ''against Israelis, against the existence of the State of Israel.''

LEAD: Two months after a Presidential task force issued recommendations on how to prevent another stock market crash, the White House is planning to form another group to draft its final, official position, White House aides said today.

LEAD: The case of Tawana Brawley has become a festering social wound. Without the alleged victim's cooperation, it may never be healed, but it can at least be treated, with an assiduous grand jury investigation. The public is entitled to justice, too, and to official closure of a case that has won national attention and continues to torment race relations.

LEAD: A Federal court jury today found Lynette (Squeaky) Fromme, who is serving a life sentence for trying to assassinate President Ford in 1975, guilty of escape. LEAD: The New York State Comptroller said today that Governor Cuomo's proposed state budget was based on an overly optimistic economic forecast and could result in a shortfall of up to $800 million.

LEAD: Scientists at Yale University are planning to transplant brain cells from aborted fetuses into patients with Parkinson's Disease in an effort to find a treatment for the crippling disease.

LEAD: R. H. Macy & Company yesterday increased the cash front end of its takeover offer for Federated Department Stores Inc. by $200 million, to $77.35 a share, from $74.50 for 80 percent of Federated's stock.

LEAD: Vice President Bush holds big leads over the Rev. Jesse Jackson or Albert Gore Jr. but only a narrow edge over Michael S. Dukakis in possible general election matchups, according to polls conducted for Time and Newsweek magazines.
LEAD: The full coach fares paid by travelers who cannot make plans far ahead are going up sharply today on many routes, and many discount fares are ending.

LEAD: Old joke in Eastern Europe: Q. What is the difference, comrade, between Communism and capitalism? A. Under capitalism, man exploits man. Under Communism, the situation is reversed. As if to illustrate, Mikhail Gorbachev now promises a radical new reform to the toiling Soviet masses: the progressive income tax.

LEAD: Life imitates art, also in Washington. In the movie ''Broadcast News,'' Holly Hunter, who has been nominated for an Academy Award for her portrayal of a television news producer, attends the annual White House Correspondents Association dinner.
LEAD: Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee since 1973, yesterday announced his intention to retire from Congress in January after 40 years.

LEAD: A TEAM of computer scientists has developed a new method of breaking down complex scientific problems into tiny pieces, letting an array of 1,024 separate processors compete with much more expensive supercomputers.

LEAD: None of the Presidential candidates, says Newton N. Minow, ''utters a word that lifts your heart, and the system we're using to choose among them is a serious mistake that's steadily getting worse.''

LEAD: N.H.L. Tie Ends Canadiens' Winning Streak: A power-play goal by Chris Chelios, a defenseman, early in the third period allowed Montreal to salvage a 2-2 tie at Bloomington, Minn., with the North Stars. Montreal entered with a 10-game winning streak, longest in the league this season. Minnesota, with the worst record in the league, earned its third point in two games after losing its previous seven games.

LEAD: Last year, while 28,000 homeless people were placed each night in municipal shelters and welfare hotels, there were 72,000 empty apartments in New York City, according to a city-sponsored study released last week.

LEAD: Cuisine of the kind rarely found outside France's best restaurants will be on its way to the stars if three enterprising Frenchmen have their way: they plan to package fine food for space flights, long expeditions on Earth or just family outings.

LEAD: TENNIS Evert, Seguso Advance: Chris Evert overwhelmed Alycia Moulton, 6-0, 6-0, and Robert Seguso celebrated the birth of his first child with a five-set triumph over Horacio de la Pena last night at the $2.1 million Lipton International Players championships in Key Biscayne, Fla. Seguso rallied to beat de la Pena, 3-6, 4-6, 6-2, 6-4, 6-2, less than 24 hours after his wife, Carling Bassett Seguso, gave birth to a boy.

They acknowledge that the current $700 million interdiction effort has increased risks for smugglers. LEAD: A prison guard and a cook were charged today with taking money to help a prisoner escape and six other guards were accused of viciously beating a second inmate.

LEAD: Israel severed international telephone links to the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip today in what the authorities described as a new effort to put pressure on the organization of the Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories.

LEAD: If pitching was a concern when the Yankees opened their training camp four weeks ago, it is less so today. LEAD: Foreign investment is becoming a hot topic on Capitol Hill. An investigation of foreign takeovers of United States banks is planned by Representative John D. Dingell, the Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee and its investigations subcommittee.

LEAD: SPRING thaws and rains often bring leaky basements with them. But several measures can be taken to remedy most problems so well that no further repairs will be necessary.

LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were mostly lower for the week ended yesterday, continuing a downward pattern in recent weeks.

LEAD: The Democratic Presidential race, clouded before the Illinois primary Tuesday, looked even murkier today as the candidates moved their campaigns into Kansas, Michigan, Wisconsin and other states that vote in the next month.
LEAD: Aurelia M. Pucinski beat former Mayor Jane M. Byrne Tuesday in the closely watched Democratic primary election for clerk of the Cook County Circuit Court.

LEAD: It is hard to imagine flamenco being gentle, low-keyed entertainment. But that was the mood created in ''Imagenes de Garcia Lorca,'' presented by La Compania de Teatro de Albuquerque and Eva Encinias's Ritmo Flamenco on Friday at Marymount Manhattan Theater.

LEAD: Barbara Conrad, a mezzo-soprano who has sung with the Metropolitan Opera and the New York City Opera, made her formal recital debut Monday evening at Alice Tully Hall, offering a program that explored some unusual corners of the art-song tradition.

LEAD: Unlike the rest of the nation, where most new jobs have been created by small businesses, New York City's small employers have made ''a steep cutback'' in the rate of expansion, according to a government study released yesterday.

LEAD: It's the moment of truth for the Gephardt amendment to the foreign trade bill, an ill-conceived scheme to punish countries whose exports are too popular with American consumers. House and Senate conferees must adopt, modify or kill the measure.

LEAD: Maurice Linder, an insurance agent for 45 years and the oldest living member of the industry's ''Million Dollar Round Table,'' died of heart failure Sunday at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 93 years old and lived in Palm Beach.
LEAD: Under attack at the polls, in criminal court and in the State Senate, Evan Mecham took the stand here today to defend himself in the first impeachment trial of a governor in almost 60 years.
LEAD: THE name Fred Marcellino may not be a household word. But those who read Tom Wolfe's best-selling novel ''The Bonfire of the Vanities'' will spend many hours with Mr. Marcellino's work.

LEAD: The eight musicians who played for a ''Salute to Dick Hyman'' at last Thursday's ''Highlights in Jazz'' concert at the Loeb Auditorium of New York University brought an unusual amount of warmth and affection to this 14th salute to a living jazz musician that has been organized by the impresario Jack Kleinsinger over the past 15 years.

LEAD: Because of dealings with three agents after the completion of the 1987 season, George Cooper, the fullback, has lost his scholarship at Ohio State. Cooper, the father of two children, said that having used up his college eligibility and needing money, he did not believe involvement with agents would influence his grant.
LEAD: An engine fire broke out today on the Scandinavian Star, leaving the cruise ship adrift for hours in the Gulf of Mexico with more than 700 people aboard, the authorities said.

LEAD: Panama's security forces tortured, beat and arrested people who peacefully protested the rule of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, killing one man who shouted ''Down with Noriega!'' in public, Amnesty International said today.
LEAD: The New York State investigation of campaign financing will spread into the Legislature, the State Board of Elections and still more contributors seeking to influence politicians.

LEAD: Hersey Hawkins of Bradley, the nation's leading Division I scorer with an average of 36 points a game, has been voted college basketball's player of the year by the United States Basketball Writers Association. Hawkins, a 6-foot-3-inch senior guard, was an easy winner over Danny Manning of Kansas.
LEAD: Bond prices slumped yesterday in light trading, as market participants sold securities following unexpectedly strong economic reports and a rebound in oil prices.

LEAD: Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, told state Democratic leaders today that he intended to endorse one of the candidates running for the Democratic Presidential nomination, and urged them to drop plans to send an uncommitted slate to the national convention.

LEAD: The Greece that is seen in Nicos Papatakis's ''Photograph'' is a place of sharp contrasts, a land of majestic mountain scenery and crumbling, tacky modern construction. It is a fierce longing for this homeland that propels the story forward, and the longing takes an unusual form. A shy, decent and illiterate Greek furrier named Gerasimos Jiras has been living in Paris for many years when, in 1971, a young relative named Ilias arrives with some information and a get-rick-quick scheme.
LEAD: In a victory for the nuclear lobby, the Senate today voted against imposing accountability for accidents on the contractors who operate the Government's nuclear research and weapons program.

LEAD: A trip to Cuba is planned soon by John Cardinal O'Connor, who would be the highest-ranking American Roman Catholic official to visit that nation since Fidel Castro took power in 1959, the Archdiocese of New York announced.

LEAD: The Henley Group Inc., created in a 1986 spinoff from Allied-Signal Inc., said today that it would split into two separate public companies. Henley also announced plans to repurchase 22 percent of its stock.

LEAD: A Federal judge has approved a settlement of a sex discrimination suit brought against the State Farm Insurance Company, which will now have to pay as much as $420,000 apiece to women who were denied jobs as insurance agents in California.
LEAD: Perry Carter scored 25 points and had 10 rebounds last night as Ohio State defeated Old Dominion, 86-73, in the first round of the National Invitation Tournament.
LEAD: When Tom Lasorda was a teen-ager in Norristown, Pa., his mother bought evaporated milk, the milk that came in the can with the picture of a cow on it.

LEAD: Dwight Gooden said it was ridiculous to panic or even to fret about it. Spring training never was his long suit, anyway, and he said he was ''right on schedule.'' He said all this immediately after the Philadelphia Phillies had raked him for 10 hits and six runs in four innings.

LEAD: Kim Dae Jung, South Korea's best-known opposition leader, resigned today as president of his party in a last-minute bid to unite the nation's bitterly divided opposition before legislative elections next month.

LEAD: Marti Jones's show at the Bottom Line on Friday was full of lost possibilities. She's a startlingly immediate singer; her voice, windowpane clear, can take the most trivial ''I . . . you'' (love/hate, see/didn't see) songwriting conceit and charge it with the sort of larger meaning that can spring from a small, tactile description.

LEAD: History is written by the victors, and that is true even of political campaigns not yet concluded. In retrospect, the winning side's decisions invariably appear brilliant, and losers almost always look foolish.

LEAD: Posing as a frightened and pregnant teen-ager, a 24-year-old banker walked into the Pregnancy Distress Center in Columbus, Ohio, six weeks ago and asked for advice. She was leaning toward having an abortion, she said, but first she wanted to make sure she understood her other options.

LEAD: The House has given final Congressional approval to legislation authorizing prime Federal parkland in Washington as a site for a national monument to the 5,000 blacks who fought the British in the American Revolution.

LEAD: If there were a list of socially endangered species, large families would be among those at the top. Only about 2 percent of American families with children under the age of 18 have five or more children at home, according to a 1986 census report. In 1960, the figure was 8 percent.
LEAD: THE William Esty Company has hired a most unusual woman as its director of new business, an important job in an agency eager to return to its previous eminence.
LEAD: The Tandy Corporation said today that it would acquire the closely held Grid Systems Corporation, a manufacturer of laptop personal computers based in Fremont, Calif.

LEAD: The banking problems in the depressed Southwest have become so acute, banking experts say, that they could create the largest one-year drain in history on the Government agency that insures deposits at the nation's banks.

LEAD: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter and two other key participants in the Iran-contra affair were indicted today on charges of conspiracy to defraud the United States by illegally providing the Nicaraguan rebels with profits from the sale of American weapons to Iran.
LEAD: Ameruso, Biaggi, Esposito, Friedman, Manes, Myerson, Simon, Turoff, Zaccaro.
LEAD: A Federal judge rejected a claim by an Italian tire maker that Ohio's anti-takeover law is unconsitutional.

LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra today rejected Reagan Administration charges that Nicaraguan forces are fighting inside Honduras, and he invited foreign observers to visit the border area to verify his statement.

LEAD: Students who skip Prof. Gerald M. Phillips's opening lecture in his course on group decision making may find themselves searching the campus in vain for any trace of him the rest of the semester.
LEAD: The Central Capital Corporastion, a Canadian financial services concern based in Toronto, bought a 7.8 percent stake in the U.S. Trust Corporation of New York for $31.3 million.
LEAD: Anna Quindlen's column will appear in this space beginning next Thursday. The Hers column will move to The New York Times Magazine, where it will appear on alternate Sundays beginning March 27.

LEAD: Perhaps it was too much to ask. The Rangers, who had continued to win games even as they lost players, were beaten, 8-4, by the Capitals last night at the Garden. It was discouraging, clouded by the loss of another player.

LEAD: TW Services Inc., the new owner of the Denny's restaurant chain, has dismissed Foote, Cone & Belding, Los Angeles, from the account after a 10-year relationship, and also let go Western International Media, which had been doing the media buying.

LEAD: Two years ago, Mayor W. Wilson Goode won widespread applause when he broke an unpopular 20-day strike by a union so powerful, in the view of many Philadelphians, that it actually ran the city sanitation department - and none too well, at that.

LEAD: After days of debate between the International Amateur Athlete Federation and British track and field officials about whether Zola Budd should be eligible for international meets because she might have competed in South Africa, she solved the problem by withdrawing from the British team at the world cross-country championships.

LEAD: For the first time in the United States, a computer program that can secretly spread from computer to computer and potentially destroy stored data has compromised a major commercial personal computer software product.
LEAD: A seven-ton patchwork quilt made of 3,488 hand-sewn panels, each commemorating a person who died of AIDS, will be displayed in segments in 20 cities in coming months.

LEAD: The 23-count indictment today against four defendants in the Iran-contra affair aims some of the standard weapons in the arsenal of Federal prosecutors at high-level officials who say they were lawfully carrying out President Reagan's national security policies.

LEAD: After spending nine years on the World Cup skiing circuit, Laurie Graham of Canada announced yesterday that she would retire after racing next Wednesday in Sallbach, Austria, in the final World Cup downhill race of the season. The 27-year-old Graham is a six-time winner on the World Cup circuit, but she failed to win a medal in three appearances in the Winter Olympic Games.(

LEAD: Q. In cold weather the glass and the aluminum frames of our skylights sweat so much that moisture accumulates and runs down off the low end. This water is damaging the drywall. Is there a cure? A. Apparently the skylights do not have double-pane insulating glass, and the aluminum frames do not have thermal barriers.
LEAD: The Prado Museum in Madrid has been selected to house a part of the Thyssen-Bornemisza collection, one of the world's richest private art collections.

LEAD: Legal considerations, and not a popularity contest, will be responsible if the Charter Revision Commission ultimately recommends against preserving the Board of Estimate, the commission secretary, Nathan Leventhal, said yesterday.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The British Government cut interest rates today to halt the surge in the value of the pound, yielding to warnings from British companies and some Government officials that the currency's continuing advance was threatening to dent the nation's exports.

LEAD: CENTURIES before the neologism grazing was coined to describe hit-and-run eaters, the Spanish were doing just that at their tascas, convivial restaurants where a copious display of appetizers, called tapas, were lined up along the bar. So it should be no surprise to Rufino Lopez, a native of Galicia in northwestern Spain, that nomadic nibblers are flocking to his inviting new restaurant,

LEAD: Ariel S. Herrera stood out last year in a showcase series for new choreographers, and ''Fish on Friday,'' the 40-minute work he presented Wednesday night, confirms that he is a young talent to be followed.

LEAD: Richard Benjamin's strategy in directing ''Little Nikita'' seems to have been to paper over the holes in the plot with routine moves from spy shows past, in hopes of making the improbable passable. Sidney Poitier, an F.B.I. agent again, gets onto a couple of K.G.B. ''sleepers'' named Richard and Elizabeth Grant, a very American couple in the southern California town of Fountain Grove, who have been waiting 20 years for the call to action from Moscow.

LEAD: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission warned today that talks between the exchanges and regulators have yet to produce sufficient agreement on new measures -including coordinated trading halts, price limits and other ''circuit breakers'' - to prevent another collapse of the stock market.
LEAD: Sandinista troops have called off a major military offensive along the northern border with Honduras after overrunning a series of contra guerrilla bases, according to local commanders.

LEAD: If Nicaragua were intent on occupying Honduran territory, that might justify President Reagan's dispatch of 3,200 U.S. troops to support an aggrieved ally. Yesterday's truculent declarations from President Daniel Ortega suggest, again, that Managua knows how to snatch defeat from the jaws of political victory.

LEAD: A new movie, ''The House on Carroll Street,'' is set in the Greenwich Village of 1951 - and much of it was photographed in the Greenwich Village of 1987. At the moment it's playing in Greenwich Village as well. And judging by comments overheard at a recent showing, the audience wasn't there only to follow the plot.
LEAD: Franc Sifkovic, the general manager of the Iskra Electronic Company here, told Mikhail S. Gorbachev today how he was being affected by perestroika, the Soviet economic restructuring.

LEAD: Private hospitals have agreed to provide most of the 412 beds being added to relieve overcrowding in New York City hospitals, according to a plan issued yesterday by the State Health Commissioner, Dr. David Axelrod.

LEAD: Bob Dole probably missed his chance for the Republican Presidential nomination when he could not follow up his Iowa victory with one in New Hampshire. Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts may look back upon Illinois as the state in which his hopes suffered a similar setback.
LEAD: A witness in municipal corruption cases pleaded guilty yesterday to obstructing justice by withholding information about a collection company for New York City's Parking Violations Bureau.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Even those used to watching Edward James Olmos regularly in his ''Miami Vice'' role will have a tough time recognizing him at first in ''Stand and Deliver,'' since Mr. Olmos has transformed himself so completely. His hair has been thinned and pasted unflatteringly across his pate; he looks heavier, wears glasses and has none of the complexion-improving makeup used for his television role.

LEAD: Sammy Price, a pianist, will lead a boogie-woogie band tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., along with a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover with a $7 minimum at tables and a one-drink minimum at the bar.

LEAD: Dr. Maurice S. Segal, professor emeritus at Tufts University School of Medicine who was a prominent researcher in lung disease, died Tuesday of a heart attack at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 80 years old.

LEAD: The House Budget Committee today approved a $1.1 trillion Federal budget for the fiscal year 1989 that generally follows the budget accord reached with President Reagan but raised some of his domestic spending proposals while reducing others.
LEAD: Dannie Richmond, a drummer whose long association with Charles Mingus made him one of the leading percussionists in modern jazz, died Wednesday in Harlem of a heart attack. He was 56 years old.

LEAD: Merv Griffin, the entertainer and businessman, made a last-minute offer today to buy Resorts International Inc. for $35 a share, or about $225 million, impeding Donald J. Trump's plan to take the casino and hotel company private.

LEAD: Patricia M. Wald, chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, in a speech at Yale Law School, provided these insights into the working lives of appellate judges:

LEAD: ROBERT MOSKOWITZ works and reworks a narrow repertory of images, inventing through mysterious scenes of icebergs, howling dogs, crosses and skyscrapers a world in which distinctions blur between past and present, solid and ephemeral. There is a hypnotic quality to these large-scale paintings and pastels, and they call forth elusive, subconscious emotions.
LEAD: The Whirlpool Corporation yesterday increased its offer for the Roper Corporation to $50 a share, topping a $45-a-share bid from the General Electric Company.

LEAD: Carrying a letter of apology from the management of the Houston Astros, Manager Hal Lanier entered the umpires' locker room in Kissimmee, Fla., on Wednesday, and offered his apologies to Pat Postema for comments made about her on Monday by Bob Knepper, the pitcher.

LEAD: COMPANIES Federal regulators will provide $1 billion in cash to First Republicbank's subsidiary banks in an effort to stop a huge outflow of deposits and a widespread loss of confidence in Texas's largest banking company. The F.D.I.C. said it would guarantee all deposits, of any amount, in the company's 73 banking subsidiaries.

LEAD: Morton Thiokol officials said today that five employees killed in a fire while fueling an MX missile motor had ignored company rules and entered the building during a phase of the operation that should have been handled by remote control.

LEAD: The Manhattan School of Music, 120 Claremont Avenue, near 122d Street and Broadway, Manhattan, will present a Haydn opera, ''La Fedelta Premiata'' (''Virtue Rewarded''), in an English translation by Marcie Stapp, tonight at 8 and Sunday at 2 P.M. The production is the American premiere of the work, and is directed by Lou Galtero, with choreography by Francis Patrelle.

LEAD: St. John's, a controversial choice for the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, made a quick but hard-fought exit here tonight.

LEAD: JAY SCHULBERG, who quit his job as the creative head of the New York office of Ogilvy & Mather to look for something different, has now become creative head of the New York office of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt.

LEAD: Unemployment in Britain fell to a seasonally adjusted 9.1 percent in February from 9.2 percent in January, the Government said today. The figure stood at 11 percent in February 1987, the Department of Employment said.
LEAD: The Devils relinquished a two-goal lead tonight and let 2 more valuable points escape from their grasp in the race for the playoffs.
LEAD: As thousands of bridge players converged on this city today to start some national championship events, another was ending.

LEAD: Andrea Robinson, beauty editor of Vogue magazine for eight years, has resigned to become president of Ultima II, a division of Revlon Inc. Ultima II markets cosmetics treatment products and fragrances. Ms. Robinson will report to Robert A. Neilson, chairman and president of Revlon's fashion and designer group.

LEAD: THERE'S a great moment in the middle of ''Paid in Full,'' a slinky rap piece by Eric B. and Rakim, remixed and tarted up for dance clubs: Out of left field comes a woman's wailing voice, obviously Middle Eastern in its gentle, hilly melismas. But her voice fits in perfectly, suggesting different cultures colliding and yet having fun.

LEAD: After a flare-up of hostilities this week in the South China Sea, Vietnam appealed to China today to negotiate an end to naval attacks around a contested offshore island chain ''and all other matters of border disputes.''

LEAD: The Music to Watch By Robert Redford, whose ''Milagro Beanfield War'' opens today (review on page C17), is to be on hand Tuesday night at Royce Hall on the campus of the University of California at Los Angeles when his Sundance Institute, in conjunction with Ascap and B.M.I., holds a star-studded event to raise funds for its effort to preserve and foster motion-picture music.

LEAD: Lawyers for Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. introduced today three letters between Henry A. Kissinger and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and said they were evidence of a Government effort to harass Mr. LaRouche.

LEAD: The new owners of the Winston Network Inc., the country's largest out-of-home media company, have changed its name to AMNI, derived from the American Out-of-Home Media Network. It has also had several promotions announced by Craig P. Heard, its president. They include four executive vice presidents: Berton Miller, Angelo Schifano, Donald Allman and Robert G.

LEAD: The Panamanian Government militarized public utilities today and ordered a curfew in the country's second-largest city in an effort to restore order after a coup attempt against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. It also began a shake-up of the military high command, The curbs were imposed after strikes by utility workers cut off electricity and water and blocked roads.

LEAD: A Federal agency today ordered foreign nations that export tuna to the United States to reduce the number of dolphins killed in fishing.

LEAD: Every airport has security checks for departing passengers. The one here even forces arriving visitors to walk through metal detectors after they leave the plane.

LEAD: President Reagan is not accused of any crime in the indictment of John Poindexter, Oliver North and two weapons traders for the Iran-contra conspiracy. The very fact of the indictment accuses him of something more serious.

LEAD: Christian Lacroix, the designer who made couture clothes sizzle, has shown he can make relatively subdued styles as well as fanciful, exhuberant ones. Both types were represented in his first extensive ready-to-wear collection. It was presented in a courtyard tent at the Louvre late Wednesday afternoon, the first day of the fall and winter fashion openings.

LEAD: Out in San Francisco, two new ad agencies are on the scene, each started by creative people from New York - one by an old pro and the other by a couple of under-30 upstarts.

Magee was one of five players in the field of 114 to birdie the 18th hole. Bay Hill's 18th, a 456-yard par-4 slightly uphill with the green tucked against water on the right, is one of the 10 most difficult holes on the PGA Tour.

LEAD: The ritual of storing winter wear is about to begin and, as uninspiring as the job may be, the time and trouble can pay off, experts say. Cleaning and covering cold-weather clothes, storing them in cool, dry places and protecting them from household pests will extend their life. Neglect will show up as holes, stains, fading, mildew and misshapen garments.

LEAD: The Whirlpool Corporation sued the General Electric Company yesterday, charging that G.E.'s efforts to acquire the Roper Corporation interfered illegally with Whirlpool's prior merger agreement with the appliance maker.
LEAD: Israeli soldiers shot and killed a Palestinian today and wounded dozens as a wave of protests continued.
LEAD: Billy Butterfield, a trumpeter who played with the Bob Crosby, Artie Shaw and Benny Goodman bands, died of cancer yesterday at his home. He was 71 years old and lived in North Palm Beach, Fla.

LEAD: Francoise Sagan, who became famous at 18 for her novel ''Bonjour Tristesse,'' was indicted today for using and transporting cocaine in Lyons. Miss Sagan, a friend of President Francois Mitterrand, said the charge was politically motivated. The writer, 52 years old and the author of 19 novels and a few film scripts, was among 30 people charged.

LEAD: There are those who feel that young conductors should be apprenticed in obscure European opera houses, neither seen nor heard until they are old enough to sidestep qualms about maturity. Esa-Pekka Salonen, a Finnish conductor who is not yet 30 years old, has been making some flashy recordings for CBS these last few years, and while one might argue that he does not always reach the depths of the broad late-Romantic works that attract him, his interpretations are usually thoughtfully conceived and persuasively executed.

LEAD: Battling Bugs The approach of warm weather brings out insects, especially in kitchens. Even if your home is bug-free, insects may hitch a ride with the groceries. You can fight them with sprays, powders, traps, even ultrasound machines. But before you shop, check your shelves: you may have the products you need, and you may see what's attracting the insects.
