LEAD: Most Americans see stress as a torturous byproduct of life in a high-speed society. But there is a growing group of entrepreneurs who are enthralled by stress, who cannot get enough of it and who are making it the latest catchword to sweep the country's vibrant self-help industry.

LEAD: Dressed in the crisp, bright colors of his own paintings as he explores the mysteries of a 70-foot-long Chinese scroll, David Hockney effortlessly connects the past and the present, revealing himself to be a splendid art teacher in the process. LEAD: Can anyone who is not well-off buy a home in Westchester County these days? ''It requires an extensive search,'' said Blossom Blum, executive director of Westchester Residential Opportunities Inc., a nonprofit open-housing group. ''We help people to try to find a way to afford what's out there.''

LEAD: ''MOOSE!'' The cry from one excited passenger sets 59 other heads aswivel, and those of us across the aisle jump out of our plush seats and lean over fellow riders to catch a glimpse of a barn-size cow and her calf grazing by the edge of a grove of birch trees. Outside the wide, curved glass windows we see unbroken wilderness; inside, we enjoy unalloyed luxury.

LEAD: MEMBERS of Congress, trying to keep a cleanup study of Long Island Sound moving at full speed, have begun fighting a Reagan Administration proposal to cut the Federal estuary program by $2.5 million in 1989.

LEAD: AMONG the first buildings to be considered for designation by the newly formed New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission in 1966 were two identical clapboard rowhouses at 312 and 314 East 53d Street, between Second and First Avenues, built a century earlier.

LEAD: THE year was 1956. The movie was ''Picnic.'' And at a New Jersey drive-in theater, according to legend, an invisible message flashed across the silver screen every 32 seconds: ''Eat popcorn. Drink Coke.'' The concession stand reportedly filled with hungry patrons, and subliminal messages were declared a box-office success.

LEAD: ECONOMY-CLASS travelers confess to being tortured by curiosity about what is happening on the other side of that curtain near the front that the flight attendants draw so decisively after takeoff. In moments when I have been on the other side, I have secretly hoped to spy out the truth. I never learned much except that carving beef on a little trolley looks like back-breaking work.

LEAD: The Feb. 14 Opinion Page article by Lee Rothberg against irradiation of food was misleading and mistaken. In her zeal, she performed a disservice by attempting to overwhelm us with facts purporting to prove the process of irradiation inherently hazardous and, therefore, to be banned.

LEAD: To the Editor: Regarding ''Costa Rica's Quiet Beaches and Lush Land'' (Travel, Jan. 24), I would like to suggest that anyone going to Costa Rica should consider a three-day raft trip on the Picuare River, which flows through lush, virgin jungle. Visitors can expect to see dazzling, electric-blue Morpho butterflies, scarlet macaws and the exotic nests of the oropendula.

LEAD: EXPERTS and administrators around the world have long been troubled by the problem of procedural penalties for such matters as tardy arrival and slow play. It seems unfair, say some, for a major knockout team match to be decided by circumstances other than actual play. The counter-argument focuses on the difficulty of discouraging misdemeanors without imposing penalties with teeth.

LEAD: WHEN word got around the island of Nevis not long ago that construction of a new golf course was being contemplated, the response from most Nevisians and long-time foreign residents was predictable: why build something we already have? That the existing course has only one hole - making it the only one-hole course in the West Indies and perhaps anywhere, for that matter - was irrelevant to most residents, who felt that one hole was quite enough.

LEAD: The Army has announced it will test buildings on its bases for the presence of the natural radioactive gas radon. ''The first structures to be tested will be day care centers, hospitals, schools and living areas,'' the Army said in a statement Friday. Radon, a natural product of decaying uranium in soil, may increase the risk of lung cancer, medical researchers say.

LEAD: In hard times, men traditionally dress up to look affluent and successful. During the Great Depression, for example, many families put a good portion of their clothing budget into the breadwinner's suit. Although we're a long way from the 1930's, it appears that the diminishing prosperity of recent times has caused many young men to abandon casual clothes for a more conservative style.
LEAD: An elderly Queens man who lived alone died yesterday of a beating he received during a robbery in his home Friday, the police said.

LEAD: A June wedding is planned by Marie Jean Vogliano and Thomas Andrew Goodman, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Ernest L. Vogliano of New York and Eatons Neck, L.I., have announced. Mr. Goodman is the son of Reynold H. Goodman of Stuart, Fla., and Betty S. Goodman of Hartsdale, N.Y.

LEAD: Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau, who had not sung in America since 1980, returned to Carnegie Hall Friday night to sing Mahler's ''Kindertotenlieder'' with the Philharmonia Orchestra of London. It was easy for him to renew his bond of communication with this public. Oboe and horn played their brief opening lament; the baritone entered with a quiet reflection that the sun would rise again as though no sorrow had befallen in the night, and instantly we were all in the world of Mahler and Ruckert (the poet) and their close examination of grief.

LEAD: THe President who sent the Marines to Lebanon on a mission without a purpose has now sent 3,000 American soldiers to Honduras. Once again their mission is unclear. Once again professional military people are troubled.

LEAD: Only $200,000 of $20 million in ''emergency'' American military aid sent to Honduras following a March 1986 border crossing by Nicaraguan troops was used to respond to the attack, according to a report by Congressional investigators that has not been made public.

LEAD: Among the 1.3 million Roman Catholics in the United States who are black, there is now one archbishop. Pope John Paul II last week named Eugene Antonio Marino Archbishop of the Diocese of Atlanta, making him the first black American to achieve that status within the church. Bishop Marino, a 53-year-old native of Biloxi, Miss., said his appointment was ''a sign of hope to black Catholics in our country and to all people of good will.

LEAD: Tools and utensils that kept houses humming a century ago have been dusted off and placed on view at the New-York Historical Society, in an exhibition called ''Bellows, Bobbins and Butter Churns: Keeping House in 19th-Century America.'' Most of the 190 or so items, on exhibit through Oct. 2, were used by women in their daily chores - cooking, spinning, sewing, laundering and keeping their houses heated, lighted and free of pests.

LEAD: The marriage of Alison Marie Belna to Andrew Edward Arbenz took place yesterday at the Four Seasons Hotel in Newport Beach, Calif. Judge Charles E. Frisco of Superior Court in Los Angeles officiated.

LEAD: THE signs are everywhere. From the gleaming shad massing in the Hudson, to the tiny crocuses crowding Westchester lawns, spring is arriving in the county.

LEAD: The Running Rams of Rhode Island came into their first National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament in a decade believing they could run with anybody. After a desperation 3-pointer by Earl Duncan, the Syracuse guard, bounced off the rim at the buzzer today, the East Regional's 11th-seeded team had proven it did indeed belong among the nation's elite.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: BARBARA MUSIC has been a designer of textiles, theater costumes and bridal and evening dresses. But her latest career is trimming bridal and evening shoes with all manner of laces, beads, buckles and fabric flowers.

LEAD: ''I am no orator, as Brutus is,'' says Al Pacino as Mark Antony, wooing the Roman mob, ''but, as you know me all, a plain blunt man.'' Indeed, prowling a stage at the Public Theater during previews of ''Julius Caesar,'' Mr. Pacino has offered a performance that is a far cry from the conventionally heroic and patrician Mark Antony of Shakespearean tradition.
LEAD: WARNING labels on alcoholic beverages could shape up as the ''Why not'' issue of 1988. And that would be a shame.
LEAD: THE Boston Post Road Stage Company of Fairfield is offering a delightful account of ''The Miss Firecracker Contest,'' a funny and touching play by Beth Henley.

LEAD: A booklet of 12 stamps from France re-create the works of French comic strip artists. The set is a salute to the comic strip as a form of communication and a belated celebration of the 1987 centennial of the appearance of the first French comic strip story.

LEAD: A condominium office building under construction in Flushing that its co-developer, Ted Schorr, said has ''a very different look from what has been built in Queens'' would fit well into any New York City suburb. The six-story structure's open surroundings and layer-cake design of alternating glass and brick are more often seen from a New Jersey Transit train than the IRT No.

LEAD: Castle in Court DEALING a stiff financial blow to Southampton Village, a Federal jury in Brooklyn has awarded Barry Trupin $1.9 million in damages because village officials denied his civil rights when they halted construction of his dream castle by the sea.

LEAD: The local authorities in Berkeley Heights, N.J., announced yesterday that all dangerous gas cylinders had been removed from the burning debris of a chemical plant where a cylinder exploded Thursday, killing three men and injuring a fourth.
LEAD: Bari Sue Kenyon, the former editor in chief of The Paper Lion at Farmingdale High School, presents a compelling case in support of freedom of the press for student journalists [ Feb. 21 ] .

LEAD: Q. I live in a condominium, and the wall I share with the next unit seems paper-thin. I inquired about having insulation blown in to keep out noise but was told this was impossible because of fire barriers in the wall. Is there a way to soundproof this wall?
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''Rashomon - it's more than just a movie. The word has come into the language now.'' Fay Kanin, the co-author, with her husband, Michael, of a 1959 adaptation of Akira Kurosawa's film, was remarking how deep a note the movie has struck here. The very name, she said, now means any conflicting versions of the same reality.

LEAD: OVER the years, Martin Markinson and Donald Tick have rebuffed an aggressive stream of realty brokers eager to find buyers for the Helen Hayes Theater on West 44th Street, which the two men have owned for almost a decade. ''We never wanted to deal with lots of brokers and prospective buyers and all that stuff,'' said Mr.
LEAD: The Air Force has adopted a policy holding that military wives' decisions to work outside the home are none of the service's business.

LEAD: WHEN University Circle, a management group, initially agreed with this city in 1974 to lease five acres near Case Western Reserve University, the idea was to create interest in the property among private developers.

LEAD: To the Editor: I concur totally with Mr. Steffens and Mr. Davis about smoking (Letters on Travel, Jan. 24), and I never hesitate to ask smokers to put their cigarettes out if they light up where smoking is prohibited.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: BEGIN cleanup of the lawn; rake off winter's debris, old leaves, twigs and dead grass; add to a compost pile or fill plastic bags for dumping; apply lime if the lawn was not limed in recent years; if no fertilizer was applied late last fall, now is the time; follow rates provided on bags for both lime and fertilizer and use a calibrated spreader to make applications accurate.

LEAD: Albert York is a strange case. This reclusive painter of deliberate, dreamlike landscapes, still lifes and portraits was born in Detroit in 1928. He went to art school in Canada and Michigan. He moved to New York City in the early 1960's and studied briefly with Raphael Soyer. He has lived for more than 20 years on the east end of Long Island, where he has witnessed more than his share of development and change.

LEAD: It is seven long and presumably uncertain weeks before the next president of France will be elected. The politician with a commanding lead in the opinion polls, President Francois Mitterrand, has not yet formally declared that he will run for a second term of office. Yet the focus of political discussion in France is not about the campaign but about who will govern with whom after the
LEAD: THE Long Island Stage Company has been facing severe financial problems recently.

LEAD: NEW JERSEY is starting to phase out its sheltered workshops in favor of finding regular jobs for the severely disabled, according to Eddie C. Moore, director of the state's Division of Developmental Disabilities.
LEAD: Everyone dumps on Lilco. Once in a while, someone should tell the other side of the story.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: TO MOST New Jerseyans, he is The Honorable Secretary of Agriculture, Mister Arthur Richard Brown Junior. But to most folks in this Atlantic County agricultural community (population: 3,000), he is just plain ''Farmer Brown.''

LEAD: I HAVE been an advertising writer for 27 years. I've written ads for everything from automobiles and airlines to ham and cheese. For many of those years, I've written commercials that helped put people in public office. I've stopped, as have a number of my colleagues, even though poltical advertising is a very profitable part of our business.
LEAD: This generation of Purdue Boilermakers had spoken of an invisible but frustrating barrier that stood at the second round of the national collegiate basketball tournament.
LEAD: CLIMBING values have encouraged many property owners to sell their land, and Northeast Utilities is no exception. The utility is auctioning land it says it no longer needs.

LEAD: The marriage of Lea Anne Schoenfeld, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Schoenfeld of Seattle, to Randall Joseph Ottinger took place last evening at the Mission Hills Country Club in Palm Springs, Calif. Rabbi Earl S. Starr performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Richard L. Ottinger of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Dr.

LEAD: To the Editor: Betsy Wade's article on the pleasure of listening to cassettes while driving (Practical Traveler, Feb. 7) neglected mentioning an affordable reference guide to thousands of available titles. ''Words on Tape'' at $29.95 lists over 15,000 titles from 435 cassette publishers. Titles are listed by author, title and subject.

LEAD: When ''The Gospel at Colonus'' had its first performance at P.S. 122 on the Lower East Side in 1980, it was a half-hour show with one actor, five singers, two songs by Bob Telson and just the beginnings of writer-director Lee Breuer's central idea: that the essential nature of Greek tragedy could be revealed to modern audiences by presenting Sophocles' ''Oedipus at Colonus'' in the form of a black Pentecostal church service.
LEAD: Spain's offer of political asylum to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama was made at the request of the United States Government, Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez said.

LEAD: VOCAL and chamber music recitals are planned for today and next Sunday, with today's highlights including a piano program, wind and brass quintet concerts and solo appearances by several Metropolitan Opera singers.
LEAD: Michael Nunn used to be maligned as a fighter who danced. Tonight, he was a dancer who punched.
LEAD: Two men were convicted yesterday in the 1984 slaying of a homeless man, who was never identified, in a deserted building in Far Rockaway, Queens, District Attorney John J. Santucci said.

LEAD: THE business of advertising and the art of photography grew up together and share many elements in common. Both, essentially, are creations of 20th century technology. Both have played an enormous role in shaping our view of the world. And both live or die on their ability to tap into the mysterious power of image.

LEAD: Andrea Jill Smith, a writer for ABC Radio, and Richard Michael Stapleton, a producer for CBS News, were married last evening at the Warwick Hotel in Manhattan by Rabbi Martin Zion. Mrs. Stapleton, a daughter of Martin G. Smith and Jeri Smith, both of New York, graduated from the Lenox School and Syracuse University.

LEAD: The Practical Traveler column on Feb. 14 about frequent flier programs misstated Pan American World Airways' policy on the types of flights taken before March 31 that would qualify a passenger for triple mileage credits on later flights this year. Shuttle flights are considered qualifying.

LEAD: FINE AND FINNISH ''Art by Design: Reflections of Finland,'' an exhibition of contemporary Finnish handcrafts and industrial design, opens at the Katonah Gallery Tuesday and continues through May 15. The exhibition is in collaboration with the Finnish Society of Crafts and Design in Helsinki.

LEAD: THE everyday face of medical ethics has changed, experts say, driven by a new cost consciousness in the medical and health care professions. And the change is well illustrated by the stories of two scarce procedures and how legislators reacted to appeals by patients.

LEAD: A House subcommittee has asked Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci to explain reports that American military personnel in West Germany use some German-made cars and buses, contending that doing so ''undermines the American automotive industry.''
LEAD: The Knicks showed again last night that they can't handle big leads.

LEAD: With the campaign between Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and Attorney General Joseph I. Lieberman offering no real differences between a Democratic liberal and Republican one, the voters of Connecticut (overwhelming supporters of Ronald Reagan in both 1980 and 1986) are without a conservative or even centrist alternative.

LEAD: What Darryl Strawberry did in January of this year was no different from what Lee Mazzilli and Wally Backman did in July of last year, or from what Keith Hernandez did in September of 1984. When Strawberry's teammates tell the media that he quit, it's to motivate him; when Strawberry says that his teammates were unmotivated, he's mouthing off, creating distractions.

LEAD: In the Jungle With Cinderella While telling stories around the campfire one night, Eric Hansen entertained his hosts in Borneo with a Malay version of Cinderella. This is from ''Stranger in the Forest: On Foot Across Borneo'' (Yolla Bolly/Houghton Mifflin).

LEAD: A 6-year-old boy was killed and three other children were injured in Harlem yesterday when a parked car, struck by another car that had accelerated out of control, careered onto the sidewalk where a group of children were playing, the police said.

LEAD: CRY OF THE OPPRESSED: The History and Hope of the Human Rights Revolution. By Robert F. Drinan. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) The Rev. Robert F. Drinan is a law professor and a Jesuit and was a congressman from Massachusetts for 10 years. Those credentials combine to make him a passionate and persuasive spokesman for human rights throughout the world.

LEAD: The engagement of Vivian Esther Steir to Dr. Douglas Stuart Rabin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney S. Rabin of West Chester, Pa., has been made known by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Berton Steir of Brookline, Mass. The couple plan to marry in September.
LEAD: At the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in Manhattan, Jeanine Lobodinski and George Marsh Flint 3d were married yesterday by the Rev. Charles A. Amstein.

LEAD: Not long ago, shortly after reading Tom Wolfe's ''The Bonfire of the Vanities'' and being dazzled by Michael Douglas's wardrobe in the film ''Wall Street,'' I put on a chalk-striped shirt with a white tab collar and walked around in it all day. It was a subsidized experiment; the shirt wasn't mine.
LEAD: Whatever happened to momentum?
LEAD: SEASON TICKET A Baseball Companion. By Roger Angell. 406 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $18.95.

LEAD: The Governor of Indonesia's disputed province of East Timor plans to ask the Suharto Administration to lift restrictions on travel and communications that have isolated the territory since Indonesia invaded and annexed it in the 1970's.

LEAD: Mobilized by Mexico's governing party, tens of thousands of workers, peasants and civil servants gathered in front of the National Palace here Friday to hear President Miguel de la Madrid honor the memory of President Lazaro Cardenas, who, 50 years earlier, ordered the takeover of foreign oil companies.

LEAD: Thirteen people, including four Americans, were injured tonight when a bomb exploded in a suburban Athens bar frequented by servicemen from a nearby United States Air Force installation, the police reported.
LEAD: THE final deals have yet to be cut, but already the floor is littered with scrapped amendments bearing the names of legislative stalwarts from both houses and both parties.

LEAD: There was more macabre violence at an Irish Republican Army funeral today as two armed British soldiers in civilian clothes drove their car into a crowd of panicked mourners and were, in turn, seized, beaten and finally shot to death.
LEAD: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, is to arrive in Washington on Sunday in search of a compromise that would ease the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan.

LEAD: Many audio manufacturers conduct training seminars for their dealers to assure that their products are presented in an informed way. At a recent session of this kind, the instructor asked for an explanation of the loudness control.

LEAD: THE MERE MENTION OF A WOMAN'S AGE once sent shudders rippling through polite society. The same was true in cosmetics advertising, with copywriters delicately discussing youthfulness instead. Today, as more women boast of their advancing years, cosmetics companies are tackling the subject with vigor and enthusiasm.
LEAD: To the Editor: How is it possible that the country that produces Hondas and Toyotas has produced Tokyo's Narita, the Edsel of airports?
LEAD: A United Nations team will visit Nicaragua as soon as possible to investigate the border conflict with Honduras, a United Nations spokesman said today.

LEAD: Executives of R. H. Macy & Company said yesterday that they would sell 11 of the 14 Abraham & Straus stores in New York and New Jersey if their concern succeeds in acquiring the corporate parent of A.& S., Federated Department Stores Inc.

LEAD: In an art scene that is already in danger of being swamped with idle talk about money - the latest record set by a van Gogh, the latest sale of a Julian Schnabel or the real size of Andy Warhol's estate - nothing could have been better calculated to make this unlovely situation even worse than it is than the recent ruling by the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs requiring that the prices of paintings and sculptures in New York's art galleries be ''conspicuously displayed'' for all visitors to exhibitions.

LEAD: To grasp the scope of the phenomenal growth and prestige of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament, one needs only to listen to Jim Hull, the captain of the 1939 Ohio State University basketball team. Hull recently recalled his team's thoughts when his coach, Harold Olsen, told them they were going to play in the first N.C.A.A.

LEAD: THE Long Island Seafood Dumpling House in the Merrick Mall Plaza is a restaurant in transition. When first visited, it had a sign outside that said East West Cafe, and so did the menu. The staff answered the phone with ''Good evening, East West Cafe.'' Since December, the restaurant has been operated by the Queens Dumpling House of Rego Park.

LEAD: AS a nurse in the same geriatric ward for a few years, I've periodically been restless for a change but never acted upon my wish for it. A few weeks ago, I finally requested to switch from days to the night shift. After waiting with mixed feelings, I was notified to start on nights the day after my vacation was through.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Montagnie Van Norden of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Juliana Van Norden to Craig Donald Wynne, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Thomas Wynne Jr. of Chagrin Falls, Ohio, and Vero Beach, Fla. The couple plan to marry in May.

LEAD: Holly Mather Stevens, a vice president and the director of media planning at DeWitt Media in New York, and Christopher Duncan Bell, a stockbroker at Equitable Securities of New York, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley officiated.

LEAD: In the verdant hills that rise and roll here, and in the rich valley nestled below them, the talk is of return.
LEAD: THE THIRTEENTH MAN A Reagan Cabinet Memoir. By Terrel H. Bell. 195 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95.

LEAD: A description of music by the Dutch composer and saxophonist Willem Breuker is inevitably a set of lists: tangos follow be-bop, brass band music merges with snarling free jazz, and unaccompanied saxophone solos follow Hollywood versions of Arabic music. Mr. Breuker is an eclectic, and like such fellow pastiche artists as the composers Carla Bley and Henry

LEAD: Nancy Colbert Friday, a writer, and Norman Pearlstine, the managing editor of The Wall Street Journal, are planning to marry this summer, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Eugene H. Scott of Lewiston, N.Y., have announced.

LEAD: WE asked 10 computer users familiar with the Macintosh and the I.B.M. PC's, PS/2's and compatibles to take the standard desert island test. ''If you were stranded and could have only one computer, which would it be?'' The findings of this unscientific survey, which has a margin of error of 100 percent, reveal more about the users who inhabit the different computer universes than about the merits of the two categories of machines.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration, wary of a possible political backlash on Capitol Hill, has rejected a proposal to use American helicopters to transport Honduran troops to the battle zone where Sandinista forces have been fighting rebels, a senior Administration official said today.

LEAD: Q. I live in a condominium, and the wall I share with the next unit seems paper-thin. I inquired about having insulation blown in to keep out noise but was told this was impossible because of fire barriers in the wall. Is there a way to soundproof this wall?

LEAD: The Rev. and Mrs. Leslie Flynn of Nanuet, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Linda Flynn to Jeremy Wadsworth Symington, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Wadsworth Symington of Washington. A June wedding is planned.
LEAD: HE played basketball for Vince Lombardi and he scouted for Bobby Knight, and now he has defeated Knight as a coach. In between, Dick Tarrant taught in high school and had ''holes in my shoes.''

LEAD: FOR much of its length between West Germany's Black Forest and the Black Sea, the Danube is a waterway for sturdy freight barges. The swift flow of the river, one of the world's fastest commercial waterways, deters leisurely boating. Dams and locks help control flow and aid navigation on a river that is shallow, quirky and full of character and vitality.
LEAD: MARY JANE PANULLO said that ever since her son, Cary, was given an electrocardiogram last year as part of his high school pre-football physical, she has rested easier.

LEAD: On Jan. 1, 1753, an 18-year-old Londoner named Elizabeth Canning celebrated the New Year at the home of her uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Colley. At 9 that night she left for the home of the Lyon family, where she was a housemaid. The Colleys accompanied her. When they left Elizabeth, she had less than a mile to go.

LEAD: At the John Street United Methodist Church in New York, Bonnie Kennedy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman Kennedy of Leawood, Kan., was married yesterday to Paul Cox, a son of Dorothy Godfrey of Floral Park, Queens, and the late Paul E. Cox. The Rev. Dr. Warren Danskin officiated. The bride, a graduate of Russell Sage College, is a technical resource analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities in New York.

LEAD: A picture caption on Jan. 24 with an article about Antigua, Guatemala, misstated the market days for the town of Chichicastenango. They are Thursday and Sunday. A brief accompanying report described Antigua's bus services incorrectly. The Greyhound company does not operate in Guatemala.

LEAD: ON the same day last week that two of his former top aides were formally charged as criminals for their covert efforts to carry out Administration policy in Central America, Ronald Reagan took one of the most open and public steps available to a President: He ordered American troops to foreign soil.

Wilson, praised C. S. Lewis for a clever portrayal of ''the devious processes of the diabolical mischief-makers,'' adding that ''somewhere in the inferno there must be considerable annoyance.

LEAD: IN 1985, Jose Feghali sprang to international fame when he won the Van Cliburn Competition in Texas. Tonight, the young Brazilian pianist will be one of the judges at the Annual Marcia Polayes Competition in Sprague Hall in New Haven.
LEAD: Almost everyone likes fairy tales. Children like their fantastic plots. Sophisticated grown-ups like their symbolism.

LEAD: THE setting is Washington and the subject Soviet-American relations, but when the Soviet Foreign Minister calls on Reagan Administration officials this week the domestic political fortunes of his country's leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, will be inextricably linked to the talks.

LEAD: L. RON HUBBARD: Messiah or Madman? By Bent Corydon and L. Ron Hubbard Jr. (Lyle Stuart, $20.) The Church of Scientology is a bizarre cult, and its founder and leader, L. Ron Hubbard, was a ''cosmic outlaw,'' in the words of L. Ron Hubbard Jr. There is little of the son in this book but a good deal of Bent Corydon, who headed one of the Scientology ''missions'' in California during the 1970's until Hubbard decided to take over these lucrative franchises, leaving their well-rewarded leaders bewildered and broke.
LEAD: Nothing in the article on New York Hospital by M. A. Farber and Lawrence K. Altman substantiates its damaging title, ''A Great Hospital in Crisis'' (Jan. 24).

LEAD: A musical tribute to the composer Frederick Loewe will take place on March 29 at 1 P.M. at the Shubert Theater, 225 West 44th Street. Julie Andrews, Richard Harris, Robert Goulet, Louis Jourdan, Agnes de Mille, Kitty Carlisle Hart and others will take part. Mr. Loewe died last month at the age of 86.

LEAD: MEMBERS of the New Jersey Supreme Court are to be congratulated for the depth and comprehensive nature of their judgment in the Baby M case. However, the complexities of the issues are such that they are likely to defy resolution by a single judgment.
LEAD: The jury in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. secretly went to Central Park yesterday morning to visit for a second time the site of Jennifer Levin's death.

LEAD: THE BEST OF DE GUSTIBUS. By Marian Burros. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Marian Burros has talked turkey in The New York Times about food, drink and much more in the kitchen cabinet or on the restaurant menu. Now, in the first collection from her De Gustibus column, which began in 1983, she offers recipes, reminiscences, letters from readers, information on ingredients and nutrition, as well as her emphatic opinions on such restaurant esoterica as dining vs.

LEAD: ABOUT 55 percent of the 23,000 people who live in Starrett City, a Brooklyn housing complex, are white; the remaining 45 percent are black or Hispanic. The managers of the 46-building complex have kept that balance by giving preference to white applicants, who account for only about one in five on the waiting list.

LEAD: STUDYING a few papers spread out over a barren desk with his oversized reading glasses, the ''Old Man,'' as aides call Yasir Arafat, appears serene, almost bookish, a far cry from the fearsome image of the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
LEAD: New England boat builders are diversifying, making sculptures and ornaments for buildings as well as custom-made yachts, to compensate for a flagging market.

LEAD: ONCE upon a time in the kingdom of Nassau County, there lived a King and Queen (anyone who owned a home in this kingdom was considered a King and Queen). Anyway, one evening this particular royal couple went to bed. All the lights were out and the castle was very, very quiet. The couple were about to fall asleep when suddenly they heard a noise coming from another part of their domain.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: When John Lennon was assassinated on Dec. 8, 1980, it seemed that a particularly vivid chapter in the history of popular music had come to an abrupt end. Of course, in the most literal sense, it had: Lennon's ''approved'' creative works - his contributions to the Beatles catalogue, his post-Beatles solo disks, the handful of songs he wrote for other performers, his two books of humorous poetry and short stories, and a number of artworks, films and video productions - would have to stand as a definitive and finite record of the material he considered ready for release.
LEAD: IN 1982, a film maker named Michael Marton began shooting a documentary on an amateur boxing program in Catskill, N.Y., run by Cus D'Amato, the septuagenerian manager and trainer.

LEAD: For Christmas, a (male) friend gave Z our two young sons some pretty authentic-looking handcuffs. They were the hit of the season. I was frankly astonished to see my two little angels arresting each other and goose-stepping around the house. But my husband took it for granted. He said: ''Well, of course.

LEAD: SENATOR Bill Bradley flew up from Washington last week to tell New Jersey Democratic leaders once again that he would not be a candidate for President and to urge them to drop any plans to send an uncommitted slate of delegates to the Democratic National Convention with him as its head.

LEAD: Stepping up their violent effort to stop national elections here on Sunday, Marxist guerrillas have killed one mayor and kidnapped two others in recent days, burned a mayor's office, exploded several bombs and burned cars, trucks and buses to paralyze road traffic.

LEAD: The engagement of Elliot Davis to John Sebastian Paolella, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Paolella of Paramus, N.J., has been announced by her father, Dr. E. William Davis Jr. of New York and Old Westbury, L.I. The couple plan to marry in June.

LEAD: A 29-year-old Branford woman was sentenced to one year in prison Friday for abducting a baby from Yale-New Haven Hospital in October 1986. The woman, Maureen Mead, was sentenced to five years in prison, suspended after one year, followed by five years' probation. Superior Court Judge John Ronan also ordered Ms.

LEAD: INSULIN INJECTIONS, SCIENTISTS HAVE LONG known, are merely a way to manage diabetes - not cure it. Diabetics no longer die of comas induced by excessive blood sugar. But they do die, before their time, of a range of complications directly related to the hour-to-hour fluctuations of blood sugar, or glucose, that persist even with insulin therapy.
LEAD: Stacey King scored 9 of his 37 points during a three-minute stretch when Oklahoma took command, and the Sooners crushed Auburn, 107-87, today in the second round of the Southeast Regional.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Prof. Robert M. Garrels, a prominent geologist, died of cancer of the colon on March 8 at his home in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 71 years old.
LEAD: A TIME OF CHANGE A Reporter's Tale of Our Time. By Harrison E. Salisbury. 352 pp. New York: A Cornelia and Michael Bessie Book/ Harper & Row. $19.95.

LEAD: I was on my way to the Houston FotoFest, just about to board the shuttle bus to my hotel, when I ran into my friend Elaine. Instead of the Leica M4 she usually wears, she was sporting the latest compact-VHS video camcorder. She had just begun recording her own documentary of the outskirts of Houston when my nose appeared in her finder.

LEAD: DR. DEVRA MARCUS, a Washington internist, left private practice to work in a prepaid health plan, but felt she had to resign after about a month. The plan, she said, ''cast decision-making in terms of finances.''

LEAD: Sallie Hibbs Gibson's engagement to Robert Patrick Fitzgerald Jr., a son of Mr. Fitzgerald of Boston and the late Sally Shaughnessy Fitzgerald, has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. E. Martin Gibson 3d of Corning, N.Y. The couple plan to marry in July.

LEAD: While immersed last week in the magnificent original cast recording of Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine's fairy-tale musical, ''Into the Woods'' (RCA Victor 6796-2RC; all three formats), I was reminded of how crucial a cast album can be to the future reputation of a show. If the score is first rate and the performances finely tuned, no matter what a show's short-term commercial fate, its cast album will keep the music circulating and win for it future champions who may never have seen it produced.

LEAD: A crowd of 6,021 gathered at the Rutgers Athletic Center today to bid farewell to Sue Wicks, the Lady Knights' superstar who was playing the final home game of a career unmatched by any player, male or female, in school history.

LEAD: Howell Raines describes a friend of Prince Charles, Laurens van der Post, as ''an 80-year-old author and anthropologist, with a New Age mystical streak.''

LEAD: SPUDS MacKenzie is tending goal. It's the last shot of the game, and Spuds makes an incredible save. The skillful maneuver by Anheuser-Busch's mascot is part of an Olympian effort to convince Americans that drinking is harmless and all-American. But during the next Olympiad, the ads may have a new twist.
LEAD: Meir Amor, a captain in the Israeli reserve army, has just completed a 21-day jail sentence for refusing an order to serve in the occupied territories.

LEAD: ''It is not an offensive building,'' said Jonathan Paskow, the developer of an almost completed, 22-story condominium at 255 West 85th Street. ''It's ugly,'' said John Kowall, chairman of Community Board 7.

LEAD: To the Editor: As a repeat visitor to Cologne, I enjoyed ''What's Doing in Cologne'' by John Dornberg (Travel, Jan. 31) and learned about a few more places to visit.
LEAD: Ben Strohecker is a chocolate maker with unconventional ideas about running a business.

LEAD: Though widely acknowledged as a major figure in American modern dance, Doris Humphrey created work whose measured tone and intellectual underpinnings have made it seem relatively inaccessible, and unsusceptible to revivifying personal interpretation. And so the Philadelphia Dance Theater's presentation of five Humphrey dances, on Thursday at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, was very welcome.
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:

LEAD: On April 4, 1865 - 123 years ago, almost to the day - Abraham Lincoln visited Richmond, for the only time. The very morning after the Confederate capital fell to his Union forces, Lincoln walked, unannounced, into the heart of the city. To his surprise the newly freed black population turned out to greet him with ''wild, indescribable, ecstatic joy,'' in the words of one contemporary journalist.
LEAD: To the Editor: Regarding the inquiry about Alaska ferries (Q & A, Feb. 21), let me report on my agreeable journey on the Alaska Marine Highway last summer.
LEAD: A year after he retired as the Rutgers rowing coach, Bill Leavitt is back at the team boathouse, but not, it turns out, to second-guess the new coach, Steve Wagner.

LEAD: American audiences -and perhaps others, too -often seem to expect Spanish performers of classical music to, somehow, be Spanish, in a way that, say, German or English performers aren't expected to look or act German or English. Despite the dignity and reserved platform manner of such eminent musicians as Pablo Casals, Andres Segovia, Nicanor Zabaleta or Alicia de Larrocha, an outmoded view of Spain persists, a Spain that seems to have something to do with the extravagantly dressed, impassioned performers in '

LEAD: PHYSICIANS, dentists and other professionals with offices in residential buildings in New York City are usually in an ambiguous situation when the buildings face cooperative or condominium conversion.

LEAD: BEYOND the coffin, out in the churchyard, red-haired Kathleen Quinn was full of fun and flirting shamelessly for all her eight years of life. ''Mister, I'm to be on the TV tonight,'' she told a stranger, squinting up happy and prim. Kathleen had taken her brother's bike and skinned her knee bloody, all while people were praying goodbye inside the church to another rebel body in another coffin.

LEAD: The Malaysian Government of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, whose political party was ruled illegal by the Kuala Lumpur High Court last month, used Dr. Mahathir's large parliamentary majority this week to push through legislation curbing the power of the judiciary.

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts maintained their strength from the Southern primaries in conventions today that will affect the allocation of 64 Texas delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

LEAD: Weeks This Last On Week Week Lis t Fiction 1 16 2 THE ICARUS AGENDA, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) A congressman's secret dealings with terrorists may bring him the Presidency - or death. 2 1 20 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe.
LEAD: COLOR is said to be the most complex, yet the most exciting, aspect of design. In painting, color is both fact and illusion.
LEAD: Senator Albert Gore Jr. scored the victories he had hoped for on Super Tuesday, winning five states and propelling himself into the front rank of the Democratic Presidential candidates.

LEAD: The worst thing was the isolation. Howard Russell can remember vividly the tormenting suspicion that he was different from everybody else in Hinesburg, the western Vermont farming community where he grew up.
LEAD: Rejecting the assertions of tobacco companies, a cancer specialist testified this week that a longtime smoker died of lung cancer caused by cigarette smoking.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur B. Gnaedinger of Pelham Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Howe Gnaedinger, to John Arlington Miles, a son of the late George Sackett Miles of Demarest, N.J., and Warren, Conn., and the late Mrs. Melvin Loos of New York.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''AT a hotel for the homeless, a child finds two pigeons. She brings them back to her hotel room. When asked what she will do with them, she says, 'I will release them, so they can find their way home again.' ''

LEAD: As spring rounds the corner, even the most buttoned-up dressers tend to relax, shedding their inhibitions with their heavy winter wraps. In the spring of 1988, that easygoing attitude will be embodied in loose-fitting, uncomplicated fashions that are certain to make last year's showy plumage seem as dated as a

LEAD: Prince Charles's influence in matters of architecture and inner-city rehabilitation has been felt here in Brooklyn, where neighborhood preservationists quote the Prince of Wales in speeches opposing high-rise luxury condominiums planned for our beloved shore front.

LEAD: If the Russians sincerely want to get out of Afghanistan, Washington should do everything reasonable to help them to the exit. Now it seems that the U.S. and Pakistan - and perhaps Moscow as well - are trying to gain marginal bargaining advantages and are losing sight of the central goal.
LEAD: Three black policemen were killed when two black men opened fire with automatic rifles on a group of people in the yard of a township west of Pretoria, the police said today.
LEAD: Trade Strawberry to Houston and bring Nolan Ryan back to New York. JOE LANDI New York

LEAD: ''SANDY HOOK pilots know a nor'west blizzard when it comes along, and every mother's son of them that got ashore yesterday with a whole skin was willing to swear by the piper that played before Moses that Monday's blow was a blow that could give Sullivan, Mitchell - or any other hard hitter - a deckload of points on the 'knocking out' business and come up smiling for an unlimited number of rounds.

LEAD: Merger activity has heated up. With the dollar at its lowest point in years, few restrictions on purchases of American stock and a liberal antitrust climate, investors are rushing to buy American companies. How long will this buying window remain open? J. TOMILSON HILL Managing director and head of mergers and acquisitions, Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

LEAD: Your article about the decline of the shipping industry noted that the local economy had undergone rapid change, but it failed to emphasize the benefits that change has brought. During the last 40 years, maritime industry has withdrawn from the Hudson waterfront, leaving much of it in a state of devastation.

LEAD: Frederick Joseph (Bun) Cook, who starred in the National Hockey League with his brother Bill for the New York Rangers in the 1920's and 1930's, died Saturday at Providence Manor, a retirement home. He was 84 years old.

LEAD: I find my history in novels - and only after the passage of time. The feminist novel, which flourished in the 1960's and 70's, held more than met the eye of the reader (and writer in some cases) at the time. Concealed within these tales are the seeds of many conflicts that bedevil the womens' movement, and women, today, though even if we had been prescient enough to recognize them then, the issues would have remained stubborn, defiant and perhaps insoluble.

LEAD: Award Dinner March 22 - Lee A. Iacocca will receive the Democratic Legacy Award of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith at a black-tie dinner at the New York Hilton. Cocktails at 6 will be followed by dinner, the presentation and entertainment by Marvin Hamlisch. Tickets $500; 212-490-2525.

LEAD: THE HUNDREDS OF ROPE bridges that once spanned the chasms in the Peruvian Andes were testaments to the engineering skills of the Incas. Part of the elaborate system of roadways within the vast empire known as Tahuantinsuyu, the bridges contributed to the remarkable commerce and communication that the

LEAD: There were five newcomers Wednesday night in the Metropolitan Opera's ''Contes d'Hoffmann'' cast, but the most striking was a familiar face: Placido Domingo in the title role. Hoffmann surely counts among the celebrated tenor's best parts. It suits his voice admirably, and he invests the acting with all his considerable intelligence.
LEAD: A FRIEND FROM ENGLAND By Anita Brookner. 205 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $15.95.
LEAD: Waves of Iraqi planes pounded Iran's biggest oil terminal today, leaving at least two tankers ablaze in the northern Persian Gulf. Iran said it shot down three Iraqi planes.
LEAD: The Mets shouldn't handle Strawberry; he should be traded to an American League team for a premier left-handed reliever and, hopefully, a young catching prospect. CARL PRINCE New York

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Arnold I. Burns of Washington and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Susan Burns, to Narses Jose Colmenares, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jose Colmenares Azuaje of Caracas, Venezuela. The couple plan to marry in July.

LEAD: NO CEILING BUT HEAVEN. By Mykal Mayfield Banta. (St. Martin's, $13.95.) This is a first novel both violent and overwhelmingly sad. ''No Ceiling but Heaven'' is the strife-filled tale of the Midwestern Harden family, as narrated by the mentally retarded Johnny. The Hardens' difficulties center mostly on Bobby, Johnny's twin brother, who is angry and destructive, a borderline psychopath.

LEAD: The engagement of Anne Simpson Cudlip to Wilfred Augustine Finnegan 3d, a son of Mrs. John G. Finnegan of Rye, N.Y., and the late Dr. Finnegan, has been announced by Nancy Clapp Cudlip of Waccabuc, N.Y., and William J. Cudlip of Grosse Pointe, Mich., parents of the future bride.

LEAD: 3-D ART As contemporary as it may seem, the concept of 3-D images is actually quite ancient. It all began when for the first time an artist tried to simulate the appearance of depth on a flat surface. With ''Seeing Is Believing: The History of 3-D in Art and Popular Culture,'' the Heckscher Museum in Huntington is exploring this cross between artistic endeavor, scientific technology and popular culture.
LEAD: Stakeout Starring Richard Dreyfuss, Emilio Estevez, Madeleine Stowe, Aidan Quinn. Directed by John Badham. 1987. Touchstone. 117 minutes. $89.95. Rated R.
LEAD: BLACK AVIATORS ''Black Wings,'' an exhibition tracing the history of black American combat and stunt pilots, is on view at the New England Air Museum through April 11.

LEAD: A proposed 399-mile natural gas pipeline in the Northeast is unacceptable because its route across the Appalachian Trail would create scenic and environmental problems, the Federal Department of the Interior said last week.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: NOTTING HILL is one of the liveliest of London's small villages.

LEAD: History disappears down the memory hole in ''Portrait of the Soviet Union.'' Good sense is flushed away, too. Ted Turner's three-part, seven-hour series is possessed by the same spirit that once led George Bernard Shaw to throw his dinner out the window of a Soviet train because food was redundant amid socialist milk and honey.
LEAD: DINNER at the New England Food Company in Danbury can be a rare gustatory experience, comparable to dining at the home of an exceptionally gifted cook who uses only the best fresh ingredients.
LEAD: MOZART FESTIVAL
LEAD: JEANNE COGHLAN is pretty sure that kissing her is a lot like kissing barbed wire. She hasn't been told this, but she said, ''I can't imagine a guy enjoying it.''

LEAD: Hispanic-Americans continue to lag behind other minority groups in entering the mainstream of higher education, a fact that seriously hinders their own economic aspirations as well as the development of the nation's future work force.

LEAD: THEY are a new breed of criminal in New York City: young members of crack-peddling gangs who murder on a whim. And though police officials say they are confident the gangs can be uprooted by methods that have worked before, other law-enforcement experts and social scientists are less optimistic.

LEAD: Q. I live in a condominium, and the wall I share with the next unit seems paper-thin. I inquired about having insulation blown in to keep out noise but was told this was impossible because of fire barriers in the wall. Is there a way to soundproof this wall?

LEAD: THE 25-year-old Icelandic grandmaster Johann Hjartarson achieved the triumph of his career by defeating the former Soviet - now Swiss - grandmaster Viktor Korchnoi in their preliminary world championship candidates match in Saint John, New Brunswick.
LEAD: LILI ELSIS slumped on her cellar stairs and put her head in her hands. ''We just moved all this in last Thursday,'' she said with a sigh.
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 29 food establishments cited for violating the health code.
LEAD: Mike Tyson, who has not fought overseas since he was an amateur, defends his world heavyweight championship against Tony Tubbs tonight in Tokyo.

LEAD: THE fact that subliminal messages have gone public does not mean covert messages have become extinct. In department stores there may be the subliminal sound of jail doors slamming or police sirens wailing to deter shoplifters. The music piped into a factory may be cautioning workers to be safe.

LEAD: THERE I am in the bathroom in the early morning, and I am looking in the glass. An elderly person stares at me, and I wonder how he got in the house. A guest of my children? Or did we leave the back door open last night? He does resemble me, though. I know what you are saying, little mirror on the wall.
LEAD: AT a period of peak prosperity, Long Island faces many critical issues that must be solved if we are to continue as the jewel of the New York State economy.
LEAD: Bundled-up visitors to Rockefeller Plaza taking in the daffodils that also braved the last day of winter.

LEAD: Give Strawberry a break. The Mets shouldn't ''handle'' him at all; they should leave him alone. If I were managing the Mets, I'd put Strawberry in the cleanup spot, day in and day out, night after night. TIMOTHY MUSKAT Ithaca, N.Y.

LEAD: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 2 FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.95.) The vicissitudes of a son of the 60's on his way to the 80's. 2 4 BOUND BY DESIRE, by Rosemary Rogers. (Avon, $4.95.) An untamed rogue pursues a maiden through the romantic spots of 19th- century Mexico, Paris, London and Spain.
LEAD: Arizona won't push Seton Hall around on Sunday afternoon.
LEAD: Mayor Koch asked about 150 local politicians and education officials yesterday to help him lobby the State Legislature for increased aid for New York City's public schools.

LEAD: THE philistines laughed, of course at the outrageous notion: Pay up to $29,000 for a slice of bare concrete no bigger than 8 1/2 by 18 1/2 feet?

LEAD: The marriage of Catherine Carroll Culhane, a daughter of Mrs. M. Carroll Culhane of Waterbury and Milford, Conn., and the late Dr. Culhane, to Peter Maximus Kennedy 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kennedy Jr. of Rye, N.Y., took place yesterday at St. Margaret's Roman Catholic Church in Waterbury. The Rev.

LEAD: An American envoy, Philip C. Habib, arrived here today to seek the backing of the Egyptian Government for an American plan for peace in the Middle East. President Hosni Mubarak has called the American plan ''encouraging'' but suggested, without specifics, that some of its provisions be elaborated.

LEAD: THOSE of us fortunate enough to live our lives without physical disability - to rush off to work, hurry home, shop, play - seldom wonder what life would be like if confined to a wheelchair, on crutches or having to cope with some other handicap.

LEAD: Terry Waldo, a pianist and singer with a rich repertory of jazz and popular material ranging from the days of ragtime to the swing era, is at the Fortune Garden Pavilion leading a group as deeply involved in this music as he is.

LEAD: IT'S hard to identify one particular place that spells Alaska. The Great Land is so diverse, so vast, that no one city or destination can act as a symbol. Still, after spending a few days in Seward, a frequent visitor to the state is tempted to suggest that this small town on the Kenai Peninsula is a good choice for those wishing to sample ''the real Alaska.
LEAD: ON THE southern edge of Claremont Channel, a grim slip on Jersey City's well-worn waterfront, a rattling conveyor belt carries the squashed remains of old automobiles up to a hopper.
LEAD: OFFICIALS hope an experiment in eastern Connecticut can offer clues to help remove people from the welfare rolls.
LEAD: SPRING is here, and with it, spring-cleaning. When a well-known politician said last fall that she and her husband needed a wife, it wasn't a new idea to me.

LEAD: THE dot that represents Madeira on world maps lies roughly at the level of Casablanca in the Atlantic Ocean, a half-inch or so off Morocco. Close inspection transforms the dot into a sunny, colorful little volcanic archipelago 340 miles from the African coast, composed of one main island called Madeira, high and green, another small sandier one, Porto Santo, which serves mainly as a beach resort, and several uninhabited bits of rock, the Desertas, which float attractively on Madeira's horizon and offer tourists on day cruises a chance to explore, and the more distant Selvagens.
LEAD: ''YOU EVER HEARD OF the pol-mil weenies?'' asked Susan F. Rasky, a colleague at The New York Times.

LEAD: Rebuffing the Reagan Administration, Panama's military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, has rejected an American offer to let him leave the country without facing extradition to the United States on drug charges, senior Administration officials said today.

LEAD: MARS TUGS AT THE HUMAN IMAGINATION like no other planet. With a force mightier than gravity, it attracts the eye to its shimmering red presence in a clear night sky. The mind vaults to thoughts of what might have been (if Mars were a little closer to the Sun) and of what could be (if humans were one day to plant colonies there).

LEAD: Classical music-lovers should be amply familiar by this time with the name of Roger Norrington, the English specialist in the period performance of 19th-century music. Mr. Norrington's Beethoven symphony recordings have been almost universally admired, and his recent Berlioz weekend in London's Queen Elizabeth Hall, capped by ''authentic'' accounts of the ''Symphonie Fantastique'' and ''Romeo et Juliette,'' were almost more revelatory than his Beethoven.

LEAD: Merrimack produced a memorable comeback tonight against Northeastern by scoring seven straight goals to defeat the Huskies, 7-3, in the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey tournament.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John Grantham Ballard of Mercer Island, Wash., and Honolulu, have announced the engagement of Mrs. Ballard's daughter, Shauna Marie Lehv, to Frank G. Binswanger 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Binswanger Jr. of Philadelphia. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: A caption on page 22 of The Times Magazine today, under the heading ''Russia Enters the Race,'' misstates part of the Soviet Union's plan to explore Phobos, one of Mars's two moons. Both Soviet craft are to engage in laser-aided analysis of the moon and send hoppers to its surface; the tasks are not allocated to one craft apiece.

LEAD: EVERY year, about half a million teen-agers have babies - often creating lifelong difficulties both for themselves and their children. Increasingly, experts are documenting the links between adolescent motherhood and a host of social ills that range from low birthweight to poverty to dropping out of school.

LEAD: Militant Irish nationalism kindles the music of the Wolfe Tones, who played for a boisterously adoring audience Thursday at the Ritz. Rough-hewn traditionalist songs, many with explicit pro-Irish Republican Army and anti-English lyrics, have made the group hugely popular in Ireland.

LEAD: Jeryl Lynn Hilleman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Maurice R. Hilleman of Lafayette Hill, Pa., was married yesterday to William Alexander Albright Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albright of Lafayette, Calif. The Rev. Richard Thayer performed the Protestant ceremony in the Stanford Memorial Church at Stanford University in Palo Alto,

LEAD: A woman about to board a bus for Washington with about two and a half pounds of cocaine was arrested Friday with a companion at the Port Authority bus terminal, the authorities reported yesterday.

I also tell people that while in the Marine Corps I was a weapons instructor at Parris Island, playing a vengeful god in the much-storied style of the
LEAD: The stove police would like this village of peanut fields, dusty trees and mud-brick houses.

LEAD: Susan Butcher took her dogs for a run across Alaska March 5. Last Wednesday night, 11 days, 11 hours and 42 minutes after she left Anchorage, Ms. Butcher and her dog team pulled into Nome, 14 hours ahead of her nearest competitor in the 16th annual running of the 1,150-mile Iditarod Trail Dog Sled Race.
LEAD: IN a departure from traditional roles in education, the East Williston School District has made selecting new teachers the responsibility of the district teachers themselves.

LEAD: To be ''site specific'' is to go on location with a play, to take it out of the theater and stage it in a natural environment. In pursuit of that objective, the En Garde Arts company has presented plays in a vacated automobile showroom and, with the help of projections, on the facade of an apartment building.
LEAD: Union workers at the only United States automobile assembly plant operated by the Mazda Motor Corporation have ratified a contract with the Japanese concern.
LEAD: Four days after we were married, I gave my beloved a tie. I'd shopped for hours and paid too much, but he was worth it.

LEAD: Six candidates had filed petitions to oppose Gov. Evan Mecham in a recall election May 17 as the petition deadline passed Friday.

LEAD: The world rushes in to the new Talking Heads album, ''Naked'' (Sire 25654 LP, cassette and CD) - and the results are marvelous. After a pair of disappointing albums and nearly two years of splinter projects, Talking Heads have regrouped for an album recorded in Paris with American, African, British, Irish and Caribbean musicians.

LEAD: Dr. Jennifer Suzanne Hock, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Hock of Great Neck, L.I., was married there last evening to Dr. Bruce Alan Brod, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth L. Brod of Broomall, Pa., and Manahawkin, N.J. Rabbi Mordecai Waxman, assisted by Cantor Henry Weintraub, officiated at Temple

LEAD: JULY MAY MARK THE official beginning of barbecuing season, but those with a passion for grilled foods gladly overlook such formalities. In deep winter, these people can be found scraping the snow from their grills; in spring, they huddle under umbrellas as they cook.

LEAD: ''IS THIS going to be a war?'' the 18-year-old woman asks the psychoanalyst who is out to get at her innermost secrets and get out the truth behind her neurosis, while she challenges him every step of the way.

LEAD: The cast for the Metropolitan Opera's production of Mussorgsky's ''Khovanshchina'' Thursday night included a number of singers who hadn't appeared in the season's first performance. Chief among them was Paul Plishka, singing his first Dosifei with the company.

LEAD: Churches were given increased protection from libel suits when the California Supreme Court ruled against a woman who said she had been defamed by a minister who called her ''one of the enemies of God's church.''

LEAD: Anthony DePalma's moving article ''From Fathers to Sons on the Waterfront'' (Feb. 21), about the declining waterfront industry, presents a human dimension that has been largely invisible to the public.
LEAD: SPRING is the traditional time for lamb. A roast, scented with herbs and served with new potatoes, steamed young carrots and peas is one of the many highlights of the season.

LEAD: Gretchen Young, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Norman Young of New York, Quogue, L.I., and Miami, was married yesterday to John Andrew Baxter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Colin Ian Wright Baxter of Los Angeles. The Rev. Andrew J. W. Mullins performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in Manhattan.

LEAD: ON Dec. 5, 1905, a man bundled in furs against the 60-degree-below temperature stepped off a sled on the frozen Yukon River, walked into the town of Eagle and asked where he could send a telegram. The message he sent (over a telegraph line constructed five years before to send military communiques) announced the discovery of the Northwest Passage; it was signed ''Roald Amundsen.

LEAD: Ask a man to name his favorite article of clothing, and he probably won't mention his most expensive suit or the elegant tuxedo he wears once a year. More likely, it will be something similar to the designer Bill Blass's old L. L. Bean boots, so comfortable, he says, ''I'll probably be buried in them.
LEAD: As he travels the industrial heartland, one of Michael S. Dukakis's surest applause lines is a pledge that reflects the economic anxiety pervading this region.
LEAD: NOT blessed with good looks, toads generally don't have too many friends among people. The Fauna and Flora Preservation Society in London is an exception.

LEAD: HEMLINES may rise and hemlines may fall, but trouser lengths stay pretty constant, stopping right there at the top of the shoe (or more and more frequently these days, tucking neatly inside a boot). Such comforting reliability may be one reason why so many women are turning to trousers to fill an ever-increasing number of sartorial bills.
LEAD: California has chosen a site for a low-level radioactive waste dump, a decision that made many people unhappy - because they wanted it in, or at least near, their backyards.

LEAD: WHAT we call London is really composed of many separate villages whose names often indicate their origins: Covent Garden was the market garden to the Convent of Westminster Abbey, and the Knightsbridge section grew up beside a bridge that crossed the Westbourne River where Hyde Park's Albert Gate stands today.

LEAD: AN outdoorsman who suffers from the pack-rat syndrome will eventually be choked by clutter whether his digs are modest or grand. At that point, he must begin to discard certain items, not only to gain breathing room, but also to save time lost in bouts of nostalgia while poking through his hoard.

LEAD: The former chief executive officer and co-founder of Radiation Technology Inc., an irradiation company, has been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiracy, obstruction of justice and violations of the Atomic Energy Act.
LEAD: Cuba has presented the United States with a proposed timetable for the withdrawal of its nearly 40,000 troops in Angola, the Government of President Jose Eduardo dos Santos says.

LEAD: The meeting between Soviet and American defense ministers here produced ''no breakthrough,'' as Secretary of Defense Frank Carlucci said. Still, it was a remarkable first, not spring but a sign of changing climate that can gradually lead to a dramatically different sense of the superpower confrontation.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Zeldon E. Rose of West Long Branch, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Susan Rose to Donnell Robert Dufford, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Darwin H. Dufford of El Cajon, Calif. An April 30 wedding is planned.

LEAD: An article in some editions last Sunday about a training program for generals in the United States Army misidentified a National Guard division involved in a battle simulation at Fort Leavenworth, Kan. It was the 47th Infantry Division.

LEAD: In 1982, 18 students from a high school in East Los Angeles took the Advanced Placement exam in calculus and passed. They received college credit for their high school work. The next year, 31 students from the same school passed, and the number has climbed steadily ever since. Eighty-seven students passed the test in 1987.
LEAD: The Israeli Army effectively blocked foreign journalists from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip today, apparently in an effort to reduce coverage of Palestinian protests.

LEAD: The Red Cross said today that units of blood that slipped through procedures tha guard against AIDS contamination were rendered harmless by processing or never actually carried the deadly virus.
LEAD: Many expert bridge players, and some not so expert, were part of an innovative international hookup at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here this afternoon.
LEAD: Whether they support or oppose the views of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel, Americans ought to be clear about the meaning of Security Council Resolution 242 of 1967.

LEAD: The engagement of Mary Frances Maher to Edward Mullins Hawley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Hawley of Los Angeles, has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. John R. Maher of Greenwich, Conn. An August wedding is planned.

LEAD: From a drawing to win a car in Chicago to discounts on hamburgers in New Orleans, public health agencies around the nation are seeking innovative ways to persuade parents to bring in their children for vaccines.

LEAD: The opinions, pro and con, on the Supreme Court's decision in the Hazelwood High School paper case [ ''Drawing the Line on Student Rights,'' Feb. 21 ] were interesting, yet both missed a point, i.e., reality.

LEAD: The destruction of the earth's protective ozone layer, set in motion by the release of industrial gases into the atmosphere, will continue for decades despite the best efforts of governments and industries to control it, scientists now agree.

LEAD: I REMEMBER William Holden telling Grace Kelly in ''The Country Girl'' that there are two kinds of women in the world: those who pay too much attention to themselves and those who don't pay enough.

LEAD: In a one-time resort now being transformed into a bedroom community, Henry V. Vaccaro is hedging his bets. Along with the first hotel to be built in Ocean Grove, N.J, in 50 years, Mr. Vaccaro plans 14 town-house condominiums. The combination resort-and-conference hotel will have 168 rooms and Victorian architecture.

LEAD: The beauty and majesty of the Hudson River have inspired artists for hundreds of years, and their interpretations have been expressed in many mediums. Opening today at the Lenoir Preserve Nature Center in Yonkers is an exhibition of nearly 75 photographs that capture a spectrum of river views, some in black and white, others in color.

LEAD: Trade him to the Dodgers for Kirk Gibson, straight up. Think of it. Darryl goes back to his hometown under the nurturing wing of Tommy Lasorda. If Darryl starts to open his big mouth at the wrong times, Tommy will stuff it full of good home-cooked pasta. Gibson comes to a contending team under the watchful eye of veteran players.

LEAD: EVER since Southern Democrats agreed to hold all of their Presidential primaries on March 8, political experts have debated whether New Jersey's primary on June 7 - traditionally one of the nation's best-covered elections - would still mean anything.

LEAD: Park Lodges Question:We are planning to visit the Grand Canyon, Bryce Canyon and Zion National Parks in May and want to stay in the parks. What accommodations are available? - B. Y. K., White Plains Answer:At the Grand Canyon's North Rim, which some visitors say has a more spectacular view than the South Rim, the sole hotel is the Grand Canyon Lodge.

LEAD: I feel sorry for Carol Reiman. In her essay (''Baby-Sitting Grandchildren: Love Them and Leave Them,'' Opinion page, Feb. 28), she announced that she did not want to baby-sit her grandsons. Simply put, it exhausted her.
LEAD: Considering how the Mets played last year, perhaps the team should listen to Strawberry instead of trying to figure out how to handle him. PETER J. CALLAHAN Newark, Del.

LEAD: To the Editor: In response to a letter (Travel, Feb. 7), Paul Delaney said he did not recommend the Hotel Colon in Barcelona because, among other things, the linens were not changed every day. I've never understood this complaint, which I've heard many times from travelers. How many of us at home have our bed linens changed daily?
LEAD: As the 1988 nesting season approaches for Eastern shore birds, seagulls on Monomoy Island still hold a commanding lead over the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.
LEAD: THE Internal Revenue Service has an April Fool's gift for some taxpayers: new rules dictating how much must be withdrawn from individual retirement accounts by April 1 to avoid a stiff penalty.

LEAD: N.B.A. 76ers 94, Bullets 89: Charles Barkley scored 27 points last night in Landover, Md., to lead Philadelphia to its third consecutive victory. The 76ers are a half-game ahead of the Bullets and the Knicks in the race for the final playoff berth in the East. Washington led, 80-76, after Jeff Malone's jumper with 7:43 remaining but did not score again until John Williams hit at 3:32.(AP)

LEAD: The engagement of Daphne d'Aubigny Moore to Douglas Andrew Butler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Butler of Orange, Calif., has been announced by her parents, Kathleen Roe Moore and John C. Moore, both of New York. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: WHEN contract negotiations stalled last fall at Echlin Inc., a Connecticut automobile parts manufacturer, union officials decided not to try a slowdown, strike or boycott. Instead, they took their case to the company's shareholders.
LEAD: NAME an obsession, a bad habit, a deficiency, or just a stage of life, and chances are some company has a subliminal cassette claiming to ease you through it.

LEAD: If Kenneth Keller had it to do over, he might just settle for a plain metal desk in battleship gray. Mr. Keller resigned as president of the University of Minnesota last week amid a continuing flap over the cost of renovations to his office and official residence. The bills for refurbishing the office came to $200,000, including $17,445 for a mahogany desk and credenza.

LEAD: ROOMS, the stock in trade of the hotel industry, have to be sold every day - a feat that becomes increasingly difficult when the supply is increased and the demand reduced. There is concern now that the county's hotel market has too many rooms and too few customers.

LEAD: THE debate in Washington over what to do about Central America's problems has underscored one essential point: though the United States may strongly influence the changes now shaking the region, it cannot bring an end to the conflicts.

Upstairs, as an investment counselor for Shearson Lehman Hutton, Mr. Joseph spends 10 hours a day consulting the green screen of his Quotron, the blue monitor of his IBM XT and the green display of his Bond Brain.

LEAD: Lisa Joy Lockwood, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Lockwood of North Woodmere, L.I., and John Bruce Winston, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Winston of Havertown, Pa., were married last evening. Rabbi Joel Y. Zion performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

Designed for thinning hair, a new crop of cosmetic solutions appeals to a man's vanity, offering all the hope and promise of youth. In fact, the name of one such lotion, from a Japanese company, translates as ''never-aging forest.

LEAD: An article on Jan. 31, about the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's investigations of possible crimes, reported allegations of wrongdoing at the Joseph M. Farley nuclear power plant in Dothan, Ala. Some charges were made by former employees at the plant who said they were dismissed because they raised safety questions.

LEAD: AFTER completing a shift at the Sixth Precinct in Manhattan, Officer Michael Fandal took a train to Seaford, L.I., to attend the funeral of Edward Byrne, the 22-year-old New York City officer who was shot to death as he sat in his patrol car guarding a witness in a narcotics case.

LEAD: IN A steamy bubble-domed enclosure on the Busch campus of Rutgers University here, 17 students marched to a rhythm without music, their cadence marked by the click of rifle butts against concrete, the slap of gloved hands against rifle stocks and the whoosh of twirling weapons.

LEAD: EDUCATORS won't be happy at first, predicted Ms. VandenBoogert of Potentials Unlimited, but bookstore owners will. The researcher, a former teacher, is putting the finishing touches on an accelerated learning program for children that is based on tapes using subliminal suggestion.
