LEAD: LAST. Always last. Despite my skills on the baseball diamond, I was mere dross as sides were drawn, unless a dork was the only other live body left.
LEAD: Chance and destiny, the possible and the impossible.

LEAD: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts won the Kansas Democratic caucuses today as the Rev. Jesse Jackson used strong showings in the state's larger counties to finish second. Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee was third.

LEAD: WISH YOU WERE HERE Starring Emily Lloyd (in photo), Geoffrey Hutchins, Tom Bell, Jesse Birdsall, Heathcote Williams. Directed by David Leland. 1987. Fries Home Video. 91 minutes. $79.95. Rated R.

LEAD: My professional life has been severely disordered by a call to jury duty in Nassau County. Though recognizing my responsibility as a citizen to serve, and beyond that being intrigued in anticipation of a new experience, I was and am worried: as a clinical social worker in agency and private practice, my extended absence would mean that depressed, anxious, sometimes abused or otherwise disturbed clients would go unserved.
LEAD: THE NEW PALGRAVE A Dictionary of Economics. Edited by John Eatwell, Murray Milgate and Peter Newman. Four volumes. 4,103 pp. New York: Stockton Press. $650.
LEAD: THE jury in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. began its deliberations last week caught in a crossfire between two out-of-town ''hired guns.''

LEAD: Twenty years after the Kerner Commission chastised the press for reporting the news ''with white men's eyes and a white perspective,'' a panel of black journalists said last week that newspapers and broadcasters had failed to recruit enough blacks into the nation's newsrooms.
LEAD: IT'S tough to be a monument in New York City.

LEAD: A PROPOSAL to change North Tarrytown's name to Sleepy Hollow was firmly rejected by residents of that village last week by a vote of 1,322 to 794. But proponents of the switch said they were a growing minority and would probably try again.

LEAD: The effect of Howell Raines's article was to leave me with admiration for Prince Charles, who, against enormous pressure, seems to have made himself something better than he needs to be. Why, then, does Mr. Raines say that Charles's education was ''a noble . . . experiment that backfired''? Judging from its results, it succeeded very well.

LEAD: FEIFFER ON CARTOONING Jules Feiffer, the Pulitzer Prize cartoonist, Obie Award playwright and Academy Award screenwriter, will lecture, with slides, on ''The Political Cartoon and the Media'' tomorrow at 8 P.M. in the Theater-in-the-Round on Seton Hall University's South Orange campus.

LEAD: An article on Dec. 27 about the business of advising parents misidentified the producer and distributor of ''The Children's Journal,'' a radio program. It is produced and distributed by Livy Morris Productions in Cincinnati.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. William Aloysius Eagan Jr. of Wellesley and Hyannis Port, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Joan Eagan to James Andrew Vahey 4th, the son of Mr. Vahey 3d of Rochester, N.H., and Laraine Winders of San Francisco. Miss Eagan, an associate at Chemical Bank in New York, graduated from the University of Virginia.
LEAD: When he was younger, Bob Froese worried about when he would get his next start. He would study the schedule, think he had figured it out, and end up regretting the whole discouraging procedure.
LEAD: A Crusade to Restore Sight HE downplays his credentials and speaks of his deeds in humble terms. Dr. Yale Solomon of Brightwaters is a modest man.

LEAD: To the Editor: Regarding Steven Barboza's article ''Going 'Home' to Africa'' (Travel, Feb. 21): His reference to Goree Island evokes a haunting, devastating experience. We -my husband and I - were there 10 or 11 years ago when visiting our daughter, then a Peace Corps volunteer in Senegal. The the slave house, the inscriptions on the walls, that flat rock from which the enslaved took their last step out of Africa are all indelibly incised in my memory.

LEAD: Hurrah for the Prince of Wales, who sees architecture not as an exercise in arcane esthetic principles enunciated by a professional priesthood, but as the living expression of the lives and aspirations of ordinary people (''Defying Tradition,'' by Howell Raines, Feb. 21).
LEAD: Deadline Set For Tickets to Seoul Games

LEAD: I FIRST visited the south of France in 1961. That is more than half my life ago, and I have returned often since. Like so many others, I find myself moved by that landscape - compelled by its long history, dazzled by its light. Some travelers are drawn to mountains, while some prefer valleys instead; for each pilgrim to the desert there is one who dreams of forests; for each lover of the lakefront there is one who wants the river.

LEAD: A simmering dispute here over leadership of the state's Democratic Party is threatening to tarnish the progressive and reformist image of Gov. Ray Mabus by raising the specter of racial politics three months after he took office.
LEAD: Illegal aliens are depressing wages and worsening working conditions for legal immigrants and native Americans in low-skilled and low-paying jobs, the General Accounting Office says.

LEAD: The European Space Agency has agreed, after two years of negotiations, to take part in the United States space station project and provide a laboratory module to be permanently attached to the earth-orbiting station.

LEAD: Jill Alyssa Garber, a registered nurse at the Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, and Dr. Todd Jay Cohen, a resident at Mount Sinai Hospital, also in Baltimore, are planning to be married May 29, the parents of the bride-to-be, Dr. and Mrs. Victor Garber of Watchung, N.J., have announced.
LEAD: Iris Neilsen, one of Australia's leading women jockeys, was killed in a fall during a race at Lismore Racecourse this afternoon, officials said.

LEAD: Jay Gatsby, Fitzgerald's fictional dandy, was the ultimate shirt connoisseur. He had only to ring up his personal buyer, and a cornucopia of elegant linens, silks and flannels would arrive. Most American men, however, buy their dress shirts the way they buy supermarket chicken - with a hasty examination of the parts visible through the plastic wrap and an assumption that what's hidden will be fine.

LEAD: Samson, a 30-year-old western lowland gorilla believed the oldest breeding male gorilla in captivity, has died at the Brookfield Zoo. The 400-pound gorilla suffered a stroke and died Thursday, said a zoo spokeswoman, Linda Elbert.
LEAD: Saudi Arabia confirmed Saturday that is is buying Chinese intermediate-range missiles, but said they would not be armed with nuclear warheads.

Msgr. Joseph Corbineau performed the ceremony.

LEAD: To the Editor: My sister and I visited Senegal last summer and found it the most uplifting of all our many excursions to foreign lands. Other black Americans that we met shared our enthusiasm. True, the street hawkers were desperate in their selling tactics, yet the Senegalese that we spoke with were quiet and dignified.

LEAD: FOR the last decade, public school districts throughout New York State have been forced by declining enrollment to make important decisions that will affect the future of their students, faculty and educational programs.

LEAD: As is the case with many coaches, there are similarities in the way John Chaney of Temple and John Thompson of Georgetown go about their jobs, blending the roles of surrogate parent and drill instructor. Thompson jokingly talked today about how he called the Hoya players just about every nasty thing he could think of during the course of the regular season, reaching a point where the players thought they were probably the worst and dumbest team ever to play for him.
LEAD: Afleet, who may have been the nation's best miler as a 3-year-old last year, made a winning seasonal debut yesterday with an impressive victory in the $110,800 Toboggan Handicap at Aqueduct.

LEAD: I guess I loved Cher the most the night she showed up at the Academy Awards looking like a tarantula. The academy had, pointedly, failed to nominate her for her top-calibre work in ''Mask'' - a calculated disciplinary action that sent shivers down the spine of every former teen-age girl in the audience who had ever been called into the principal's office for yet another futile round of ''life style correction'' measures.
LEAD: THE 1988 Democratic Presidential campaign has become a marathon steeplechase, in which candidates run, fall, get up and start running again.

LEAD: A small civilian airplane crashed today on Quantico Marine Base as it tried to fly out of a snowstorm, killing all three people on board, the authorities said. They said the single-engine Cessna 210 left Greensboro, N.C., at 8:25 A.M. and was headed for National Airport at Washington. A Marine spokesman said the plane crashed in a field between a chapel where services were in progress, and Lejeune Hall, the base headquarters.

LEAD: Nearly a month after he forced President Eric Arturo Delvalle out of office, the Panamanian military strongman, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, is more besieged and isolated than ever. But he has shown no further willingness to end the 10-month political crisis in his country by voluntarily relinquishing power.

LEAD: Mikhail Gorbachev has launched another disarmament proposal. He must be up to several dozen in his three-year tenure, but who's counting? In his latest, made last week in Yugoslavia, he proposes to freeze the number of Soviet and American warships in the Mediterranean and then to withdraw the fleets altogether.

LEAD: Zhao Ziyang, in his first major elaboration on China's political future since his formal appointment as Communist Party chief last November, has called for the development of a type of town hall democracy throughout the country.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A Delta Air Lines jet with 76 people aboard made an emergency landing this afternoon after its landing gear malfunctioned, and one wing caught fire briefly as it scraped the runway, the authorities said. No one was injured.

LEAD: A 41-year-old man who was accused of snatching $20 from a woman in a bakery in East Harlem was fatally beaten yesterday by more than a dozen angry people who chased and caught him about a block from the store, the police said.

LEAD: Skiing Downhill Title for Zurbriggen: Karl Alpiger of Switzerland won the final men's downhill of the World Cup season and Pirmin Zurbriggen clinched his second straight World Cup downhill title yesterday. Alpiger had a time of 1 minute 44.48 seconds down the course at Are, Sweden, which was shortened to 2,890 meters because of strong winds and poor visibility.
LEAD: The panel appointed to review policies and programs of the United States Olympic Committee, with George Steinbrenner as chairman, has begun work. Its report is due next month.

LEAD: WHETHER from beach or mountain, meadow or city park, scanning the night skies is among summer's sweet pastimes. And with a little study a beginner will soon be able to identify many of the major constellations or their more prominent members.
LEAD: Industry in the United States and abroad is moving aggressively to curb uses of chemicals believed to be destroying the earth's ozone shield.
LEAD: Matthew A. Howard, who has been with Sears, Roebuck & Company for 26 years, has been named senior executive vice president of merchandising for the Sears Merchandise Group.

It didn't require genius for David Henry Hwang to see that there were the makings of a compelling play in the 1986 newspaper story that prompted him to write ''M. Butterfly.'' Here was the incredible true-life tale of a career French foreign service officer brought to ruin - conviction for espionage - by a bizarre 20-year affair with a Beijing Opera diva. Not only had the French diplomat failed to recognize that his lover was a spy; he'd also failed to figure out that ''she'' was a he in drag. ''It was dark, and she was very modest,'' says Gallimard (John Lithgow), Mr. Hwang's fictionalized protagonist, by half-joking way of explanation. When we meet him in the prison cell where he reviews his life, Gallimard has become, according to own understatement, ''the patron saint of the socially inept.''

LEAD: William Moersch's instrument is the marimba, and he is drawn to contemporary works that challenge his technical and interpretive skills. On Thursday evening, he brought five recent scores to Alice Tully Hall for a performance that was impressive and at times transfixing. Particularly appealing was a new concerto by Richard Rodney Bennett.
LEAD: The local appeals court here today set aside a ruling by a three-judge panel that a gravely ill pregnant woman could be forced to undergo a Caesarean delivery in an attempt to save the fetus.

LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Seeking a knockout blow in its battle to win Federated Department Stores, the Campeau Corporation made higher offers to both Federated's shareholders and board yesterday.

LEAD: The Intel Corporation is expected to announce Wednesday an alliance with Micron Technology Inc. that will help pave the way for Micron to increase its production of computer memory chips, industry executives said today.

LEAD: For much of its 135-year history, Manhattan College was the bootstrap used by many blue-collar Irish and Italian families to achieve a better life. But as those groups continue to climb the social ladder, Manhattan College finds itself looking to to two new groups to survive and grow - children of the affluent and of the urban poor.

LEAD: A prosecutor accused of fabricating death threats against herself during extradition proceedings for two Sikhs charged with terrorism gave F.B.I. agents a description used to make a sketch of a suspect, a defense lawyer said yesterday.
LEAD: President Reagan called again today for renewed aid to the Nicaraguan rebels as the White House worked to fashion a contra aid package that could win bipartisan support in Congress.

LEAD: A new town that is the spiritual headquarters of a cult is being built just north of Yellowstone National Park, and area residents and park officials say their worst fears about it are close to being realized.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''By putting my signature beneath the dishonest materials of the Communist Party, you have insulted me before the whole country. I am obliged to beg forgiveness not only of the Armenian people but also before all honest people of our country.'' - Yuri Arakelyan, a Pravda correspondent, to his editor.
LEAD: A Brooklyn man was sentenced to three to nine years in prison yesterday for a 1986 automobile crash that killed a Bronx couple on the Interborough Parkway.
LEAD: Japan, which has outclassed the United States in the manufacture of cars, cameras and electronic goods, is now out to prove that it can make a better domed stadium, too.

LEAD: HARRIET and Leon Powers made a fortune selling fine linens at a discount in Louisiana, then lost it when the local economy crashed. So they moved back to their native Dallas a year ago, determined that their next line of work would involve no inventory whatever. ''I didn't want to end up stuck with millions in unsold fabric again,'' Mrs.

LEAD: Tuition prepayment programs allow parents to pay a flat fee now that will cover the future cost of college at a given school when their child is ready to enroll. The programs guarantee that the child's education will be paid for, regardless of tuition increases in the intervening years. * Is there a maximum annual amount that can be contributed?

LEAD: In the battle for the Democratic Presidential nomination, there is no group comparable to the superdelegates, the 646 Governors and members of Congress and the Democratic National Committee who will automatically attend this year's Democratic convention. And the battle for their votes in now in full fury.
LEAD: DeAndra Anrig was flying a kite when it suddenly started to fly her, her parents say. It was just a short hop, but one that DeAndra, who is 8 years old, is not likely to forget.
LEAD: Janet Evans being congratulated yesterday after setting the 800-meter freestyle world record in Orlando, Fla. Page A24. (AP)
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Governor Cuomo's chief representative in talks with the Long Island Lighting Company said today that he believed a public takeover of the utility now would cost too much and that he would prefer to see the state ''sit and wait, watching the company deteriorate.''
LEAD: A settlement was reached early today ending a one-day strike by thousands of Stop & Shop supermarket workers in Connecticut and in western Massachusetts, a company spokeswoman said.

LEAD: The chief of the Environmental Protection Agency, alerted by a letter of protest from agency scientists, has barred from an E.P.A. report on a toxic gas any data that the Nazis acquired in experiments on concentration camp prisoners.
LEAD: Tart bons mots fly across the stage of the American Place Theater in ''Tallulah Tonight,'' Helen Gallagher's one-woman salute to Tallulah Bankhead.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Sam W. Reynolds, a businessman who was appointed a United States Senator and served for seven months, died at home of pneumonia Sunday. He was 97 years old.
LEAD: As a Federal bankruptcy judge began final hearings today on the reorganization plan of Texaco Inc., the company said two potential obstacles to ending its yearlong bankruptcy had been removed.

LEAD: The Black & Decker Corporation yesterday called off its takeover bid for American Standard Inc., in return for a $25 million payment from Kelso & Company, which last week agreed to buy Standard for $2.5 billion.

LEAD: John A. Maurer, an inventor who developed 16- and 8-millimeter sound recording and reproduction systems, died of a heart attack Sunday at the Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 83 years old and lived in Somerset, N.J.

LEAD: WITH its red and white ice-cream parlor tables, pastry display case and nonstop espresso machine, Romolo's is a virtual institution in San Mateo, about a half-hour south of San Francisco. Many Italian-American clubs and Italian restaurants in the Bay Area rely on Romolo's for their desserts, and residents rely on it for respite and cappuccino during the week and for special treats at

LEAD: Under pressure from the United States, Taiwan has stopped work on a secret installation that could have been used to obtain plutonium, a main ingredient in nuclear weapons, according to Administration officials.
LEAD: The United States filed a lawsuit in Federal court in Manhattan today in an attempt to force the Palestine Liberation Organization to shut its observer mission to the United Nations.

LEAD: Rates are scheduled to change April 3. The E stamp was printed as an interim stamp before the increase was officially approved. Among the rate increases: Letters . . . 25 cents Extra ounce . . . 20 cents Post cards . . . 15 cents Article, page D26

LEAD: There is no evidence that G. D. Searle & Company withheld information from the Food and Drug Administration in winning approval for its Copper-7 intrauterine contraceptive device, an F.D.A. spokeswoman said today.

LEAD: When Jim Burnley climbs behind the wheel of his white Mustang V-8 convertible and slaps in a rhythm-and-blues cassette into the tape player, he might not be instantly recognizable as the nation's Secretary of Transportation.

LEAD: Phil Stinnie matched his career high with 34 points and Virginia Commonwealth eliminated the defending champion, Southern Mississippi, from the National Invitation Tournament with a 93-89 victory tonight.
LEAD: The Central American isthmus makes life hard for headline writers.
LEAD: The Senate has refused to cancel a new 30-year nuclear cooperation agreement with Japan that critics say could promote the spread of nuclear weapons.

LEAD: The ticket lines are endless, the planes are late and now fares are going up. Coach class jumped 10 to 40 percent last week on many popular routes, and restrictions were tightened on discounts used by many business travelers. Is airline competition dying, a victim of increased market concentration and monopoly pricing?

LEAD: Orders to the nation's factories for durable goods fell 1.8 percent in February, the Commerce Department said today. Although it was the second consecutive monthly decline, analysts said it did not shake their belief that manufacturing will be a bright spot in the economy this year.

LEAD: The Rural Electric Cooperative Grantor Trust established by the Kansas Electric Power Co-op is offering $62.4 million of grantor trust certificates in two parts through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.
LEAD: F.B.I. Harassment Charged

LEAD: Reaching deep into a drawer, Ruth Mitchell grabbed a fistful of job forms and splayed them across the desktop. ''Messenger, forklift operator, dental assistant,'' she said, glancing at form after form. ''This employer wants a secretary who can type 40 words per minute and speak Korean.''

LEAD: A new Air Force report has raised questions about some conclusions of an often-cited 1984 Government study that was supposed to be ''reassuring'' for Vietnam veterans exposed to the herbicide Agent Orange.

LEAD: President Reagan presented a new Presidential Medal of Freedom to the White House chief of staff, Howard H. Baker Jr., on Monday after the original was lost in a break-in at the Baker home in northwest Washington. Mr. Baker ''is probably the only person who has received two Medals of Freedom,'' a White House spokesman said.

LEAD: A self-described paramilitary retribution gunman, his eyes blackened, his face puffy, was charged today with the murders of three mourners in a grenade attack here last Wednesday on an Irish Republican Army funeral.
LEAD: Overriding President Reagan's veto, Congress voted by large margins today to extend the reach of Federal civil rights laws.

LEAD: Dr. Patrick Steptoe, the obstetrician who inaugurated a new era in 1978 when one of his patients delivered a baby girl conceived in a laboratory dish, died Monday in Canterbury, England. He was 74 years old Dr. Steptoe's family said he had been suffering from cancer.
LEAD: Greg Bathon, one-time president of J. Walter Thompson U.S.A., a unit of the WPP Group, has joined Burkhardt & Christy, an $8 million agency with 12 employees.
LEAD: ''Philadelphia is not as bad as Philadelphians think it is.'' That message, seen on a billboard here not too many years ago, was meant to be complimentary.
LEAD: Mohammed Ag Mahamoud, a descendant of the fierce Tuaregs once called lords of the desert, crouched behind a sand dune and weeded his carrots.

LEAD: Ronald S. Lauder, the former Ambassador to Austria and heir to the Estee Lauder fortune, is preparing to seek the Republican nomination to challenge Representative George J. Hochbrueckner, a Democrat, in the First Congressional District of eastern Suffolk County.

LEAD: Charlie Colon riding his bike around the Unisphere in Flushing Meadows Corona Park in Queens as the temperature reached 43 degrees yesterday. Today's temperature is expected to climb to 52. (NYT/Barton Silverman)

LEAD: Since the 1984 Olympics, when he won three gold medals in swimming, Rowdy Gaines has earned hundreds of thousands of dollars for endorsements and appearances. For two years, he also coached young swimmers on a team called the Las Vegas Gold. Now, at age 29, though he is not in gold-medal shape, Gaines wants to swim with the Gold in the 400-meter freestyle relay Friday in the Phillips 66/U.S.

LEAD: The Supreme Court, striking down key portions of a 50-year-old law, today cleared the way for protesters to conduct hostile demonstrations near foreign embassies in the District of Columbia as long as they do not disrupt embassy activities or threaten security.
LEAD: To The Living Section:

LEAD: LAMB has not been high in favor in this country in recent years, and mutton, its adult counterpart, is almost entirely unknown in modern butcher shops. Once a feature of Colonial banquets, a boned leg of mutton slowly spit-roasted before a bank of embers is something few of us will have the good fortune to taste.

LEAD: On Monday, students at the University of Rhode Island camped in the lobby of Keaney Gymnasium, one underclassman pitching a pup tent, others toting mattresses. Music played, there were card games, and a festive air pervaded.

LEAD: A report on Sunday in the Going Out Guide of the New Jersey Weekly incorrectly described admission to a lecture this Friday by Representative Patricia Schroeder at William Paterson College in Wayne. Tickets are not free; they cost $10 ($8 for students, faculty members and the elderly).

LEAD: Aquatic dancing in the Columbia University swimming pool, an experimental performance series at P. LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Alice Dresel Beal Van Santvoord, a patron of artists and a contributor to theatrical and educational institutions, died of complications following surgery Friday at St. Luke's Hospital in Newburgh, N.Y. She was 95 years old and lived in Newburgh.
LEAD: Anna Quindlen's column will appear regularly on page C2 in The Home Section starting tomorrow.
LEAD: Hollywood has a new ''in'' drink. At cocktail parties and premieres all over the area and throughout the film industry, Perrier has given way to Diet Coke as the drink of choice.
LEAD: The Senate Intelligence Committee expressed ''grave concerns'' today about American ability to monitor Soviet compliance with a proposed treaty limiting long-range nuclear missiles.

LEAD: The CSX Corporation, a diversified transportation company, agreed to sell its oil and gas subsidiary, the CSX Oil and Gas Corporation, to the North American unit of a leading French energy concern, Total Compagnie Francaise des Petroles, for $612 million in cash.
LEAD: A long dispute between several states and the insurance industry over the reduction or elimination of liability coverage for local governments reached a turning point today.
LEAD: The South African Government closed a leading anti-apartheid newspaper for three months today after declaring that it was bent on stimulating revolution.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: GARY CARTER looks around at the talent in the Mets' training camp and he knows he had better switch to Plan B. Plan B involves him catching long enough to break Bob Boone's ongoing record for most games caught in ''oh, five years or so.'' His hamstrings have no comment.

LEAD: Charles Merrill Mount, a scholar and art historian who is charged with transporting documents stolen from the Library of Congress and National Archives, went on trial today, denying the allegations but predicting he would be convicted.

LEAD: Video cameras and monitors watch over the characters in Atom Egoyan's ''Family Viewing'' with the patience and passivity of vultures, but without the enthusiasm. The advent of this modern technology seems to have drained all vitality out of the participants in Mr. Egoyan's very peculiar black comedy, and it's their listlessness that makes them so funny and sad.

LEAD: If Gene Wilder undertook an all-Oriental takeoff on ''The Night of the Living Dead,'' he might come up with something like ''A Chinese Ghost Story.'' Ching Siu-Tung's spooky spoof, which plays at the Museum of Modern Art today at 6 and Friday at 8:30 P.M. as part of the New Directors/New Films festival, features a klutzy hero who keeps falling into pools and puddles; a supernatural seductress who slaughters her lovers on behalf of her evil master, Lord

LEAD: The jury in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. begins its seventh day of deliberations today, apparently concentrating on the internal injuries medical examiners found on the body of Jennifer Dawn Levin.
LEAD: Supporters of Pat Robertson will apparently control the Nevada Republican convention next month as a result of county conventions held last weekend, party officials say.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Sandinista and contra leaders offered differing proposals for a cease-fire during their second day of talks at a southern border outpost. The head of the contra delegation, Adolfo Colero, said that progress had been made. Page A1 Renewed aid for the contras was called for by President Reagan as the White House worked to fashion a contra aid package that could win bipartisan support in Congress.

LEAD: * The Leonard Group, Elizabeth, N.J., to Keyes Martin Gaby Linett, Springfield, N.J., for Beauty Barn and Health Fair stores, two New Jersey retail chains.
LEAD: The Miami City Ballet, directed by Edward Villella, presented more of its dancers in New York debuts with the company Sunday afternoon at Whitman Hall at Brooklyn College.

LEAD: The Men's Tennis Council has approved a bonus system designed to combat competition from lucrative exhibition events that conflict with official Grand Prix tournaments. ''We want to eliminate the confusion caused when other events clash with Grand Prix tournaments in which players are competing for world rankings,'' said Marshall Happer, administrator of the council.

LEAD: Even though Nicaraguan troops have been withdrawn from Honduras, American military officers said today, the United States will keep its expeditionary force of 3,500 soldiers here for 10 days more to stand watch and to train.

LEAD: Elie Wiesel, the chronicler of the Holocaust, decided yesterday to cancel a day of lectures scheduled for tomorrow after learning that the lectures were underwritten by a conservative Michigan publisher who has been accused by the Justice Department of being an agent of the South African Government.

LEAD: The Israel Chamber Orchestra is a finely polished ensemble with a lovely string sound and winds that play firmly and precisely. Like most orchestras, it has its strengths and weaknesses in matters of repertory, and its director, Yoav Talmi, let us see some of each in a Sunday afternoon concert at Carnegie
LEAD: General Assembly HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

LEAD: Congress has wisely and firmly turned back one of the most important political challenges to civil rights in recent years. The vote to override President Reagan's veto of the Civil Rights Restoration Act reconfirms a solid bipartisan consensus in Congress. It also catches the Reagan Administration, once again, on the wrong side of a civil rights issue.
LEAD: Keith P. Fischer, the former president of a number of agencies, has added still another agency to the list. This time it is MacNamara, Clapp & Klein, billing about $48 million.

LEAD: A Japanese court today found the Toshiba Machine Company guilty of selling militarily sensitive technology to the Soviet Union, but it imposed a light fine on the company and gave suspended prison terms to two former executives.
LEAD: ''There's no change,'' Gov. Michael S. Dukakis protested as he pledged his support for tough new trade legislation.
LEAD: WHEN Manfred Esser was at the Harvard Business School, at one of those middle-management programs a few years ago, he put on a wine tasting for his classmates.
LEAD: A major diplomatic effort by the Reagan Administration involving Angola and South Africa appears at an impasse, according to several diplomats and Government officials.

LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote of 292 to 133 by which the House of Representatives today overrode President Reagan's veto off a civil rights bill. A ''yes'' vote was a vote to override the veto and enact the law. A ''no'' vote was a vote against it. Voting ''yes'' were 240 Democrats and 52 Republicans.
LEAD: Stock prices ended mixed in light trading yesterday after moving in a narrow range for most of the day.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, began crucial talks today on nuclear arms reduction and other issues to set the stage for a summit meeting in Moscow this spring.
LEAD: A year and a half and 25 yards have amounted to a world of difference for Ted Sator.

LEAD: Hunter College announced yesterday that Jeff Bieder resigned as basketball coach after four seasons in which his teams had a record of 58-52, including a 17-12 mark this season. Bieder has taken a job as basketball coach at Long Island City High School. . . . Bobby Dodd, the former Georgia Tech football coach, has been released from an Atlanta hospital after undergoing chemotherapy.

LEAD: The classroom is in the Correctional Institution for Women on Rikers Island, and the students, all young women, are awaiting trial or serving short sentences - almost all on charges of selling drugs.
LEAD: A fire that started in a kitchen raged across Lashio, a northern Burmese city, killing 113 people and leaving 20,000 homeless, the Government radio reported tonight.

LEAD: Esther Shapiro and Aaron Spelling Productions are key members of the team that brought forth ''Dynasty.'' Now, sensing that fantasies about fabulously wealthy schemers may have run their course as the Reagan years draw to a close, the producers have decided to become more reality-oriented. As usual in the dizzy world of entertainment, reality is a relative concept.
LEAD: Roy Tarpley set a club record with 24 rebounds and scored a career-high 29 points tonight, leading the Dallas Mavericks to a 124-105 victory over the Knicks.

LEAD: An article on Sunday about money owed to the Federal Government by the nuclear power industry misidentified sponsors of a Senate amendment to require the industry to pay $8.8 billion. They are Senators Gordon J. Humphrey, Republican of New Hampshire, and William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin.

LEAD: Women addicted to the tightly swathed, brilliantly colored, sexy dresses that have become Emanuel Ungaro's signature need not worry. Even though, like most other designers, he's changing his style, some things remain constant.

LEAD: The New York State Board of Elections, under criticism recently for its apparent laxity, conducts such cursory examinations of campaign filings that violators of the state's contribution limits are almost never caught and even blatant discrepancies in campaign accounts are often not investigated.
LEAD: Leaders of the Sandinista Government and Nicaraguan contras offered differing proposals today for a cease-fire when they met for their second day of talks at this southern border outpost.

LEAD: IMAGINE a lipstick that moisturized every time a woman puckered up or kissed, or a foot powder that provided more antifungal relief with every step. These are two of many applications now possible with microsponges, microscopic synthetic spheres that can be ''programmed'' to release cosmetic or pharmaceutical agents in response to pressure, time or temperature.

LEAD: In some way, the education of every college student in the country is financed from the public trough. Taxes pay tuition, taxes buy books, taxes build buildings. We provide subsidies because, as Jefferson instructed, higher education is for the common good: It trains the country's professionals, improves morals, and forms in students the ''habits of reflection and correct action, rendering them examples of virtue to others, and of happiness within themselves.

LEAD: A State Supreme Court Justice, acting on a petition from the police patrolmen's union, has ordered the Koch Administration to defend a new policy that would require candidates for police sergeant to complete 64 units of college credit.

LEAD: Hockey players, who spend half their season on the road and often have several days of free time between games, eat in restaurants almost as much as they play on the ice. It's no wonder that so many have entered the restaurant business as a sideline to their profession.
LEAD: Demonstrators protesting the handling of a special grand jury investigation into the case of Tawana Brawley today blocked the main entrance to the armory where the panel meets.
LEAD: The West German Cabinet today approved a much-debated tax-change plan that is designed to reduce the nation's net tax bill by 20.7 billion marks, or more than $12 billion, starting in 1990.

LEAD: BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Placed Mike Mason, pitcher, on waivers for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release. PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Traded Jeff Stone and Keith Hughes, outfielders, and Rick Schu, infielder, to the Baltimore Orioles for Mike Young, outfielder, and a minor-league player to be named later.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: It began as a rumor, and today it ended that way. There will be no deal between the Yankees and the Toronto Blue Jays that will bring George Bell, last season's American League Most Valuable Player, to New York for Dave Winfield.

LEAD: SINCE the famous paper crunch of the late 1960's, the securities industry has been searching for new ways to guard against counterfeiting of stocks and bonds. Placing special codes that a computer reads on the certificates has caused problems because computers read only the codes and cannot distinguish between bona fide certificates and good imitations.

LEAD: The night has a thousand eyes, but thank heavens most are friendly. In ''The City Never Sleeps,'' nighttime in New York is inviting. The WNBC-TV film, on Channel 4 at 7:30 tonight, says darkness brings an eccentric congeniality to the streets. Even if that's not all it brings, the film is amusing.
LEAD: The Vatican has been invited to send a delegation to the Soviet Union for a major religious celebration in June, but Pope John Paul II will not attend, a senior Vatican official said today.

LEAD: Chemical Bank, a subsidiary of the Chemical New York Corporation, announced yesterday that it had been appointed financial adviser to the Department of the Interior. The appointment is connected to the sale of the department's loan portfolio.
LEAD: ANYONE who has ever prepared a meal with a process called sous vide, which involves putting ingredients in a plastic pouch and cooking them, raves about the wonderful tastes that result.
LEAD: With a pledge of better service, the Postal Service said today that it would institute higher postage rates, including a 25-cent charge for first-class letters, beginning April 3.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: EVEN among the high-rise structures now going up in the west midtown section of Manhattan, the 55-story residential structure nearing completion on Eighth Avenue at 57th Street is a standout.

LEAD: Senator William Proxmire, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the Banking Committee, today assailed a proposed compromise that he said would weaken the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act.

LEAD: LAMB has been a traditional springtime food in the Middle East since Biblical times. It is appropriate to serve lamb for Passover, but rules govern the preparation, and are subject to various interpretations.

LEAD: A dedication ceremony for the collected newspaper columns and memorabilia of the late Red Smith will take place this afternoon in the Rare Book Room of the Hesburgh Library at the University of Notre Dame. The sportswriter's widow, Phyllis Smith of New Canaan, Conn., gave the Red Smith Collection to the Rev.

LEAD: SCIENTISTS at the General Electric Company have come a step closer to marrying the new high-temperature superconductors to silicon-based integrated circuits by depositing a superconducting thin film on a silicon wafer. Superconductivity is the ability of a substance to carry electricity without resistance.

LEAD: Chiat/Day of Los Angeles, San Francisco and New York, opened an office in Chicago in January to woo the Nissan Mid-West Super Group, made up of dealers in 25 markets in the Middle West who spend $5 million a year on advertising. Chiat/Day was interested since it is already serving the national Nissan account.

LEAD: For the second year in a row, the number of serious crimes in New York City rose in 1987, with murders up 5.7 percent and aggravated assaults up 12.1 percent, according to Police Department figures released yesterday.

LEAD: Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House, has had testy relations with the Republican minority since assuming office more than a year ago. Republicans have charged him with dictatorial tactics, and they openly mourn the departure of Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Mr. Wright's predecessor, who retired in 1986 after 10 years in the job.

LEAD: Charging in legal documents that the city had inadequately trained the police officers who he said punched and taunted him, Dwight Gooden of the Mets is suing the city of Tampa and three officers who arrested him after a scuffle Dec. 13, 1986.

LEAD: The worst thing that ever happened to ''Julius Caesar'' was its adoption by teachers nationwide as the ninth-grade student's ideal introduction to Shakespeare. In countless classrooms, ''Julius Caesar'' became the play that was Good for You - a sodden launching pad for earnest discussions about the perils of democracy, despotism, mob rule and .
LEAD: An Armenian correspondent for Pravda has disavowed an article published over his signature, an article that dashed Armenian hopes for a favorable resolution of territorial demands.

LEAD: IN French terminology, a dish with tomatoes, garlic, olive oil, peppers, olives and saffron is considered to come from the Mediterranean regional tradition. Such dishes are gaining in popularity, and chicken is one of the easiest and most appropriate foods to cook in Mediterranean style.

LEAD: Six American artists - Christopher Brown, James DeMartino, Susan Hauptman, Albert York, Daisy Youngblood and Susan Lichtman -have been honored for their work by the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters. Each artist will receive a $5,000 cash award at a ceremony in May. More than 100 works by the six artists are on view through March 27 at the academy's galleries, on Audubon Terrace between 155th and 156th streets.
LEAD: The price tag for four years of college will approach $80,000 at some of the nation's campuses next September, about the cost of a modest house in many parts of the country.
LEAD: The National Endowment for the Humanities announced today that it was providing money to establish a research center to improve history instruction in elementary and secondary schools.

LEAD: Suzy Frelinghuysen, a former opera singer and a painter whose work is increasingly recognized by collectors and museums, died of a stroke on Saturday in Pittsfield, Mass. She was 76 years old, and had homes in New York City and Lenox, Mass.

LEAD: Burgville is a fast-food town. You come in from the east, half mad with hunger after the long drive from Washington, and suddenly it's all spread out along the highway in front of you, and you cry, ''Paradise at last!''

LEAD: * American General Corp., Houston, a provider of financial services, named Joe D. Heusi president and chief executive of Maryland Casualty Co., Baltimore, its principal property-liability insurance company.

LEAD: John T. De Palma , former chairman of Republic National Bank of New York in the mid-1970's, died Saturday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 76 years old and lived in Cranford, N.J.
LEAD: To The Living Section:
LEAD: Israel said today that it was detaining 3,000 Palestinians in connection with the protests in the occupied territories, including 700 arrested in the last week alone.

LEAD: Two Cabinet officers warned Japan today that failure to end its curbs on imports of beef and citrus products by the end of this month would provoke punitive action by the United States within the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

LEAD: A fire in a Bronx crack den killed two people early yesterday and injured five others, including two people described as squatters who jumped from the roof. The authorities said that the fire in the city-owned building had been set and classified the deaths as homicides.

LEAD: In a move to encourage land reform and create a real estate market, China began accepting bids today from foreign investors who want to buy long-term leases to develop sites here. Diplomats and members of the foreign business community saw the act as historic because control of land by foreigners has been taboo since the Communist armies marched down the Bund here in 1949 and declared that all foreign property belonged to

LEAD: MARTIN SORRELL'S London-based WPP Group is suing the newly formed Lord, Einstein, O'Neill & Partners, the six men who founded the agency and Young & Rubicam, which has invested in it. They are charged with conspiring to take business from Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, the WPP subsidiary they quit en masse last
LEAD: George Lehr, a former State Auditor in Missouri who was credited with helping to clean up the scandal-plagued Teamsters Union Central States pension fund, died at his home here Monday.
LEAD: To The Living Section:

LEAD: SKIING Another Victory for Tomba: Alberto Tomba of Italy captured his sixth World Cup slalom victory of the season yesterday, finishing just ahead of Tetsuya Okabe of Japan in Oppdal, Norway. Tomba had runs of 57.30 seconds and 55.45, for a combined time of 1 minute 52.75 seconds, 55-hundredths of a second faster than Okabe's.
LEAD: Home Box Office has a history of building its boxing programming around multifight deals with fighters it thinks will become headliners.

LEAD: Paul Fireman, the owner of the Reebok shoe company, hopes to decide by tomorrow whether to buy the New England Patriots and straighten out their financial status. ''At this time, we are continuing intense negotiations with William H. Sullivan, owner of the team, and Francis Murray,'' said Fireman in a statement released Monday.

LEAD: Kosher Competition The traditional thick, sweet wine for Passover has considerable competition. Dozens of dry white and red kosher wines are available, including Champagnes, Chiantis, Beaujolais, Bordeaux whites and reds, and California cabernet sauvignons.
LEAD: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration announced a new policy today, ordering its inspectors to examine hazardous areas of factories and not just job injury and illness records.
LEAD: Alexander F. Giacco, a leading American chemical industry executive, has been named vice chairman and chief executive of Montedison S.p.A.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Southland Corporation said today that it was raising $320 million for its recent leveraged buyout through a loan from its convenience-store licensee in Japan.

LEAD: A border dispute between Afghanistan and Pakistan has emerged as a new obstacle to a treaty ending the Afghan civil war and allowing the withdrawal of Soviet troops, according to officials close to the negotiations.
LEAD: Last year, when Janet Evans broke three world swimming records, she lost one of them to an East German 23 days after she set it. Today, she regained that record.

LEAD: The dispatch of American and European warships to the Persian Gulf was eventually organized into an effective operation despite the sloppy start. ''It worked,'' says Adm. Pierre Lacoste, former head of France's secret service, ''and because it worked you don't hear that it is working.''

LEAD: James H. Webb Jr., who angrily quit last month as Secretary of the Navy, is still a popular man on campus at the Naval Academy in Annapolis. Seven years ago Mr. Webb, a 1968 graduate of the Academy, wrote a fictional novel, ''Sense of Honor,'' based on his experiences at Annapolis as a midshipman.

LEAD: An article on the Fashion page yesterday about the fall and winter showings in Paris incorrectly ascribed one of Karl Lagerfeld's collections. It is produced by the House of Karl Lagerfeld, not by Stillman.

LEAD: A Pennsylvania woman has accused the Federal Bureau of Investigation of trying to coerce her into making false and damaging statements about a black F.B.I. agent who had brought charges of racism against the bureau.
LEAD: Nolan Ryan's fastball thudded into Wally Backman's right forearm today at about 93 miles an hour. Backman was miffed.

LEAD: At a recent discussion of forthcoming college tuition increases, the president of Kalamazoo College in Michigan raised some eyebrows among his colleagues by declaring that he was considering writing an ''honest letter'' to parents for the first time.
LEAD: There has been intense interest among judges and lawyers in the capital over who will be named to the Federal appeals court here to replace Judge Robert H. Bork, who resigned early last month.
LEAD: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes were virtually unchanged yesterday as traders shrugged off several items of economic news that on other days might have started a rally.

LEAD: Apparently bending to pressure from President Jose Sarney and Brazil's powerful armed forces, a Constitutional Assembly voted in favor tonight of maintaining this country's presidential system of government.
LEAD: Northwest Airlines is expected to announce today that it will become the only major American carrier to ban smoking on all its United States flights, an industry official said last night.

LEAD: Eastern Air Lines filed an appeal today of a Federal judge's rulings that barred the carrier from selling its East Coast air shuttle service and threatened hefty fines if the company proceeded with the deal. The airline asked United States District Judge John H. Pratt to reverse his own March 10 contempt finding against Eastern for trying to sell the shuttle, said John J.

LEAD: The entertainer Merv Griffin raised his bid for Atlantic City's Resorts International Inc. today by 31 percent, to $295 million, apparently trying to entice the casino company's controlling shareholder, Donald J. Trump, to sell his interest. Last Thursday, the former talk show host said he would bid $35 a share, or $225 million, for Resorts class A and

LEAD: Four Palestinians who had sought political asylum in Sweden were ordered expelled today for undisclosed security reasons, Erik Lempert, a senior official of the Labor Ministry, said. The order was issued after Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson's Government met in a special session to consider their appeal against a ruling by police and immigration authorities that they leave the country, he said.
LEAD: Mayor Koch's nominee from Staten Island to the Landmarks Preservation Commission was approved by the City Council yesterday, ending a 14-month battle by Anthony M. Tung to hold on to the post.

LEAD: FIRST signs of spring (however blustery) in Greenwich Village, as spotted by J. Porter Reilly: cooing mourning doves near St. Vincent's Hospital, budding ailanthus twigs at Greenwich Avenue and Eighth Street, swelling crocus stalks in Washington Square and, the surest one of all, this sign in the window of the A.
LEAD: A reputed leader of the Medellin drug cartel escaped after a shootout between his bodyguards and soldiers at a country estate near here early today, the army reported.
LEAD: The Economy
LEAD: The Ark Sakura By Kobo Abe Translated by Juliet Winters Carpenter. 336 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

LEAD: If there is one lingering criticism of Dean Smith's basketball program at North Carolina, it is that his teams do not win championships. And on March 13, when the Tar Heels lost the title game of the Atlantic Coast Conference Tournament for the third time in four years, that talk surfaced again.
LEAD: Ending months of speculation, President Francois Mitterrand, a 71-year-old Socialist, said tonight that he would seek a second seven-year presidential mandate.
LEAD: A small study has found that an experimental treatment that stimulates the immune system can double the survival rate of patients in the early stages of lung cancer, a scientist reported today.
LEAD: Two New York-area experts stepped out of their usual role and captured a major title at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here Monday night.

LEAD: In sharp contrast to recent practice, the Iran-Iraq war has become focused on offensives far from the major battlefronts on land that Teheran views as decisive in determining the eventual victor.

LEAD: It's no fun inside a burning clown house, even while the audience is shrieking with laughter. Shotgun shells keep going off, black-powder smoke squibs keep detonating, and puffs of flame keep exploding alarmingly. No wonder, then, that clowns will go to almost any lengths to escape: They'll go so far as to jump into a net held by a clown fire brigade.
LEAD: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today approved the restarting of the Tennessee Valley Authority's Sequoyah Unit 2, a $2 billion reactor closed in 1985 for safety deficiencies.
LEAD: The forces of Carlo de Benedetti came up short today in their latest effort to gain majority control of Societe Generale de Belgique, Belgium's largest company. Compagnies Europeennes

LEAD: President Reagan likes to warn Congress that his ''veto pen'' is ready whenever Congress is considering legislation he opposes, but the record shows that he has vetoed far fewer bills than some of his predecessors did. Following are the top Presidents for vetoes cast and those overridden by Congress, which requires a two-thirds vote by each house.

LEAD: With President Reagan calling again for the ouster of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama, Administration officials today dismissed General Noriega's offer to resign by 1989, calling it a ploy.

LEAD: The New York City Council yesterday extended the municipal rent-control and rent-stabilization laws for three years, and it turned back a request from the real-estate industry to deregulate apartments renting for more than $850 a month.
LEAD: Four East Harlem residents pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that they chased down and fatally beat a fleeing theft suspect.

LEAD: Ransom Wilson, a flutist and conductor of the Tuscaloosa Symphony Orchestra and the chamber orchestra Solisti New York, has been awarded the first Alabama Prize by the New York Times Company Regional Newspaper Group. The award of $10,000 is given in alternate years to a visual artist or a performing artist who was born in
LEAD: THE generic drug business has turned stronger, reflecting several trends that could carry its $4 billion in annual sales past $11 billion by the mid-1990's.

LEAD: The Brooklyn Academy of Music announced yesterday that its sixth annual Next Wave Festival would open on Oct. 19 with ''The Warrior Ant,'' an epic work, conceived as a Japanese Bunraku play, by Lee Breuer and Bob Telson. The play traces the life of a mythical warrior ant, using Afro-Caribbean songs, dance and puppetry.

LEAD: Roy Hinson did not miss a shot from the field for the Nets, and Charles Barkley missed the entire second half for Philadelphia tonight as the Nets came away with a 102-90 victory at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.
LEAD: * Air France said it had ordered two additional Boeing 747's.

LEAD: Foods and Wines of France Inc. has named Lois Pitts Gershon Ponn/ GGK as agency for its wines and spirits. It will arrange to have its cheeses and other food products promoted by agencies or freelancers working on a project basis.
LEAD: Members of a Senate committee today criticized the Agriculture Department for a proposed budget cut that would eliminate financing for the distribution of surplus food to the poor.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH it's not absolutely necessary to have special kitchen equipment to turn typical American meals into healthful ones, some appliances can make the job easier. Since one of the most frequently heard complaints is that nutritionally sound food takes too long to prepare, anything to make the job more efficient is a plus.

LEAD: In this lonely outpost of the American political campaign, a band of Democrats trickled into a polling place in the shadow of Westminster Abbey today and helped pick Gov. Michael S. Dukakis as their choice for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
LEAD: The body of a 3-year-old boy who was apparently scalded to death was found yesterday by the police in a Manhattan welfare hotel, the police said.
LEAD: The Rev. Gerhard Claas, general secretary of the Baptist World Alliance, has died of injuries suffered in a traffic accident near Lodi, Calif., the alliance announced today.

LEAD: COMPUTER memory technology is advancing so rapidly that some engineers believe that in the next decade silicon chips will begin to replace magnetic disks as the main way of storing information in computers.
LEAD: A former executive of the Wedtech Corporation testified yesterday that he paid the personal lawyer of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d about $800,000 for ''his influence with Ed Meese.''

LEAD: Democrat Robert Sweeney defeated Republican James Caples by 43 votes in the race for the state Assembly seat in the 11th District in Suffolk County, the Board of Elections announced yesterday after a recount of the vote.

LEAD: In an act of hope, determination or just plain boredom, Kim Baumguardner and her husband, Sam, are planting trees in this dusty West Texas town. Two tiny shrubs, all but hidden by barbed wire, sit in the center of a newly purchased plot next to the Baumguardner home. Mrs. Baumguardner's best friend used to live there.

LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today overrode President Reagan's veto of a civil rights bill: FOR THE BILL - 73 Democrats 52 Adams, Wash. Baucus, Mont. Bentsen, Tex. Bingaman, N.M. Boren, Okla. Bradley, N.J. Breaux, La. Bumpers, Ark. Burdick, N.D. Byrd, W.Va.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To The Living Section:
LEAD: Ruben Blades's 'Truth'
LEAD: Mayor Koch rightly denounces the gang that pursued, beat and fatally injured an alleged thief in East Harlem. But city and community leaders dare not ignore the frustration behind the crime.

LEAD: The president of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries called off a news conference today, and his action pushed oil prices down. He had been expected to announce measures to bolster prices.
LEAD: IN London, young men's thoughts are turning to romantic reworkings of classic fashions.
LEAD: To The Living Section:
LEAD: Students do not have to give up on attending the college of their choice even when they find a growing gap between the cost of school and their financial aid package.
LEAD: To The Living Section:
LEAD: The Metropolitan Washington Airport Authority is tentatively offering $125 million of subordinated revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 8.20 percent for those due in 2018.

LEAD: Ferris Fain, the American League batting champion in 1951 and 1952, is being held without bail in Placerville, Calif., after deputies raided his home last Thursday and arrested him when they found more than 400 marijuana plants, according to Lieut. Howard Wilson of the El Dorado County Sheriff's office.

LEAD: In an attempt to revitalize the Humana Festival of New American Plays, Jon Jory commissioned plays from three name writers, guaranteeing them production in the 1988 festival. For ''personal reasons,'' Susan Sontag did not fulfill her commission. Marsha Norman, the only playwright of the three, felt that her play was still in a developmental phase and requested that the workshop production not be ''subject for review or literary criticism at this point.
LEAD: Joseph S. Tushinsky, a former audio-industry executive, inventor and musician, died of pneumonia at his home in Encino, Calif., Monday. He was 78 years old.

LEAD: Griffin Bacal Inc., which has proved its skill with children's advertising as the agency for Hasbro, Milton Bradley and Playskool, will next be doing advertising for the Muppet line of dental products from Gillette's Oral-B. These include the character toothbrushes as well as Kermit the Frog mild mint toothpaste and Miss Piggy bubble gum toothpaste.

LEAD: EASTER is the misfit among American holidays. In principle it is the most important date in the Christian calendar, but its religious significance has been its secular undoing. The country, it seems, is too religious and too Christian to ignore Easter, but also too pluralist and too secular to absorb it comfortably as a national holiday.

LEAD: The usual onward spirit at Cooper Union is punctuated these days by unmistakable signs of hesitation that give pause for thought, or at least contemplation, on the venerable school's second floor.

LEAD: A girl who became the first cancer patient to receive a bone marrow transplant through the services of a computerized national registry has been pronounced free of leukemia, hospital officials say.
LEAD: Commerce remained at a standstill in much of Panama today on the third day of a strike called to protest the rule of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

LEAD: Sedric Toney, the 6-foot-1-inch guard, has been impressive enough for the Knicks to sign him yesterday for the remainder of the season rather than to another 10-game contract. The move also enabled the Knicks to retain the rights to Toney, who had been out of the N.B.A. since the 1985-86 season.

LEAD: In a display of collegiality and bipartisanship rarely seen on budget matters, the House of Representatives today overwhelmingly approved a $1.1 trillion budget resolution for the coming fiscal year.

LEAD: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, right, with Senator Bill Bradley at New Jersey's Liberty State Park after Mr. Bradley endorsed his candidacy for President. Mr. Bradley, who has declined calls to enter the Presidential race himself, called Mr. Dukakis the Democrats' best hope against Vice President Bush, the Republican front-runner.

LEAD: Louis O. Kelso, whose investment banking firm emerged victorious this week in the battle for American Standard Inc., wastes no love on Wall Street. ''We have to take capital ownership out of that gambling casino,'' he says.
LEAD: Transportation Secretary Jim Burnley testified at a Senate hearing today that he was dismayed at what he said was the Federal Aviation Administration's resistance to improved safety rules.

LEAD: Senator Bob Dole said today that the Democratic Presidential candidates had rejected the legacy of Harry S. Truman and John F. Kennedy in the belief that the United States ''must not be too forceful'' and ''must mistrust its own power.''

LEAD: The Presidential campaign of Senator Albert Gore Jr. today defended its refusal to disclose details of an estimated $1.3 million in bank loans. It said ''no one is more scrupulous'' in following Federal election laws.

LEAD: Normally, the type of contamination that worries the Nuclear Regulatory Commission is radioactive. But when the agency recently moved into its new headquarters in Maryland, it found itself concerned with another kind of contamination: lead.

LEAD: The Cuomo administration has been overstating by 500 percent, or more than 100,000, the number of housing units produced by the state since Governor Cuomo took office five years ago, according to records released by the administration today.

LEAD: THIRTY-FIVE years ago Egon Runte, a Swiss engineer, started to manufacture a new kind of radiator that perhaps ranks with the cuckoo clock and the numbered bank account as among Switzerland's significant contributions to Western culture.

LEAD: International Inc., the hotel-casino concern with operations in New Jersey and the Bahamas, said its board had rejected a sweetened $295 million takeover bid by Merv Griffin, the entertainer-turned-businessman.

LEAD: The chairman of the House Banking Committee today released a draft of his proposed legislation that would give the nation's banks only modest new securities underwriting powers. The proposal contrasts sharply with a bill in the Senate that would give broad new powers to banks.

LEAD: There was much to admire in Laura Gilbert's flute playing on Monday evening at Weill Recital Hall. Her tone is deep, smoothly rounded and alluring, and her manipulation of dynamics and timbre - detailed enough to make trifles like Doppler's virtuosic ''Hungarian Fantasy Pastorale'' sound witty rather than merely charming, and to impose an unusually compelling dramatic shape on Luciano Berio's '

LEAD: THE Tokai Bank of California, the United States subsidiary of the Tokai Bank Ltd. of Japan, wanted to enter the field of lending to Hollywood film producers. Prudential-Bache Capital Funding was looking for new public financing techniques after tax-law changes severely restricted the use of tax-free industrial development bonds.

LEAD: Impervious to the present, ageless caravans of nomads are leading their camels across the barren plateau around this dusty garrison town in the desert, heading toward summer pasture even higher than Quetta's 5,500 feet above the distant sea. They hardly seem to notice the new nomads, who have - temporarily, perhaps - taken possession of much of the land.
LEAD: The old days of round-the-clock drinking, swearing and poker are gone. In their place, there are now saunas, rowing machines and computers.
LEAD: Sales of new American-made cars and light trucks exceeded last year's level by seven-tenths of a percent in the March 11 to 20 period, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

LEAD: A candy store owner in Elizabeth, N.J., who admitted to fatally shooting one of two men who he said robbed his store on Tuesday, was charged yesterday with purchasing his gun without a permit. The merchant, Mohamed Taha, 47 years old, was not charged in the shooting, the police said. The dead man was shot once in the chest in the store and was found 100 yards away with loot.
LEAD: The Power Game How Washington Works By Hedrick Smith 793 pages. Random House. $22.50.

LEAD: At one point in the Rangers' 3-2 loss to the Sabres Tuesday night, Michel Bergeron stood on his bench, screaming into a hushed and humbled Madison Square Garden and swinging a stick against the boards. At another point, he prowled the corridor underneath the stands, berating Bob Hall, the referee, and shaking his fists in disgust.
LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds slipped again in the week ended yesterday.
LEAD: Bond prices continued to erode yesterday in another sluggish session that had traders searching for business.

LEAD: A Federal magistrate has denied a prisoner's request for materials to worship Satan, ruling that Satanism is not a religion and that the knitting needles the prisoner wanted for bloodletting would pose a security risk. The Satan worshiper, Charles McCorkle, serving a 40-year sentence at the maximum-security Holman Prison for three burglary convictions, had filed a lawsuit in which he sought access to the knitting needles and to books on the occult.

LEAD: In a puzzling new twist in the Tawana Brawley mystery, school books the teen-ager was believed to have been carrying on the day she disappeared in November turned up last week in her former high school in Wappingers Falls, N.Y., according to people familiar with the investigation.

LEAD: The training of new teachers by the New York City Board of Education is ''notoriously ineffective,'' and the least experienced teachers are often sent to the city's most troubled schools, according to a report prepared for the new Schools Chancellor, Dr. Richard R. Green.
LEAD: The General Assembly overwhelmingly adopted a resolution today deploring the United States attempt to close the Palestine Liberation Organization's observer mission.

LEAD: A loophole in New York State's campaign contributions law exempts from public reporting the tens of thousands of dollars in operating funds that supposedly pay for political parties' staff, rents and other routine expenses. Investigations suggest that ''housekeeping'' funds are often diverted to pay party officials' campaign or personal expenses.

LEAD: Senator Robert C. Byrd, the majority leader, served notice today that Democrats would insist on clarifying a dispute with the Reagan Administration over treaty interpretation before approving a new nuclear arms pact.

LEAD: Cancer patients whose bone marrow had been destroyed by therapy regained marrow after receiving injections of their own blood cells, suggesting an alternative to marrow transplants, according to a study issued here today.
LEAD: Americans overwhelmingly oppose pardoning Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North of the Marines before he goes on trial in the Iran-contra scandal, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

LEAD: Marvin Davis, growing impatient at the Lorimar Telepictures Corporation's failure to respond to his $771 million conditional offer, wrote a letter to Merv Adelson, Lorimar's chairman, threatening to take unspecified hostile actions. Company officials declined to comment.
LEAD: Leaders of the Sandinista Government and the contra guerrillas signed a cease-fire agreement tonight that both sides described as historic.

LEAD: Less than two months ago, when the Presidential candidates were focusing on the Iowa caucuses, the New Hampshire primary and the multiple contests of Super Tuesday, the Connecticut Presidential primary of March 29 was merely a speck on the maps of most campaign strategists.

LEAD: THE longer I garden, the more I appreciate plants that really earn their keep, those that are of interest in more than a single season. I am also increasingly fond of plants that have a place in my childhood memories.

LEAD: In a marketing gamble, Northwest Airlines said yesterday that it would ban smoking on all its North American flights. It is the only smoking ban by a major American airline.
LEAD: President Reagan said today that he would visit Moscow from May 29 to June 2 for his fourth meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration said today that American forces would start leaving Honduras on Monday, about 10 days after they were deployed in response to a Nicaraguan offensive against base camps of the contra rebels.
LEAD: Carl Hildebrand, former president of Sandvik Steel Inc. of Fairlawn, N.J., died at his Manhattan home Monday after a long illness. He was 91 years old.
LEAD: Leaders of the rightist Nationalist Republican Alliance say they are astonished by the wide margin of their victory over the ruling party in elections Sunday.

LEAD: About 370 blacks and women who were turned down for jobs by Honda of America Manufacturing Inc. will receive a total of $6 million from the automobile maker in a settlement of a Federal discrimination case, the Government and Honda announced today.

LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev speaking yesterday at the fourth National Congress of Collective Farmers in Moscow. Mr. Gorbachev called for revival of agricultural cooperatives ''in the form of a modern, high-standard movement extensively integrated'' with government-run collective farms. (Agence France-Presse)

LEAD: Horace Rumpole is back. Despite periodic public protestations from John Mortimer, the writer, and Leo McKern, the actor, that the barrister is just about played out, the grumpy old darling is once again shuttling between legal chambers and Pomeroy's pub, where it is his pleasure to quaff the house wine, sometimes referred to as Chateau Thames Embankment.

LEAD: The board of Federated Department Stores is due to meet in New York this morning to discuss a sweetened $6.6 billion takeover bid from the Campeau Corporation.

LEAD: Letters written by Mark Twain in his formative years - nearly half of them never before published and many of them appearing in full for the first time rather than excerpted - will enable scholars and readers to trace the origins of some of the writer's major novels and stories.
LEAD: The rating of the Texas Utilities Electric Company's $6.3 billion of debt was lowered yesterday by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

LEAD: A New York State Assemblyman said today that all the ethnic advertising for the ''I [ love ] New York'' campaign in the last two years has been placed in black and Hispanic newspapers, ignoring other ethnic papers that reach more readers.

LEAD: Yet another piece of electronic equipment once found only in large business offices is taking up residence in American homes alongside computers and copiers. Facsimile machines, which transmit typed or handwritten letters, graphic designs and photographs over telephone lines in seconds, are being purchased by the owners of home businesses.
LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3*FULLER, H B CO (OTC) Qtr to Feb 29 1988 1987 Sales 154,620,000 137,421,000 Net inc 4,742,000 3,649,000 Share earns .49 .38

LEAD: Du Quoin, Ill., which from 1957 to 1980 was the home of the Hambletonian, the famous mile race for 3-year-old trotting horses, will make an attempt Saturday to regain race from the Meadowlands race track in East Rutherford, N.J. The race has been at the Meadowlands since 1981.

LEAD: After months of uncertainty marked by acute economic problems and even coup rumors, an assembly drafting a new constitution has signaled that it will allow President Jose Sarney to complete a five-year term.
LEAD: The New York Times Company Magazine Group has named Kate White editor in chief of its Child magazine, which began publication in 1986 and now has a circulation of 250,000.

LEAD: A FEW years ago, a friend asked his father if he could borrow the car to go to the beach. His father thought about it, asked some questions and finally said no. He did not trust his son to make such a trip by himself.
LEAD: Two attackers thought to be leftist guerrillas fired rocket-propelled grenades at the United States Embassy here Wednesday night. An embassy spokesman said no one was hurt.

LEAD: If you were among the unfortunate victims of the latest strain of influenza or the mysterious virus that has been prostrating people for up to seven days, you may have considered yourself recovered when the virus retreated, enabling you to return to your usual activities. But in addition to the expected setbacks of a debilitating illness, your body must now also recover from the effects of the treatment: bed rest.

LEAD: Lawyers and opposition politicians criticized President P. W. Botha today for intervening to prevent the trial of six soldiers charged with murdering a prominent black nationalist in South-West Africa, the South African-run territory also known as Namibia.
LEAD: A 17-year-old Brooklyn youth was shot in the back during an argument with another student yesterday morning at Prospect Heights High School in Brooklyn, the police said.
LEAD: Ten percent of the elderly Americans who undergo a common operation intended to prevent strokes either die or suffer strokes as a direct result of the surgery, a new study shows.

LEAD: Consumer prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area declined by two-tenths of 1 percent in February, the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. It was the region's first decline in 15 months.

LEAD: Kansas City Southern Industries said a letter it had received from the New York investor Howard Kaskel to buy the railroad and data processing company for $60 a share, or $588 million, ''appears to be an effort to stimulate trading in Kansas City Southern stock.'' Mr. Kaskel leads a group of investors who control 11.3 percent of the common shares.

LEAD: Fish and Roses and Volcano Suns, two entirely different rock groups who played at CBGB's on Saturday, are both obssessed with musical duration. Fish and Roses, a trio of bass, drums and keyboards, exudes a Lower East Side, populist intellectuality. It makes everything short: the songs seem as if they stop and start every 15 seconds, vocals are fragmented and used as just another formal element, the same as the next staggering, collapsing riff.

LEAD: Tony Williams's drumming fills all the requirements of modern jazz. It propels and punctuates the ensembles, goads and comments on every solo; it swings with furious precision. Yet in the first set by Mr. Williams and his quintet on Wednesday at the Village Gate (Bleecker and Thompson Streets), where the band is performing through tonight, his jazz technique evoked elemental forces: gale winds, avalanches, tsunamis.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. R. Herbert Sinek of Chappaqua, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nicole Irene Sinek, to Leo Peter Arnaboldi 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnaboldi Jr. of Greenwich, Conn. The wedding is to be May 28.

LEAD: Nan Robertson quotes a rabbi, who states, ''There are no Jewish alcoholics.'' I hope that readers do not get the impression from this that knowledgeable rabbis are not fully aware of the extent of alcoholism among Jews.

LEAD: A surprisingly frequent, though unusual, home-improvement task is attaching wood to concrete. Two instances where this is necessary are covering a concrete slab by building a wood or wood-supported floor over it, and installing a partition wall in a basement containing a concrete floor.

LEAD: In elections with broad implications for relations between Spain and Britain, Gibraltar voters have chosen a Socialist government opposed to negotiations between the two countries over the status of the territory.

LEAD: To the Editor: Hotel management, architects, construction engineers and builders so often conspire, seemingly, to annoy hotel guests. The Bali Sol, from which I am writing, is a magnificent example of a complete lack of understanding of a guest's needs. Beautifully landscaped, the hotel fronts on the sea.
LEAD: A 64-year-old Bronx man was found beaten to death Friday night in his ransacked apartment in Co-op City, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: Don Bredes's disappointment must be painful (About Men: ''Rights and Choices,'' Feb. 21.) But he makes it hard for us to sympathize with him. He writes of injustice and a man's rights, rather than telling the story of a risky human adventure that failed for very understandable reasons. He casts himself as victim, rather than as a participant who needs to wonder how he may have contributed to an impulsive and, possibly, mistaken decision, and to the unhappy outcome.
LEAD: THE greatest sound in the world to Peter Jensen, Iona quarterback, would be wild cheers from fans at a home game in New Rochelle. Right now, that is impossible.

LEAD: IN response to concerns about releasing living, gene-altered microbes into the environment, scientists have learned to program bacteria to destroy themselves when their work is done.

It was Saturday, the second night of the New Year, and a brilliant full moon bathed the tree-lined square.
