LEAD: EVERY NIGHT WHEN CARL SCHAAB RETURNS FROM WORK to his New Jersey home, his wife gives him a kiss - and a sniff. If her husband smells as though he has been romping with several women, each wearing a different fragrance, then all is well. Wanda Schaab can be sure he spent the day at work.

LEAD: DORIS LILLY answered her telephone recently and was, as she put it, ''paralyzed with disbelief.'' A disembodied voice announced that it was the billing department of a major hospital, requested that she hold the line and assured her that a representative would be with her in a minute. She's almost certain the pronouncement was followed by music, but she wouldn't swear to it because she was still in a small state of shock about being called by a message machine.

LEAD: OF the preliminary world championship candidates matches in Saint John, New Brunswick, the one that most resembled a tug of war was that contested by the 36-year-old Dutch grandmaster Jan Timman and the 23-year-old Soviet grandmaster Valery Salov. Throughout the first five games of the six-game series, one player or the other seemed to have the upper hand, yet neither succeeded in capitalizing on anything.

LEAD: The Rev. Jeb Stuart Magruder, the former White House aide who spent seven months in jail for his part in the Watergate scandal, just kind of naturally perks up when talk turns to ethics. So Mr. Magruder, who was ordained a Presbyterian minister in 1981, seemed delighted when civic leaders in Columbus, Ohio, recently asked him to head a Commission on Values and Ethics.

LEAD: John T. Schwarzlose, executive director of the Betty Ford Center, advises drug addicts who wish to join A.A. ''. . . to say they are both alcoholics and drug abusers.'' I believe Mr. Schwarzlose is missing the most important and, perhaps most difficult, tenet of A.A. - honesty. How can anyone expect to recover in a program based on honesty if he is there on the basis of a lie?
LEAD: BUSINESS, church and community groups and educators have banded together in a consortium that will create job incentives designed to help students complete their high school education.

LEAD: THE FIRST COMMERCIAL TELEPHONE RESEMBLED A clunky box camera. Designed in 1877 by Alexander Graham Bell and Thomas A. Watson, it cost what was then a princely sum: $20 a year in two advance installments. In relative terms, telephones can now be just as pricey, but they also do much more. Many function as secretaries, having built-in answering machines and memories that record the time of a call or automatically dial a series of preprogrammed numbers.

LEAD: INDOORS separate annual and vegetable seedlings and pot them individually; keep hairlike roots covered to prevent them from drying out; water carefully and put in a shaded location for a day or two until the roots are settled; then provide full sun and use water-soluble fertilizer diluted to half-rate.

LEAD: JUST elected leader of what could be, but is not, one of the strongest Republican organizations in the state, Assemblyman John C. Cochrane of Brightwaters last week tackled one of the decisions that will help determine whether he can lead a comeback of the Suffolk Republican Party.

LEAD: Alexandra Meigs Meredith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Meredith of Pennington, N.J., was married in Princeton, N.J., yesterday to Ward Shaffer Taggart, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Taggart of Dallas.
LEAD: Two men have been charged with the murder of 5 supermarket employees in a robbery Sept. 4 in which 4 of the victims were shot in the back of the head after being ordered to lie on the floor.

LEAD: INTRODUCED to Christianity through their native Celtic Church, absorbed into Roman Catholicism and transmuted through diktat to Anglicanism by King Henry VIII, the Welsh waited until the coming of the ironworks, coal mines and slate quarries late in the 18th century and throughout the 19th before molding Nonconformist denominations according to their own image and emerging with dramatic oratory and four-part harmony onto the religious center stage.
LEAD: Nearly two decades later, the words of Eisaku Sato still glisten in the annals of Japanese verbal befuddlement.

LEAD: Eritrean rebels fighting the Ethiopian authorities say they killed or captured 18,000 Government soldiers and seized three Soviet military advisers in an offensive that they said had ''broken the backbone of the Ethiopian Army'' in Eritrea.

LEAD: IN JAPAN,'' SAYS JAPAN Air Lines in a series of radio ads, ''most everyone writes a haiku now and then, even busy executives.'' Now J.A.L. is urging busy American executives and other listeners to follow suit - with the chance of winning two first-class, round-trip tickets to Tokyo and $1,000 in spending money.

LEAD: As one who left the ''Great and Sovereign State of Mississippi'' following a number of painful experiences in 1964, I found little cause for joy in Peter J. Boyer's article ''The Yuppies of Mississippi'' (Feb. 28). Mississippi seems to have replaced rebel-flag-waving bigotry with the self-serving desire to achieve ''drastic change.

LEAD: Mrs. F. Whitney Clark of Bedford, N.Y., and William D. George 3d of Sewickley, Pa., have made known the engagement of their daughter Alexandria Pinkerton George to Park Gilbert Mauck, a son of Louise G. Crimmins of Somers, N.Y., and Ward L. Mauck of New York. An October wedding is planned.

LEAD: Bicharra Qumsaya kneaded the black worry beads in his right hand as he scanned the faces of his neighbors crowded into the Greek Orthodox Church. He wore a well-tailored dark suit and the traditional white Arab headdress, held in place with a double black band.

LEAD: Writing in Foreign Affairs magazine, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir maintains that Israel's frontiers were ''virtually indefensible'' until the conquests of 1967. So he resists withdrawal from the West Bank, whose heights dominate Israel's ''population centers, main industrial zones, rail and road arteries and international airport.

LEAD: ''MY name is Ruth Minsky Sender. I am a Holocaust survivor.''

LEAD: Iowa answered the age-old question about the tree falling in the deserted forest today. Even without the national press, the network crews, the out-of-town pundits and the pollsters, Iowans gathered once again to voice their Presidential preferences in a second round of caucuses.

LEAD: A proposal to allow oil and gas exploration off the Florida Keys has been dropped from the Federal Government's five-year leasing plan after state officials agreed to withdraw legal challenges to it.

LEAD: NOT LONG AGO, DURING a country-house weekend, I was puzzled to see a successful businessman I know who looks like a wispier Woody Allen climb into a new Porsche 911. When he drove off, my experienced ear told me he knew very little about the sports car, its engine or gearbox. ''What's he doing in that Porsche?

LEAD: It wasn't easy for Howard Evans to watch. Mark Macon, his friend and backcourt partner for Temple, was living out a nightmare of air balls as the Owls' hopes of a trip to the Final Four were deflated by Duke, 63-53, in the East Regional final today.
LEAD: CAN a successful Manhattan leather-goods manufacturer move upstate and make out as a goat farmer?
LEAD: Relationships are indeed complicated, but ''. . . a baby on the way . . .'' is no way to ''. . . help us banish . . . more stubborn doubts.''

LEAD: To the Editor: It's too bad the confused passengers on the Ambus missed their meal at the Polka Dot Cafe around the corner from the railroad station in White River Junction. We had breakfast there after spending the night across the street at the Hotel Coolidge. After gorging ourselves on muffins and the bottomless cups of coffee, we purchased a bagful to fortify us on our journey.
LEAD: THE WORLD OF THE NEWBORN By Daphne Maurer and Charles Maurer. Illustrated. 293 pp. New York: Basic Books. $20.95.

LEAD: RUNNING the length of the original wing of Stapleford Park, a stately home near this Leiscestershire village, is an inscription that reads: ''William Lord Sherard, Baron of Letrym, Repayred this Building, Anno Domini 1633.''

LEAD: Bill Robinson is a black man who wants to be a baseball manager. He is serious enough about gaining experience that he managed in Latin America over the winter, picking up a roaring case of malaria as a souvenir.
LEAD: The World Health Organization is joining with economic aid agencies in an expanded effort to slow the spread of AIDS in developing countries, officials of the agency here say.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John Bassett Moore Place of San Francisco and Portola Valley, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter Judith Gauntlett Place to Harold Dean McMillan Jr., a son of Mr. McMillan of Astoria, Ill., and Rachel Mitzbacher of Woodside, Queens. An October wedding is planned.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Stephen P. Carney of Easton, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Kathleen Carney, to Dr. Frederick A. Godley 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Godley Jr. of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., and New Canaan, Conn.
LEAD: ''We never ask the women,'' Sultan Mohammad said indignantly.
LEAD: A second consecutive year of low rainfall is causing drought conditions in much of the West and threatening to force water rationing in many communities.

LEAD: There was a time when Au-gust Wilson - a playwright whose reputation is built on his facility for capturing the poetic richness of the language of ordinary black America - did not know how to get his characters to speak.

LEAD: Eight elderly men and women sat quietly in a semicircle, chopping vegetables for the borscht they were to eat for lunch, when one of them struck up a Yiddish tune made popular by the Andrews Sisters in the 1930's.
LEAD: Amid the poverty, political turmoil and violence of Bangladesh, there is no sadder place than the University of Dhaka.
LEAD: THE concept was big: a 300- or 400-acre walled ''City of God,'' with temples, canals, elephants and other beasts of burden.
LEAD: ON THE DAY BEFORE HIS inauguration as President of South Korea on Feb. 25, Roh Tae Woo posed in front of his party headquarters to be photographed with giggling cleaning ladies in overalls.

LEAD: The New York Urban League, hobbled by debts, is seeking contributions from corporations, foundations and individuals to help the 69-year-old social service agency survive and continue to assist the city's disadvantaged.

LEAD: Sarah Caldwell has called her extraordinary American-Soviet festival in Boston ''Making Music Together,'' but as any anthropologist will tell you, man moved before he sang. And so it is only natural that dance is also - through Maya Plisetskaya's participation - a major component of this festival.

LEAD: The sight was as hard to believe as the notion of a top-seeded team being removed from the national collegiate basketball tournament. On one night, hundreds of miles from home, there they were: Kansas State fans, in their purple and white, rooting for the University of Kansas, and Jayhawk fans, dressed in crimson and blue, cheering for the Wildcats.

LEAD: The Feb. 21 article about the Little Village School did a pretty good job of portraying all handicapped children as being helpless and without any hope for a normal life. While it started out as sounding positive with the title ''Here, Small Steps of Hope,'' by the time one was finished reading it, it seemed like a hopeless tale of woe.
LEAD: I was deeply touched by the article ''Here, Small Steps of Hope.'' As a parent of a child who attends the Little Village School, I have nothing but praise for this wonderful place.

LEAD: Amityville $305,000 16 Braham Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; fireplace, decks, 60-foot bulkhead on water; taxes $4,400. Bay Shore $665,000 121 South Awixa Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, sun porch, 1 acre with boatslip, 2-car garage; taxes $6,700.

LEAD: THE storefront of Ichizawa Hanpu Kogyo (Ichizawa Sailcloth Enterprises) in Kyoto is so modest it's very easy to pass it by. The many-paned window of the shop is not markedly different from that of the other old offices and shops on Higashioji-dori, and the earthy colors of the bags visible through the glass blend in with the dark wood, gray roof tiles and copper rain pipes of the shop's exterior and that of other buildings on the street.

LEAD: THE consulting veterinarian for Turtle Back Zoo in West Orange, Dr. Barry M. Adler, charged last week that poor management, zoo maintenance and animal care had contributed to the deaths of at least 13 animals since January and were to blame for other problems in recent years.

LEAD: LAST June in Indianapolis, children were found playing with vials of blood they took from a dumpster near several doctors' offices. Two of the vials were infected with the deadly AIDS virus. In July several homeowners in Manchester, N. H. woke up to find their backyards littered with assorted operating-room waste.

LEAD: Peekskill, N.Y. $227,000 Eagle Court 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new frame colonial; family room, eat-in kitchen, 0.39 acre, not yet assessed. Pleasantville, N.Y. $253,000 24 Brentwood Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 38-year-old frame ranch; rec room, workshop, patio, 1-car garage, 0.4 acre; taxes $4,700.

LEAD: ''CONVERGENCES/CONVERGENCIAS,'' at the Lehman College Art Gallery, appears to be yet another tribute to democracy. All save one of its eight participants are Latin American by birth or descent (the exception comes from Portugal) and all are living and working in the United States. What makes the show different from others of its type is the essay that comes with it.
LEAD: A different kind of regatta has surfaced on the West Coast. The event downplays the superstars of the sport in favor of the yacht clubs that have produced them.
LEAD: WITHOUT warning, the snowy owl flew up in the face of the woman who cared for it, the strong flight feathers brushing her blond hair. The woman remained calm.

LEAD: IN A NICE middle-class neighborhood less than 10 miles from the beach, hundreds of families say they are being held hostage. Not, however, by drug dealers or terrorists; their kitchen faucets have made these families' lives a nightmare.

LEAD: They've been there all winter, cackling from their favorite tree-top turret. LEAD: Those Soviet parents who have had mixed feelings about the glorification of Pavlik Morozov may be resting easier these days. The authorities are toning down the hero image of Pavlik Morozov, who had been held up as a model of Communism since 1932, when, as a 13-year-old, he denounced his father as a class enemy and was subsequently murdered as an informer.

LEAD: To the Editor: Having just returned from the same trek, I would urge anyone interested in going to talk to people who have trekked recently. That trail is a difficult one; mud slides wiped out some of the paths two years ago. The new ones are often harrowing.

LEAD: THE long and crowded race to the White House makes an important stop in Connecticut on Tuesday, when the state holds what will be the only presidential preference primary in the nation this week.

LEAD: I AM not a native New Englander. I was born and grew up in the Middle West. In elementary school, we learned about the group of small states in the Northeast corner of our country where the first settlers battled harsh winters and farmed land that was more rock than soil. New Englanders, we were told, were fiercely protective of their own way of doing things, a characteristic that time has not erased.

LEAD: Down by the old mill stream, Burton Handelsman is building colonial-style homes and mending a colonial mill. His seven-house project in Harrison, N.Y., at a bend in the Mamaroneck River will include the restoration of a 17th-century grist mill. Built in 1690, the stone-and-wood structure is the oldest mill in Westchester County, said Michael Cassarella, Harrison town historian.

LEAD: In one of the worst fires in recent Newark history, six people were killed and six others were injured early yesterday when flames swept through a three-story frame house in the Central Ward, fire officials said.
LEAD: Bridge players from the New York metropolitan region were successful on two fronts Friday, winning one national title and putting themselves in a good situation to win another.

LEAD: When he received the report almost four years ago about the high incidence of children with diarrhea and mysterious skin rashes, Dr. Laurance Nickey wondered if he was really reading about the United States.

LEAD: Catherine Jay Du Bois and Harold Augustus O'Callaghan 3d, a son of Mrs. and Mrs. O'Callaghan Jr. of Katonah, N.Y., and Nantucket, Mass., plan to marry in June, the parents of the future bride, Adrienne Allen Du Bois of Rye, N.Y., and Dr. John Jay Du Bois of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., have announced.

LEAD: When Congress eliminated the favorable treatment of capital gains in 1986, many thought it would hurt venture capital companies' ability to raise money. The Oct. 19 stock market collapse also caused alarm. But venture capital funds have more money than ever. What is the outlook for this industry?

LEAD: OVER THE DIN AT THE OYSTER Bar, the cavernous subterranean restaurant in New York's Grand Central Terminal, Philip F. Anschutz, the Denver oil baron, was being fed a proposal for a leveraged buyout of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. Jerry M. Seslowe, one of his financial advisers, laid the figure of $6.5 billion on the table, a chilling amount even for a billionaire who had recently pocketed $500 million in cash from the sale of some energy properties.

More than 20 bombs went off Friday during a fair in the village of Kaliakandipara in Sirajganj district, about 50 miles northwest of Dhaka, according to police officials.

LEAD: A WALL STREET trader interrupted a telephone interview last week to check on the status of the takeover battle for Federated Department Stores. The news was good. Campeau had raised its bid to $73 a share from $68. ''And I bought in late, two weeks ago, at 66,'' he reported. ''Not a bad gain.'' On Wall Street, the talk of big deals and easy money is back.

LEAD: It must seem sometimes to lovers of classi-cal music that all the old verities are crumbling under their feet. Critics pontificate about the fate of classical music, suggesting that it may not have a future in this age of pop and electronics and cultural upheaval. Composers freight concert programs with unlistenable exercises in modernist rigor or cheesy crossover pastiches.

LEAD: MOST players think of suit combinations as kid stuff. They are indeed the basic building blocks of play, with more varieties, perhaps, than there are bridge players in the world to play them. But some of the combinations are quite deceptive, and difficult to analyze.

LEAD: DON'T DIET. By Dale M. Atrens. (Morrow, $16.95.) With the fervor of a roadside revival preacher, Dale M. Atrens exhorts us to embrace adiposity and live. A professor of psychobiology at the University of Sydney, Australia, Mr. Atrens believes it is our fixation on fat, not the fat itself, that gets us into trouble.

Rabbi Gerald Wolpe, assisted by Cantor Isaac Wall, performed the ceremony at Har Zion Temple in Penn Valley, Pa.

LEAD: ZOOS have come a long way since they housed their pitiful inmates in bare cells.

LEAD: To the Editor: I would like to share with your readers an experience I had in Zabreb. My wife and I were traveling through Yugoslavia last fall. In a hotel in Zagreb, at approximately 11 P.M., I started to shake and tremble. I became frightened and thought I had a heart attack. My wife called the desk and we were given a number to call for first aid.

LEAD: Abandoning her game to save a child's life won her a special exemption to play in the Turquoise Classic, but becoming a hero hardly helped Mary Bea Porter's golf game. LEAD: To the Editor: I had the wonderful experience of trekking in the Nepal Himalayas last fall. ''Preparing for Nepal's Rugged Reality'' by Marcia R. Lieberman (Travel, Feb. 21) was well done but omitted one important bit of advice for anyone about to embark on an experience of a lifetime. I discovered the most important item in my duffle bag was a Katadyn water filter.

''He played 20 moves ahead to our two or three,'' Bob Joy recalls, ''and analyzed our moves far too deeply.

LEAD: My wife is neither prudish nor anti-intellectual. Nevertheless, upon reading one of the works of the Marquis de Sade, she reacted in a way that has come to be regarded as typical of the complacent bourgeois mentality: without saying a word, and having gone through about one-third of the book, she flung the slim volume into the trash can and went straight to the bookshelves to look for a substitute - the apposite word might be antidote - for her interrupted reading.

LEAD: Prof. and Mrs. Marvin Druger of Syracuse have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lauren Jane Druger, to Brian Andrew Jamieson, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Graham Jamieson of Bethesda, Md. The wedding is to be in September.

LEAD: MORE THAN ANY OTHER JEWISH holiday, Passover is unwavering in its traditions. Even the most inventive chef is likely to turn to his mother's recipes, perhaps with just a bit of fine-tuning, for the festive feast.

LEAD: AS they build computers that are easier to use, computer makers have been making hardware and software that is more complex and more expensive. LEAD: Hungary Question:I have heard conflicting accounts from friends about the amount of Hungarian currency that must be purchased by visitors to Hungary. Can you enlighten me? What is the time involved in getting a visa? Is a visa required for Austria as well? -R. R., Buffalo Answer:Hungarian officials say there is no requirement to purchase a specified amount of Hungarian currency.

LEAD: Alice Rubinstein is a choreographer whose gaze is turned outward at the world around her, to judge by a program presented by her Footpath Dance Company on Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church. And the dancers of Footpath, which is based in Cleveland, move well and are good-looking and very likable.

LEAD: As a member of A.A., I read your article with interest. I was distressed to read that the General Service Office of A.A. would not allow recovering alcoholics to handle its finances. I am the controller of an investment-banking firm in New York City, and wonder what the management of my firm will think when they read that the management of A.A., which knows alcoholics better than anyone, will not trust a recovering alcoholic to handle its finances.

LEAD: THE COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF PUBLIC HEALTH COMPLETE GUIDE TO HEALTH AND WELL-BEING AFTER 50. Edited by Robert J. Weiss and Genell J. Subak-Sharpe. (Times Books, $24.95.) Old age is a shipwreck, de Gaulle used to complain, but Dr. Robert J. Weiss and Genell J. Subak-Sharpe insist that it is never too late to turn it into something more like a Caribbean cruise.

LEAD: DEMOCRATS on the Board of Legislators called last week for major changes in the county government's budget process, ones that they said could help replace yearly tax-levy increases of 12 to 16 percent with ''modest'' rises roughly equivalent to the growth in the cost of living.

LEAD: IN Italian, il mulino means the mill, and that has little connection to the shopping center Il Mulino is part of. But never mind. This small new storefront restaurant in the Springdale section of Stamford is prettier inside than outside, with gray wood walls and partitions counterpointed by greenery, pink tablecloths and red
LEAD: THE ICARUS AGENDA By Robert Ludlum. 677 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Instant replay? How about a dome over Wrigley Field? MARC GRIGOROV Cortland, N.Y.

LEAD: The Government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, combining military muscle and threats of legal action, moved swiftly today to force an end to the economic paralysis that has gripped Panama for weeks.
LEAD: CELEBRATION OF O'NEILL Eugene O'Neill's centennial is being observed by the Yale Repertory Theater and a stellar company of performers, directors and designers.

LEAD: THE ROAD TO RIO Starring Bob Hope (in photo, right), Bing Crosby (in photo, left), Dorothy Lamour, Gale Sondergaard and the Andrews Sisters. Songs by Johnny Burke and James Van Heusen. 1947. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video. 101 minutes. $69.95.
LEAD: One day a world championship will be determined by a wrong call. Why not make the change before that happens? CHARLES A. KROLOFF Westfield, N.J.

LEAD: Roberto Castillo, a 40-year-old Honduran legislator and real estate developer, stood in a passageway in the National Assembly, quietly talking about the thousands of Nicaraguan rebels who have been camping in his country for the last seven years.
LEAD: The Princeton Tigers had more than a fair amount of success in foul weather today as they swept all their rowing races against Navy on the Severn River.

LEAD: Somewhere in suburban Long Island, a teen-age girl is up in her room, chatting on the telephone while her television set flickers with the sound off. She's talking about her parents and sisters, her friends at high school and her piano lessons. But mid-sentence she giggles and says, ''Wait a minute, I have to tape this.

LEAD: The way was cleared for Texaco to emerge from bankruptcy and pay the $3 billion to Pennzoil that will settle their four-year-old legal battle. A Federal bankruptcy judge approved Texaco's plan for ending the bankruptcy protection that it sought almost a year ago; at that time, it was beset by problems caused by the $10.5 billion award that Pennzoil had won in a Texas court.

LEAD: HOW does a small, bearded writer who looks like a Talmudic scholar, who grew up speaking Yiddish in a house ''just like the shtetl,'' find his way to writing about the sacred cows of American food and popular culture? In Max Apple's books, food packages come alive in the capers of characters called Birdseye and C.

LEAD: With contracts covering 195,000 workers expiring this week, New York State is negotiating with bargaining units representing everyone from prison guards to chemists who test blood samples for AIDS.

LEAD: On a sunny, late-winter afternoon in Yuma, Ariz., in an otherwise forgettable intrasquad game at the remote training camp of the San Diego Padres, Dickie Thon doubled, and members of both teams joined the small crowd in its cheers.

LEAD: Electronic fetal monitors have been under attack for more than a decade by some women's groups and parts of the medical community. But despite research showing that using monitors does not produce healthier babies, most obstetricians say that a complicated interplay of legal and economic pressures makes it almost impossible to stop using them.

LEAD: WITH audience after audience in recent months, Governor Cuomo has wasted little time getting to one of his favorite topics: Liberty Scholarships. ''It can catch on all over the U.S.,'' Mr. Cuomo said in a speech to 350 Hispanic leaders earlier this month, ''and everywhere I talk about it, I have people say to me on the way out of the room, 'Mario, stay with it.
LEAD: THE conventional wisdom of Presidential politics is that flowery endorsements from fellow politicians don't mean much.

LEAD: THERE IS A HIGH RISK for the United States in the current strategic arms reduction talks, known as START, that call for a 50 percent reduction in strategic nuclear warheads. The risk is less in what we negotiate with the Russians than in how we divide up the 50 percent we would be allowed to retain.

LEAD: ONLY a few hundred people live in this hamlet on the southeastern coast of what Hawaiians call the Big Island. Rural and slow-moving, with old wooden buildings where the local people trade gossip and buy fruit-flavored cones of shaved ice, the village recalls Hawaii at the turn of the century, before its landscape and lifestyle were forever changed by huge military bases and glittering beachfront resorts.

LEAD: A renovation of four adjacent city-owned buildings under way in the rubble-strewn South Bronx offers a mix of market and low-income rents and has drawn 1,000 applications for its 110 apartments, according to its developers. The large number of requests reflects not only the quality of the project but also the shortage of livable buildings in the area, said Brien O'Toole, executive director of the Mount Hope Housing Company, the nonprofit sponsor with FGK Development, a private company.
LEAD: Any proven technological methods deployed to increase the accuracy of any judgmental decision, I am definitely in favor of for any sport. LEO FONTANELLA Hillside, N.J.

LEAD: ON Tuesday, Finland, Sweden and the United States will celebrate the 350th anniversary of the first landing made by Swedes and Finns in North America. The colony located in what is now Delaware was named New Sweden, after its founder, the New Sweden Company. At the time, Peter Minuit was the company's director.
LEAD: To the casual observer, the scene being filmed would appear to be nothing special. Yet, something surprising is happening.
LEAD: THE DREAMING BRAIN By J. Allan Hobson. Illustrated. 319 pp. New York: Basic Books. $22.95.

Kessler of New York and Hilton Head Island, S.C., was married at St. Paul's German Lutheran Church in New York yesterday to Charles Neil McDermott, a son of Mrs. Charles H. McDermott of Worcester, Mass., and the late Mr. McDermott. The Rev.
LEAD: No. No. No. Can no sport be left as originally played? There is enough analysis of every pitch, every swing of the bat, every move of the players. ALICE SCHREIBER Stamford, Conn.

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson's Presidential campaign has won more delegates for less money than any of his competitors. It has done so by merging the passion of a political movement with some of the modern techniques of campaign management.

LEAD: There are enough bad backs on the PGA Tour to fill a hospital's orthopedic ward. The latest man to feel those aches and pains is Hal Sutton, who failed to make the cut Friday in the Players Championship.

LEAD: The engagement of Alla Steffen Wright to John Ernest Crowther, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Crowther of Menston, Yorkshire, England, has been announced by the future bride's mother, Mrs. Willard M. Wright Jr. of Wynnewood, Pa.

LEAD: About 8,400 gallons of slightly radioactive water leaked into the Hudson River from the Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant, the plant's operator said today. The water was discovered missing from a 345,000-gallon storage tank outside the containment structure, said a spokeswoman for Con Edison, Bea Meltzer.

LEAD: Six Moslem fishermen were shot and killed off Sri Lanka and nine of their companions were missing and feared dead, a Sri Lankan military official said today. A news agency blamed the attack on Tamil separatists.

LEAD: Pierre Elliott Trudeau, seldom free of controversy in his 15 years as Prime Minister, has been telling friends since retiring four years ago how pleasant it has been to have others fighting the political battles.
LEAD: A Darien couple will not be allowed to keep a partially blind, epileptic tiger in their home, a Federal judge ruled this week.

LEAD: HOW much is it worth? When it comes to real estate, the value often is not determined by the seller or the buyer but by the mortgage lender. Banks, which once relied upon their own officers to inspect properties and set a fair-market value before granting mortgages, now pay fees to real-estate appraisal companies to perform the service.

LEAD: IF DANTE HAD SEEN THE TREASURY BOND PIT AT the Chicago Board of Trade, he would have added another circle to his vision of hell. Imagine a ring of steps around an octagonal floor, about 35 feet in diameter on the top step, occupying the northwest corner of a wood-paneled trading room the width of a city block.

LEAD: Alfredo Kraus is a tenor of many distinctions, and one among them on which all observers would have to agree is the really unusual preservation of his voice. We have at the moment a fair number of opera singers clustered around the age of 60 who have lasted impressively well, but Mr. Kraus, who was born in 1927, has conceded less to time than any of them.

LEAD: ONE of the first things I noticed as we landed in Los Cabos, the airport at the southernmost tip of the Baja California peninsula, was the cloud of vultures darkening the sky at the end of the runway. The opportunity for metaphor, or message, was obvious.

LEAD: BEGINNING Friday, many workplaces in Connecticut will have something they did not have before: smoke-free areas. The task of setting up those areas has many employers posting signs, circulating memos and holding meetings with their workers to discuss the new rules.
LEAD: Iraq said it fired two long-range missiles into Teheran today, and Iran said its fighter-bombers attacked Iraqi troops in a battle for a strategic region in northeastern Iraq.

LEAD: Leave a pendulum to its own devices and it most assuredly will swing the other way. So it has been lately with a theory of health and healing that treats the mind as a weapon at least as powerful as the best of modern medicaments. After nearly a century stuck on the side of the body, the pendulum has recently cut a wide arc toward the mind.

LEAD: THE CBS CORRESPONDENT Bob Schieffer, reporting election returns on one of the primary nights, wondered aloud whether a percentage figure he was giving should be described as less or fewer. The grammarian on the spot immediately pronounced judgment: when a percentage is used to indicate an amount or quantity, it takes less; when used to describe a number, it takes fewer.

LEAD: EXCEPT for the switch to disposable plastics, the design of the hypodermic syringe remains much as it was when Charles Pravaz, a French physician, invented it in 1853. Soon that will change.
LEAD: Kathy B. Gannett has won a battle against a formidable former boss, the Federal Government. In the process she also hopes she has furthered the cause of civil rights in Boston.

LEAD: Governor Cuomo, whose administration was found this week to have overstated by 500 percent the number of housing units created by the state during his five years in office, has ordered an inquiry into the accuracy of his housing division's figures and into the way it compiles them.
LEAD: ''DOUBLES,'' a mean-spirited comedy by David Wiltse, has just opened at the Studio Theater in Lindenhurst. Its subject is male bonding and how men of a certain class relate to one another.
LEAD: A range of top New York City officials has criticized a proposal to create a special crime category for bias-related incidents, calling the measure too narrow and difficult to enforce.

LEAD: Franklin Lakes $250,000 541 Shirley Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 19-year-old contemporary; patio, dining room, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,108. Maplewood $196,000 14 Carleton Court 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 42-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, 1-car garage, deck; taxes $3,726.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Beale of Geneseo, N.Y., have annonced the engagement of their daughter Martha Kimberley Beale to Frederick E. Nicholson, a son of William A. Nicholson of Palm City, Fla., and the late Gladys Marie Nicholson. Miss Beale is an assistant head nurse in the operating room at the North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I.

LEAD: I AM shooting down the Colorado River in gray rubber raft No. 612 with a mountainy boatman, a headphoned Upper West Sider and a Midwestern couple protected from the spray in see-through rain slickers, like potatoes in a Baggie. The Upper West Sider is listening to the ''Ride of the Valkyries'' on a Walkman supplied by one of the guides on our 13-day, 235-mile voyage through the Grand Canyon; modern rivermen don't quite trust the crashing river to hold the interest of tourists with contemporary attention spans.

LEAD: The second solo recital in Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau's Carnegie Hall engagement found the baritone in tremendous form Thursday, careening through the colorfully populated landscapes of ''Des Knaben Wunderhorn'' with a zest and command that made for an unforgettable evening.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Nancy Beth Kadner, the promotion director at Rolling Stone magazine in New York, and John Harry Feingold, a director of mortgage trading at Salomon Brothers in New York, plan to be married May 15. Ms. Kadner is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kadner of Los Angeles. Her fiance is the son of Raymond Feingold and Natalie Gittelson, both of New York.

LEAD: ''White, clean and neat'' - that's the way Robert Plant recalls his childhood in the mid-50's, in the song of the same name that concludes his new album, ''Now and Then'' (Esparanza/Atlantic 790863 LP, cassette and compact disk). He remembers Pat Boone singing mellifluous bromides to ''Take Daddy's Blues Away,'' and Debbie Reynolds, and Johnny Ray, all ''sugar, sugar white clean and neat.

LEAD: Aladar Szegedy-Maszak, a Hungarian diplomat who resigned as Ambassador to Washington in 1947 in a rejection of Communist rule in his country, died Friday at his home in Washington after a long illness. He was 84 years old.

LEAD: TRAVEL in Baja California has eased considerably since the first Jesuits ventured up the peninsula by horse and mule in the 17th century founding missions, but several logistical details must still figure into exploring the Baja.

LEAD: Gatwick Gets New Terminal Nearly 30 years after opening the South Terminal at Gatwick Airport, Queen Elizabeth dedicated the new North Terminal there on March 18, and passengers were due to begin using the building last week.

LEAD: A NEW industry has been developed over the last few years by companies offering to handle infectious waste ''from cradle to grave,'' transporting the red-bag garbage in special plastic boxes and burning it in incinerators or autoclaving. Red-bag waste is estimated to account for 10 percent of a hospital's garbage, but it can account for more than half of the disposal budget.

LEAD: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York, Dr. Elizabeth Anne Maher, an ophthalmology resident at the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, was married yesterday to Dr. Anthony Steven Borcich, a fellow in gastroenterology at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. The Rev.

LEAD: AARON ZIEGELMAN, one of New York City's biggest co-op converters, bought the seven-story apartment building at 97th Street and Broadway almost as an afterthought. He had just bought another building on Central Park West and the sellers said, well, as long as he was buying, why not look at this one too?

LEAD: About two years ago Irving Weinman, in his first novel, ''Tailor's Dummy,'' introduced Detective Inspector Lenny Schwartz of the New York Police Department. Schwartz had some unusual things going for him. He was a Harvard graduate. He was literate. He was smart. He was likable. He also at one time had taken a bribe in order to send his son through college, and that was something always at the nasty end of his subconscious - and his conscious, for that matter.

LEAD: The National Metaphor Baseball is the national metaphor as well as the national pastime, and nobody has a better batting average with a pen than Roger Angell. This is from ''Season Ticket: A Baseball Companion,'' (Houghton Mifflin).

LEAD: It is a car buff's dream. Here I am at the foot of a twisting-turn hill with five world-class automobiles at my disposal, and the object is to hop into one of them and get to the top as quickly as possible - without hurting myself or bending the machinery.

LEAD: Despite its lack of regimentation, A.A. works. More than three years ago, I learned that there is no single ''correct'' way to become, and to remain, sober. Some spend their days going from one meeting to another, others attend only one or two a month. At the meetings, some share their histories and their daily lives; some sit quietly and listen to the others.

LEAD: I have roamed the writing landscape, going from novels to biographies to short stories to television dramas to ballets to Broadway plays -but despite all that variety, for as long as I can remember I have coveted what I secretly considered the ultimate but elusive spice - writing a musical comedy.

LEAD: THE CLOSING BELL AT the New York Stock Exchange had not even sounded on Black Monday before Wall Street was blaming the Reagan Administration and Congress for provoking the crash with out-of-control budgets and deliberate debasement of the dollar. Washington, meanwhile, was accusing the investment banking crowd, with its megabillion-dollar mergers and exotic trading techniques, of turning our capital markets into one gigantic casino.

LEAD: ''Espressiv: central Euro-pean Art Since 1960'' - an exhibition hunkered down in the basement of the Hirshhorn Museum through April 17 -brings together a sobering dose of grim, gritty art from five countries: Yugoslavia, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Poland and Austria. For the artists represented in the show, the focus is squarely on the human figure, twisted into anguished, grotesque, defiant, occasionally amusing shapes.

LEAD: Pat LaFontaine negotiates an ice rink the way a water beetle negotiates a pond. He skitters across it, preferring a series of zig-zags to the more conventional route. Even mobile defensemen are left twirling in place from the effort of trying to imitate his path. Goaltenders, trying to anticipate his every move, see only a darting blur instead of a straightforward forward.

LEAD: TWONG! THAT'S A sound no one wants to hear this spring as golfers tee off at Willowbend Golf Club in Wichita, Kan. The brainchild of entrepreneur George J. Ablah, Willowbend boasts an original sculpture at every tee. LEAD: The engagement of Cornelia Liu to Dr. Edward Lloyd Trimble, a son of Mrs. I. Ridgeway Trimble of Baltimore and the late Dr. Trimble, has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Dr. and Mrs. Darrell T. Liu of Bethesda, Md. The couple plan to marry May 7.

LEAD: President Daniel arap Moi being sworn in for his third five-year term yesterday in Nairobi. He has been President since 1978, when he succeeded Jomo Kenyatta, the country's first leader. (Reuters)

LEAD: Because some of its forms make use of castanets and stampings, Spanish dance can be an art of sound as well as sight. But sounds and sights were occasionally blurred in the program that Andrea Del Conte and the American Spanish Dance Theater gave Thursday night at the Triplex Theater of Borough of Manhattan Community

LEAD: Anne Neal Emmons and James Stephenson Mason, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Mason of Parkersburg, W.Va., and Kennebunkport, Me., plan to marry in June, the parents of the future bride, Diane Neal Emmons of Manchester, Mass., and Robert W. Emmons Jr. of Annisquam, Mass., have announced.

LEAD: Laura Ann Hood, a dancer with the American Ballet Theater, and Robert Martin Hupp, the managing director of the Jean Cocteau Repertory Theater, were married yesterday at the Society of Friends Meeting House in Manhattan. Bishop Anthony Fennimore of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints performed the ceremony.

LEAD: WHEN negotiations between the Nicaraguan Government and rebel leaders opened Monday morning at the southern border outpost of Sapoa, a group of visiting Americans was on hand to offer moral support to the Sandinistas, none quite believing that this was really happening. As the contras touched Nicaraguan soil legally for the first time in years, one of the visitors called out, ''The North American people want a cease-fire.

LEAD: In the afternoon, the gray station wagon left parked on a residential block in Manhattan's Chelsea district still looked like a station wagon. After dark, the scavengers arrived and removed some of the engine and the rear wheels. Then, finding nothing else of value, they smashed all the windows, showering broken glass and leaving behind another in the rising tide of abandoned hulks that deface American streets.

LEAD: ''Some days we really suffered, but that's war. What we really want is to live in peace. I believe we can stop hating each other.'' - Daniel Verona, 18, after two years in the Nicaraguan Army. [ 19:1. ]
LEAD: MADISON AVENUE was alive with drama last week, as top executives at Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein defected from the shop's British parent, WPP Group P.L.C., and set up their own firm.
LEAD: ONE OF THE GUYS The Wising Up of an American Man. By Harry Stein. 269 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

LEAD: Two men appeared in court today on charges that they murdered two British soldiers during a funeral for an Irish Republican Army member in which the soldiers were beaten, stripped and then shot.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Leder of Margate, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cynthia Ruth Leder to Jeffrey Glekel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Newton Glekel of Manhattan. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: IT WAS A WEEKLY TUESDAY LUNCH AT Cafe 43 in Manhattan, the home of the esteemed Theodore Gordon Flyfishers. And as surely as the mayflies hatch on the hallowed surface of the Beaverkill River in the third week of April, thoughts turned - as they invariably do among fishermen sounding the depths of winter - to spring.

LEAD: The tobacco industry failed to exercise its moral responsibility to research the risks of smoking after independent studies in the 1930's began to link lung cancer to cigarettes, an epidemiologist testified in Federal District Court here this week.

Pei as architect for the much-needed renovation of the Louvre; and when Pei's sleekly contemporary design emerged, it generated public outrage on both political and cultural grounds.

LEAD: Stephanie Anne Wiley and Ronald David Sernau, graduates of the Cornell University Law School, were married last evening at the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook, N.Y., by Rabbi Sandy Bogin.

LEAD: AN astronomy book from 1474 has two wheels that turn to show the movements of the moon. An 1850 work on obstetrics has 50 flaps that lift to reveal anatomical details. A 1977 artist's book contains a real tortilla sealed in Mylar. A book about Georgia is shaped like Georgia, and Poemobiles have poems popping up from flat surfaces.
LEAD: With more than 700 soldiers being discharged from military service at the Sandinista Army base here today, it was natural that the air be filled with cheers and enthusiasm.
LEAD: A Lumbee Indian who was a candidate for Superior Court judge in racially troubled Robeson County was found shot to death today at his home, officials said.

LEAD: TWELVE-FOOT-HIGH walls. Steel gates. Dogs and armed guards. Inside, cool, high-ceilinged old houses, oases of green lawns, servants slipping noiselessly about - and women. For six weeks last spring I went from one feudal family compound to another in Pakistan. And always it was the same. Glasses of pomegranate juice.
LEAD: THE story of Holy Week is being told in music around the state this week as churches present the seasonal works of composers from medieval to modern times.

LEAD: Riot policemen backed by water cannon beat and arrested hundreds of Roman Catholics in western Czechoslovakia on Friday night when they demonstrated for religious freedom, Western reporters said today.

LEAD: AMERICAN officials are learning a basic history lesson from the mounting political and economic crisis in Panama: that just being on what they perceive as the right side of an issue is not enough to change the course of events.

LEAD: To the Editor: A few additional words on health and Himalayan travel: I became badly ill in Ladakh in 1985. At Srinagar I was given Mexoform, an antibiotic. This and the similar Enteroviaform are sold over the counter all over India. I learned that they are extremely dangerous - possible side effects include blindness - and are not sold here.

LEAD: After leading Florida Southern to the N.C.A.A. basketball semifinals, Jerry Johnson has been named the 1987-88 Division II player of the year. . . . Dan Jansen, the speed skater who fell twice during the Olympic Winter Games in Calgary, Alberta, has been asked to throw out one of the two first balls at the Milwaukee Brewers' home opener April 15.

LEAD: IN HIS MOST RECENT SHOWING OF MEN'S fashions in Milan, Franco Moschino gave tradition a vigorous tweak. Staging his show in a makeshift supper club, rather than in a conventional auditorium, he decked out his models in waiters' coats, and sent real waiters milling about arrayed in his new winter wares.

LEAD: In her March 6 essay (''To Sit, to Sleep, Perchance to Clap,'' Opinion page), Caren S. Goldberg wrote of her difficulty in staying awake in regional theater.

LEAD: The 50-odd piano pieces that Mendelssohn called ''Songs Without Words'' have been largely forgotten. They are small and unprepossessing, while the symphonies of Mahler are large and unavoidable. I suspect that every time Beethoven's Ninth takes a walk through our imagination, a miniature or two gets crushed underfoot.
LEAD: THE Fischoff and Coleman competitions are among the most prestigious in the world, and the Ridge String Quartet - formed only five years ago - has won both.

LEAD: As a recovering alcoholic, I was pleased to read Nan Robertson's article ''The Changing World of Alcoholics Anonymous'' (Feb. 21). Her style reflects our slogans -straightforward; no hype. As Ms. Robertson points out, ''It is in the intimacy of neighborhood meetings that . . an inkling of the reasons for A.A.
LEAD: ROGER W. POWERS is the president of Keep America Beautiful, a private, nonprofit organization based in Stamford and ''dedicated to building a national cleanliness ethic.''

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL/3-23 The Noriega Government in Panama moved swiftly to try to force an end to the economic paralysis that has gripped the country for weeks, using a combination of military muscle and threats of legal action. Page 1
LEAD: In her final competition as an amateur, Katarina Witt of East Germany tonight won the World Figure Skating Championship for the fourth time.

LEAD: I lived in Louisiana in the mid-1970's and had the opportunity to visit Carville on one occasion. I was struck by three things about the place - a sort of decaying beauty, an ethereal quiet and an overwhelming sense of isolation. At the time, I felt that Carville was in decline and that there would never be a need for another place like it again.

LEAD: THE burial of the dead inevitably is followed by the resurrection of politics in the ceaseless Irish-Anglo agony. But a striking quality in the latest episode of violence and despair, the worst in more than a decade, is how much of the post-mortem debate remains focused on surface points of conflict.
LEAD: Because of a transmission error, the telephone number for the state's AIDS hot line was incorrect in an article last week on AIDS education campaigns. The number is 1-800-624-2377.

LEAD: LAST DECEMBER A major clinical trial to determine whether aspirin could reduce the risk of heart attack in men was suddenly halted. Every other day for five years each of the 22,000 healthy doctors who had agreed to take part in the experiment had taken a white pill; half took an aspirin, half a placebo, and none knew what he was getting.

LEAD: For Temple, it was worse than having a kid brother tag along to the playground for a pickup basketball game, stepping on your toes along the way. The only place the Owls could find sanctuary from Duke today was in their huddle, and most of those sessions with their coach, John Chaney, were not at all pleasant.
LEAD: LONG ISLAND SOUND will be designated an ''estuary of national significance'' in ceremonies tomorrow, guaranteeing Federal financing for the Long Island Sound Study until at least 1991.

LEAD: 'Phantom' Party March 30 - The Joffrey Ballet is holding a theater benefit at ''The Phantom of the Opera.'' The evening will begin with cocktails at 6:30 at Sardi's. Tickets, $250 each or $1,000 for a pair, limousine service and an original cast recording, from 212-265-7300. Singles' Seder
LEAD: More than 3,000 people have gathered here to ponder soap operas, nursery rhymes, hair styles and other attributes of American popular culture.

LEAD: ''Objective'' explanations of the A.A. program are informative. But ''gritty'' facts cannot communicate the essential truth of the program. Bill Wilson and Bob Smith changed the world, not only for alcoholics, but for families and friends of alcoholics - Al-Anon and ACOA (Adult Children of Alcoholics) -gamblers (Gamblers Anonymous), drug addicts (Narcotics Anonymous), people with eating disorders (Overeaters Anonymous) and scores of others who find they need a program of recovery.

LEAD: Dr. Laurie Ellen Ellman, a dentist in Brooklyn Heights, and Dr. Matthew Jan Garfinkel, a resident in orthopedic surgery at the Montefiore Medical Center, were married last evening. Rabbi David E. Fass officiated at Singer's restaurant in Spring Valley, N.Y.

LEAD: For more than 30 years my father worked in Filene's, the Boston department store. As I look back, it seems important that he worked ''in'' Filene's, or ''with'' Filene's. I don't think I ever heard him say he worked ''for'' Filene's. There was a spirit of identification - a sense of family, to risk sounding maudlin - that the store's employees seemed to share.
LEAD: President Miguel de la Madrid has charged the Reagan Administration with emphasizing might over diplomacy in its Central American policy, at a high cost in death and destruction.

LEAD: THEY came to work in jeans and T-shirts, and passed the hours with magazines, video games and rubber band fights. Often, they took turns sleeping, and sometimes everyone on the shift was dozing.
LEAD: PROBABLY the most time-honored investment axiom is this: When everybody starts pushing the same products, or starts predicting the same things, do just the opposite.
LEAD: REDEVELOPMENT has begun to restore Armour Boulevard, one of Kansas City's major east-west thoroughfares, which had been tarnished by years of neglect.

LEAD: DeAndra Anrig was flying a kite near her home in Mountain View, Calif., last weekend when something stronger than the first breeze of spring caught hold of it.
LEAD: The contestants entered the old red brick recreation center here, picked up their numbered bibs and sat down on the wooden benches lined up across the gym floor.

LEAD: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., Jill Allison Barlow, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clive Barlow of Woodsburgh, L.I., was married last evening to Eric Mark Sussman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Sussman of Meadowbrook, Pa. Rabbis Joel Zion and Aaron Landis and Cantor David Benedict officiated.
LEAD: Phil Esposito, the general manager of the Rangers, was halfway out the door of the jubilant locker room before he turned, and began to try and address his team.

LEAD: To the Editor: ''Riding the Ghost Train'' (Travel, Jan. 31) confirmed my own experiences with Amtrak. They sell you a ticket on the grandiloquently titled Silver Star, Sarasota to New York. Unless you are a skillful timetable reader, you don't know till you get to the Sarasota Amtrak station that the first several hours will be spent on a bus from Sarasota to Tampa where the rail trip starts.

LEAD: A CENTURY-OLD Manhattan landmark is being converted from neighborhood eyesore to New York's biggest youth hostel. The project is a rare collaborative effort involving a West Side community group, a midtown developer, an international foundation, two Wall Street securities firms, seven government agencies and 300 profit-seeking investors in 30 states.
LEAD: MINDWORKS Time and Conscious Experience. By Ernst Poppel. Translated by Tom Artin. Illustrated. 224 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.95.

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson dealt a blow to the Presidential candidacy of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis today, trouncing him in the popular vote in Michigan's Democratic caucuses and denying him the momentum he had sought in this big industrial state.

LEAD: Skiing Zurbriggen Retains Title: Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland retained his World Cup overall title yesterday with two aggressive, risky runs in the season's last slalom in Saalbach, Austria. Alberto Tomba of Italy fell in the second run, but by then the battle for the title was decided.

LEAD: The engagement of Deirdre Finney and James Richard Boylan has been announced by Mrs. Thomas Dunn Finney of Idabel, Okla., a grandmother of the future bride. A June wedding is planned.
LEAD: Frank Johnson and Mark Alarie, both reserves, combined for 25 points tonight to help the Washington Bullets to a 99-88 victory over the Nets.

LEAD: Some listeners may regard the bright, vigorous sound of a wind ensemble as so seductive that the quality of the literature it plays doesn't matter. But listening to the Harmonie Ensemble's concert at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday evening, one had the impression that the greatest dilemma facing the director of such a group is finding literature worth hearing.

Nitze - in the play ''A Walk in the Woods'' on Broadway, Sam Waterston is adding two more characters to his ever-growing gallery of nonfictional heroes.

LEAD: ON International Women's Day earlier this month, the Chilean military Government outlawed public gatherings and sent army troops in battle gear into busy city streets and crowded shopping malls. The action was not a reflection of the Government's policy toward women but rather of its fear that the occasion would provide an excuse for anti-Government protests.

LEAD: I applaud the passion with which Gilbert W. Cass wrote ''Strategies for Dealing With Teen-Age Suicide'' (Opinion page, March 6). I strongly believe that everyone needs to know more about how to deal with and prevent the tragic waste of our adolescents who use suicide as a solution to the problems in their lives that appear to be insoluble.
LEAD: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis overcame a strong showing by the Rev. Jesse Jackson in the final weekend of Democratic caucuses to win North Dakota's Presidential preference poll today.
LEAD: The critical problems facing Mississippi's Gov. Ray Mabus are reminiscent of the problems that were successfully attacked in Vermont in the 1960's.
LEAD: Donald J. Trump disclosed yesterday that he had bought the Plaza Hotel for $390 million and would upgrade it into ''the most luxurious hotel in the world.''

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Theodore F. Brophy of Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Anne Redmond Brophy, to Standish Heminway O'Grady, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. O'Grady of Princeton, N.J. The couple plan to marry in August.

LEAD: ABOUT $80 million in public and private money has been invested in the last five years in new manufacturing plants, businesses, homes and public works in this town of 13,000 people nestled beside the Androscoggin River.
LEAD: IN the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx, a commercial and residential revival has uprooted the bingo players of Upper Broadway.

LEAD: IN an era when influencing government is a big business, the New York State Commission on Government Integrity is focusing on a new type of power broker - the public relations consultant representing private interests who doubles as a fund-raiser for politicians who often control the fate of those same interests.

LEAD: THE big news in fashion lately has been the rejection by many women of the miniskirt. Be that as it may, there is still a segment of the population, mostly young and obviously in excellent shape, that has embraced the shorter styles - or rather, let the styles embrace them. For these women the mini, especially the mini evening dress, is standard attire.

LEAD: REPRESENTATIVE John D. Dingell emerged from a recent closed-door meeting with his arm draped around the shoulders of Representative John Bryant. Moments later, he warmly greeted Treasury Secretary James Baker in a Capitol corridor, and the door of Mr. Dingell's office closed behind the two.

LEAD: The engagement of Allison Chisolm to Peter Holger Hansen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Holger Hansen of Swarthmore, Pa., has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. William A. Chisolm of New York. The couple plan to marry in June.

LEAD: The score is tied at 3-3, it's the last half of the ninth, runner on second base. Here comes the pitch: a hit to centerfield . . . runner is on the way home . . . the throw from center field . . . batter slides . . . the umpire calls the batter out. Extra innings. Wait. The home-team manager asks for instant replay.
LEAD: WITH camera and clipboard in hand, Mary McCahon has been driving along every street, avenue and byway in Westport, taking pictures of buildings of historic interest.

LEAD: ''I don't know how to invest that kind of money without acquiring something.'' - J. Hugh Liedtke, Pennzoil's chairman, on how to spend $3 billion.

LEAD: The program that Chris Burnside shared with Mickey McLaughlin and Dancers on Friday night at St. Mark's Church contained dances jammed with steps. Yet the most effective work was a monologue in which clever lines were heightened with a few well-chosen movements.

LEAD: THE NEW AGE: Notes of a Fringe-Watcher. By Martin Gardner. (Prometheus, $19.95.) Martin Gardner preaches to the unbeliever. He seeks not only to explain seemingly unexplainable phenomena, but to put them into context. Half of this book, which will be in stores in late April, is composed of Gardner columns called ''Notes of a Fringe-Watcher,'' written for the Buffalo journal Skeptical Inquirer.

LEAD: LOSING an airplane ticket can be worse than losing your passport. United States Embassies can rapidly replace a lost or stolen passport, but you may never get a penny back if your ticket is stolen, or it could take 18 months to recover what you have to spend to get a new one. There are some bright spots.

LEAD: AMONG those who fear infectious diseases the most are surgeons who can be exposed to large amounts of blood while operating. ''A small minority of surgeons refuse to operate on AIDS patients,'' said Dr. Edward Quebbeman of Milwaukee, a member of the Committee on the Operating Room Environment of the American College of Surgeons.

LEAD: THE Tax Reform Act of 1986 is creating a new trend: his and her tax returns. Before, almost all married couples saved money by filing joint tax returns. Couples who filed separately faced higher tax rates. More important, they lost valuable tax benefits like the ''two earner'' deduction, which was equal to 10 percent of the salary of the lower-earning partner, up to $3,000.

LEAD: THE BODY IN TIME By Kenneth Jon Rose. Illustrated. 237 pp. New York: John Wiley & Sons. $19.95.

LEAD: THE weekend of Easter observances and the beginning of Passover coincide this year. Home cooks will be busy preparing Passover seders on Friday and Saturday evenings or putting together Easter Sunday dinners.

LEAD: HEDGEHOG pudding, fruit creams, tansies, syllabubs, flummeries, junkets, trifles: not just one, but all of these fancifully named sweets would have adorned an English banquet table in the 18th century. LEAD: In his article ''When Fear Conquers'' (Feb. 28), Douglas Shenson has, in large measure, figured out the key to educating the nation about the dreaded disease AIDS. He has done so by asking us to reflect on our past behavior as we worked our way through the fear that accompanied another dreaded disease, leprosy.
LEAD: American residents of the former Canal Zone say the Panamanian Government is harassing and intimidating American civilians and military personnel here.

LEAD: A decade ago, when the number of homeless people in the City of New York was roughly a fifth of what the city estimates it to be today, this problem could not be seen in terms of architecture. It was more a matter of management, of helping people find what housing existed and getting them the money to pay for it.
LEAD: A 16-month-old conference in Vienna on security and humanitarian issues has recessed with progress reported toward new negotiations on conventional arms, but little movement on human rights.
LEAD: An attempt by townspeople to protect mating salamanders from being killed by cars has been thwarted - all but one of the amphibians has ignored tunnels installed for them beneath a busy street.

LEAD: A United States team led by the former world champion Bruce Baumgartner and two-time National Collegiate Athletic Association champion Royce Alger will meet the Cuba national wrestling team in a dual meet Thursday at Edinboro University.

LEAD: The cinema is an art that thrives on legend, but it took time for it to develop legends of its own. In the beginning it borrowed themes and motifs from the other popular arts, from well-established traditions in fiction, the theater, vaudeville, genre painting; and if early movies seemed thrillingly modern when they first appeared, with the passage of time one of their most interesting aspects has become the way in which they frequently preserve the spirit of the 19th century.

LEAD: THEY swept into Elmont's Petite Corner restaurant: the Gold Coasters, with ankle-length white coats, furs, fashionable dresses and the unmistakable aura of people in the know. Now their secret is out. This is a gem of a restaurant, well worth a trip to Elmont.

LEAD: DESPITE the vast changes that have taken place within 35-millimeter cameras in the last 10 years, including a dramatic shift from mechanical to electronic controls, the outsides have stayed pretty much the same. The typical camera body is still a pudgy rectangle about the size of a deli ham sandwich with a lens stuck in the middle.
LEAD: Property-tax exemptions totaling $4.3 billion were granted to more than a million New Yorkers in 1986, according to a state report issued this week.

LEAD: The article, ''Legislators Weigh Raceway Proposal'' [ March 6 ] , outlines many of the ramifications of establishing betting parlors in our county. One overlooked consequence of legitimizing and facilitating easy access to horse race betting is the possible increase in the number of pathological gamblers.
LEAD: Iran's attack into northeastern Iraq last week was a tactical success, but is of little strategic importance, according to both American and Iraqi military experts.

Stanley Shaw of Bayside, Queens, was married last evening to Lon Jay Goldstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Goldstein of East Norwich, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Arnold B. Marans officiated. The bride, a sales assistant for Shearson Lehman Hutton, graduated from Syracuse University.

LEAD: International A3-13 Nicaragua freed 100 prisoners under the cease-fire agreement signed by the Government and rebels. The prisoners released represent a cross-section of those being held for violating the public security law. Page A1 Flour seized by Panamanian troops will be sold to the baking industry.

LEAD: Whenever the phone used to ring at the Temple University bookstore, it was usually a personal call for one of the employees or a wrong number. Occasionally, it was a faithful alumnus seeking a sweatshirt for his grandson.

LEAD: A new cartoon character has shown up in Chilean newspapers in the past year: a cowboy-hatted kangaroo, its pouch stuffed with dollars, telephones and the documents of complicated financial deals.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Behind the dry statistics of drug-case prosecutions that help to choke New York City's court dockets are episodes that illustrate typical arrests and typical plea bargains.
LEAD: Cable cars travelling their daily route on Powell Street, one of San Francisco's steepest slopes, near Nob Hill. Today the Powell Street line will celebrate it's 100th anniversary. (AP)

LEAD: Last summer, in yet another setback for American industry, the bankrupt LTV Corporation closed down J & L Structural Inc., one of the last functioning mills in LTV's vast steel-making complex along the Ohio River near here. Gene Gormley, the mill operator, scratched the date on his control console as if it were an epitaph: 8-14-87.
LEAD: In an effort to lure white students back into the Seattle public schools, Superintendent William M. Kendrick is proposing to halve the number of children bused for racial integration.

LEAD: Two tough foursomes, liberally supplied with both skill and stamina, fought here this afternoon in the final of the Vanderbilt knockout team championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.

LEAD: From the chaos of mass protest, strikes and ethnic violence that have rocked two southern Soviet republics, a sharp new debate has begun to emerge about what ''democracy'' means in Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Soviet Union.
LEAD: The Equimark Corporation, a Pittsburgh-based financial holding company, has not only announced it is searching for a new agency but also the names of the four finalists, all in New York.

LEAD: Joan Harris Blum, director of a drug and alcohol counseling program in Millbrook, N.Y., died of cancer today at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan and Millbrook.

LEAD: Lee Guber, who helped produce nearly a dozen shows on Broadway and was part of an entertainment chain that brought such performers as Judy Garland, Jack Benny, Sammy Davis Jr., Perry Como and Liberace to suburban theaters and concert halls around the country, died of brain cancer yesterday at his home on the East Side of Manhattan.
LEAD: More than 12.3 million cars, trucks, vans and motorcycles valued at $52 billion were stolen over a 13-year period, the Federal Government said today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''What would I ask them?'' Maggie Rodriguez repeated. ''About the drug problem, the crack problem, that's the biggest problem around here.'' ''Holdups, robberies,'' Carmen Velez said. ''Now that we have the new houses here it's going to get worse,'' Mrs. Rodriguez predicted. ''The more new houses we have, the more customers, the more people are going to try crack.
LEAD: A fire apparently started by a kerosene heater spread through four row houses early Sunday, killing five people and forcing 17 others to flee, officials said.

LEAD: A 35-year-old pitcher may keep going for 10 more years. A 35-year-old defensive end may rush the passer all game without tiring. But 35-year-old tennis players are not meant to play for 3 hours 39 minutes when the temperature is 83 degres in the stands and more than 120 on the cement court and the humidity is 63 degrees and draining.

LEAD: Marchers carrying Greek and American flags as they marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday in Greek Independence Day parade. Spectators, right, also waved blue and white Greek flags in celebration of the 167th anniversary of the country's independence. (NYT/Vic DeLucia)

LEAD: ALONG with snowdrops blooming in secluded places, pussy willow catkins swelling and the first orange-red nodules of rhubarb emerging from last year's mulch, another sure sign of spring in New York State is the opening of the trout season April 1.

LEAD: Three new cast members assembled in ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' at the Metropolitan Opera Saturday evening. Douglas Ahlstedt, as Ferrando, came closer than he has in other seasons to fulfilling the promise he showed when he came on the scene in the 1970's. His tenor rang out bright and true in the first scenes, he acted with spirit, and though he is not a model of elegant phrasing, he did quite capable work in the lyrical movements.
LEAD: Corporate raiders used to look at one thing in picking an acquisition target: the value of a company's businesses in relation to its stock price.

LEAD: In Heine's ''Doch die Kastraten Klagen,'' a poet and singer derides the castratos, with their pure tones and crystal trills, for objecting to the roughness of his own song. A new setting of the poem, by David Blake, was heard at Weill Recital Hall Friday night in the course of a joint recital by the baritone John Shirley-Quirk and the oboist Sara Watkins.

LEAD: North Carolina's Rick Fox trying to knock ball away from Arizona's Steve Kerr in West Regional championship. Arizona won, 70-52, and will face Oklahoma in the Final Four. Kansas beat Kansas State, 71-58, in Midwest Regional and will meet Duke. SportsMonday, page C1. (AP)

LEAD: Bolstered by substantial increases in exports, orders for American-made machine tools remained strong for the second straight month, increasing by two-tenths of 1 percent in February from the previous month, to $298 million, the industry's trade association said.

LEAD: Last October a little girl named Jessica McClure fell into a well hole in Midland, Tex. Four hundred people - public employees and volunteers - worked for three days and two nights to get her out.
LEAD: * Armstrong World Industries has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $250 million of debt securities.

LEAD: The Omnicom Group has split Doremus Porter Novelli back into its previous components, with Doremus Public Relations handling financial and investor relations, and Porter Novelli doing general public relations and serving as the worldwide coordinator of the Omnicom PR Network. Both units are part of Omnicom's Diversified Agency Services division.

LEAD: As Beazer P.L.C. of Britain made its sweetened bid for the Koppers Company official last week, executives of the Pittsburgh-based company stepped up their campaign to ward off the takeover through a publicity campaign that has mobilized state and local officials.

LEAD: The nation's stock and commodity markets will be closed April 1 in observance of Good Friday. Most foreign stock exchanges will be closed. Banks will be open, as will most businesses and Government offices. The Labor Department is scheduled to report on the nation's unemployment rate for March, and the Commerce Department is scheduled to report on construction spending for February.

LEAD: Jack Clark limped from the trainer's room to his locker to the whirpool and back. It was obvious he still felt some of the pain from the torn muscle in his left calf, but as he spoke about it today, his voice carried distinct shades of optimism.

LEAD: Fred Jacobson, a former United States Foreign Service officer and a lyricist, died of a heart attack at Greenwich Hospital today. He was 73 years old and lived in Greenwich, Manhattan and Florence.

LEAD: Presidents come and presidents go, but one thing has always remained constant here. For Panamanians, the National Lottery could always be counted on to stay immune to the vicissitudes of politics and daily life.

LEAD: Dr. Addie Sherbany, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Sherbany of Manhasset Hills, L.I., and Milan Ganik, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vojtech Ganik of Phoenix, were married yesterday at the Water Club in Manhattan by Rabbi M. Asher Murciano.

LEAD: KEYE/DONNA/PEARLSTEIN of Los Angeles will reveal itself tomorrow as the cunning collective brain behind the mysterious print advertisements for Mammoth Pervasive and Bland Inc., a nonexistent agency.

LEAD: The security forces shot and killed four people accused of being Kurdish guerrillas in southeastern Turkey today, the Anatolia news agency reported. The agency said the four, who were discovered in a cave, opened fire on Government troops searching the area near Bahce, a village in Adiyaman Province.

LEAD: Mark McCumber, who gave up the landscaping business for the pro golf tour 10 years ago, completed a record score of 15-under-par 273 on the Tournament Players Club course today to easily win the Players Championship.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY Interest rates seem unlikely to move much from recent levels, although the credit markets may be stimulated in the short term by the drop in stock prices. There is little evidence that either the economy or inflation will shoot up, analysts say. They predict that yields on the Treasury's 30-year bond are likely to remain within a range of 8.50 percent to 8.75 percent for a few weeks.
LEAD: A Long Island man died after throwing himself in front of a Metro-North train yesterday afternoon in what officials described as an apparent suicide.

LEAD: Twenty Texas savings and loans lost more than $4 billion last year. Now insolvency is consuming the commercial banks as well. Texas Commerce Bancshares and First City Bancorporation of Houston are belly up, and last week the giant First RepublicBank of Dallas took the first formal steps toward oblivion.

LEAD: On April 15, 1986, when U.S. bombers gave a permanent headache to Libya's Muammar el-Qaddafi, Bill Casey brought a group of non-C.I.A. economists in to see the President. As bombs fell on Tripoli, statistics about the Soviet economy rained on Ronald Reagan.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In 1983, Gov. William J. Sheffield urged the Alaska Legislature to end the year-old program giving Alaskans a personal slice of the state's oil wealth, which meant an annual check of several hundred dollars for each resident.
LEAD: As part of a big push to make a name for itself in the United States, the French clothing chain Rodier has named Max J. Garelick president and chief executive of Rodier U.S.A.
LEAD: Tens of thousands of young people jammed the streets of this desert resort Saturday for traditional spring break revelry watched closely by a reinforced police presence.
LEAD: Maya Plisetskaya as diva - that is the image to retain of the Bolshoi Ballet's superstar in the title role of ''Anna Karenina.''

LEAD: Representative Jack F. Kemp is expected to endorse Vice President Bush on Monday. But the man who played that role in the 1974 film ''Uptown Saturday Night'' is also an internationally known acrobatic tap-dancer.

LEAD: ''We parents will take our own hang-ups to the grave, but there's no reason for our kids to continue them.'' - Cindy Brannigan of Belfast, Northern Ireland. [ A10:2. ]

Derek Walcott, the poet, Ralph Ellison, the novelist, and Dr. Mary Schmidt Campbell, the city's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs and an authority on Mr.

LEAD: Deborah Khazei, who does aerobics for a living and is currently one of the Crystal Light national mixed-pairs champions, made a celebrity appearance yesterday at the first New York Sports Expo, downtown at the Palladium.

LEAD: A rarity in racially troubled Robeson County, Julian Pierce was respected by blacks, Indians and whites, but many of his supporters say he was slain because someone did not want a Lumbee Indian to be a judge.
LEAD: Ogilvy & Mather has once again won the richest purse in advertising, the $100,000 award bestowed by the Magazine Publishers of America for the best magazine advertising of the year.
LEAD: Israeli soldiers shot dead four more Palestinians today as the army pressed a campaign that the Government says has led to the arrest of nearly 2,000 people in a week and a half.
