LEAD: * Jim Scalfone has joined the William Esty Company, a part of Saatchi & Saatchi, as senior vice president, executive art director.

LEAD: An intense rivalry is shaping up between two star vocalists, Edward I. Koch, the Mayor of New York, and Philippe de Montebello, the director of the Metropolitan Museum, on the sonic battlefield of cassette tapes.
LEAD: Washington Goes to War By David Brinkley Illustrated. 286 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.
LEAD: Malaysia's liveliest English-language newspaper, The Star, has resumed publication after a five-month ban.

LEAD: After nearly a year of delays, a court unit devoted exclusively to narcotics cases will begin operating in Queens today in an effort to speed the prosecution of dealers arrested in the borough's drug-plagued neighborhoods.
LEAD: The average retail price of gasoline fell again during the past two weeks, to less than 95 cents a gallon, according to a nationwide survey.

LEAD: George Steinbrenner's prolonged cold war with Dave Winfield advanced to a new front today. The Yankee owner said Winfield's recently published autobiography would disrupt team unity, and he suggested that the player's physical attributes might be diminishing.

LEAD: Take your choice: relations between men and women these days are generally a matter of (a) cynical hustling or (b) wary truce. Depends on which television channel you stumble into. For the hustler theory, tune in at 9 P.M. tonight to ''Addicted to His Love,'' an ABC television movie starring Barry Bostwick as a modern Lothario on the prowl.

LEAD: The 114th Kentucky Derby is just 40 days off, but it is as difficult to find anyone with a strong opinion about the race as it is to find a colt who looks like a good bet to win it.

LEAD: The Defense Department spends billions in developing high-tech weapons to offset the Soviet edge in numbers. To understand how perversely this vital agenda is pursued, consider the death of the Aquila, a pilotless plane that the Army has been developing for 14 years. It is one of the few new weapons canceled in the new defense budget.
LEAD: A retired Spanish Air Force general was shot to death and a bomb exploded in central Madrid today, wounding two people. The police blamed the Basque separatist group E.T.A. for both attacks.

LEAD: Robin Ruskin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. Ronald Ruskin of New York and Menands, N.Y., and Brian David Linder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome J. Linder of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., were married yesterday at the Harmonie Club in New York. Rabbi Stanley Davids, assisted by Cantor David Benedict, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The recent sharp drop in stock prices may provide a short-term stimulant to the fixed-income markets, but most analysts say that interest rates are likely to remain mired in the narrow range they have occupied for the past several weeks.

LEAD: The Army has decided to reconsider its plan to build a laboratory in Utah for testing defenses against biological weapons. The decision came after a week marked by increasingly intense local opposition.
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company's non-automotive subsidiaries together earned a $62 million profit in 1987, their first money-making year since 1979, the auto maker said in its annual report.

LEAD: August Wilson continues to rewrite the history of the American theater by bringing the history of black America - and with it the history of white America - to the stage. In ''Joe Turner's Come and Gone,'' Mr. Wilson's third play to reach New York, that history unfolds with the same panoramic sweep that marked ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom'' and ''Fences.

LEAD: All accused persons are presumed innocent until proved guilty, but few enjoy that presumption as fully as the indicted Iran-contra defendants. President Reagan, the highest law officer in the land, the man for whom the attorney general works, said of them last week: ''I just have to believe that they're going to be found innocent because I don't believe they're guilty of lawbreaking of any kind.

LEAD: Gene Moore is leaning back in his chair this morning in his seventh-floor office at Tiffany & Company dreaming about Easter 1989. ''Eggs,'' he is thinking, as he has every Easter for the 53 years since he began to dress windows in the stores along Fifth Avenue. ''What can I do with eggs that I haven't done before?
LEAD: THROUGHOUT the economic expansion of the 1980's the economist Edward A. Hyman warned time and again that the longer it continued the greater grew the risk of a 1930's-type depression.
LEAD: Counting laps as one swims can be tedious, especially when the numbers approach three digits. Now, there is a computer designed to do the task.

LEAD: IN the next room, the framed pictures of his U.C.L.A. championship teams have been hung on a wall. Each of the 10 frames holds the young faces of Bruins - Lew Alcindor, Bill Walton, and champions that came before, between and after - with the backdrop of the arena that housed the national semifinals and finals.

LEAD: N.H.L. Penguins 6, Nordiques 3: Mario Lemieux scored two short-handed goals yesterday as Pittsburgh, playing on the road, beat Quebec and moved into a fourth-place tie in the Patrick Division with the Rangers. Lemieux, the league's leading scorer with 65 goals, has figured in 13 the last 14 goals scored by the Penguins.

LEAD: Ronne G. Mandelker, the daughter of Evelyn Ostow Mandelker of New York and the late Benjamin Mandelker, and Andrew Halfin Braiterman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Hirsh Braiterman of Baltimore, were married yesterday. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein officiated at Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun in Manhattan.

LEAD: After 12 years of trading their currency at a discount to the United States dollar, Canadians have watched recently with a mixture of satisfaction and concern as the Canadian unit has bumped progressively upward, passing the 80-cent (United States) level last recorded in February 1984.

LEAD: At Congregation Rodeph Sholom in New York, Amy Gail Knoblauch, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney G. Knoblauch of Reading, Pa., and James David Dubin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel S. Dubin of State College, Pa., were married yesterday by Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH the national obsession with fitness is now more than a decade old (some would argue more than two decades old), beginning a serious exercise program for the first time can still generate excitement and turn a person's life around.

LEAD: Lynne Barbara Whitman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ira L. Whitman of East Brunswick, N.J., was married yesterday to Daniel Solomon Solender, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen D. Solender of Manhattan. Rabbi Eric Milgrim officiated at the Livingston (N.J.) Country Club.

LEAD: If the advocates are correct, raising the minimum wage, now $3.35 an hour, would have few noticeable adverse effects on business or employment and could stimulate the economy by increasing the purchasing power of the 4.7 million Americans who earn it.

LEAD: It's hard to explore ideas on television; the medium moves too fast. Moreover, if it slows down, we grow bored. No matter how thoughtful television tries to be, it doesn't work unless it commands our attention. ''Moyers: Facing Evil'' is thoughtful; it commands our attention as well. In the least likely places, it is full of exhilaration.

LEAD: * Butterick Co., a consumer products company specializing in home sewing patterns, fashion publications and greeting cards, set up a new division called Butterick Sales Co. and named Allan Feller its president.

LEAD: There is indeed an unsensational, nonviolent story to be told about the troubled Irish of Belfast. It is about a fragile integrated school started by Protestant and Roman Catholic parents sick of what the sectarian divide has done to the minds of children.

LEAD: Injuries, suspensions and academic problems could easily have ruined their season, but the Kansas Jayhawks seemed to survive with the brilliance of Danny Manning and a hard-working, complementary mix. LEAD: A Northwest Airlines jet was evacuated tonight at Detroit Metropolitan Airport here when residual fuel vapors briefly ignited, causing what witnesses thought to be a fire, officials said. Four passengers were injured slightly while evacuating the Boeing 727 shortly after it landed at 8:20 P.M., and the incident forced the airport to close for about 20 minutes.
LEAD: In Washington, social functions can make strange bedfellows, or in this case, pillow-fellows.
LEAD: Ivan Toms, a 35-year-old physician, chose to go to jail for 21 months rather than continue serving as a reserve lieutenant in the South African Defense Force.
LEAD: After their 7-2 triumph over the Rangers here this afternoon, the Devils have come a step closer to believing the last playoff spot in the Patrick Division is within their grasp.

LEAD: Senta Driver once called her dances portraits of herself thinking. She certainly was a thinking choreographer on Saturday night when her company, Harry, came to the Emanu-El Midtown Y. Ms. Driver revived ''Memorandum,'' a cerebral and astonishing solo dating from 1975 in which she simply trudged while reciting names of famous ballet dancers.

LEAD: Ron Darling, the thinking man's pitcher, is thinking less and winning more these days. And he gave another rave performance for the Mets today when he buzzed seven innings of one-hit shutout ball against the Houston Astros.

LEAD: A Jerusalem district court today sentenced a former nuclear technician, Mordechai Vanunu, to 18 years in prison for telling a London newspaper that Israel was secretly manufacturing atomic bombs in an underground factory.

LEAD: South Korea's gross national product grew 12 percent last year, down from a growth rate of 12.3 percent in 1986, the Bank of Korea announced Friday. Bank officials said exports accounted for 46.1 percent of the G.N.P. last year, reaching a record total of $47.2 billion, up 36.2 percent from a year earlier.

LEAD: Brian M. Powers, an American from Massapequa, L.I., became one of the most powerful people in Hong Kong by being named ''tai-pan,'' or ''big boss,'' of Jardine Matheson & Company, the big trading concern.

LEAD: A prominent Arab oil expert, describing the oil market as ''very weak,'' warned today that the failure of members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to abide by their output quotas could bring a collapse of oil prices.
LEAD: Richard and Kathleen Bradley of Westford, Mass., have a tradition: they ring a Swiss cowbell on the front porch of their colonial house every time their daughter wins a golf tournament.
LEAD: The authorities here have confirmed that suicide was the cause of death of a New Jersey education official who had been dismissed amid a criminal investigation of his office.

LEAD: President Reagan's farewell appearance at the Gridiron Club dinner transformed the Washington press corps' annual tribal rite in white-tie-and-tails into an evening likely to be remembered for its sentimentality as much as for the pungency of its political one-liners.
LEAD: Regina Belle and Peabo Bryson slid cleanly through a moderately inspired pop concert at the Beacon Theater on Saturday night.
LEAD: Reports of evil spirits haunting trees and swooping down to possess innocent villagers have shown a marked reduction here in recent years.

LEAD: Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat, implied last year that he would not seek another term as Senate majority leader. But Mr. Byrd's advisers now say he has not decided what he will do. Rivals are not waiting for the final word.

LEAD: Democratic Party leaders expressed astonishment today at the Rev. Jesse Jackson's landslide victory in the Michigan caucuses Saturday and confessed that they found it hard, after weeks of surprises, to predict how or when the party's Presidential race would be decided.

LEAD: Although Mary Cleere Haran has appeared on and off Broadway in shows like ''The 1940's Radio Hour,'' ''The Heebie Jeebies,'' and ''Hollywood Opera,'' her stage work barely suggested the superbly supple and witty cabaret singer she has become.

LEAD: A 10-year-old boy and two adults were killed, and two girls were injured in a head-on crash Saturday night, the state police said yesterday.

LEAD: WPP Group of Britain will go to court today in an effort to ward off the potential collapse of its Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein subsidiary. But the company's actions may help make its chairman, Martin Sorrell, the target of anti-British feelings that have surfaced in the advertising business.
LEAD: The Hampton University women's basketball team traveled to North Dakota this past weekend, looking to win its first National Collegiate Athletic Association Division II championship.

LEAD: It is four days until Passover, but by yesterday afternoon the air inside Schapiro's had the sweet, sticky smell of the seder table after the fourth glass of wine. Small wonder. LEAD: When the definitive history of Wall Street is written, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. is assured a place as the house that built the junk bond. But had it not been for David H. Batchelder, adviser to the Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens, the age of the junk bond might well have arrived much later.

LEAD: The Democratic Presidential campaign comes to New York State in earnest this week with three candidates debating at Fordham University tonight and New York politicians trying to assess the Rev. Jesse Jackson's stunning victory Saturday in Michigan.
LEAD: When Arizona began its season with victories over Syracuse, Michigan and Iowa, skeptics said that Lute Olson's Wildcats were playing too well too early and predicted burnout by February.

LEAD: Even if they try, jurors usually are unable to follow a judge's instructions to disregard inadmissible testimony introduced in trials, says a Northwestern University researcher who studied cases involving illegal searches.

LEAD: Some of the strongest backers of the World Bank, which has never had a lot of friends in Congress, may turn against it this year in an election-year showdown over the need for additional capital.

LEAD: Outrage over the seizure by troops of thousands of sacks of flour from the country's two largest mills deepened today after the military Government announced that it planned to sell all 1.3 million pounds to the baking industry.

LEAD: Michael Bowman explaining the fine art of kite flying to his son, Esis, yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. Today is expected to be much like yesterday with temperatures in the 50's and mostly sunny skies. (NYT/Suzanne DeChillo)
LEAD: Regulars at JD's Circle In weren't about to stand by idly when armed robbers burst into the bar and demanded money from the owner, Donna Hannum.

LEAD: A jubilant Jesse Jackson, fresh from a stunning victory in the Michigan Democratic caucuses Saturday, brought his campaign to Connecticut today, telling cheering supporters that he has a better record of service here than any of his opponents in the Connecticut primary Tuesday.

LEAD: A man who climbed to the top of the Brooklyn Bridge in despondency over family problems surrendered Saturday to the police, a police spokesman said yesterday.

LEAD: Andre Dawson said in a report published today that he would stay with the Chicago Cubs, regardless of his possible free-agent status, if he could sign an acceptable two-year contract with the club.

Shultz, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel complained that the meeting violated a United States commitment not to meet with members of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
LEAD: One hundred Nicaraguan prisoners walked through a wire gate to freedom today, the first direct beneficiaries of the new cease-fire accord.

LEAD: Suppose you had a beautiful city by the bay with a projected budget deficit of $172 million. Suppose that bay had a 12-acre rock sitting in it, formerly the home of an infamous Federal prison and now a tourist attraction that draws nearly 800,000 people each year.

LEAD: The cease-fire agreement that was signed on Wednesday in Nicaragua by the Sandinista Government and the contras, aimed at ending a long internal conflict, will have no apparent effect on that country's decision to skip the Summer Olympics this year in Seoul, South Korea.

LEAD: Passion is volatile in Sinead O'Connor's songs; within a verse, it can become love, anger, lust, vulnerability, defiance or religious fervor. The songs on her debut album, ''The Lion and the Cobra,'' carefully channel those raw emotions, shifting unpredictably from plea to accusation or from meditation to rock stomp; her voice can be sweet or lacerating, delivering endearments in a bitter rasp or breaking into wordless ululation.

LEAD: Worshipers bearing palm branches and tourists bearing cameras walked by as Norma Valdez stood silently in the rear of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday with her 1-month-old daughter, Angelica, all rosy and pink, swaddled in her arms.

LEAD: In rare praise for a nuclear weapons program, the House Armed Services Committee said today that the Navy's program to build an improved Trident submarine-launched missile appears to be on time and under budget. ''The other programs we've looked at had a variety of problems, so this is kind of a man-bites-dog story,'' said Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin and the panel's chairman.
LEAD: George W. Cornell, a New York lawyer and former Republican state senator, died last Thursday at his home in Boca Raton, Fla.. He was 91 years old and formerly lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.
LEAD: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts brought his Presidential campaign home to New England today to ask Connecticut voters to salve the wound of his defeat in Michigan.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration has miscalculated the ability of Panama's military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, to withstand American economic pressure aimed at forcing his ouster and is now considering further moves against him, a senior State Department official said today.

LEAD: Peter S. Kalikow and Peter O. Price, the new owner and publisher of The New York Post, have begun what they describe as ''evolutionary changes'' intended to highlight the newspaper's ties to Manhattan and make it ''the in-flight magazine of the New York City commuter.''

LEAD: A couple of nights ago, somebody asked John Sarandrea, the coach at St. Nicholas of Tolentine, one of the top-rated high-school basketball teams in the nation, what it had been like to coach under the scrutiny and pressure his Wildcats saw this season.

LEAD: DESPITE the numerous tax law changes that were incorporated in the 1987 income tax returns, the most common errors cropping up this season are mainly the kind that taxpayers have made in years past: sloppy math and putting numbers in the wrong places on the tax forms.

LEAD: Mimi Gross created magic in ''Matches,'' a new theater-dance piece choreographed by Douglas Dunn and performed by Douglas Dunn and Dancers on Saturday night at the Kitchen. All the wit and exuberance of Ms. Gross's paintings inform the set and costumes she designed for this full-evening work, which must be the first theatrical event to list ''volunteer leaf painters'' in its credits.
LEAD: JOHN DICK was a junior at Oregon in 1939 when the Ducks defeated Ohio State in the first National Collegiate Athletic Association national championship basketball game.

LEAD: The issue of how best to run an elimination tournament in college hockey came into focus again over the weekend, and it was hard to say which of two formats was fairer for athletes and spectators, total goals or the mini-game.
LEAD: A man gave up his life preserver to save his son after a boating accident near here and was missing and presumed drowned today in the Sandy River.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A man walking along a footpath in Carl Schurz Park on the Upper East Side of Manhattan yesterday afternoon found a pipe bomb about 200 feet south of Gracie Mansion, the residence of Mayor Koch, the police said.

LEAD: The highest governing body of the Assemblies of God church is expected to meet Monday to resolve a dispute over discliplinary action against the Rev. Jimmy Swaggart for his admitted moral lapses.

LEAD: Mary Beth Whitehead Gould and William Stern, the parents at the heart of the bitter Baby M surrogacy and custody dispute, have taken sharply differing views on the amount of time Mrs. Whitehead Gould should be allowed to see their daughter, Melissa Stern.

LEAD: The Charter Revision Commission will hear its chairman's proposal for revamping the New York City government today, at a meeting bound to irritate further the frayed tempers of elected officials who favor the status quo.

LEAD: The marriage of Roberta Wohl, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Wohl of Queens Village, Queens, to Jonathan Hervey Francis, a son of Mrs. Jonathan B. Francis of Victoria, British Columbia, took place yesterday at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Charles Lippman officiated.

LEAD: Phillip J. Stevens, right, of Irvine, Calif., after being named a special chief in the at the Rosebud Sioux Indian Reservation in Mission, S.D. At left was Chief Oliver Red Cloud of the Oglala Sioux tribe.

LEAD: There were more than five minutes left in the third period today when Michel Bergeron of the Rangers pulled his goaltender. For the Rangers, who lost to the Devils, 7-2, to complete a disappointing weekend, time is running out and desperation may be setting in.

LEAD: Debi Thomas, the United States figure skating champion and Olympic bronze medalist, announced today that she was married to a University of Colorado student just before the world figure skating championships that ended here Saturday.

LEAD: IT originated in 1939, when it was won by the University of Oregon's basketball team, the Tall Firs as they were known. LEAD: Susan Butcher had the sniffles, which seemed natural enough for someone who recently spent 11 days 11 hours 42 minutes shivering through some the worst weather Alaska has to offer while chasing a dog sled over 1,158 miles of some of the state's most forbidding terrain.
LEAD: The elevation of the Veterans Administration to Cabinet status was virtually assured today as a Senate committee chairman agreed to drop a proposed amendment that had threatened the change.

LEAD: Irked by an airline advertisement touting a way for Americans to delay paying their Federal income taxes, the Internal Revenue Service today closed a longstanding loophole in the law that gave taxpayers who managed to be out of the country on April 15 an extra two months to pay.
LEAD: Long Island Sound was designated yesterday as an ''estuary of national significance,'' guaranteeing $1 million a year in Federal financing for an ecological study of the waterway.
LEAD: The Israeli Army announced tonight that it was sealing off the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip in anticipation of planned Arab demonstrations on Wednesday.

LEAD: State budget talks, which were said to be on the verge of conclusion late Sunday night, stalled today, apparently because of disagreements over apportioning money for housing, transportation and education.
LEAD: A battalion of 700 American paratroopers returned from Honduras today as the United States began to withdraw a 3,500-man contingent sent in a show of force against Nicaragua.

LEAD: Abraham W. Rosenthal, the former executive director of the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. and the former chairman of the Council of Social Agencies, both in the Bronx, died Thursday at his home in Santa Monica, Calif., after a short illness. He was 91 years old.

LEAD: A protest is being mounted to save a Metro-North rail station in the South Bronx from closing this week, but the noise is not coming from local residents, many of whom say they have no idea the train even stops in their neighborhood.
LEAD: FORDHAM UNIVERSITY is seeking classroom space in the Wall Street area for its graduate school of business, now based in the Lincoln Center area.

LEAD: ARCHEOLOGISTS have long puzzled over the means Egyptian pyramid builders used to raise and move immense blocks of stone without the help of wheels, pulleys or domestic animals. A new study suggests that the basic stone-raising tool along the Nile 5,000 years ago was the simple bamboo pole.
LEAD: A delegation of contra commanders entered Nicaragua today to begin detailed talks about the size and location of cease-fire zones into which they are expected to withdraw.

LEAD: The green freight train that the Nets derailed in Boston Garden about a month ago didn't begin to roll tonight until midway through the third quarter. And when it began moving, it was 17 points behind.

LEAD: The National League named two new umpires yesterday, but Pam Postema, who was seeking to become the first female umpire in major league history, was not among them. Postema, who had been given only an outside chance of being selected, will work this year in the American Association.

LEAD: * Forschner Group Inc., Shelton, Conn., a maker of cutlery, pocket knives and wicker baskets, announced that John B. Balson, chairman and chief executive, would leave the company, a subsidiary of the Prospect Group Inc., as chairman, chief executive and a director to join Stendig Industries as president and chief executive in early April.
LEAD: It's not uncommon for a woman, or a man, to put her salary on her back. What's uncommon about a woman named Ivana Trump is that she'll get her new salary only by putting it on her back.
LEAD: The city of Chicago has agreed to pay $9.2 million in back pay to settle a discrimination case involving 729 black, Hispanic and female police officers, the Justice Department said today.
LEAD: Two decades after serving in Indochina as an Army officer, Senator Larry Pressler will return to Vietnam on a ''humanitarian mission'' to improve relations between Washington and Hanoi.

LEAD: Investigators have taken two suspects into custody in the shotgun slaying of Julian Pierce, an Indian who was running in the May 3 primary for Superior Court judge, the county sheriff said early today.

LEAD: A recent article in The Times painted a grim picture of New York State's hospital system. Emergency rooms, Bruce Lambert reported, are jammed with patients waiting for beds. Ambulances containing emergency cases are routinely diverted from one overloaded hospital to another. The emotionally disturbed, brought into crowded psychiatric wards, sometimes spend the night strapped to stretchers.

LEAD: Efforts by House Democratic and Republican leaders to fashion an aid package for the Nicaraguan rebels broke down tonight over Republican demands for an early vote on renewed military aid for the contras if the current truce collapses.

LEAD: In an unusual application of state law, a Brooklyn judge yesterday ordered a convicted heroin dealer dealer to pay more than $2 million in restitution, with the money to be used to support drug rehabilitation programs in New York City.

LEAD: Are you old enough to remember the Age of Aquarius? While you are at it, resurrect the rest of your hippie regalia, including the caftans and tunics of crushed velvet, embroidered or tie-dyed fabrics.

LEAD: Karen Khachaturian, a prominent Soviet composer, paused today in front of a photograph of John F. Kennedy and sobbed. The 68-year-old Mr. Khachaturian bowed several times before the picture, which hung on the wall of Rose Kennedy's memento-filled home. ''It's not fair,'' he said softly. The Kennedy family and its Hyannis Port complex on Cape Cod have always held a special place in the hearts of many Americans.

LEAD: The Du Pont Company has pledged to phase out all production of CFC's, the chemicals that erode the life-protecting ozone layer in the high atmosphere. Du Pont, the world's largest producer of CFC's, with sales of $600 million a year, set no specific timetable. But it said a ''reasonable goal'' would be to cut output by 95 percent by the year 2000 - nearly double the goal set by an international protocol last year.

LEAD: One-third of all baseball job openings in the last year were filled by members of minority groups, the baseball commissioner's office announced yesterday. LEAD: MOURNING a loved one is always painful, but some people find the process more difficult than others, either becoming too distraught or holding too much emotion in. In studying these extreme reactions, researchers are coming to a sharper understanding of the normal course of mourning, and of the signs that it has gone awry.

She said most studies show that 90 to 95 percent of the victims are women.

LEAD: For seven years, the Administration has angrily decried Soviet cheating on arms accords. LEAD: In the strongest attack yet by a Democratic Presidential candidate on the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Albert Gore Jr. assailed Mr. Jackson's foreign policy views yesterday and said he was ''dismayed'' by Mr. Jackson's ''embrace of Arafat and Castro.''

LEAD: The phrase ''politico-military'' entered the strategists' jargon about a generation ago. It was a handy way of reminding diplomats and military men, who tend to go their own ways, that their concerns are tightly linked. Clausewitz observed that war and politics have shared goals, but he made it sound as though they were alternatives when in fact there are constant interconnections.

LEAD: With the number of AIDS victims increasing faster than the money available to help them, some minority and gay groups serving neighborhoods hit by the disease now find themselves battling for the same government dollars.
LEAD: Two Israeli soldiers who admitted beating and burying alive four Arabs were sentenced to jail terms that were stiffer than those requested by prosecutors, Israeli radio reported today.

LEAD: The campaign for the French presidency has swiftly designated its two front-runners: President Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist, and Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, the leader of the conservative neo-Gaullist movement.

LEAD: The price to take over one of the nation's biggest textile producers, J. P. Stevens & Company, continued to rise yesterday amid Wall Street speculation that stockholders may yet see further increases in the bidding.

LEAD: The Walt Disney Company has paid $85.2 million for a 50 percent interest in the Wrather Corporation that was held by the New Zealand financier Ronald A. Brierley. Last year, Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., a La Jolla, Calif., company controlled by Mr. Brierley, acquired 28 percent of Wrather, a hotel operator based in Beverly Hills.

LEAD: After 13 weeks in court, including nine days of fruitless jury debate, the murder case of the People of New York v. Robert Chambers Jr. ended in a compromise plea to manslaughter. LEAD: Some Democrats took the pledge in 1972, after a third of their party's voters defected, enlarging the Nixon landslide. Some more took the pledge after the 1980 Reagan landslide. LEAD: The Arizona Senate today dismissed the most serious of three impeachment charges against Gov. Evan Mecham and moved toward considering a verdict on the two charges that have already been heard.

LEAD: Ever since September, when he relinquished his Islander captaincy and announced his plan to retire this spring, the season has been one long going-away party for 34-year-old Denis Potvin, the most decorated defenseman in the National Hockey League.

LEAD: Chiu-tze Lin, a Taiwan-born pianist whose career has been centered in the American Midwest, drew a full house for her debut at Weill Recital Hall on Saturday afternoon. In works of Mozart, Prokofiev, Schumann and Bach she displayed a strong but not foolproof technique and a hearty tone that sounded - even after allowing for the amplifying effect of this auditorium - big and unforced.

LEAD: ''Look at those marks,'' said Rita Dushock, pointing to two freshly painted orange stripes, 500 feet apart, along the unbroken curb of Valentine Street that forms the southern border of St. Joseph's Seminary. ''That's where the housing will go.''

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, seeking to ''raise the comfort level'' toward his Presidential campaign and quell talk of a stop-Jackson movement, today convened a get-acquainted breakfast of Democratic Party elders.

LEAD: Donald Barthelme is to receive the third annual Rea Award for the Short Story. The $25,000 award is given by the Dungannon Foundation to honor living American writers who have made ''a significant contribution to short-story writing.'' Mr. Barthelme, whose works have included ''Forty Stories,'' ''Overnight to Many Distant Cities,'' ''City Life'' and ''Unspeakable Practices, Unnatural Acts,'' was selected by a jury that included Cynthia Ozick, Benjamin DeMott and Bill Henderson.

LEAD: Rabbi Samuel J. Gedalowitz of the Civic Center Synagogue in lower Manhattan died of cancer today at Booth Memorial Hospital in Queens. He was 59 years old and lived in Kew Gardens Hills, Queens.
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Representatives were bipartisan in overwhelmingly approving a $47.9 million aid package for the Nicaraguan insurgents. The vote was 345 to 70. Page A1

LEAD: A modest but pleasing exhibition at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford offers a sampling of quilting techniques and patterns covering almost 300 years. Most of the 35 quilts are American, drawn from the museum's collection and augmented by works from collectors from the Hartford area. The show is entitled, ''Drunken Paths and Ladders to the Stars,'' after traditional quilt patterns.
LEAD: Pearl E. Joseph, a senior vice president at Young & Rubicam Inc., died of a heart attack Sunday at her home in Carmel, N.Y. She was 47 years old.

LEAD: Dave Winfield was the Yankees' quiet man today, but controversy continued to swirl around the right fielder. Rumors of a trade - this time to Baltimore for Fred Lynn - were coupled with talk that sounded as if it were coming from an unsettled clubhouse.
LEAD: The developing world's most indebted nation began an experimental program this week to swap a small portion of its $112.7 billion foreign debt for equity interests in Brazilian enterprises.

LEAD: IN the five months that Shirley Angus has called Stamford, Conn., home, she has made more friends than in the five years she lived in England. ''When I moved to England from South Africa,'' she recalled, ''there was no way to meet people unless you took the bull by the horns and introduced yourself to strangers.

LEAD: How should a playwright confront the assassinations and conspiracies that have scarred American life since the 1960's and avoid sounding a trite one-note lament? In her play ''June 8, 1968,'' Anna Theresa Cascio, a dramatist of considerable promise, recasts an event trivialized long ago by television into her own grotesque, funny-sad pop fantasy of what might have happened.

LEAD: William Ball was sworn in Wednesday as Secretary of the Navy, replacing James Webb, who resigned last month to protest Pentagon plans to postpone completion of a 600-ship navy. Mr. Ball, 39 years old, is a former State Department official.

LEAD: The most striking quality about Steve Ross, the singer and pianist who began an extended engagement at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel on Tuesday, is his physical resemblance to Cole Porter.

LEAD: A complaint alleging that they violated Federal labor laws during negotiations with the National Football League Players Association last year has been issued against Billy Sullivan, the New England Patriots' president, and against the team itself by the National Labor Relations Board. Sullivan and the Patriots are charged with unlawful union discrimination for waiving the union vice president, Brian Holloway, the day after he appeared on national television and criticized club owners for their bargaining stance.
LEAD: Bond prices dipped slightly in very quiet trading yesterday as market partcipants began to close out positions in advance of a long holiday weekend.

LEAD: Key legislators said tonight that they were ready to agree on a $3 billion transportation bond issue that would pay for road and bridge repairs over the next four years. The bond issue would be the largest in the state's history.

LEAD: * Allied-Signal Aerospace Co., Morristown, N.J., a unit of Allied-Signal Inc., said it had completed the consolidation of its Bendix and Garrett units and would sell three divisions with combined annual sales of $200 million to sharpen its focus as a major supplier of aircraft systems.

LEAD: The New York City Health Department yesterday resumed inspections of restaurants after they were suspended last week when 28 current and former city inspectors were charged with extorting payments from restaurants.
LEAD: IF women were dressing to please men, the mini might have made it.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: * Gerald E. Murray has been named executive vice presiden tand assistant general manager of the Chicago office of Porter Novelli, public relations, a subsidiary of the Omnicom Group.

LEAD: EACH of the other three teams in the Final Four has a glamorous all-American name: Danny Manning of Kansas, Sean Elliott of Arizona, and Danny Ferry of Duke, blue-chip National Basketball Association prospects either this year or next. But the University of Oklahoma has a stack of blue chips, three immediate or eventual first-round N.B.A.
LEAD: The far right-wing Conservative Party strongly won a by-election today for a seat in Parliament from the Randfontein voting district in Transvaal Province in South Africa.
LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange is considering new rules to halt trading if the market rises or falls more than a certain amount in one day, John J. Phelan Jr., the exchange's chairman, said.
LEAD: Letters to Olga June 1979 - September 1982 By Vaclav Havel Translated by Paul Wilson 397 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $25.
LEAD: Ecstatic pandemonium reigned at the Apollo Theater last Friday night, the sort that comes from a show mixing humor, pride in achievement and the healing qualities of dance music.

LEAD: Dr. Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., the historian, will give the first Nancy Hanks lecture on Arts and Public Policy on April 13 at 7 P.M. at the National Academy of Sciences, 2101 Constitution Avenue, N.W., Washington.

LEAD: One of the more intriguing aspects of watching ''Voices and Visions,'' public television's 13-part series on American poets, is the discovery of certain patterns and motifs. There is, for instance, the curious phenomenon of the ''double life.'' William Carlos Williams was a world-renowned poet and a practicing pediatrician in a small New Jersey town.
LEAD: Prostitution has enjoyed a joyously lurid history in this fun-loving old city, where tourists once ogled the palaces in the red-light district near the French Quarter.

LEAD: The Irving Bank Corporation yesterday offered to provide the Bank of New York with the same financial information that it is providing other potential acquirers on the condition that the Bank of New York give up its hostile takeover attempt. Irving's offer was in response to a March 28 letter from J.
LEAD: Swaggart Defies Order
LEAD: The Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association charged today that Japanese companies are dumping compact trucks on the American market.

LEAD: It is almost on the sly that the best exhibition of Russian avant-garde art that has ever been allowed out of the Soviet Union has arrived here at the Museum for the Applied Arts, where it can be seen through May 15.
LEAD: Without the telephone and the computer, modern American life would be impossible. But combine them, and the result can seem diabolical.

LEAD: IN early 19th-century Germany, the architect Friedrich Weinbrenner designed urban palaces and gardens for the ruling family of Baden, in the southwestern part of what is now West Germany. He also devised elaborate schemes to make farming a scientific endeavor. And in the city of Karlsruhe, the capital of Baden,
LEAD: The King of Aqueduct is old and cranky. It can take him a leisurely 20 minutes to walk the 100 yards from his home in Barn 11 to the track, and he won't stand for being hurried along.

LEAD: Thousands of meter readers, cashiers and other utility employees are looking out for the welfare of many of the 1.8 million elderly people in Illinois by volunteering for the state's Gatekeeper program.
LEAD: E. F. Hutton Group Inc. will plead guilty to criminal charges that it laundered money for unidentified clients who have previously been reported to be organized crime figures.

LEAD: Art Schlichter, the former Indianapolis Colts quarterback who was suspended by the National Football League in 1983 for gambling, has filed for bankruptcy protection, a television station reported yesterday. Schlichter, who is Ohio State's career passing leader, filed a bankruptcy petition in United States Bankruptcy Court in Columbus, Ohio, listing his debts at about $1 million and his assets at $1,800, station WBNS reported.
LEAD: The Senate approved landmark legislation today that would radically weaken the 55-year-old law that separates the banking and securities industries.
LEAD: The Rev. Jimmy Swaggart will return to the pulpit on May 22, his lawyer said today, defying national Assemblies of God church officials who had suspended him for a year.

LEAD: The Atlanta Falcons said yesterday that they would make Aundray Bruce, a linebacker from Auburn, the first player to be picked in the National Football League draft on April 24. Coach Marion Campbell reported that the Falcons would immediately begin trying to negotiate a contract and have Bruce signed before draft day.

LEAD: MANY of the things that every garden should have, according to the theoreticians of horticultural design, are notably absent in my own suburban plot. Gardens ought to have vistas, but there's not a trace of a vista in mine, just a whole lot of plants crammed into every spare inch.

LEAD: Rome at Easter - the first tourist invasion of the season, when tens of thousands of pilgrims converge at St. Peter's for mass and a glimpse of Pope John Paul II, and among them will be Secretary of State George P. Shultz and his wife.

LEAD: Time Inc. is believed to be considering the sale of Scott Foresman & Company, its textbook publishing unit, Wall Street sources said. The company refused to comment. Time bought the company two years ago for $520 million.

LEAD: The wife of Sir Rudolph Bing, who last year spirited her disoriented husband overseas in violation of a court order, was arrested yesterday in Manhattan after an executive of Columbia Artists Management complained of harassment.
LEAD: Three former executives of WNYW-TV, Channel 5 in New York, and two associates were indicted yesterday on charges of selling advertising time and keeping the proceeds.
LEAD: Chun Kyung Hwan, the younger brother of former President Chun Doo Hwan, was arrested early today on charges of embezzlement and influence peddling.
LEAD: Just as the old order changeth, yielding place to the new, so does the old-boy network change, making way for the new-boy network.
LEAD: Federal and state agencies were investigating yesterday whether 40 bags of asbestos found in a tube of the Lincoln Tunnel had been dumped there deliberately.
LEAD: Solicitor General Charles Fried today urged the Supreme Court to uphold a 1981 Federal law that grants money to religious groups, and others, to counsel teen-agers on premarital sex.
LEAD: Four Palestinians were shot to death by Israeli forces in the occupied territories today as Arabs staged a widespread protest strike despite heightened security.

LEAD: Armenians threatened to continue a general strike paralyzing the main city of a disputed southern region until the Government agreed to make the region part of Armenia, newspapers reported today.
LEAD: Top executives of Texaco Inc. have taken a close look at a management-led buyout as one way to protect the company's independence, Wall Street sources disclosed yesterday.

LEAD: The wrong people are leaving the Department of Justice. Edwin Meese, the Attorney General, having forfeited the confidence of everyone but President Reagan, clings to his job. Unable to make the White House see the chaos at Justice, two competent and concerned top officials have jointly resigned, widening the gaps in the department's leadership.

LEAD: Recharged by a solid victory in Connecticut, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis looked ahead to Wisconsin and New York primaries, where the outcomes may hinge on whether the Massachusetts Governor can quickly get the race focused as a two-man contest with the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

LEAD: Roger T. Briggs, who participated in more than 60 acquisitions and divestitures over the years as the top lieutenant of Donald P. Kelly, said yesterday that he was parting with the Chicago deal maker to manage his own portfolio.

LEAD: A baby girl was killed and four people, including two firefighters, were seriously injured in a fire early yesterday in the South Bronx that investigators said was apparently caused by careless use of candles in an apartment without electricity.

LEAD: A preliminary injunction barring random drug testing of 9,400 civilian Army employees was set aside by a Federal appellate court Tuesday while it considers the Justice Department's appeal of a lower court order.
LEAD: House Democrats and Republicans joined forces today and approved a $47.9 million aid package for the Nicaraguan rebels. The vote was 345 to 70.

LEAD: The Government is considering charging space shuttle customers up to $245 million a flight, nearly three times the current maximum, for carrying cargo into space, a Congressional panel was told Tuesday. There were indications that the idea was meeting stiff resistance.

LEAD: More news organizations are conducting public opinion polls than in any other Presidential election year, and the Democratic caucuses in Michigan have once again raised questions about the role of opinion surveys in covering campaigns.
LEAD: The Economy
LEAD: TO neighbors and passers-by, the exterior of a house speaks volumes about the people living in it, according to a survey by researchers in city and regional planning at Ohio State University.

LEAD: R. H. Macy & Company says its latest bid for Federated Department Stores has a sharply higher value than Wall Street's estimates on the non-cash part of its offer, according to people close to its takeover battle with the Campeau Corporation.

LEAD: The race is on in the chemical industry for what is envisioned as a multibillion-dollar market for substitutes for chlorofluorocarbons, the widely used compounds suspected of destroying the earth's ozone shield.
LEAD: The Senate Budget Committee overwhelmingly approved a $1.1 trillion spending plan for 1989 today in line with many of President Reagan's priorities.
LEAD: The city discharged 23 more provisional Emergency Medical Service workers yesterday for taking part in a ''sickout'' early this month to protest work conditions and wages.

LEAD: SLUGGISH drains in sinks and tubs rank high among household annoyances. However, remedies for drain woes are usually simple. If the problem is addressed early, restoring a sluggish drain to full effectiveness or even clearing a drain that has become completely clogged seldom require much skill or effort, and may require only a few tools.

They could just as easily have been in a village square. LEAD: Mayor Koch, whose political credo seems to be ''Take no prisoners,'' revealed yesterday that he had given equally strong orders for handling anyone who might take him captive: ''Pay no ransom.''

LEAD: Evidence is growing that France is negotiating with Iran to gain the release of the three French hostages held by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon. The developments are surrounded by intrigue and electoral maneuvering by both Iranian and French politicians.

LEAD: Donald J. Trump, chairman of Resorts International Inc., said today that because of confusion created by a competing offer he was withdrawing his $22-a-share, $123 million proposal to take the Atlantic City casino operator private.
LEAD: Dramatic advances in the treatment of kidney stones have eliminated the need for major surgery in all but a relatively few patients, a panel of experts concluded today.

LEAD: The California Court of Appeal has ruled in favor of Barron Hilton in his long battle to obtain control of a 27.4 percent block of stock in the Hilton Hotel Corporation that was left by his father, Conrad Hilton.

LEAD: ORIGINALLY slipcovers, or loose covers as they were called in Europe centuries ago, were used to protect good furniture from dust and summer sun. In light cottons or muslins, they gave a room an informal, fresh feeling.
LEAD: At 24, Lori Leonard is younger than most of her students at Chad University.

LEAD: The romance of Jesse Jackson's candidacy is running so strong now that it seems ungenerous to point to reality. Here is a black outsider rousing voters, black and white, with a message of hope in change. Here is a candidate with little money running a superb campaign.
LEAD: Former Senator Barry Goldwater said today that the Rev. Jesse Jackson was the most intelligent Democratic Presidential candidate in the 1988 race.

LEAD: Grover is a teen-age nerd, but will he stay nerdy for long? Of course not. He is the hero of ''The Invisible Kid,'' a movie that proves you can cull every known cliche from successful teen adventure films and still come up with a bomb.
LEAD: The Panamanian Government appeared today to have all but broken protest strikes by middle-class businessmen and public employees.

LEAD: All 12 active judges on a Federal appeals court held a hearing yesterday on whether the Government could prevent defendants from hiring the lawyers of their choice by freezing the defendants' assets, including the money they intended to use for legal fees.

LEAD: Maria Meirelles, a Brazilian-born pianist now based in Michigan, returned Monday night to Weill Recital Hall, the scene of her New York debut several seasons ago. On that occasion she offered, in seven concerts, all the Beethoven sonatas. So by comparison, her enormous program Monday night - big sonatas by Schumann and Prokofiev, Franck's Prelude, Chorale and Fugue, short pieces by Villa-Lobos and the whole of Ravel's ''Gaspard de la

LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote of 345 to 70 by which the House of Representatives today approved a $47.9 million package of assistance to the Nicaraguan rebels. A ''yes'' vote was a vote in favor of the aid; a ''no'' was a vote against it. Voting ''yes'' were 179 Democrats and 166 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 65 Democrats and 5 Republicans.
LEAD: At the highest levels bridge is a highly disciplined game, with players striving for accuracy and avoiding anything that might lead their partners astray.
LEAD: Even as armed fighters continue an age-old battle for dominance in Sri Lanka, a team of monks and scholars is updating a 1,400-year-old chronicle that records the origins of the conflict.

LEAD: A front-page caption Monday with a picture supplied by the Associated Press showing the West Regional Championship basketball game between North Carolina and Arizona misidentifed a player. He was Tom Tolbert of Arizona, not Steve Kerr.

LEAD: The Utah Jazz will reprimand Frank Layden after the National Basketball Association's decision to fine the franchise $10,000 for remarks made by the coach. The N.B.A. announced the fine Tuesday for Layden's criticism of the officiating in a Jazz-Nuggets game in Denver earlier this month. David Checketts, president of the Jazz, s said, meanwhile, that he was writing Commissioner David Stern about the incident and would likely appeal the fine.

LEAD: The only synagogue in Hong Kong - a turn-of-the-century Sephardic building with creamy white walls, marble pillars and graceful buttresses - is facing demolition as developers prepare to build two high-rise apartment towers.

LEAD: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. said yesterday that Ralph D. Caulo, an executive vice president, had been named president and chief operating officer.
LEAD: Everything is working with the precision of a Swiss watch for the Devils, at the most crucial part of the season.

LEAD: Since 1985, when the Navy ended the General Dynamics Corporation's monopoly on producing the Tomahawk cruise missile and encouraged competition from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the missile's average price has fallen to $653,000, from slightly more than $1 million.

LEAD: Both the title and the advertising campaign for Sandra Bernhard's one-woman show, ''Without You I'm Nothing,'' toy ambiguously with romantic imagery. If the title suggests a sudsy love story, the ads and the show, which opens today at the Orpheum Theater (126 Second Avenue, at Eighth Street), juxtapose photos of Ms.

LEAD: As director, Anne Bogart has had the ingenious notion of staging Bertolt Brecht's theories rather than one of his plays. In collaboration with members of three experimental troupes, Otrabanda, the Talking Band and Ms. Bogart's own Via Theater, she is presenting a collective performance piece with a self-descriptive title: ''No Plays No Poetry but Philosophical Reflections Practical Instructions Provocative Prescriptions Opinions and Pointers From a Noted Critic and Playwright.

LEAD: A report in Business Day on Saturday about the British Petroleum Company inaccurately described a plan to change the name of the Standard Oil Production Company, a subsidiary. Standard Oil Production will be renamed but the new name has not been disclosed. British Petroleum will not be renamed.

LEAD: About 250 ships remained anchored in Duisburg-Ruhr port yesterday as runoff continued to swell the Rhine River near Weisbaden. American servicemen joined local firefighters and volunteers in piling sandbags along the river to shore up dikes and prevent further flooding. Six people were reported to have died in accidents in what officials described as the worst flooding in 70 years.

LEAD: In an unexpected move, a House Judiciary subcommittee today refused to accept a report written by its staff that concluded that Congress should allow the Government to approve patents for new kinds of animals, including those that have been altered through genetic engineering.

LEAD: The United States has asked China for help in curbing opium and heroin production in Burma, where the Communist Party is now thought to be the major supplier of narcotics, according to a group of Western officials briefing reporters here today.
LEAD: Virginia's Fairfax County, in the Washington area, is offering $99.8 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities.
LEAD: Three Iranian gunboats opened fire today on a Kuwaiti island outpost in the Persian Gulf, wounding two Kuwaiti soldiers and drawing return fire, the Kuwaiti Defense Ministry said.

LEAD: WISHING that someone sleep like a baby may be more of a curse than a benediction. The brain of a sleeping child works differently from the brain of an adult. There is a link between the 3-year-old who sleeps so soundly that he does not wake up when you carry him from the car to the house and get him undressed for bed, and the toddler who frightens the whole family with his screams of terror a few hours after he goes to sleep.

LEAD: It seems obvious that air travel has become less safe since deregulation, as cost-conscious airlines look to younger, less experienced pilots to fly through ever more crowded skies. Obvious, and wrong. According to a recent study for the Brookings Institution by Steven Morrison and Clifford Winston, it simply isn't true.

LEAD: The General Dynamics Corporation is offering $100 million of 9.95 percent debentures due in 2018 at a price of 98.95 to yield 10.061 percent through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

LEAD: The Soviet Union has indicated it will consider allowing military aid to continue to reach the Afghan guerrillas after the cutoff date set in a peace accord now being negotiated, senior Administration officials said today.

LEAD: There was, to be sure, little art to the deal. In order to make the playoffs, the Rangers, lacking leverage, agreed they had to win all three of their remaining games just to fulfill their end of an uncertain bargain.

LEAD: Robb Stauber, the University of Minnesota goalie who has some unfinished business ahead of him, was named today as the winner of the Hobey Baker Award as college hockey's outstanding player. The award is named for Princeton's fabled athlete of the World War I era.

LEAD: Metro-North commuter rail service between New Haven and Stamford was interrupted for three hours early this morning by a fire at a lumberyard here, officials said. Service was halted while firefighters stretched hoses across the tracks at about 4:30 A.M. to fight the fire, which destroyed one building at Ring's End Lumber.
LEAD: Vassily Ivanchuk, an 18-year-old international master from Russia, had a clear victory yesterday in the New York International chess tournament at the Penta Hotel.
LEAD: BECAUSE she has just celebrated her 90th birthday, the normally active Elizabeth Cornelia Hall has been even more active than usual.
LEAD: Charles Barkley scored 33 points and grabbed 14 rebounds and four other 76ers scored in double figures tonight as Philadelphia downed the Milwaukee Bucks, 134-109.
LEAD: Joe B. Hall knows how to win the national championship. And Joe B. Hall knows how to lose it.
LEAD: More than 470 children were sent home when the city's Health Director closed their elementary school yesterday after finding high levels of lead in paint and air samples, officials said.

LEAD: Laura Davies wound up and let fly with one of the longest drives ever seen in women's competition early this month. She paced it off with her brother, Tony, who is also her caddie, and said the ball went 341 yards.
LEAD: Voters in two southern Mississippi Congressional districts have selected nominees for seats that Representatives Trent Lott and Wayne Dowdy are giving up to run for the Senate.
LEAD: Leona Maricle, a stage and film actress for 40 years, was found dead, apparently of a heart attack, in her Manhattan apartment last Friday. She was 81 years old.

LEAD: Rupert Murdoch will have another chance to persuade the Federal Communications Commission to let him keep both The Boston Herald and a Boston television station a little longer, as a result of a Federal appeals court ruling on Tuesday.

LEAD: The New York City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, who last week forced the Board of Estimate to cut $13,500 from the price it would pay for the house of a drug-case witness, said yesterday that he had arranged for two private donors to give the witness a $25,000 reward.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration's decision to deny Medicare payments for use of a heart attack drug that costs more than $2,000 a treatment is a form of health-care rationing, industry spokesmen asserted yesterday.
LEAD: Two state legislators submitted bills today to let New York City residents vote on more than just the recommendations of a charter revision commission appointed by Mayor Koch.
LEAD: Francis P. Pandolfi, who began his magazine publishing career while still an M.B.A. candidate at Harvard, is going to join Times Mirror Magazines as president.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Yes, ''Lost in the Stars'' is painfully dated. The gentle hope of ''Cry, the Beloved Country,'' Alan Paton's novel on which the Kurt Weill-Maxwell Anderson ''musical tragedy'' was based, has been crushed by the events in South Africa. Almost 40 years after the play opened on Broadway, the glimmer of reconciliation with which it ends flickers like a liberal pipe dream.

LEAD: The Aluminium Company of America will concentrate on the business that its name reflects, said Paul O'Neill, the chairman of the company. He said in a letter to shareholders with the company's 1987 annual report that the company would shun the diversification strategy touted by his predecessor.

LEAD: William F. Weld, who resigned Tuesday as Assistant Attorney General, had become so concerned about the legal troubles of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d over the last few months that, if he had been prosecuting the case, ''he would have to seriously consider indicting Meese,'' according to a close aide.

LEAD: William Bedford, the Detroit Pistons' reserve center, has entered a rehabilitation program to be treated for chemical dependency, the team announced yesterday. Bedford, 24 years old, was to begin treatment yesterday at the Adult Substance Abuse Program based in Van Nuys, Calif., according to a Pistons spokesman, Matt Dobek.

LEAD: The Mets pursued talks with the Baltimore Orioles and half a dozen other teams today about trading Mookie Wilson. But they said later that nothing seemed imminent, and predicted the odds were 70-30 that Wilson would still be a member of the Mets when the season opened next week.
LEAD: In a major policy change, the Federal Aviation Administration has sharply accelerated its program for preventing midair collisions near busy airports, agency officials said yesterday.

LEAD: The Mentor Graphics Corporation said it would acquire the computer-aided engineering and computer-aided software engineering business of Tektronix Inc. for $5 million in cash, a small fraction of the price Tektronix paid for the company two years ago. The two companies, both based in Beaverton, Ore., also said they would form a strategic alliance to link Mentor's electronic design business with
LEAD: Supporters of the Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that his second-place finish Tuesday in the Connecticut Democratic Presidential primary really constituted a victory.

LEAD: The reputed leader of the Mafia in Southern California and six associates have pleaded guilty to extortion or racketeering charges, but they denied being members of an organized crime syndicate.

LEAD: Stocks dropped sharply in the last few minutes of trading yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average ended down 20.22 points, or 1 percent, at 1,978.12. Broader measures than the Dow were also lower and declining stocks outnumbered those that rose by 917 to 571.

LEAD: Consumer prices in the 12-nation European Community rose three-tenths of a percent in February from January, and 3 percent from February 1987, the European Community reported today. The 3 percent rate remained unchanged from January. That compares with inflation rates of nine-tenths of 1 percent in Japan and 3.9 percent in the United States.
LEAD: President Corazon C. Aquino and military officials claimed a major victory over Communist rebels today after the capture of the rebel army's leader and the Communist Party's No. 2 man.

LEAD: WHEN the 1,350 employees of Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton show up for work next Tuesday after a long weekend, they may not have the Art Deco spire of the Chrysler Building towering majestically over their heads, but they will have a fully equipped health club and running track in their penthouse. Less for the soul, more for the body.

LEAD: The European Community's executive body has approved French Government aid to the giant auto maker Renault but has set certain conditions on the assistance. The European Community commission approved aid to Renault of 20 billion French francs, or $3.54 billion. The decision marked the end of a two-year investigation into Government assistance to Regie Nationale des Usines Renault, a state agency.

LEAD: Justice Department officials, describing disarray at the department after the resignation of two senior aides to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, said today that there might soon be other resignations protesting Mr. Meese's continuing presence at the department.

LEAD: There, on page 3 of People's Daily, organ of the Communist Party, was a postcard-sized photograph of three men in China's Parliament sitting with their hands in their laps while around them hands fluttered aloft. It was an extraordinary display of official discord.

LEAD: MANY of the chicquest models on runways from New York to Paris are donning quirky, sometimes comical glasses. The designs are the brainchild of Alain Mikli, who has garnered a reputation for haute-couture glasses.

LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra has made several public pleas in recent days for American economic help and a diplomatic thaw, suggesting that a desire to rebuild relations with Washington was his main reason for approving a cease-fire agreement.

LEAD: The visitation hearing in the Baby M dispute ended today, with opposing lawyers and mental health experts sharply divided on the role Mary Beth Whitehead Gould should play in the life of 2-year-old Melissa Stern.
LEAD: The 12-nation European Community loses at least $250 billion a year in extra costs and lost economic opportunities by staying divided along national borders, a two-year study has concluded.
LEAD: General Assembly HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON NEW AND RENEWABLE SOURCES OF ENERGY - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.
LEAD: By a vote of 17 to 2, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee recommended today that the Senate approve the Soviet-American accord banning medium- and shorter-range missiles based on land.
LEAD: There was a bit of account action of interest to those of covetous bent.

LEAD: Q. I want to build a brick walkway without using cement or mortar. Can I just set the bricks into the soil, or should I put down a bed of sand first? A. It is best to put down a sand base first; otherwise, the bricks will sink into the soil. Dig out the soil to a depth of at least four inches; then spread a two-inch layer of sand on the bottom as a base for the bricks.

LEAD: ''If there was proven wrongdoing, it would be devastating to the Administration and to Republicans this fall. But Mr. Meese deserves the presumption of innocence to which all Americans are entitled, even if he's the Attorney General.'' - Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona. [ B10:3. ]
LEAD: The Federal Farm Credit Banks began offering $2.91 billion of three-month and six-month bonds at par yesterday through various dealers.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Ruth Crosby Noble, an author, died March 15 at the Allendale (N.J.) Nursing Home, where she lived. She was 91 years old.

LEAD: The resignations of top Justice Department officials prompted demands from Democrats today that Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d resign, and Republicans expressed concern that Mr. Meese's legal troubles could damage the party's prospects in the fall elections.

LEAD: Orders to American factories for manufactured goods fell for the second consecutive month in February, the Commerce Department reported today, but analysts said the decline of eight-tenths of 1 percent was not a cause for alarm.

LEAD: Joel B. Steinberg in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. He pleaded not guilty to drug and gun charges added in a superseding indictment after he was charged in the beating death of Lisa, the 6-year-old girl he had raised. She was found comatose in his Greenwich Village apartment Nov. 2. A bail request hearing was postponed and he was returned to jail.

LEAD: In this once-forgotten border town on the banks of the River Arauca, where tranquillity was long the solitary reward for living in poverty, the discovery of oil nearby five years ago is no longer remembered as the moment when things began to get better.
LEAD: A TREASURY of Tiffany jewelry, much of it made with gems found in the United States, is on exhibit at the American Museum of Natural History through June 5.

LEAD: A Company Briefs report on March 15 misstated the stake that the General Electric Capital Corporation holds in the FGIC Corporation. General Electric Capital owns 37.5 percent of FGIC's common stock.
LEAD: Angeles Corp., Los Angeles, a holding company involved in investment programs, said Edward J. Hall had joined the company as executive vice president and chief financial officer.

LEAD: For the Zuni Indians of New Mexico, the modern rallying cry is ''Ho Chikwa: Weykkya Hanukwa.'' It means, ''I outran diabetes.'' The popular saying reflects the fact that running and other modes of exercise have become central to the lives of the Zuni, 40 percent of whom develop diabetes by the age of 45.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d told Congress today that he strongly disagreed with proposals to forgive some of the third world's debt, now more than $1 trillion.
LEAD: Tomorrow is Good Friday, Saturday is the first day of Passover and Sunday is Easter. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK

LEAD: Tennis Noah Eliminates Mayotte: Yannick Noah, off to the best start of his eight-year pro career, improved his record to 19-3 this year by eliminating Tim Mayotte, 6-4, 6-3, 6-3, last night in the quarterfinals of the World Championship Tennis Finals at Dallas. Noah advanced to tomorrow's semifinals where he'll face the winner of last night's second quarterfinal between top-seeded Stefan Edberg and Martin Jaite.

LEAD: Dr. Herman J. Burman, a former professor and otolaryngologist, died of a heart ailment yesterday in the Memorial Hospital in Hollywood, Fla. He was 89 years old and lived in Hallandale, Fla., and Manhattan.

LEAD: With its tightly made, small-scaled zarzuela productions, Repertorio Espanol has manufactured virtue from necessity in recent years - the necessity being the company's tiny, if appealingly decrepit, theater on East 27th Street. There has been some spreading out this spring: roughly a third of the showings are moving to new basement premises in the Equitable Tower on Seventh Avenue.

LEAD: The Philadelphia Stock Exchange will expand its night session trading list on April 14 with the addition of futures and options on the British pound and the Swiss franc. Night trading at the exchange, which runs from 7 to 11 o'clock Sunday through Thursday, began on Sept. 16 with the options on Australian dollars, Deutsche marks and Japanese yen.
LEAD: The Reagan Administration extended its veto threat today to another contentious section of the trade bill that House and Senate conferees are rushing to complete before the Easter recess.
LEAD: The Squibb Corporation made two major executive appointments yesterday, naming Jan Leschly president and chief operating officer and Dr. Charles A. Sanders vice chairman.

LEAD: The Government has announced that the Mexican economy grew by a small 1.4 percent last year, recovering from a steep recession that caused a 4 percent contraction in 1986. In a report delivered late Tuesday to the legislature, the office of President Miguel de la Madrid said that non-oil exports soared by 24 percent, giving the nation a surplus of $4.2 billion in the 1987 current account.

LEAD: Flying in the face of the growing movement to give divorced parents joint custody of their children, a new study has found that such arrangements do not necessarily benefit the children and in some cases may even be detrimental.

LEAD: For more than a year the Congressional Budget Office has been without a permanent director as a result of a deadlock between House and Senate leaders over one candidate. And the chances of a quick resolution appear slim.

LEAD: The official publication date isn't until April 18, and bookstores have barely had time to unpack their advance orders. Spurred by some stinging free publicity from the Yankees' owner, George Steinbrenner, however, copies of ''Dave Winfield: A Player's Life'' have been fairly flying off the shelves, according to W.

LEAD: David Tyler Paul, an editor and publisher of educational books and video programming, died of lung cancer Monday at Abington Memorial Hospital, Willow Grove, Pa. He was 53 years old and lived in Chestnut Hill, Pa.

LEAD: SIX years ago, just after he arrived in New York from Poland, the architect and stage designer Jan Jakub Gontarczyk saw an office chair on the street. It had a swivel base and a beautiful Art Nouveau back. He renovated it and gave it to a friend.

LEAD: The subject was fear at the formal news conference at the Plaza Hotel yesterday announcing the June 27 Mike Tyson-Michael Spinks heavyweight title fight in Atlantic City.

LEAD: When Tim Robb was laid off last summer from his job assembling truck frames at a General Motors plant here, his fate seemed all too familiar a story for Michigan, whose automobile industry has lost 130,000 blue-collar jobs in the last decade.

LEAD: ''WE don't do clothing or motorcycle seats,'' said Michele Costello, the apprentice at Robert Falotico Studios, a leather repair business. Robert Falotico, the owner, echoed his assistant: ''Clothing, handbags, luggage we do not do.''
LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were mostly unchanged for the week ended yesterday.

LEAD: Kenneth W. Tucker, senior vice president and general manager of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt Public Relations of New York, died of cancer Sunday at Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 41 years old and lived in Manhattan and Southampton, L.I.

LEAD: The hand-lettered signs in the lobby of Bellevue Hospital Center proclaim March as Social Work Month. But on the 19th floor prison ward, where even the steel bars are painted white, one social worker doesn't feel very welcome.
LEAD: AS the popularity of folk art soars, the number of fake paintings and decorative objects on the market has multiplied.

LEAD: The thing about Mildred Hilson is that men are mad about her. Not long ago, 21 socially prominent men gave a dinner at ''21'' to honor Mrs. Hilson, grande dame of the diamond brigade. ''It was just Mildred and her men,'' Angier Biddle Duke was saying. ''We wore 'I Love Mildred' T-shirts.''
LEAD: ''Spratt Decries 21% Drop in Bearing Work Force,'' read the headline on a press release from the office of Representative John M. Spratt Jr., Democrat of South Carolina.

LEAD: HOW exclusive is a beach house when it is flanked to the north by a towering Holiday Inn and to the south by an orange-roofed Howard Johnson, particularly when thousands of college students on spring break cruise past at all hours of the day and night?
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Excerpts from the diary of Etty Hillesum, a victim of the Auschwitz concentration camp, are to be read by the actress Viveca Lindfors on April 17 at 7:30 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. The excerpts are from the book ''An Interrupted Life,'' which was published by Pantheon Books in 1981.
LEAD: BROCK JOBE can examine a pine chest of drawers and know it was made sometime between 1754 and 1770 by craftsmen from Boston or Salem, Mass.

LEAD: The Road Trip, like any truly worthwhile college road trip, was planned and executed within hours. Robert (Knobby) Farha, a senior at the University of Kansas and a manager at The Wagon Wheel Cafe, and Shawn Archer, a senior who works downstairs at Pyramid Pizza, were determined to follow their Jayhawks to the Midwest Regional championship.

LEAD: Most rock bands that have been around as long as the Kinks, who emerged in 1964, are oldies acts. The Kinks have staved off that fate for so long that they can take it lightly; at a sold-out Beacon Theater concert Tuesday, they dipped into their catalogue of hits but weren't confined to it.

LEAD: The House approved legislation today that would require the Federal Aviation Administration to rehire 1,000 air traffic controllers who were dismissed after an illegal strike nearly seven years ago.

LEAD: Walt Hazzard was dismissed yesterday after four seasons as head basketball coach at U.C.L.A. Hazzard guided the Bruins to a 16-14 record this season, well below expectations for a team coming off a Pacific-10 Conference championship. The Bruins finished in a tie for second in the Pac-10 this season, but were upset by Washington State in a first-round game of the conference tournament.

LEAD: Ralph Markham and Kenneth Broadway have performed as a piano duo since 1979, but they didn't get around to making their New York debut until Monday evening. For the occasion, they came to Town Hall with a program that ran the gamut from salon works to blockbusters, with the New York premiere of a shimmering work composed for them in 1981 by Alexina

LEAD: When Harold Nicholas sidles out onto the stage of the Joyce Theater, where he and the Jazz Tap Ensemble of Los Angeles are performing through Sunday, every inch and atom of his body seem to be primed for entertainment. A little avuncular, a bit of a lover, he dedicates steps to various sections of the audience.

Neither rose above the temptation. After Mr. Dole's news conference, the state's Republican Governor, Tommy G.

LEAD: Steve Pikiell does not look like the type of player who could beat a team as talented as Ohio State. The 6-foot-2-inch guard is a reserve for Connecticut and he enters the game when Coach Jim Calhoun wants to settle the team down.

LEAD: Israeli troops and their Lebanese Christian militia allies stormed a Shiite Moslem village in southern Lebanon today and fought with pro-Iranian guerrillas, reports said.
LEAD: In Jewish communities all around New York, where preparations for tomorrow night's Passover seder have reached a fever pitch, everybody is talking about the Great Shmura Matzoh Shortage of '88.

LEAD: EVER since the stock market collapsed on Oct. 19, investors familiar with history have been waiting for the other shoe to drop. The bull market of the 1980's was so similar to the one in the 1920's, they believed, that as in 1929-30 the collapse would have to follow the 1930's script and end with another market drop six months later, leading to a depression.
LEAD: Eddie Milner, a Cincinnati Reds outfielder, was suspended from baseball for one year without pay today by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth for using cocaine as a repeat offender.

LEAD: MANY years ago I fell in love with a boy who was the sort that didn't so much want to date you as to brand his initials in your forehead with a red-hot iron.
